document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,SEPTEMBER 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-12008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression

 

 

 

 

Introduction

This annual evidence update on complementary and alternative medicine for depression aims to identify, organise and present the latest information on this topic. We have searched a large number of databases for studies published or updated in the last 5 years in order to update work originally conducted as part of the CAMEOL project. 

For more details about the search methods and the selection process please see the Methodology section.

This update is linked to the Annual Evidence Update on depression produced by the Mental Health Specialist Library which is focusing on evidence published since January 2007. For a full list of studies published since January 2007 see Studies Found. For further information on depression including information on other treatments, see the relevant pages on the Mental Health Specialist Library.


Contents

  • Background information
  • Overviews of the evidence on CAM in depression
  • Evidence on specific therapies and approaches
    • Acupuncture
    • Diet and nutrition 
    • Herbal medicine (excluding St John's wort)
    • Massage, aromatherapy and reflexology
    • Meditation and mindfulness
    • St John's wort (Hypericum perforatum) STOP PRESS: New Cochrane review
    • Yoga
    • Other therapies

 

Studies found                            Methodology

document.title: 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Acupuncture
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS D-E,DATE ADDED,SEPTEMBER 2008,2008]]>
document.body:
111-12008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Acupuncture

Three meta-analyses focusing on acupuncture in depression were published between 2004 and 2007 (1-3). All concluded that the evidence was insufficient to determine efficacy of acupuncture compared to medication, wait list control or sham acupuncture. One suggested that the effect of electroacupuncture may not be significantly different from that of antidepressants (2), a finding that was supported by a systematic review that specifically focused on electroacupuncture and included studies from a Chinese database (4). However, both found that a lack of well-designed, large scale studies precluded firm conclusions.


It has recently been suggested that additional reviews of the same literature are unlikely to be helpful (5) for two reasons:

  • The lack of published clinical trials of acupuncture in the English-language literature
  • The fact that different diagnostic methods (individualized Chinese diagnosis vs Western standardized diagnostic criteria) and treatment approaches (e.g. manual acupuncture in various acupoints, electroacupuncture in two predetermined acupoints) were used in trials.

Nevertheless, in 2008 a further meta-analysis has been published (6). This review was limited to trials testing active against ‘sham’ acupuncture so that only 8 studies were included, although 3 of these had been published since the previous reviews. Again, the quality of studies was reported as low but a significant difference was found on the reduction of the severity of depression. The difference was small but statistically significant (mean difference in depression scores based on the Hamilton depression scale -0.65 95% CI -1.18 to -0.11) and no difference was found on response rate or remission rate.


The majority of RCTs published since 2004 compare acupuncture against drug therapy. In addition, most trials have been conducted in China with daily acupuncture treatments being provided, a treatment regimen unlikely to be offered in the UK. Three of the studies comparing active and ‘sham’ acupuncture were included in the systematic review by Wang (6) mentioned above. The recent trial by Allen (7) which was conducted in the USA in patients meeting the DSM IV criteria for depression was well-designed. Acupuncture based on traditional Chinese medicine principles was compared with needling at non-specific points and a wait list control group. Patients were treated twice weekly for the first 4 weeks then weekly for the next 4 weeks. Both groups receiving acupuncture improved more than those on the waiting list but no evidence of a difference in efficacy between the specific and non-specific points was found. Response rates after 8 weeks were relatively low and only reached 50% after 16 weeks. Possible reasons for this are discussed including the fact that it is unclear whether non-specific points have an effect.


Overall, there is still a lack of trials conducted in a Western health context although several are currently underway or have recently been completed in the USA and the UK.


References:

  1. Smith CA, Hay PPJ. Acupuncture for depression. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2004, Issue 3. Art. No.: CD004046. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004046.pub2. [Full text]
  2. Mukaino Y, Park J, White A, Ernst E. The effectiveness of acupuncture for depression--a systematic review of randomised controlled trials. Acupuncture in Medicine. 2005, 23(2):70-6. [Full text] [DARE provisional record]
  3. Leo RJ, Ligot JS, Jr. A systematic review of randomized controlled trials of acupuncture in the treatment of depression. Journal of Affective Disorders. 2007, 97(1-3):13-22. [PubMed Abstract] [DARE structured abstract]
  4. Sha Y. General situation of electro-acupuncture in treating depressive disorders: Comparing the effect with that of drug therapy. Chinese Journal of Clinical Rehabilitation. 2005, 9(44):181-3.
  5. Halbreich U. Systematic reviews of clinical trials of acupuncture as treatment for depression: how systematic and accurate are they? CNS Spectrums. 2008, 13(4):293-4, 299-300. [Full text]
  6. Wang H, Qi H, Wang BS, Cui YY, Zhu L, Rong ZX, Chen HZ. Is acupuncture beneficial in depression: A meta-analysis of 8 randomized controlled trials? Journal of Affective Disorders. 2008, Jun 10. [PubMed abstract]
  7. Allen JJ, Schnyer RN, Chambers AS, Hitt SK, Moreno FA, Manber R. Acupuncture for depression: a randomized controlled trial. Journal of Clinical Psychiatry. 2006, 67(11):1665-73. [PubMed abstract] (Also located as Allen JJ. Acupuncture in the treatment of depression. clinicaltrials.gov 2006)

document.title: 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Background information
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS D-E,DATE ADDED,OCTOBER 2008]]>
document.body:
111-12008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Background information

Complementary therapy use in depression

A series of national surveys have suggested that the use of complementary therapies by individuals suffering with depression is not only significant but increasing over time (1-5). In the US, a large survey demonstrated that depression, along with anxiety and insomnia, was among the most common reasons for individuals to seek treatment with complementary therapies: 22.4% of respondents who met the criteria for major depression had used therapies during the past 12 months.(1) Similar findings were reported from Canada where the prevalence of use in those with major depression was 19.4% in 1994-95 and 23.8% by 1996-97.(5) The situation was similar in Australia: a survey of over 6000 randomly selected adults suggested that self-help strategies including complementary therapies were very commonly used to cope with depression.(4)

A recent qualitative study conducted in the UK with 60 patients from four primary care practices in the West Midlands, revealed that almost two-thirds of participants had attempted to use self-chosen therapies during their recent illness though few had discussed their use with health service practitioners (6). A wide range of different therapies are reported to be used as demonstrated by the topics addressed by studies and reviews that have been published.


Why do people choose to use complementary therapies?

The study of patients from four primary care practices indicated that use of self-chosen therapies was linked to a belief that they were natural and the desire to avoid consulting health professionals. Conversely, those that did not use self-chosen therapies reported confidence in health practitioners and concern about the possibility of drug interactions.(6)


Which therapies do they use?

A wide range of different therapies are reported to be used with patterns of use varying by country. In the US, relaxation techniques and forms of healing were most frequently used.(2) A more recent survey indicated that manual therapies (such as massage), medicinal herbs and teas and nutritional supplements were most popular with women with depression.(7) In Australia, for mild depression, the therapies used included massage and meditation, while those for moderate depression included aromatherapy, St John’s wort (Hypericum perforatum), yoga and nutritional supplements. Relaxation therapy was mentioned in relation to moderate to severe episodes but no complementary therapies were reported to be used for severe depression. In the small sample studied in the UK by Badger and Nolan, St John’s wort was the most frequently used therapy.


Are complementary therapies covered by national guidelines on depression?

The NICE guidelines on depression (8) currently include the following statement on St John’s wort:

Although there is evidence that St John’s wort may be of benefit in mild or moderate depression, healthcare professionals should not prescribe or advise its use by patients because of uncertainty about appropriate doses, variation in the nature of preparations and potential serious interactions with other drugs (including oral contraceptives, anticoagulants and anticonvulsants). (p. 60)

The guidelines also mention mindfulness as part of mindfulness-based cognitive behavioural therapy:

Mindfulness-based CBT, usually delivered in a group format, should be considered for people who are currently well but have experienced three or more previous episodes of depression, because this may significantly reduce the likelihood of future relapse. (p. 67)

Guidelines on non-pharmacological management of mild to moderate depression are also being developed by SIGN (Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network). These cover a range of complementary and alternative therapies and are currently in draft form (PDF format).


References:

  1. Unützer J, Klap R, Sturm R, Young AS, Marmon T, Shatkin J, Wells KB. Mental disorders and the use of alternative medicine: results from a national survey. American Journal of Psychiatry. 2000, 157(11):1851-7. [Full text]
  2. Kessler RC, Soukup J, Davis RB, Foster DF, Wilkey SA, Van Rompay MI MI, Eisenberg DM. The use of complementary and alternative therapies to treat anxiety and depression in the United States. American Journal of Psychiatry. 2001, 158(2):289-94. [Full text]
  3. Wang JL, Patten SB, Russell ML. Alternative medicine use by individuals with major depression. Canadian Journal of Psychiatry. 2001, 46(6):528-33. [PubMed abstract]
  4. Jorm AF, Griffiths KM, Christensen H, Parslow RA, Rogers B. Actions taken to cope with depression at different levels of severity: a community survey. Psychological Medicine. 2004, 34(2):293-9. [PubMed abstract]
  5. Wang J, Patten SB, Williams JV, Currie S, Beck CA, Maxwell CJ, El-Guebaly N. Help-seeking behaviours of individuals with mood disorders. Canadian Journal of Psychiatry. 2005 Sep;50(10):652-9. [PubMed abstract]
  6. Badger F, Nolan P. Use of self-chosen therapies by depressed people in primary care. Journal of Clinical Nursing. 2007 Jul;16(7):1343-52. [PubMed abstract]
  7. Wu P, Fuller C,  Liu X, Lee HC, Fan B, Hoven CW, Mandell D, Wade C, Kronenberg F. Use of complementary and alternative medicine among women with depression: Results of a national survey. Psychiatric Services. 2007, 58:349-356. [Full text]
  8. Depression: Management of Depression in Primary and Secondary Care. London: National Institute for Clinical Excellence, 2004. [Amended April 2007]. Available at: http://www.nice.org.uk/CG023. 

 

Link back to 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression

]]>

document.title: 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Diet and nutrition
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS D-E,OCTOBER 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-12008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Diet and nutritionOmega-3 fatty acids

A series of reviews focusing on omega-3 fatty acids in depression have been published in recent years. The review by Williams et al (2006) only searched for studies published up to 2001 and included varied study types. Appleton et al (2006) searched up to June 2006 and found 18 randomized controlled trials, 12 of which reported data that could be included in a meta-analysis. The authors reported that trial evidence was limited and difficult to summarize and evaluate because of considerable heterogeneity. However, results from 6 trials in patients with major depression were combined with trials in patients with depressed mood associated with other psychiatric or medical conditions. One of these was a large trial in angina sufferers which reported no effects. The authors concluded that the evidence available provides little support for the use of omega-3 fatty acids to improve depressed mood. Lin and Su (2007) found 10 double-blind, placebo-controlled studies (329 patients in total) by searching the literature up to August 2006. Studies included patients with depression and those with bipolar disorder. An effect size of 0.61 was calculated by the authors who reported that omega-3 fatty acids significantly improved depression in patients with clearly defined depression. Due to publication bias and heterogeneity, more large-scale trials are required and Lin and Su suggest that these should be directed at defining the most appropriate target group, the therapeutic dose of EPA, and the composition of omega-3 fatty acids in treating depression. A Cochrane review on this topic has been planned (Silvers et al 2003).


Systematic reviews

Appleton KM, Hayward RC, Gunnell D, Peters TJ, Rogers PJ, Kessler D, Ness AR. Effects of n-3 long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids on depressed mood: systematic review of published trials. American Jourbal of Clinical Nutrition. 2006, 84(6):1308-16. [Full text]

document.body:
111-12008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Herbal medicine (excluding St John's wort)

Note: see separate section for St John’s wort/Hypericum perforatum


Systematic reviews

Two recent reviews have addressed a range of herbs in depression (Ernst 2007, Sarris 2007). Both focus primarily on St John’s wort (Hypericum perforatum) which is covered in a separate section. Several herbs are described as promising including Lavender (Lavendula angustifolia) and Saffron (Crocus sativus L). Trials on individual herbs or herbal mixtures are listed below.

Ernst E. Herbal remedies for depression and anxiety. Advances in Psychiatric Treatment. 2007, 13(4):312-6. [Full text] 

Sarris J. Herbal medicines in the treatment of psychiatric disorders: a systematic review. Phytotherapy Research. 2007, 21(8):703-16. [PubMed abstract]

Safety

Recent systematic reviews of the safety of herbs specifically used in depression include a review of complementary medicines used in psychiatry (Werneke 2006), a review of case reports of herb-drug interactions (Gohil and Patel 2007) and those listed in the section on St John’s wort.

Gohil KJ, Patel JA. Herb-drug interactions: A review and study based on assessment of clinical case reports in literature. Indian Journal of Pharmacology. 2007, 39(3):129-39. [Full text]

Werneke U, Turner T, Priebe S. Complementary medicines in psychiatry: Review of effectiveness and safety. British Journal of Psychiatry. 2006, 188(2):109-21. [Abstract]

Randomized controlled trials (RCTs)

Chinese herbal medicine

The only trial of Chinese herbal medicine to be included in either of the systematic reviews mentioned above was that by Luo et al. (2006). In Luo’s trial 66 patients with depression were randomised to treatment with  maprotiline plus placebo Chinese herbal mixture or herbal mixture plus placebo maprotiline (63 completed the trial). The results suggested that there was little difference between the Chinese herbal mixture danzhi xiaoyao powder and the antidepressant, maprotiline and that both were highly effective. However, it is unclear whether the study was large enough to detect any difference between the two treatments. The study by Li et al. (2007) presented further results from the same trial. There have been no further trials to confirm these findings and in the case of the other herbal mixtures, only single studies have been published to date.

Li YJ, Luo HC, Qian RQ. [Effect of Danzhi Xiaoyao Powder on neuro-immuno-endocrine system in patients with depression]Zhongguo Zhong Xi Yi Jie He Za Zhi. 2007, 27(3):197-200. Chinese. [PubMed abstract]


Luo HC, Qian RQ, Zhao XY, Bi J, Xin H, Jiang X, Xu K, Yan S. [Clinical observation on effect of danzhi xiaoyao powder in treating depression] Zhongguo Zhong Xi Yi Jie He Za Zhi. 2006 Mar;26(3):212-4. Chinese. [PubMed abstract]


Shen ZM, Zhu ML, Zhao AQ. [Comparative observation on efficacy of jieyu pill and maprotiline in treating depression]Zhongguo Zhong Xi Yi Jie He Za Zhi. 2004 May;24(5):415-7. Chinese. [PubMed abstract]


Zhang G, Ruan J. Treatment of mental depression due to liver-qi stagnancy with herbal decoction and by magnetic therapy at the acupoints--a report of 45 cases. Journal of Traditional Chinese Medicine. 2004, 24(1):20-1. [PubMed record]


Zhang ZJ, Kang WH, Li Q, Tan QR. The beneficial effects of the herbal medicine Free and Easy Wanderer Plus (FEWP) for mood disorders: double-blind, placebo-controlled studies. Journal of Psychiatric Research. 2007, 41(10):828-36. [PubMed abstract]


Zhang HW, Wang CY, Xu HN, Zhao X, Dai Q, Li J, et al. [Clinical study on effect of fluoxetine combined with Chinese medicine or tibetan drugs in treating senile depression in plateau district]. Zhongguo Zhong Xi Yi Jie He Za Zhi. 2006, 26(3):202-4. [PubMed abstract]

Crocus sativus L. (Saffron)

A series of randomised controlled trials have been conducted in Iran on Crocus sativus, which has been used in traditional Persian medicine to treat depression. Two studies suggested that Crocus sativus petal and stigma (saffron) were more effective than placebo in mild to moderate depression (Akhondzadeh et al., 2005; Moshiri et al., 2006) while two studies of saffron suggested similar effectiveness to the antidepressants imipramine and fluoxetine (Akhondzadeh et al., 2004; Noorbala et al., 2005). These studies have been included in previous systematic reviews (Ernst, Sarris) where the potential limitations are discussed including the fact that all the trials were small (30-40 patients) and there was limited follow-up (6-8 weeks).  Since these reviews were published, a further trial by the same group of researchers has been published (Akhondzadeh et al 2007). Crocus sativus petal was compared with fluoxetine but as with previous studies, the trial was small and limited to 8 weeks of treatment. In view of these preliminary positive results, it seems that larger scale trials are required. However, it may be that the cost of Saffron extract prohibits any realistic consideration of its potential as a possible treatment for depression.


Akhondzadeh BA, Moshiri E, Noorbala AA, Jamshidi AH, Abbasi SH, Akhondzadeh S. Comparison of petal of Crocus sativus L. and fluoxetine in the treatment of depressed outpatients: a pilot double-blind randomized trial. Progress in Neuro-psychopharmacology & Biological Psychiatry. 2007, 31(2):439-42. [PubMed abstract]


Akhondzadeh S, Fallah-Pour H, Afkham K, Jamshidi AH, Khalighi-Cigaroudi F. Comparison of Crocus sativus L. and imipramine in the treatment of mild to moderate depression: a pilot double-blind randomized trial [ISRCTN45683816]. BMC Complementary and Alternative Medicine. 2004 Sep 2;4:12. [Full text] (stigma)


Akhondzadeh S, Tahmacebi-Pour N, Noorbala AA, Amini H, Fallah-Pour H, Jamshidi AH, et al. Crocus sativus L. in the treatment of mild to moderate depression: a double-blind, randomized and placebo-controlled trial. Phytotherapy Research. 2005, 19(2):148-51. [PubMed abstract] (stigma)


Moshiri E, Basti AA, Noorbala AA, Jamshidi AH, Hesameddin AS, Akhondzadeh S. Crocus sativus L. (petal) in the treatment of mild-to-moderate depression: a double-blind, randomized and placebo-controlled trial. Phytomedicine. 2006, 13(9-10):607-11. [PubMed abstract]


Noorbala AA, Tahmasebi-Pour N, Akhondzadeh S, Khani M, Jamshidi AH. Crocus sativus L. in the treatment of mild to moderate depression: A double-blind, randomised and placebo controlled trial. Faslnamahi Giyahani Daruyi [Journal of Medicinal Plants]. 2004, 3(10)(pp 31-38+XV). (unobtainable)


Noorbala AA, Akhondzadeh S, Tahmacebi-Pour N, Jamshidi AH. Hydro-alcoholic extract of Crocus sativus L. versus fluoxetine in the treatment of mild to moderate depression: a double-blind, randomized pilot trial. Journal of Ethnopharmacology. 2005, 97(2):281-4. [PubMed abstract] (stigma)

Echium amoenum (Boraginaceae)

Only one trial has been published on the use of this herb, which is a wild herb found in Iran, in treating depression. The herb appeared to be superior to placebo but, as the authors point out, it was a small trial (35 participants) and the duration of treatment was short (6 weeks).

Saiiah Bargard M, Assadi SM, Amini H, Saiiah M, Akhondzadeh S, Kamalinejad M. Efficacy of aqueous extract of Echium amoenum L. in the treatment of mild to moderate major depressive disorder: A randomized double blind clinical trial. Faslnamahi Giyahani Daruyi [Journal of Medicinal Plants]. 2004, 3(10)(pp 61-68+XIX). (unobtainable) [Abstract]


Sayyah M, Sayyah M, Kamalinejad M. A preliminary randomized double blind clinical trial on the efficacy of aqueous extract of Echium amoenum in the treatment of mild to moderate major depression. Progress in Neuropsychopharmacology & Biological Psychiatry. 2006 Jan;30(1):166-9. [PubMed abstract]

Lavendula angustifolia (Lavender)

One small randomised controlled trial comparing lavender with an antidepressant was included in the two systematic reviews of herbs in depression. The trial was conducted in Iran in 45 patients with a score of a least 18 on the Hamilton Scale for depression and utilised a tincture of lavender. After 4 weeks of treatment, the results demonstrated that the Lavender extract was less effective than the antidepressant drug (imipramine) but a combination of both agents was more effective than imipramine alone. Confirmation of these preliminary results is not possible as no further trials of lavender in depression have been published. 


Rhodiola rosea L. (Roseroot)

The herb Roseroot has been used in northern Europe as a remedy for negative stress reactions. The potential of the herb Roseroot in the treatment of depression has previously been highlighted although no published trials could be found (see Sarris 2007 above). A trial has been published recently in which 89 patients with mild to moderate depression were randomised to one of three groups (340mg per day of Roseroot extract, 680 mg per day of extract or placebo). After 6 weeks improvements were seen in the Roseroot groups but not the placebo group with no serious side effects in any group. Based on these preliminary results, the researchers recommend that larger multicentre studies with a 12 week follow-up are now required.

Darbinyan V, Aslanyan G, Amroyan E, Gabrielyan E, Malmstrom C, Panossian A. Clinical trial of Rhodiola rosea L. extract SHR-5 in the treatment of mild to moderate depression. Nordic Journal of Psychiatry. 2007, 61(5):343-8. [Pubmed abstract]

 

Link back to 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Massage, aromatherapy and reflexology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ AROMATHERAPY,REFLEXOLOGY,MASSAGE,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,DATE ADDED,OCTOBER 2008]]>
document.body:
111-12008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Massage, aromatherapy and reflexology

Four randomised controlled trials were included in a recent systematic review focusing on massage therapy for the treatment of depression (Coelho et al 2008). Three of the trials compared massage therapy with relaxation therapy in depressed adolescents, women with postnatal depression and women who were depressed during pregnancy respectively. In the fourth trial, massage was compared against acupuncture in depressed pregnant women.  The authors concluded that there was a lack of evidence on massage therapy for depression. This is in contrast to a previous review of CAM for depression which had concluded that ‘MT appears to have short-term benefits’ although no detailed appraisal of the individual studies had been carried out (Jorm et al 2002). A meta-analysis of massage in a range of conditions also had positive conclusions: that ‘reductions in trait anxiety and depression following a course of treatment were among massage therapy’s largest effects’ but included trials where depression was one of the outcome measures rather than the diagnosis (Moyer 2004). A broader systematic review found that massage therapy compared favourably with relaxing activities such as viewing a videotape, yoga plus progressive muscular relaxation or no treatment in various patient populations (Pilkington et al 2006a). Consequently, further studies examining specific forms of massage and benefits to different patient groups are likely to be valuable. 

Only one study has attempted to examine whether aromatherapy had an additive effect with massage (Lemon 2004). The trial, which compared individualised aromatherapy massage with massage alone in elderly patients with anxiety and/or depression, reported promising results but no further trials have been published so the findings are unconfirmed.

Similarly, although several studies have been published reporting the effects of reflexology on mood or depression in patients with co-morbid conditions such as cancer, a systematic review conducted in 2004 found no published trials focusing specifically on depression (Pilkington et al 2006b). One trial was subsequently been published in Korean (Song and Kim 2006a) but appears to have been retracted (Song and Kim 2006b).


Systematic reviews

Coelho HF, Boddy K, Ernst E. Massage therapy for the treatment of depression: a systematic review. International Journal of Clinical Practice. 2008, 62(2):325-33. [PubMed abstract]

Moyer CA, Rounds J, Hannum JW. A meta-analysis of massage therapy research. Psychological Bulletin. 2004, 130(1):3-18.  [PubMed abstract] [DARE provisional record]

Pilkington K, Kirkwood G, Rampes H, Richardson J. Aromatherapy and massage for depression: a systematic review. Complementary and Alternative Medicine Evidence Online (CAMEOL) Database. (2006) Available at: http://www.rccm.org.uk/cameol/Default.aspx [Accessed Aug 2008].

Pilkington K, Kirkwood G, Rampes H, Richardson J. Reflexology  for depression: a systematic review. Complementary and Alternative Medicine Evidence Online (CAMEOL) Database. (2006) Available at: http://www.rccm.org.uk/cameol/Default.aspx [Accessed Aug 2008].


Randomized controlled trials (RCTs)

Feijo L, Hernandez-Reif M, Field T, Burns W, Valley-Gray S, Simco E. Mothers' depressed mood and anxiety levels are reduced after massaging their preterm infants. Infant Behavior & Development. 2006, 29(3):476-80. [PubMed abstract]

Field T, Diego MA, Hernandez-Reif M, Schanberg S, Kuhn C. Massage therapy effects on depressed pregnant women. Journal of Psychosomatic Obstetrics and Gynaecology. 2004, 25(2):115-22. [PubMed abstract] (included in SR by Coelho et al 2008)

Fujita M, Endoh Y, Saimon N, Yamaguchi S. Effect of massaging babies on mothers: pilot study on the changes in mood states and salivary cortisol level. Complementary Therapies in Clinical Practice. 2006, 12(3):181-5. [PubMed abstract]

Lemon K. An assessment of treating depression and anxiety with aromatherapy. International Journal of Aromatherapy. 2004, 14:63-9.

Manber R, Schnyer RN, Allen JJB et al. Acupuncture: a promising treatment for depression during pregnancy. Journal of Affective Disorders 2004; 83: 89–95. [PubMed abstract] (included in SR by Coelho et al 2008; massage was the control intervention)

Muller-Oerlinghausen B, Berg C, Scherer P, Mackert A, Moestl HP, Wolf J. [Effects of slow-stroke massage as complementary treatment of depressed hospitalized patients]. Deutsche Medizinische Wochenschrift. 2004 Jun 11;129(24):1363-8. [PubMed abstract]

Muller-Oerlinghausen B, Berg C, Droll W. [The efficacy of Slow Stroke Massage in depression]. Psychiatrische Praxis. 2007 Sep;34 Suppl 3:S305-S308. [PubMed abstract]

O'Higgins M, Roberts IS-J, Glover V. Postnatal depression and mother and infant outcomes after infant massage. Journal of Affective Disorders, 2008, 109(1-2)189-92. [PubMed abstrcat]

Song RH, Kim DH. [The effects of foot reflexion massage on sleep disturbance, depression disorder, and the physiological index of the elderly]. Taehan Kanho Hakhoe chi. 2006, 36 (1):15-24. [PubMed abstract] Retraction: Song RH, Kim DH. Journal of Korean Academy of Nursing. 2006, Feb;36(1):432-432.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Meditation and mindfulness
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,MEDITATION,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS D-E,MINDFULNESS-BASED STRESS REDUCTION (MBSR),OCTOBER 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-12008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Meditation and mindfulness

Meditation

A review of meditation conducted in 2004 (Kirkwood et al 2005) succeeded in locating only a limited number of studies including two studies in which elderly patients suffering from depressive symptoms were treated with interventions consisting of meditation combined with relaxation. No evidence of a reduction in measures of depression in this group was seen while the sole study located on patients with clinical depression was a preliminary report with insufficient details for evaluation. Thus, there was a lack of evidence from controlled trials and a general lack of research in this area on which to base conclusions on either the effectiveness of meditation in easing depression or on the potential for meditation to exacerbate depression (Kirkwood et al 2005). Several studies have published subsequently in which the intervention is described as yoga but meditative techniques are either incorporated or form the basis of the intervention. For details of relevant trials (Sharma et al. 2005, 2006) see section on yoga.


Systematic reviews

Kirkwood G, Rampes H, Richardson J, Pilkington K. Meditation for depression: a systematic review. Complementary and Alternative Medicine Evidence Online (CAMEOL) Database. 2005. Available at: http://www.rccm.org.uk/cameol/Default.aspx [Accessed Sept 2008].


Randomized controlled trials (RCTs)

See yoga section for more details

Sharma VK, Das S, Mondal S, Goswampi U, Gandhi A. Effect of Sahaj Yoga on depressive disorders. Indian Journal of Physiology and Pharmacololy. 2005, 49(4):462-8. [PubMed abstract]


Sharma VK, Das S, Mondal S, Goswami U, Gandhi A. Effect of Sahaj Yoga on neuro-cognitive functions in patients suffering from major depression. Indian Journal of Physiology and Pharmacololy. 2006, 50(4):375-83. [PubMed abstract]


Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT)

The potential benefits of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) in people with depression have been reported. Two trials published in 2000 plus two of the trials listed below (Ma and Teasdale 2004, Kingston et al 2007) were included in a recent systematic review (Coelho et al 2007). The evidence from these trials suggests that, for patients with 3 or more previous depressive episodes, MBCT has an additive benefit to usual care. However, the review authors suggested that because the control groups received only usual care with no additional intervention, it is unclear if the findings are due to MBCT-specific effects. Further studies are needed to clarify whether this is the case but MBCT is currently recommended in UK guidelines for depression (section 4.6.3.10, p. 67, NICE guidelines).


Systematic reviews

Coelho HF, Canter PH, Ernst E. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy: evaluating current evidence and informing future research. Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology. 2007, 75(6):1000-5. [PubMed abstract]  


Randomized controlled trials (RCTs)

Barnhofer T, Duggan D, Crane C, Hepburn S, Fennell MJ, Williams JM. Effects of meditation on frontal alpha-asymmetry in previously suicidal individuals. Neuroreport. 2007, 18(7):709-12. [PubMed abstract]


Kingston T, Dooley B, Bates A, Lawlor E, Malone K. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy for residual depressive symptoms. Psychology and Psychotherapy. 2007, 80(Pt 2):193-203. [PubMed abstract]


Ma SH, Teasdale JD. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy for depression: replication and exploration of differential relapse prevention effects. Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology. 2004, 72(1):31-40. [PubMed abstract]


Ongoing or unpublished studies (from Current Controlled trials)

Butler LD and Spiegel D. Meditation and hypnosis for chronic depressed mood. NCT00226863. Completed.


Foley D, Baille A, Renner P. CBT plus mindfulness for depression and anxiety outside model programs: Increased treatment gains? Decreased relapse rates? 29th Australian Association for Cognitive and Behaviour Therapy Annual Conference; 2006 October 18-23; Manly 2006;43.


Segal ZV. Preventing Depression Relapse With Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy. NCT00183560. Start date: 2004. Ongoing.


Other studies of interest

Qualitative research

Smith A, Graham L, Senthinathan S. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy for recurring depression in older people: A qualitative study. Aging & Mental Health. May 2007;-357. [PubMed abstract]


Finucane A, Mercer SW. An exploratory mixed methods study of the acceptability and effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy for patients with active depression and anxiety in primary care. BMC Psychiatry. 2006 Apr 7;6:14. [Full text]

 

Link back to 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Methodology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,OCTOBER 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-12008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Methodology

The aim of the Annual Evidence Update (AEU) on CAM for Depression is to identify, organise and present the most up-to-date evidence for this topic. As this is the first update, we have comprehensively searched a large number of databases, covering the period from January 2004 to September 2008.

This update is linked to the Annual Evidence Update on Depression hosted by the Mental Health Specialist Library. It also builds on work previously conducted as part of the CAMEOL project. In order to meet the needs of the CAMEOL project, the methods differ to some extent from those used in previous AEU.


Preparatory work

In order to focus on therapies that are likely to be used by people with depression, the following sources were examined in April 2008 for all therapies mentioned in relation to the treatment of or use in depression:

  • UK mental health websites
    • Depression Alliance
    • MIND
    • Mental Health Foundation 
    • Rethink
    • Royal College of Psychiatrists
  • International CAM websites (NCCAM, USA, http://nccam.nih.gov/)
  • International depression websites (BluePages Depression Information, Australia, http://bluepages.anu.edu.au/)
  • National surveys on the use of complementary therapies in depression (listed under Background information)


Search strategy

Based on the above work, the search strategy included text words and terms for CAM in general and for specific CAM therapies mentioned in any of the sources examined. These were combined with text word and terms for depression. Methodological filters for systematic reviews and randomised controlled trials (RCTs) were also used.

The search strategy can be found here.


Sources searched

The Cochrane Library (CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHS EED), PubMed (and MEDLINE), EMBASE, AMED, CINAHL, PsycINFO

Mental Health SL


Search process

The searches for systematic reviews were carried out in May-June 2008 and were limited to articles published since January 2004. To identify relevant systematic reviews the information specialist has searched the sources listed above using the CAM SL systematic reviews filter, which emphasizes specificity (precision) over sensitivity. In addition a search of PubMed using the systematic reviews subset was conducted.

The Cochrane Library CENTRAL database was searched to identify RCTs published since 2004. As some of the searches for the CDAN register had been carried out in mid-2007, additional searches for RCTs were carried out in June-August 2008 in all major databases to identify more recent studies. Further searches of individual therapies not included in the original search strategy were also conducted (e.g. for individual herbs).


Selection criteria

Study types: guidance/guidelines, systematic reviews, meta-analyses, HTA reports, cost effectiveness and economic evaluation studies, RCTs.

Systematic reviews must have met the following inclusion criteria:
- Explicit description of search process and statement of methodology (at least 2 sources must have been searched and there must be a statement that the study is a meta-analysis or a systematic review).
- Focused on depression
 
Exclusion criteria:
- The study is not one of the types specified above
- The main focus is not on depression (e.g., a systematic review on specific therapy, which may include a range of conditions) 

Note
Studies likely to be of particular interest but not meeting the inclusion criteria above (e.g. methodology studies, qualitative research) have been included where relevant and listed under ‘Other studies of Interest’.


Search results

The total number of records retrieved was 1417 systematic reviews (SRs) and 2103 RCTs. After removing the duplicates there were 867 SRs and 1208 RCTs. Of these, 115 were selected as potential systematic reviews and 216 as potential RCTs. The final selection includes 54 systematic reviews and 103 RCTs (including 12 ongoing trials).

A list of the relevant guidelines, systematic reviews and meta-analyses is given in the Studies Found page.

 

Link back to 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression

]]>

document.body:
111-12008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Other therapies

Ayurveda

Randomized controlled trial  

Krishnamurthy MN, Telles S. Assessing depression following two ancient Indian interventions: effects of yoga and ayurveda on older adults in a residential home. Journal of Gerontological Nursing. 2007, 33(2):17-23. [PubMed abstract]


Dance therapy 

Randomized controlled trials (RCTs)

Jeong YJ, Hong SC, Lee MS, Park MC, Kim YK, Suh CM. Dance movement therapy improves emotional responses and modulates neurohormones in adolescents with mild depression. International Journal of Neuroscience. 2005, 115(12):1711-20. [PubMed abstract]


Homeopathy

Systematic review

Pilkington K, Kirkwood G, Rampes H, Fisher P, Richardson J. Homeopathy for depression: a systematic review of the research evidence. Homeopathy. 2005, 94(3):153-63. [PubMed abstract] [DARE structured abstract]

Randomized controlled trial 

Katz T, Fisher P, Katz A, Davidson J, Feder G. The feasibility of a randomised, placebo-controlled clinical trial of homeopathic treatment of depression in general practice. Homeopathy. 2005, 94(3):145-52. [PubMed abstract] (included in above SR)


Hypnosis

Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) 

Alladin A, Alibhai A. Cognitive hypnotherapy for depression: an empirical investigation. International Journal of Clinical and Experimental Hypnosis. 2007, 55(2):147-66. [PubMed abstract]

Guse T, Wissing M, Hartman W. The effect of a prenatal hypnotherapeutic programme on postnatal maternal psychological well-being. Journal of Reproductive and Infant Psychology. 2006;24:163-77. [Abstract]

Ongoing studies

Butler LD. Meditation and hypnosis for chronic depressed mood. NCT00226863. controlled trials com 2006.


Light therapy

Systematic reviews

Even C, Schröder CM, Friedman S, Rouillon F.Efficacy of light therapy in nonseasonal depression: a systematic review. Journal of Affective Disorders. 2008 May;108(1-2):11-23. [PubMed abstract]

Golden RN, Gaynes BN, Ekstrom RD, Hamer RM, Jacobsen FM, Suppes T, et al. The efficacy of light therapy in the treatment of mood disorders: a review and meta-analysis of the evidence. American Journal of Psychiatry. 2005, 162(4):656-62. [Full text]

Krasnik C, Montori VM, Guyatt GH, Heels-Ansdell D, Busse JW; Medically Unexplained Syndromes Study Group.The effect of bright light therapy on depression associated with premenstrual dysphoric disorder. American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology. 2005, 193(3 Pt 1):658-61. [PubMed abstract]

Tuunainen A, Kripke DF, Endo T. Light therapy for non-seasonal depression. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2004, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD004050. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004050.pub2. [Full text]

RCTs not included for light therapy


Music therapy

Systematic review

Maratos AS, Gold C, Wang X, Crawford MJ. Music therapy for depression. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2008, Issue 1. Art. No.: CD004517. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004517.pub2. [Full text]


Qigong

Randomized controlled trial 

Tsang HW, Fung KM, Chan AS, Lee G, Chan F. Effect of a qigong exercise programme on elderly with depression. International Journal of Geriatric Psychiatry. 2006, 21(9):890-7. [PubMed abstract]


Reiki

Systematic review

Lee MS, Pittler MH, Ernst E. Effects of reiki in clinical practice: a systematic review of randomised clinical trials. International Journal of Clinical Practice. 2008, 62(6):947-54. [PubMed abstract]

Vitale A. An integrative review of Reiki touch therapy research. Holistic Nursing Practice. 2007,21(4):167-79. [PubMed abstract] 

Ongoing systematic review

Joyce J, Herbison P. Reiki treatment for psychological symptoms. (Protocol) Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2007, Issue 4. Art. No.: CD006833. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD006833. [Full text] 

Randomized controlled trial  

Shore AG. Long-term effects of energetic healing on symptoms of psychological depression and self-perceived stress. Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine. 2004, 10(3):42-8. [erratum appears in Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine. 2004, 10(4):14]. [PubMed abstract] 


Relaxation techniques

Ongoing systematic review*

Jorm AF, Morgan A, Hetrick SE. Relaxation for depression. (Protocol) Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews. 2008, Issue 2. John Wiley & Sons, Ltd. DOI: 10.1002./14651858.CD007142.

*New: This review has been published on 8th October 2008 (see citation and link to full text below)

Jorm AF, Morgan AJ, Hetrick SE. Relaxation for depression. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2008, Issue 4. Art. No.: CD007142. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD007142.pub2. [Full text]

Ongoing randomized controlled trial 

Krogh J, Petersen L, Timmermann M, Saltin B, Nordentoft M. Design paper: the DEMO trial: a randomized, parallel-group, observer-blinded clinical trial of aerobic versus non-aerobic versus relaxation training for patients with light to moderate depression. Contemporary Clinical Trials. 2007, 28(1):79-89. [PubMed abstract]


Tai chi

Systematic review

Tsang HW, Chan EP, Cheung WM. Effects of mindful and non-mindful exercises on people with depression: a systematic review. British Journal of Clinical Psychology. 2008, 47(Pt 3):303-22. [PubMed abstract]

Ongoing systematic review

Chi I, Jordan-Marsh M, Guo M, Xie B, Zhang M. Tai Chi for depression. (Protocol) Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2008, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD007143. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD007143. [Full text]

Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) 

Cho KL.  Effect of Tai Chi on depressive symptoms amongst Chinese older patients with major depression: the role of social support.  Medicine & Sport Science. 2008, 52:146-54. [PubMed abstract]

Chou KL, Lee PW, Yu EC, Macfarlane D, Cheng YH, Chan SS, et al. Effect of Tai Chi on depressive symptoms amongst Chinese older patients with depressive disorders: a randomized clinical trial. International Journal of Geriatric Psychiatry. 2004, 19(11):1105-7. [PubMed record]


Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM)

Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) 

Chen LP, Wang FW, Werner H. Effect of the combination of acupuncture and shuyusan in the treatment of depression. Chinese Journal of Clinical Rehabilitation. 2004, 8:4250-1.

He Q, Zhang J, Tang Y. A controlled study on the treatment of mental depression by acupuncture plus TCM medication. Journal of Traditional Chinese Medicine. 2007, 27(3):166-169. [PubMed abstract]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Overviews of the evidence on CAM in depression
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,OCTOBER 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-12008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Overviews of the evidence on CAM in depression

A number of overviews of the evidence on a range of complementary therapies in depression have been published. The following have taken a systematic approach to identifying relevant research evidence:


General overviews 

Morgan AJ, Jorm AF. Self-help interventions for depressive disorders and depressive symptoms: A systematic review. Annals of General Psychiatry. 2008, 7(1):13. [Full text]

Pilkington K, Rampes H, Richardson J. Complementary medicine for depression. Expert Review of Neurotherapeutics. 2006, 6(11): 1741-51. [Abstract]

Thachil AF, Mohan R, Bhugra D. The evidence base of complementary and alternative therapies in depression. Journal of Affective Disorders. 2007, 97(1-3):23-35. [PubMed abstract] 

Werneke U, Turner T, Priebe S. Complementary medicines in psychiatry: Review of effectiveness and safety. British Journal of Psychiatry. 2006, 188(2):109-21. [Abstract]

Overviews focused on special populations

Frazer CJ, Christensen H, Griffiths KM. Effectiveness of treatments for depression in older people. Medical Journal of Australia. 2005,  20;182(12):627-32. [Full text]

Jorm AF, Allen NB, O'Donnell CP, Parslow RA, Purcell R, Morgan AJ.  Effectiveness of complementary and self-help treatments for depression in children and adolescents. Medical Journal of Australia. 2006, 185(7):368-72. [Full text]

Meeks TW, Wetherell JL, Irwin MR, Redwine LS, Jeste DV. Complementary and alternative treatments for late-life depression, anxiety, and sleep disturbance: a review of randomized controlled trials. Journal of Clinical Psychiatry. 2007, 68(10):1461-71.  [PubMed abstract]

 

Link back to 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: St John's wort (Hypericum perforatum)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,OCTOBER 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-12008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: St John's wort (Hypericum perforatum)

Systematic reviews 

A large number of systematic reviews and meta-analyses have been published on St John’s wort and have been summarised previously.(1) The Cochrane review of St John’s wort in depression published in 2005 concluded that ‘current evidence regarding hypericum extracts is inconsistent and confusing’ as several recent placebo-controlled trials suggested minimal beneficial effects in patients who met the criteria for depression while other trials suggested that hypericum and standard antidepressants had similar beneficial effects.(2) (see STOP PRESS below). The authors also highlighted the possible variability in pharmaceutical quality of preparations on the market and those included in the trials. Since this review was published, a number of trials have been published and are listed below under the heading RCTs as have several more reviews. One study involved a reanalysis of data from patients in the acute phase of mild depression from previous trials.(3) Over 200 patients of the original 1,200 patients had a Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression (HAMD) scores of 20 or less and were included in the re-analysis (3). The results indicated that St John’s wort leads to a substantial increase in the probability of remission in patients with mild depression. 


Safety

Other systematic reviews have focused on safety of St John’s wort. Systematic reviews of safety published up to 2005 have been discussed previously (1).  These concluded that the available evidence suggested that St John’s wort is, in general, well-tolerated although there have been case reports of adverse effects including allergy or photosensitivity and possible induction of manic episodes in susceptible individuals. The main safety concern is the potential to interact with other drugs and the list of those drugs likely to be affected is constantly being extended. Three of the systematic reviews found during this Evidence Update address safety, one focusing on safety in pregnancy and lactation (4), and two on drug interactions (5,6). See also articles listed in the safety section of Herbal Medicine and the updated Cochrane review (see Stop Press below).

 
STOP PRESS (8th October 2008)

An update of the Cochrane review has been published today. It now focuses on major depression and concludes that:

“The available evidence suggests that the hypericum extracts tested in the included trials a) are superior to placebo in patients with major depression; b) are similarly effective as standard antidepressants; c) and have fewer side effects than standard antidepressants. The association of country of origin and precision with effects sizes complicates the interpretation.”

Linde K, Berner MM, Kriston L. St John's wort for major depression. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2008, Issue 4. Art. No.: CD000448. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD000448.pub3. [Full text] See also analysis from Behind the Headlines. 


References:

  1. Pilkington K, Boshnakova A, Richardson J. St John's wort for depression: time for a different perspective? Complementary Therapies in Medicine. 2006, 14(4):268-81. [PubMed abtract]
  2. Linde K, Mulrow CD, Berner M, Egger M. St John's Wort for depression. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2005, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD000448. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD000448.pub2.
  3. Kasper S, Gastpar M, Muller WE, Volz HP, Dienel A, Kieser M, et al. Efficacy of St. John's wort extract WS 5570 in acute treatment of mild depression: a reanalysis of data from controlled clinical trials. European Archives of Psychiatry and Clinical Neuroscience. 2008, 258(1):59-63. [PubMed abstract]
  4. Dugoua JJ, Mills E, Perri D, Koren G. Safety and efficacy of St. John's wort (Hypericum) during pregnancy and lactation. Canadian Journal of Clinical Pharmacology. 2006, 13(3):e268-e276. [Full text]
  5. Nieuwstraten C, Labiris NR, Holbrook A. Systematic overview of drug interactions with antidepressant medications. Canadian Journal of Psychiatry. 2006, 51:300-16. [PubMed abstract] [DARE provisional record]
  6. Zhou SF, Lai X. An update on clinical drug interactions with the herbal antidepressant St. John's wort. Current Drug Metabolism. 2008, 9(5):394-409. [PubMed abstract]


List of all relevant studies

Systematic reviews (and DARE appraisals)

Clement K, Covertson CR, Johnson MJ, Dearing K. St. John's wort and the treatment of mild to moderate depression: a systematic review. Holistic Nursing Practice. 2006, 20(4):197-203. [PubMed abstract] [DARE provisional record]


Dugoua JJ, Mills E, Perri D, Koren G. Safety and efficacy of St. John's wort (Hypericum) during pregnancy and lactation. Canadian Journal of Clinical Pharmacology. 2006, 13(3):e268-e276. [Full text]


Jou HJ, Hsu IP, Ling PY, Huang HT, Lin CT, Wu SC. Extracts of St. John's wort for mild to moderate depression: a meta-analysis of randomized, double-blinded and placebo-controlled trials. Nutritional Sciences Journal. 2005, 30(4): 166-173. [DARE provisional record] 


Kasper S, Gastpar M, Muller WE, Volz HP, Dienel A, Kieser M, et al. Efficacy of St. John's wort extract WS 5570 in acute treatment of mild depression: a reanalysis of data from controlled clinical trials. European Archives of Psychiatry and Clinical Neuroscience. 2008, 258(1):59-63. [PubMed abstract]


Linde K, Knuppel L. Large-scale observational studies of hypericum extracts in patients with depressive disorders: a systematic review. Phytomedicine. 2005, 12:148-57  [PubMed abstract] [DARE appraisal]


Linde K, Berner M, Egger M, Mulrow C. St John's wort for depression: meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials. British Journal of Psychiatry. 2005;186:99-107. [Full text] Duplicate publication of Cochrane review below.


Linde K, Mulrow CD, Berner M, Egger M. St John's Wort for depression. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2005, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD000448. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD000448.pub2. [Full text]


Nieuwstraten C, Labiris NR, Holbrook A. Systematic overview of drug interactions with antidepressant medications. Canadian Journal of Psychiatry. 2006, 51:300-16. [PubMed abstract] [DARE provisional record]


Zhou SF, Lai X. An update on clinical drug interactions with the herbal antidepressant St. John's wort. Current Drug Metabolism. 2008, 9(5):394-409. [PubMed abstract]


Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) 

Anghelescu IG, Kohnen R, Szegedi A, Klement S, Kieser M. Comparison of Hypericum extract WS 5570 and paroxetine in ongoing treatment after recovery from an episode of moderate to severe depression: results from a randomized multicenter study. Pharmacopsychiatry. 2006, 39(6):213-9. [PubMed abstract]

Bjerkenstedt L, Edman GV, Alken RG, Mannel M. Hypericum extract LI 160 and fluoxetine in mild to moderate depression: a randomized, placebo-controlled multi-center study in outpatients. European Archives in Psychiatry and Clinical Neuroscience. 2005 Feb;255(1):40-7. [PubMed abstract]

Farabaugh A, Mischoulon D, Fava M, Wu SL, Mascarini A, Tossani E, et al. The relationship between early changes in the HAMD-17 anxiety/somatization factor items and treatment outcome among depressed outpatients. International Clinical Psychopharmacology. 2005 Mar;20(2):87-91. [PubMed abstract]

Fava M, Alpert J, Nierenberg AA, Mischoulon D, Otto MW, Zajecka J, et al. A Double-blind, randomized trial of St John's wort, fluoxetine, and placebo in major depressive disorder. Journal of Clinical Psychopharmacology. 2005, 25(5):441-7. [PubMed abstract]

Gastpar M, Zeller K. [Comparison of hypericum extract STW3 and sertraline in the treatment of mode-rate depression: a double-blind randomized 24-week-study]. Psychopharmakotherapie. 2005, 12:146-53.

Gastpar M, Singer A, Zeller K. Efficacy and tolerability of hypericum extract STW3 in long-term treatment with a once-daily dosage in comparison with sertraline. Pharmacopsychiatry. 2005, 38(2):78-86. [PubMed abstract]

Gastpar M, Singer A, Zeller K. Comparative efficacy and safety of a once-daily dosage of hypericum extract STW3-VI and citalopram in patients with moderate depression: a double-blind, randomised, multicentre, placebo-controlled study. Pharmacopsychiatry. 2006 Mar;39(2):66-75. [PubMed abstract]

Kasper S, Dienel A, Kieser M. Continuation and long-term maintenance treatment with Hypericum extract WS 5570 after successful acute treatment of mild to moderate depression--rationale and study design. International Journal of Methods in Psychiatric Research. 2004, 13(3):176-83. [PubMed abstract]

Kasper S, Anghelescu IG, Szegedi A, Dienel A, Kieser M. Superior efficacy of St John's wort extract WS 5570 compared to placebo in patients with major depression: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multi-center trial [ISRCTN77277298]. BMC Medicine. 2006, 4:14. [Full text]

Kasper S, Anghelescu IG, Szegedi A, Dienel A, Kieser M. Placebo controlled continuation treatment with Hypericum extract WS 5570 after recovery from a mild or moderate depressive episode. Wiener Medizinische Wochenschrift. 2007, 157(13-14):362-6. [PubMed abstract]

Moreno RA, Teng CT, Almeida KM, Tavares JH. Hypericum perforatum versus fluoxetine in the treatment of mild to moderate depression: a randomized double-blind trial in a Brazilian sample. Revista Brasileira de Psiquiatria. 2006;28:29-32. [PubMed abstract]

Papakostas GI, Crawford CM, Scalia MJ, Fava M. Timing of clinical improvement and symptom resolution in the treatment of major depressive disorder. A replication of findings with the use of a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of Hypericum perforatum versus fluoxetine. Neuropsychobiology. 2007;56(2-3):132-7. [PubMed abstract]

Randlov C, Mehlsen J, Thomsen CF, Hedman C, von FH, Winther K. The efficacy of St. John's Wort in patients with minor depressive symptoms or dysthymia--a double-blind placebo-controlled study. Phytomedicine. 2006 Mar;13(4):215-21. [PubMed abstract]

Szegedi A, Kohnen R, Dienel A, Kieser M. Acute treatment of moderate to severe depression with hypericum extract WS 5570 (St John's wort): randomised controlled double blind non-inferiority trial versus paroxetine. BMJ. 2005, 330(7490):503. [PubMed abstract] Erratum in: BMJ. 2005 Apr 2;330(7494):759. dosage error in text.

Uebelhack R, Gruenwald J, Graubaum HJ, Busch R. Efficacy and tolerability of Hypericum extract STW 3-VI in patients with moderate depression: a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trial. Advances in Therapy. 2004, 21(4):265-75. [PubMed abstract]


Other studies of interest (linked to RCTs)

Gelenberg AJ, Shelton RC, Crits-Christoph P, Keller MB, Dunner DL, Hirschfeld RM, et al. The effectiveness of St. John's Wort in major depressive disorder: a naturalistic phase 2 follow-up in which nonresponders were provided alternate medication. Journal of Clinical Psychiatry. 2004, 65(8):1114-9. [PubMed abstract]

Kieser M, Szegedi A. Predicting stable treatment response in patients with major depression treated with hypericum extract WS 5570/5572. Pharmacopsychiatry. 2005, 38(5):194-200. [PubMed abstract]

Lecrubier Y, Bech P. The Ham D(6) is more homogenous and as sensitive as the Ham D(17). European Psychiatry. 2007, 22(4):252-5. [PubMed abstract]

Mischoulon D, Schwartz F, Papakostas G, Farabaugh A, Cusin C, Nierenberg AA, et al. Characterization of the placebo response in the Hypericum Depression Trial Group's study. 46th Annual NCDEU Meeting; 2006 June 12-15; Boca Raton , FLorida. 2006, p. 265. [Abstract]

Vitiello B, Shader RI, Parker CB, Ritz L, Harlan W, Greenblatt DJ, et al. Hyperforin plasma level as a marker of treatment adherence in the National Institutes of Health Hypericum Depression Trial. Journal of Clinical Psychopharmacology. 2005, 25(3):243-9. [PubMed abstract]

Murck H, Fava M, Alpert J, Nierenberg AA, Mischoulon D, Otto MW, et al. Hypericum extract in patients with MDD and reversed vegetative signs: re-analysis from data of a double-blind, randomized trial of hypericum extract, fluoxetine, and placebo. International Journal of Neuropsychopharmacology. 2005, 8(2):215-21. [PubMed abstract]

document.body:
111-12008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Studies found

The following relevant studies on this topic have been published since January 2004.

These studies have met our selection criteria. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.


Guidelines

Depression: Management of Depression in Primary and Secondary Care. London: National Institute for Clinical Excellence, 2004. [Amended April 2007]. Available at: http://www.nice.org.uk/CG023.


Systematic reviews and/or meta-analyses

2008

  1. Coelho HF, Boddy K, Ernst E. Massage therapy for the treatment of depression: a systematic review. International Journal of Clinical Practice. 2008, 62(2):325-33. [PubMed abstract]
  2. Even C, Schröder CM, Friedman S, Rouillon F. Efficacy of light therapy in nonseasonal depression: a systematic review. Journal of Affective Disorders. 2008 May;108(1-2):11-23. [PubMed abstract]
  3. Kasper S, Gastpar M, Muller WE, Volz HP, Dienel A, Kieser M, et al. Efficacy of St. John's wort extract WS 5570 in acute treatment of mild depression: a reanalysis of data from controlled clinical trials. European Archives of Psychiatry Clinical Neuroscience. 2008, 258(1):59-63.  [PubMed abstract]
  4. Lee MS, Pittler MH, Ernst E. Effects of reiki in clinical practice: a systematic review of randomised clinical trials. International Journal of Clinical Practice. 2008, 62(6):947-54. [PubMed abstract]
  5. Maratos AS, Gold C, Wang X, Crawford MJ. Music therapy for depression. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2008, Issue 1. Art. No.: CD004517. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004517.pub2. [Full text]
  6. Morgan AJ, Jorm AF. Self-help interventions for depressive disorders and depressive symptoms: A systematic review. Annals of General Psychiatry. 2008, 7(1):13. [Full text]
  7. Tsang HW, Chan EP, Cheung WM. Effects of mindful and non-mindful exercises on people with depression: a systematic review. British Journal of Clinical Psychology. 2008, 47(Pt 3):303-22. [PubMed abstract]
  8. Wang H, Qi H, Wang BS, Cui YY, Zhu L, Rong ZX, Chen HZ. Is acupuncture beneficial in depression: A meta-analysis of 8 randomized controlled trials? Journal of Affective Disorders. 2008, Jun 10. [PubMed abstract]
  9. Wang L, Sun DW, Zou W, Zhang JY. [Systematic evaluation of therapeutic effect and safety of acupuncture for treatment of depression] Zhongguo Zhen Jiu. 2008, 28(5):381-6. [PubMed abstract]
  10. Zhou SF, Lai X. An update on clinical drug interactions with the herbal antidepressant St. John's wort. Current Drug Metabolism. 2008 Jun;9(5):394-409. [PubMed abstract]

2007

  1. Clayton EH, Hanstock TL, Garg ML, Hazell PL. Long chain omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids in the treatment of psychiatric illnesses in children and adolescents. Acta Neuropsychiatrica. 2007,19(2):92-103. [Abstract]
  2. Coelho HF, Canter PH, Ernst E. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy: evaluating current evidence and informing future research. Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology. 2007, 75(6):1000-5. [PubMed abstract]
  3. Ernst E. Herbal remedies for depression and anxiety. Advances in Psychiatric Treatment. 2007, 13(4):312-6. [Full text] 
  4. Gilbody S, Lightfoot T, Sheldon T. Is low folate a risk factor for depression? A meta-analysis and exploration of heterogeneity. Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health. 2007, 61(7):631-7. [PubMed abstract]
  5. Gohil KJ, Patel JA. Herb-drug interactions: A review and study based on assessment of clinical case reports in literature. Indian Journal of Pharmacology. 2007, 39(3):129-39. [Full text]
  6. Leo RJ, Ligot JS, Jr. A systematic review of randomized controlled trials of acupuncture in the treatment of depression. Journal of Affective Disorders. 2007, 97(1-3):13-22. [PubMed Abstract] [DARE structured abstract]
  7. Lin PY, Su KP. A meta-analytic review of double-blind, placebo-controlled trials of antidepressant efficacy of omega-3 fatty acids. Journal of Clinical Psychiatry. 2007, 68(7):1056-61. [PubMed abstract] [DARE provisional record]
  8. Meeks TW, Wetherell JL, Irwin MR, Redwine LS, Jeste DV. Complementary and alternative treatments for late-life depression, anxiety, and sleep disturbance: a review of randomized controlled trials. Journal of Clinical Psychiatry. 2007, 68(10):1461-71.  [PubMed abstract]
  9. Ross BM, Seguin J, Sieswerda LE. Omega-3 fatty acids as treatments for mental illness: which disorder and which fatty acid? Lipids in Health and Disease. 2007, 6:21. [Full text] [DARE provisional record] 
  10. Sarris J. Herbal medicines in the treatment of psychiatric disorders: a systematic review. Phytotherapy Research. 2007, 21(8):703-16. [PubMed abstract]
  11. Thachil AF, Mohan R, Bhugra D. The evidence base of complementary and alternative therapies in depression. Journal of Affective Disorders. 2007, 97(1-3):23-35. [PubMed abstract]
  12. Vitale A. An integrative review of Reiki touch therapy research. Holistic Nursing Practice. 2007,21(4):167-79. [PubMed abstract] 
  13. Werneke U. Risk management of nutritional supplements in chronic illness: the implications for the care of cancer and depression. Proceedings of the Nutrition Society. 2007, 66(4):483-92. [PubMed abstract]

2006

  1. Appleton KM, Hayward RC, Gunnell D, Peters TJ, Rogers PJ, Kessler D, Ness AR. Effects of n-3 long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids on depressed mood: systematic review of published trials. American Jourbal of Clinical Nutrition. 2006, 84(6):1308-16. [Full text] [DARE provisional record]
  2. Clement K, Covertson C R, Johnson M J, Dearing K. St. John's Wort and the treatment of mild to moderate depression: a systematic review. Holistic Nursing Practice. 2006, 20(4): 197-203. [PubMed abstract] [DARE provisional record]
  3. Dugoua JJ, Mills E, Perri D, Koren G. Safety and efficacy of St. John's wort (Hypericum) during pregnancy and lactation. Canadian Journal of Clinical Pharmacology. 2006;13(3):e268-e276. [Full text] 
  4. Freeman MP, Hibbeln JR, Wisner KL, Davis JM, Mischoulon D, Peet M, et al. Omega-3 fatty acids: evidence basis for treatment and future research in psychiatry. Journal of Clinical Psychiatry. 2006, 67(12):1954-67. [PubMed abstract]
  5. Jorm AF, Allen NB, O'Donnell CP, Parslow RA, Purcell R, Morgan AJ.  Effectiveness of complementary and self-help treatments for depression in children and adolescents. Medical Journal of Australia. 2006, 185(7):368-72. [Full text]
  6. Nieuwstraten C, Labiris NR, Holbrook A. Systematic overview of drug interactions with antidepressant medications. Canadian Journal of Psychiatry. 2006, 51(5):300-16. [PubMed abstract] [DARE Provisional record]
  7. Pilkington K, Kirkwood G, Rampes H, Richardson J. Aromatherapy and massage for depression: a systematic review. Complementary and Alternative Medicine Evidence Online (CAMEOL) Database. 2006. Available at: http://www.rccm.org.uk/cameol/Default.aspx [Accessed Aug 2008]
  8. Pilkington K, Kirkwood G, Rampes H, Richardson J. Reflexology  for depression: a systematic review. Complementary and Alternative Medicine Evidence Online (CAMEOL) Database. 2006. Available at: http://www.rccm.org.uk/cameol/Default.aspx [Accessed Aug 2008]
  9. Pilkington K, Rampes H, Richardson J. Complementary medicine for depression. Expert Review of Neurotherapeutics. 2006, 6(11): 1741-51. [Abstract]
  10. Werneke U, Turner T, Priebe S. Complementary medicines in psychiatry: Review of effectiveness and safety. British Journal of Psychiatry. 2006, 188(2):109-21. [Abstract]
  11. Williams AL, Katz D, Ali A, Girard C, Goodman J, Bell I. Do essential fatty acids have a role in the treatment of depression? Journal of Affective Disorders. 2006, 93(1-3):117-23.

2005

  1. Frazer CJ, Christensen H, Griffiths KM. Effectiveness of treatments for depression in older people. Medical Journal of Australia. 2005, 182(12):627-32. [Full text]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Yoga
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,YOGA,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,DATE ADDED,OCTOBER 2008]]>
document.body:
111-12008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression: Yoga

A review of clinical trials of yoga in depression published up to 2004 found 5 randomised controlled trials, each of which utilised different forms of yoga interventions and participants with mild to severe symptoms. (Pilkington 2005) All trials reported positive findings although various methodological details were missing. No adverse effects were reported with the exception of fatigue and breathlessness in participants in one study. It was concluded that the initial indications are of potentially beneficial effects of yoga interventions on depressive disorders. Several of the interventions may not be feasible in those with reduced or impaired mobility. Nevertheless, further investigation of yoga as a therapeutic intervention was considered valuable. 


Subsequently, 2 further RCTs have been published, both of which were conducted in India. In the first, 69 older adults (60+ years) in a residential home participated in yoga classes or received Ayurveda or were randomised to a wait list group to be offered treatment at a later stage (Krishnamurthy 2007). Yoga consisted of regulated breathing, physical postures (asanas) and relaxation for 75 minutes 6 times weekly over a period of 6 months. Scores on the short version of the Geriatric Depression Scale decreased for those in the yoga group but no significant changes were seen in other groups. This trial had the benefit of a long duration of treatment as is often required in depression but the attrition rate in the Ayurvda group was considerable (11 patients discontinued treatment). The groups were reported to be well-matched initially but the actual numbers participating were small and the context of the study limits applicability in practice. The second study included patients between 18 and 45 years of age with a DSM IV diagnosis of depression (Sharma 2005). Fifteen patients participated in Sahaj Yoga (a meditation-based form of yoga) while 15 participated in a control intervention which provided the same environment and attention as yoga subjects. However, actual meditation was not practiced and participants were instructed to simply place their hands at different positions as during Sahaj Yoga practice and thereafter sit quietly with their eyes closed. The intervention lasted for 30 minutes 3 times weekly for 8 weeks. Both groups continued on their current medication. A significant decrease in scores on the Hamilton rating scale for depression was reported in both groups but the percentage improvement in the Sahaj Yoga group was significantly higher.The number of patients who went into remission (scores of 7 or less) after two months of intervention were also significantly higher in the yoga group. Further outcomes from this study were reported in Sharma et al 2006. Trials of yoga conducted in a Western health context are still required in order to see if these preliminary positive results are translated into practice.


Systematic reviews

Pilkington K, Kirkwood G, Rampes H, Richardson J. Yoga for depression: the research evidence. Journal of Affective Disorders. 2005, 89(1-3):13-24. [PubMed abstract] [DARE structured abstract]


Randomized controlled trials (RCTs)

Krishnamurthy MN, Telles S. Assessing depression following two ancient Indian interventions: effects of yoga and ayurveda on older adults in a residential home. Journal of Gerontological Nursing. 2007, 33(2):17-23. [PubMed abstract]


Sharma VK, Das S, Mondal S, Goswampi U, Gandhi A. Effect of Sahaj Yoga on depressive disorders. Indian Journal of Physiology and Pharmacololy. 2005, 49(4):462-8. [PubMed abstract]


Sharma VK, Das S, Mondal S, Goswami U, Gandhi A. Effect of Sahaj Yoga on neuro-cognitive functions in patients suffering from major depression. Indian Journal of Physiology and Pharmacololy. 2006, 50(4):375-83. [PubMed abstract]


Woolery A, Myers H, Sternlieb B, Zeltzer L. A yoga intervention for young adults with elevated symptoms of depression. Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine. 2004, 10(2):60-3. (included in systematic review above) [PubMed abstract]


Other studies of interest

Shapiro D, Cook IA, Davydov DM, Ottaviani C, Leuchter AF, Abrams M. Yoga as a complementary treatment of depression: effects of traits and moods on treatment outcome. Evidence-based Complementary and Alternative Medicine. 2007, 4(4):493-502. [Full text]

 

Link back to 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture
document.publisher: Complementary and Alternative Medicine Specialist Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,APRIL 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture

Published: 20 April 2009

 

 

Introduction


The 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture aims to identify, organise and present all relevant systematic reviews and large-scale randomised controlled trials (RCTs) published between February 2008 and February 2009.

Previously published studies have been included in the 2008 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture or can be found by searching this website.


We have searched a large number of databases and used strict selection criteria for the identified studies, in order to base the annual update on the best current evidence available. The studies included in this update have met our selection criteria but have not been fully appraised. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

For more details about the search methods and the selection process for this annual update see the methodology section.

The full results are listed below. For a list of studies selected by the topic editor as being of particular importance click here.

For a brief overview of the topic of Acupuncture, including information on clinical uses and safety, see the introductory article.

 

Contents

  • Methodology
  • Results of the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture
    • Systematic reviews and meta-analyses categorised by health topic
      • General reviews of acupuncture
      • Allergies/ENT 
      • Cancer
      • Cardiovascular diseases
      • Child health
      • Male urogenital diseases
      • Mental health
      • Musculoskeletal diseases 
      • Neurological disorders
      • Obesity
      • Pain
      • Skin disorders
      • Stroke
      • Surgery/Theatres
      • Women’s health/Pregnancy and childbirth
    • Systematic reviews and meta-analyses (all topics)
    • Cost-effectiveness studies
    • Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)
  • Additional resources - systematic reviews and guidelines covering a range of interventions including acupuncture

Acknowledgement

The CAM Specialist Library project team would like to thank the topic editor Dr Mike Cummings for his contribution to the development of the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture. 

]]>

document.publisher: Complementary and Alternative Medicine Specialist Library
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,APRIL 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture - Methodology

Sources searched:

The Cochrane Library (CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHS EED), CRD databases (DARE, NHS EED, HTA), PubMed (and MEDLINE), EMBASE, AMED, CINAHL, PsycINFO

Selection criteria (at screening stage)

Inclusion criteria:

  1. Systematic reviews - explicit description of search process and statement of methodology (at least 2 sources must have been searched and there must be a statement of methodology)
  2. HTA reports and cost-effectiveness studies 
  3. Large randomised controlled trials (RCTs) – with more than 100 participants. 
  4. Topic relevance (studies should focus on acupuncture or include acupuncture as one of the investigated interventions)

Exclusion criteria:

  1. The study is not a systematic review, meta-analysis, HTA report, cost-effectiveness study or a large RCT. 
  2. The study does not focus on acupuncture or include acupuncture as one of the investigated interventions.
  3. The study is published in a language other than English and English abstract is not available.

Search process

The searches were carried out between 19 and 23 February 2009 and were limited to articles published since 1 January 2008. To identify relevant systematic reviews the information specialist searched the sources listed above using the CAM SL systematic reviews filter, which emphasizes specificity (precision) over sensitivity. The PubMed Clinical Queries systematic review filter was also used.
More details of search terms and filters used are available by contacting the information specialist. 

Results

The totals number of records retrieved was 469. After removing the duplicates there were 202 to screen. Of these 74 were selected as potential systematic reviews. If any uncertainty existed records were still included in the list. The titles and abstracts of the potential systematic reviews were then screened by the topic editor and categorised by medical specialty, condition or symptom. The final selection includes 56 systematic reviews and 2 cost-effectiveness studies with a main focus on acupuncture. There were 9 systematic reviews and guidelines which covered a range of interventions including acupuncture.

In addition a search for relevant, large-scale (100 or more participants) randomised controlled trials (RCTs) was carried out. The totals number of records retrieved was 621. After removing the duplicates there were 392 to screen. The final selection includes 78 RCTs.


Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture

]]>
