document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture - Musculoskeletal diseases

The following relevant studies on this topic have been published between February 2008 and February 2009.

These studies have met our selection criteria but have not been fully appraised. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

  1. Cui Y, Wang Y, Liu Z. Acupuncture for restless legs syndrome. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2008, Issue 4. Art. No.: CD006457. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD006457.pub2. [Full text]
  2. Ee CC, Manheimer E, Pirotta MV, White AR. Acupuncture for pelvic and back pain in pregnancy: a systematic review. American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology. 2008, 198(3):254-9. [PubMed abstract] [DARE appraisal]
  3. Fu LM, Li JT, Wu WS. Randomized controlled trials of acupuncture for neck pain: systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2009, 15(2):133-145. [PubMed abstract]
  4. Harland S, Bleakley C, McDonough SM. Acupuncture in soft tissue injury management: a systematic review. Rehabilitation and Therapy Research Society Third Annual Conference: Collaborative research... making it a reality, held on 26-27 April 2007 at the University of Ulster. Physical Therapy Reviews. 2008;13(2):121-3. [Conference abstract, subscription required to access this publication] 
  5. Johnston BC, da Costa BR, Devereaux PJ, Akl EA, Busse JW; Expertise-Based RCT Working Group. The use of expertise-based randomized controlled trials to assess spinal manipulation and acupuncture for low back pain: a systematic review. Spine. 2008, 33(8):914-8. [PubMed abstract]
  6. Lee MS, Shin BC, Ernst E. Acupuncture for rheumatoid arthritis: a systematic review. Rheumatology (Oxford). 2008, 47(12):1747-53. [PubMed abstract]
  7. Lee MS, Pittler MH, Shin BC, Kong JC, Ernst E. Bee venom acupuncture for musculoskeletal pain: a review. Journal of Pain. 2008, 9(4):289-97. [PubMed abstract] [DARE provisional record]
  8. Schuller BK, Neugebauer EA. [Evidence for laser acupuncture in cases of orthopedic diseases : a systematic review]. [German] Evidenz zur Laserakupunktur bei orthopadischen Erkrankungen : Ein systematisches Review. Schmerz. 2008, 22(1):9-15. [Abstract]
  9. Selfe TK, Taylor AG. Acupuncture and osteoarthritis of the knee: a review of randomized, controlled trials. Family and Community Health. 2008, 31(3):247-54. [PubMed abstract]
  10. Tough EA, White AR, Cummings TM, Richards SH, Campbell JL. Acupuncture and dry needling in the management of myofascial trigger point pain: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials. European Journal of Pain. 2009, 13(1):3-10. [PubMed abstract]
  11. Wang C, de Pablo P, Chen X, Schmid C, McAlindon T. Acupuncture for pain relief in patients with rheumatoid arthritis: a systematic review. Arthritis and Rheumatism. 2008, 59(9):1249-56. [PubMed abstract]
  12. Yuan J, Purepong N, Kerr DP, Park J, Bradbury I, McDonough S. Effectiveness of acupuncture for low back pain: a systematic review. Spine. 2008, 33(23):E887-900. [PubMed abstract]
  13. Yuan J, Kerr D, Park J, Liu XH, McDonough S. Treatment regimens of acupuncture for low back pain--a systematic review. Complementary Therapies in Medicine. 2008, 16(5):295-304. [PubMed abstract]

document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-B,ASTHMA,CAM GENERAL,EDUCATION/CPD,APRIL 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma

Published: 5 May 2009

 

 

 

Introduction

The 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma aims to identify, organise and present the latest information on this topic. We have searched a large number of databases for studies published or updated between March 2008 and March 2009. For more details about our methods, please see the methodology section.

Previously published studies have been included in the 2008 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma or can be found by searching this website.

For further information on asthma see the relevant pages from the NHS Evidence - respiratory specialist collection.


Contents

  • Methodology
  • Results of the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma 
  • Commentary on the results of the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma
  • Additional resources – continuing professional development (CPD)/ education

 

]]>

document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ASTHMA,CONDITIONS A-B,VITAMIN C,VITAMIN E,BETA-CAROTENE,FOOD AND BEVERAGES,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,VITAMINS,PROBIOTICS,MAY 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma - Commentary

Introduction

Diet and nutritional supplements are the main focus of the 2009 CAM Annual Evidence Update on asthma. Three reviews assess the evidence on antioxidants (Gao et al. 2008, Karpinski and Touger-Decker 2008, Kaur et al. 2009) and each uses a different approach to this topic. The fourth review is on the potential benefits of probiotics. (Vliagoftis et al. 2008) Finally, three reviews of specific therapeutic approaches included one or more trials of asthma.


Vitamin C in asthma: evidence from trials

The first review is a Cochrane review of vitamin C supplementation in asthma (Kaur et al. 2009). Vitamin C is one of the key antioxidant vitamins and is present in the extracellular fluid lining the lung. The rationale for examining vitamin C in asthma is based on the fact that  studies have shown that both adults and children with asthma have lower concentrations of vitamin C compared with non-asthmatics. Low intake including infrequent fruit consumption has been associated with reduced lung function or lung dysfunction. While consumption of fruit and vegetables in countries such as the UK has decreased, incidence and prevalence of asthma has increased. One supposition is that people with asthma either have low supplies of vitamin C or an increased demand for vitamin C. Three previous reviews on this topic have been published but reached differing conclusions.

The authors found 9 randomised controlled trials (RCTs) with a total of 330 participants. Seven studies involved adult patients, one involved children and one included adults and children. Study size ranged from 6 to 210 participants. All treatments were administered orally, either as tablets or as an oral solution. The dose used and duration of treatment varied, from single doses of between 500mg and 2g to long-term supplementation with 1g vitamin C daily for up to 6 months. There was also considerable variation in the outcomes measured. Five trials contributed numerical data to the review on lung function, symptom scores, IgE levels and inhaled steroid use. One small study showed a significant difference in % drop in FEV1 post-exercise. The authors' conclusions were that ‘At present, evidence from randomised-controlled trials is insufficient to recommend a specific role for vitamin C in the treatment of asthma.’


Vitamin C, vitamin E and beta-carotene: evidence from observational studies

The second paper is a meta-analysis of 10 observational studies on dietary antioxidants in asthma including 13,653 participants with asthma (Gao et al. 2008). The authors searched MEDLINE for case-control or cross-sectional studies up to March 2007 but the 3 studies mentioned in the review below were not included. Focussing specifically on vitamin C, vitamin E and beta-carotene, the authors reported that ‘a higher dietary intake of these antioxidants was not associated with a lower risk of asthma’.


Antioxidants and diet in general: evidence from trials and observational studies

The third review addresses a range of antioxidants in asthma (Karpinski and Touger-Decker 2008). Initially, a detailed case history of a female patient whose asthma was apparently improved with dietary supplements including antioxidant supplementation is presented. This is followed by a review of evidence published between 2003 and 2007 which included 3 reviews, 4 RCTs and 3 observational studies (all published in 2006). The supplements tested in the trials included selenium, vitamin C and magnesium, and vitamin E while the observational studies examined dietary intake of a range of antioxidants. The various studies were apparently appraised but the criteria used are not described and it is not entirely clear how the findings were synthesised. Results of the largest study, investigating incidence of asthma in a cohort of over 68,000 people in France, suggested that a higher intake of antioxidants through diet, especially leafy vegetables, carrots and tomatoes may help prevent and manage asthma. However, the overall conclusions of the review were that ‘… there is insufficient evidence to support the addition of antioxidant supplementation to the current clinical practice guidelines for asthma’.


Probiotics in asthma

The systematic review by Vliagoftis and colleagues published in 2008 addressed probiotics in both allergic rhinitis and asthma. According to the WHO, probiotics are ‘live microorganisms which when administered in adequate amounts confer a health benefit on the host’. Probiotics are currently available in a range of products including yoghurts and previous studies had suggested a beneficial effect in allergic conditions. As in Gao et al.’s review above, the authors only searched one database (PubMed) and excluded studies in languages other than English. Of the 16 RCTs located, four were in asthmatic patients with two in children, one in young adults and one in a mixed age range and asthma severity varied. Different probiotics were used in each study and given as fermented milk/yoghurt, as suspension or in capsules. Quality of life, number of asthma episodes and use of other medication were not significantly different between the patients on probiotics and those taking placebo. The authors concluded that ‘there was no effect of probiotics on asthma treatment’.


Other therapies

No further systematic reviews focusing on asthma were found. Single studies of asthma were included in reviews of reflexology (Wang et al. 2008) and Boswellia serrata (frankincense) (Ernst 2008). A trial of frankincense in 80 people reported beneficial effects but the findings require further confirmation. Reflexology was tested against non-specific foot massage in a small trial of 40 people with bronchial asthma but was not found to be superior. A systematic review of yoga in children also included studies on asthma (Galantino et al. 2008). Four studies were located which reported positive findings although the reviewers suggested that there was clinical heterogeneity and participants were undergoing one of a variety of additional drug treatments so that the results are difficult to interpret.


Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma 

]]>

document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,APRIL 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma - Methodology

Sources searched

The Cochrane Library (CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHS EED), PubMed (and MEDLINE), EMBASE, AMED, CINAHL, PsycINFO

NHS Evidence - respiratory (formally an NLH Specialist Library)


Selection criteria

Inclusion criteria:

  • Explicit description of search process and statement of methodology (at least 2 sources must have been searched and there must be a statement that the study is a meta-analysis or a systematic review).
  • Topic relevance (studies should be focused on asthma)
  • Study types: guidance/guidelines, systematic reviews, meta-analyses, HTA reports, cost effectiveness and economic evaluation studies.

Exclusion criteria:

  • The study is not one of the types specified above. 
  • The study is published in a language other than English and English abstract is not available.

Search strategy

The search strategy included terms for asthma, general text words and terms for CAM and selected CAM therapies, including dietary and nutritional therapies, and a methodological filter for systematic reviews. The searches were carried out on 18-20 March 2009 and were limited to articles published since 1 January 2008.

To identify relevant systematic reviews the information specialist has searched the sources listed above using the CAM specialist collection systematic reviews filter, which emphasizes specificity (precision) over sensitivity. In addition a search of PubMed using the systematic reviews subset was conducted.

More details of the search terms and filters used are available by contacting the information specialist.


Search results

The total number of records retrieved was 89. After removing the duplicates there were 48 citations for screening. Of these 13 were selected as potential systematic reviews or other relevant study types. The titles and abstracts were further screened for relevance. The final selection includes 7 systematic reviews. As there were few systematic reviews published in the last 12 months, we have also included reviews where the main focus is on a on specific therapy if trials on asthma were included.


Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma 

]]>

111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma - Results

The following relevant studies on this topic have been published between March 2008 and March 2009.

These studies have met our selection criteria but have not been fully appraised. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

  1. Gao J, Gao X, Li W, Zhu Y, Thompson PJ. Observational studies on the effect of dietary antioxidants on asthma: a meta-analysis. Respirology. 2008, 13(4):528-36. [PubMed abstract]
  2. Karpinski C, Touger-Decker R. Antioxidants and asthma: a case report and review of the evidence. Topics in Clinical Nutrition. 2008, 23(3):259-68. [Abstract]
  3. Kaur B, Rowe BH, Arnold E. Vitamin C supplementation for asthma. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2009;(1):CD000993. [Full text]
  4. Vliagoftis H, Kouranos VD, Betsi GI, Falagas ME. Probiotics for the treatment of allergic rhinitis and asthma: systematic review of randomized controlled trials. Annals of Allergy Asthma & Immunology 2008 Dec;101(6):570-9. [PubMed abstract]

In addition to the systematic reviews with a main focus on asthma three reviews focused on specific therapeutic approaches included one or more trials of asthma.

  1. Ernst E. Frankincense: systematic review. BMJ. 2008, Dec 17;337:a2813. doi: 10.1136/bmj.a2813. [Full text] [DARE appraisal]
  2. Galantino ML, Galbavy R, Quinn L. Therapeutic effects of yoga for children: a systematic review of the literature. Pediatric Physical Therapy. 2008, 20(1):66-80. [PubMed abstract] [DARE provisional record]
  3. Wang M, Tsai P, Lee P, Chang W, Yang C. The efficacy of reflexology: systematic review. Journal of Advanced Nursing. 2008, 62(5):512-21. [PubMed abstract] [DARE provisional record]

Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma

document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain

Published: 16 November 2009

 

 

 

Introduction

This annual evidence update on complementary and alternative medicine for low back pain aims to identify, organise and present the latest information on this topic. We have searched a large number of databases for studies published or updated between July 2008 and September 2009. Previously published studies have been included in the 2008 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain or can be found by searching this collection.

This year's highlight is the NICE guideline on early management of persistent non-specific low back pain.


For more details about the search methods and the selection process please see the methodology section.

For further information on low back pain see also the relevant pages from the NHS Evidence - musculoskeletal and the NHS Evidence - trauma and orthopaedics specialist collections.

 

Contents

  • Evidence on specific therapies and approaches
    • Acupuncture
    • Herbal medicine
    • Massage
    • Osteopathy
    • Spinal manipulation
    • Other therapies
  • Results of the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain
  • Methodology


Acknowledgements

The CAM specialist collection project team would like to acknowledge the contribution made by a number of people to the development of this annual evidence update and thank them for all their efforts. In particular Prof Alan Breen, Dr Mike Cummings, Carol Fawkes and Michael McIntyre who wrote the expert commentaries.

]]>

document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Acupuncture
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,BACK PAIN,CONDITIONS A-B,NOVEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Acupuncture

Mike Cummings, Medical Director of the British Medical Acupuncture Society


Since the Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain 2008 there have been three notable publications that add to the knowledge base on acupuncture for low back pain.


A NICE Guideline on early management of persistent non-specific low back pain was released on 13th May 2009.1 This guideline recommended as a key priorities:

  • Provide people with advice and information to promote self-management of their low back pain.
  • Offer one of the following treatment options, taking into account patient preference: an exercise programme, a course of manual therapy or a course of acupuncture. Consider offering another of these options if the chosen treatment does not result in satisfactory improvement.

With regard to a course of acupuncture the guideline recommended a course of acupuncture needling comprising up to a maximum of 10 sessions over a period of up to 12 weeks.


One relevant systematic review has been published in 2009.2 On the basis of their review the authors recommended that acupuncture should be advocated as an adjunct to conventional care in the European Guidelines for the treatment of chronic low back pain. The review method was a best evidence synthesis, so we still do not have an updated systematic review with pooling of data in meta-analysis since the Cochrane review by Furlan in 2005.3


There was one large RCT of acupuncture in low back pain in 2009.4  Cherkin et al compared four groups in 638 patients with chronic low back pain: individualised acupuncture; standardised acupuncture; simulated acupuncture (with cocktail sticks); and usual care alone. The three acupuncture groups had very similar results, and they all demonstrated significant benefits over usual care at all time points from 8 weeks to a year. The authors concluded that ‘although acupuncture was found effective for chronic low back pain, tailoring needling sites to each patient and penetration of the skin appear to be unimportant in eliciting therapeutic benefits’. Whilst this study was large, it was not powered for equivalence; therefore we cannot be sure that cocktail sticks have the same effect as true acupuncture. I doubt the results of this trial, or that of Haake et al 5, will change the results of pooling data in meta-analysis of acupuncture over sham, since neither demonstrate a trend in favour of sham acupuncture, indeed the largest trial (Haake et al)5 has a trend in favour of true acupuncture.


As indicated by NICE, it is now time to start routine use of acupuncture for back pain in the NHS accompanied by further evaluative research to guide maximising benefits for patients and cost utility for the tax payer.


References

  1. Savigny P, Kuntze S, Watson P, Underwood M, Ritchie G , Cotterell M, Hill D, Browne N, Buchanan E, Coffey P, Dixon P, Drummond C, Flanagan M, Greenough,C, Griffiths M, Halliday-Bell J, Hettinga D, Vogel S, Walsh D. Low Back Pain: Early Management of Persistent Non-specific Low Back Pain. London: National Collaborating Centre for Primary Care and Royal College of General Practitioners, 2009. [Full text]
  2. Yuan J, Purepong N, Kerr DP, Park J, Bradbury I, McDonough S. Effectiveness of acupuncture for low back pain: a systematic review. Spine. 2008, 33(23):E887-900. [PubMed abstract] 
  3. Furlan AD, van Tulder MW, Cherkin DC, Tsukayama H, Lao L, Koes BW, Berman BM. Acupuncture and dry-needling for low back pain. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2005, Issue 1. Art. No.: CD001351. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD001351.pub2. [Full text]
  4. Cherkin DC, Sherman KJ, Avins AL, Erro JH, Ichikawa L, Barlow WE et al. A randomized trial comparing acupuncture, simulated acupuncture, and usual care for chronic low back pain. Archives of Internal Medicine. 2009, 169(9):858-66. [PubMed abstract]
  5. Haake M, Müller HH, Schade-Brittinger C, Basler HD, Schäfer H, Maier C, Endres HG, Trampisch HJ, Molsberger A. German Acupuncture Trials (GERAC) for chronic low back pain: randomized, multicenter, blinded, parallel-group trial with 3 groups. Archives of Internal Medicine. 2007, 167(17):1892-8. [PubMed abstract] 

 

Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Herbal medicine
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-B,BACK PAIN,NOVEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Herbal medicine

Commentary by Michael McIntyre, European Herbal and Traditional Medicine Practitioners Association

Update of 2007 evidence summary by Saul Berkovitz, Royal London Homoeopathic Hospital


There are a number of systematic reviews of the use of herbal medicines in the treatment of low back pain.1-6 Overall, the evidence is promising but certainly not definitive. Methodological problems include the small number of trials admitted for review because of the variable quality of studies. For example, a recent overview of the evidence included only one systematic review and one further RCT on herbal medicines for chronic lower back pain.1 This clearly says more about the poor quality of research into herbal interventions than the efficacy or otherwise of herbal treatment itself. 


Further methodological difficulties are posed by the variety of extracts used, which does not allow statistical pooling and by the lack of clarity about plant species used. In two of the reviews1,2 several herbal medicines are reported as treatments for low back pain but there appears to be confusion with regard to their names. For example Camphora momol would appear to confuse Commiphora molmol, (myrrh) and Cinnamomum camphora (camphor), Maleluca alternifolia should be Melaleuca alternifolia (Ti Tree), Menthe peperita should be Mentha piperita (peppermint) and Tancaetum parthenium should be Tanacetum parthenium (feverfew). In addition, positive evidence from clinical trials using high-quality, high-potency, often standardised products unavailable in the UK is not necessarily generalisable to the extracts available in the UK market.


There are also important questions unanswered. As mentioned below, studies into the efficacy of Harpogophytum (Devil’s claw) used specific doses of harpagoside, the purported active constituent of H. procumbens, as a marker but there is certainly a possibility that this constituent does not account for the action of the whole plant. In addition, some herbal traditions use mixtures of herbs together rather than individual plants on their own. Angelica sinensis, reported as used in the treatment of low back pain1,2 is rarely used on its own in the Chinese herbal tradition from which it comes. What herbal practitioners do in practice clearly needs evaluation or the benefits of traditional treatments may be missed.


Devil’s claw has been examined in two systematic reviews.3,4 Overall, the results are tentatively positive, although studies are heterogeneous in terms of the dose and type of extract used (aqueous, ethanolic or dry powder). There are four studies in acute exacerbations of chronic low back pain over 4-6 weeks. The most convincing of these showed benefit in pain reduction from aqueous extracts standardised to 50 or 100mg of harpagoside (a supposed quality marker) over placebo. The other studies, although all reported as positive, can be criticised for lack of sufficient statistical power, lack of double-blinding, or improvement in secondary outcome measures only. Adverse effects were generally mild and consisted largely of gastrointestinal upset; however it is relevant that a contraindication to the use of Devil’s claw is significant gastritis or peptic ulcer disease, which might apply to patients intolerant of non-steroidal inflammatory drugs seeking herbal medicine as an alternative approach. This said, a recent systematic review of the safety of Harpogophytum preparations identified 28 double-blind clinical trials involving 6,892 patients who received this herbal medicine. In none of double-blind trials was the incidence of adverse effects during treatment with Harpogophytum higher than that observed during placebo treatment.7


Two studies of Salix alba (willow bark) products, standardised for their salicin content, have been performed in acute exacerbations of low back pain2. One study in 210 patients, using two doses (120 or 240mg salicin) or placebo, showed a moderate, dose-dependent effect over 4 weeks for pain relief and analgesic reduction. A second study was reported as showing equivalence of Salix 240mg/day with rofecoxib (‘Vioxx’) 12.5mg daily. Although this was randomised it was not double-blind but an open study and so carries less weight. A systematic review on the effectiveness of willow bark for musculoskeletal pain published in 2009 identified 7 publications reporting four trials with confirmatory and four with exploratory study designs. Three manuscripts presented the same trial data One confirmatory and two exploratory studies indicate a dose-dependent analgesic effect not inferior to rofecoxib in patients with low back pain. In one exploratory and one confirmatory study conflicting results were achieved in participants with osteoarthritis. No significant effect was seen in a confirmatory study in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, but this study was grossly underpowered. All studies investigated ethanolic extracts with daily doses up to 240 mg salicin over periods of up to six weeks. The study noted that in the treatment of low back pain, pain reduction appears to be dose dependent: an extract providing 240mg of salicin a day was more effective than half that dose. Further studies are required to find out if treatment of osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis requires extract with higher doses than 240 mg salicin per day. The study commented that “ethanolic willow bark extract is a promising analgesic in the treatment of low back pain with low incidence of adverse effects”.5


Topical plasters containing extracts of Capsicum frutescens (cayenne pepper) have been tested against ‘placebo’ plasters in two studies of chronic LBP in a total of 484 patients2. In both studies there was significantly better pain relief in the Capsicum group. However it is difficult to make a true placebo because of the sensation of warmth caused by initial application of the capsicum plasters (in one study this was experienced by 95% in the Capsicum group and only 48% in the placebo group). Both studies, despite being reported as being of moderate to high quality, may therefore have been subject to a degree of ‘unblinding’. There were also positive results in two short-term (one to two-week) studies of topical capsicum preparations, one of a combined capsicum / salicylate ointment versus placebo in acute LBP and one study showing equivalence of a Capsicum gel with a homeopathic gel in mixed acute and acute-on-chronic LBP. It is debatable whether topical capsaicin products are best described as ‘complementary’ as their use is well-established in other conditions such as neuropathies and osteoarthritis.


A meta-analysis to estimate the analgesic effects of treatments for non-specific low back pain reported in placebo-controlled randomized trials included 76 trials reporting on 34 treatments, 50% of which were considered to have statistically significant effects compared with placebo. Thirteen of these treatments, including 4 trials using herbal medicines, were assessed as having moderate effects compared to placebo.6


A paper measuring the impact of herbal medicines on physical impairment suggests that there may be little to lose from omitting the time-consuming assessments of "physical impairment" in studies of the (primarily analgesic) effectiveness of herbal preparations.8 In conclusion, moderately strong evidence exists for Devil’s Claw (Harpagophytum procumbens) in acute exacerbations of low back pain and for capsaicin plasters. There is inconsistent evidence for willow bark products. No other herbal products have been rigorously tested and there are clearly some significant problems with the designs of trials which need addressing before more research is undertaken.


References

  1. Gagnier JJ. Evidence-informed management of chronic low back pain with herbal, vitamin, mineral, and homeopathic supplements. Spine Journal. 2008, 8(1):70-9. [Full text on journal website]
  2. Gagnier JJ, vanTulder M, Berman B, Bombardier C. Herbal medicine for low back pain. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2006, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD004504. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004504.pub3. [Full text]
  3. Brendler T, Gruenwald J, Ulbricht C, Basch E; Natural Standard Research Collaboration. Devil's Claw (Harpagophytum procumbens DC): an evidence-based systematic review by the Natural Standard Research Collaboration. Journal of Herbal Pharmacotherapy. 2006, 6(1):89-126. [PubMed abstract]
  4. Gagnier JJ, Chrubasik S, Manheimer E. Harpgophytum procumbens for osteoarthritis and low back pain: a systematic review. BMC Complementary and Alternative Medicine. 2004, 4:13. [Full text] [DARE structured abstract]
  5. Vlachojannis JE, Cameron M, Chrubasik S. A systematic review on the effectiveness of willow bark for musculoskeletal pain. Phytotherapy Research. 2009, 23(7):897-900. [PubMed abstract]
  6. Machado LA, Kamper SJ, Herbert RD, Maher CG, McAuley JH. Analgesic effects of treatments for non-specific low back pain: a meta-analysis of placebo-controlled randomized trials. Rheumatology (Oxford). 2009, 48(5):520-7. [PubMed abstract]
  7. Vlachojannis J, Roufogalis BD, Chrubasik S. Systematic review on the safety of Harpagophytum preparations for osteoarthritic and low back pain. Phytotherapy Research. 2008, 22(2):149-52. [PubMed abstract]
  8. Chrubasik C, Black A, Müller-Ladner U, Chrubasik S. Impact of herbal medicines on physical impairment. Phytomedicine. 2008, 15(6-7):536-9. [PubMed abstract]

Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Methodology
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,NOVEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - MethodologyThe annual evidence update on CAM for Low Back Pain aims to identify, organise and present the latest information on this topic. We have searched comprehensively a large number of databases, covering the period from July 2008 to September 2009. Previously published studies have been included in the the 2008 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain.


Sources searched


The Cochrane Library (CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHS EED), PubMed (and MEDLINE), EMBASE, AMED, CINAHL, PsycINFO, the NHS Evidence - musculoskeletal and NHS Evidence - trauma and orthopaedics specialist collections.


Selection criteria
Inclusion criteria:

- Study types: guidance/guidelines, systematic reviews, meta-analyses, HTA reports, cost effectiveness and economic evaluation studies, RCTs
- Focused on low back pain
- CAM interventions

To identify systematic reviews the definition of a systematic review from the Glossary of Cochrane Collaboration and research terms was used:

“A review of a clearly formulated question that uses systematic and explicit methods to identify, select, and critically appraise relevant research, and to collect and analyse data from the studies that are included in the review. Statistical methods (meta-analysis) may or may not be used to analyse and summarise the results of the included studies.”

Exclusion criteria:

- Main focus is not on low back pain
- Not CAM
- Other study/publication types – e.g., animal studies, in vitro studies, narrative reviews, editorials, letters, comments
- The study is published in a language other than English and English abstract is not available


Search strategy

The search strategy included text words and indexing terms for low back pain, for CAM in general and for specific CAM therapies, and methodological filters for systematic reviews and randomised controlled trials (RCTs).

The search strategy for low back pain is based on the Cochrane Back Group strategy.

Below is an example of the strategy used to search the MEDLINE database (NHS Search 2). 

1. (acupuncture OR acupressure OR electroacupuncture OR "auricular therapy" OR auriculotherapy).ti,ab
2. exp ACUPUNCTURE/ OR exp ACUPUNCTURE THERAPY/
3. ("Alexander technique" OR "Alexander principle").ti,ab
4. (aromatherapy OR "aroma therapy" OR "essential oil*" OR "volatile oil*").ti,ab
5. exp OILS, VOLATILE/ OR exp AROMATHERAPY/
6. (chiropractic OR "spinal manipulation").ti,ab
7. exp CHIROPRACTIC/ OR exp MANIPULATION, CHIROPRACTIC/
8. exp MANIPULATION, SPINAL/
9. (homeop* OR homoeop*).ti,ab
10. exp HOMEOPATHY/
11. (hypnosis OR hypnotiz* OR hypnotis* OR hypnotherapy OR "hypnotic susceptibility" OR autosuggestion OR autohypnosis OR self-hypnosis).ti,ab
12. exp HYPNOSIS/
13. exp SUGGESTION/
14. massage.ti,ab
15. exp MASSAGE/
16. meditat*.ti,ab
17. exp MEDITATION/
18. osteopath*.ti,ab
19. exp OSTEOPATHIC MEDICINE/
20. exp MANIPULATION, OSTEOPATHIC/
21. (reflexolog* OR "zone therapy" OR reflexotherapy).ti,ab
22. (yoga OR yogic OR asanas OR dhyana OR pranayama).ti,ab
23. exp YOGA/
24. (herb* OR phyto* OR "plant extract").ti,ab
25. exp PLANTS, MEDICINAL/ OR exp PHYTOTHERAPY/ OR exp PLANT EXTRACTS/ OR exp DRUGS, CHINESE HERBAL/ OR exp HERB-DRUG INTERACTIONS/
26. ("art therapy" OR "autogenic training" OR Ayurved* OR mindfulness OR mbsr OR "music therapy" OR naturopath* OR relaxation OR "tai chi" OR "therapeutic touch" OR "Chinese medicine" OR TCM OR "traditional medicine").ti,ab
27. exp ART THERAPY/
28. exp AUTOGENIC TRAINING/
29. exp MEDICINE, AYURVEDIC/
30. exp MUSIC THERAPY/
31. exp NATUROPATHY/
32. exp TAI JI/
33. exp THERAPEUTIC TOUCH/ OR exp MENTAL HEALING/
34. exp MEDICINE, CHINESE TRADITIONAL/
35. exp MEDICINE, TRADITIONAL/
36. ("alternative medicine*" OR "alternative therap*" OR "complementary medicine*" OR "complementary therap*").ti,ab;
37. exp COMPLEMENTARY THERAPIES/
38. 1 OR 2 OR 3 OR 4 OR 5 OR 6 OR 7 OR 8 OR 9 OR 10 OR 11 OR 12 OR 13 OR 14 OR 15 OR 16 OR 17 OR 18 OR 19 OR 20 OR 21 OR 22 OR 23 OR 24 OR 25 OR 26 OR 27 OR 28 OR 29 OR 30 OR 31 OR 32 OR 33 OR 34 OR 35 OR 36 OR 37
39. diet*.ti,ab
40. exp DIET/
41. "nutrition* therap*".ti,ab
42. exp NUTRITION THERAPY/
43. food.ti,ab
44. exp FOOD/
45. exp BEVERAGES/
46. (micronutrient* OR mineral* OR vitamin*).ti,ab
47. exp MICRONUTRIENTS/ OR exp VITAMINS/
48. exp MINERALS/
49. antioxidant*.ti,ab
50. exp ANTIOXIDANTS/
51. ((diet* OR nutrition* OR nutraceuti* OR nutriceuti*) AND supplement*).ti,ab
52. exp DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS/
53. 39 OR 40 OR 41 OR 42 OR 43 OR 44 OR 45 OR 46 OR 47 OR 48 OR 49 OR 50 OR 51 OR 52
54. 38 OR 53
55. "back pain".ti,ab
56. exp BACK PAIN/
57. backache.ti,ab
58. dorsalgia.ti,ab
59. "lumbar pain".ti,ab
60. lumbago.ti,ab
61. sciatica.ti,ab
62. exp SCIATICA/
63. 55 OR 56 OR 57 OR 58 OR 59 OR 60 OR 61 OR 62
64. 54 AND 63
65. 64 [Limit to: Publication Year 2008-2009]

More details of the search terms and filters used are available by contacting the information specialist. 


Search results

The total number of records retrieved was 1372. After removing the duplicates there were 773 citations. Of these, 89 were selected as potential systematic reviews or other relevant study types. The titles and abstracts were further screened for relevance. Studies with a main focus on non-clinical topics, narrative reviews and protocols of on-going systematic reviews were excluded at this stage.

The final selection includes a new NICE guideline and 25 systematic reviews, meta-analyses, systematic overviews of primary and secondary research, randomised controlled trials (RCTs) and economic evaluations. Based on the identified studies several topics were selected for preparing commentaries on the evidence about the use of specific therapies in the management of low back pain.

A list of all relevant studies is given in the Results page.

 

Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain

 

]]>

document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Osteopathy
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OSTEOPATHY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-B,BACK PAIN,NOVEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Osteopathy

Evidence from randomised controlled trials (RCTs)

By Carol Fawkes, National Council for Osteopathic Research


Chown M, Whittamore L, Rush B et al. A prospective study of patients with chronic back pain randomised to group exercise, physiotherapy or osteopathy. Physiotherapy. 2008, 94:21-28.


This study attempted to investigate the difference in outcome between patients being treated with group exercise, physiotherapy or osteopathy. This was undertaken using a prospective study of patients referred through local NHS routes for random allocation to one of three interventions. Patients were eligible for referral to the trial if they had experienced back pain lasting longer than 3 months. The interventions offered were group exercises led by a physiotherapist, a one-to-one session with a (predominantly manipulative) physiotherapist, and a one-to-one session with an osteopath. The research aimed to examine two specific research questions:

  1. Is group-led physiotherapy exercise as effective as one-to-one physiotherapy for patients with chronic low back pain?
  2. Is one-to-one physiotherapy as effective as one-to-one osteopathy for patients with chronic low back pain?

A sample of 330 patients was identified from statistical calculations. In reality a total of 239 patients participated in the study; initial recruitment had identified 499 potential patients but a variety of difficulties resulted in a smaller number of participants leading to the study being relatively underpowered in comparison to what was originally intended. Clear inclusion and exclusion criteria were identified. Randomisation was undertaken systematically by a third party and block randomisation ensured that participants in all treatment arms were equally matched for age and sex. A range of primary and secondary outcome measures was employed to allow assessment of each patient at baseline. The outcome measures used were the Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) the EuroQol EQ-5D (including a simple health status visual analogue scale), a shuttle walk test (SWT), and questions relating to life satisfaction and satisfaction with the intervention.

Outcome data was collected at baseline, at six week follow-up, and 12 months after discharge by an independent assessor. Data analysis was also undertaken by a statistician who was blind to the identity of the three groups. Other factors were assessed separate to the outcome data including patient attendance, gender and age.

Results at 6 week follow up
The study results can be summarised simply. Attendance levels were poorest for group exercise (40%) compared with physiotherapy (74%) and osteopathy (80%). The reasons for non-completion of the intervention programmes related to problems with waiting times and lack of flexibility of appointment times. A total of 63% of eligible patients provided follow up data at 6 weeks. The mean change in ODI score was greater for group exercise participants than that of physiotherapy participants by 0.32 (95% CI -4.0 to 4.6). The mean change in ODI score for osteopathy participants exceeded that of physiotherapy participants by 0.84 (95% CI -0.35 to 5.2). The analysis of changes in shuttle walk test (SWT) proved problematic due largely to ceiling effects. Similarity between groups was also demonstrated when comparing two elements of the EuroQol health scale where mean EQ-5D scores increased by approximately 1.0 for each group.

Subjective responses were also recorded to four questions using a five-point scale. Three related to symptoms and satisfaction. The percentage of patients reporting that their symptoms were “not at all bothersome” or “slightly bothersome” increased across all treatment groups. This was mirrored by the reduction in levels of interference with normal life caused by back pain. All three treatment groups expressed that they were “somewhat satisfied” or “very satisfied” with their overall medical care.

Results at 12 month follow up
Only 23% of patients responded at final follow up. Analysis suggests that the mean change in ODI from 6 weeks to final follow up is generally sustained but the small sample sizes and variability among individuals within each treatment groups renders the estimate of mean change rather imprecise. Telephone and postal contact was made with non-responding study participants. Analysis of this sub-group does not suggest that participants returning for full follow up contribute to an over-representation of cases with better outcomes.
The drop out rate at this stage of the study was found to be less among the osteopathy group; a number of reasons have been suggested for this including more flexible appointment schedule, patients’ preference for hands-on treatment, personal characteristics, or past experience within private practice. The study experienced problems with recruitment and retention of patients from the outset and this underlines the difficulty faced by many clinicians who are attempting to research practice while having to deliver patient care.
The task of discriminating between single therapies is understandable from the perspective that professional groups want to preserve their own identity and celebrate their uniqueness. This is in stark contrast to the approach of the BEAM trial1 which used professionals from three different professions: osteopathy, chiropractic and physiotherapy to deliver an agreed therapeutic intervention. It is noticeable, also, that the publication of recent guidelines by the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence2 has also focussed on a therapeutic intervention rather than on delivery by a specific profession. The study underlines the importance of interdisciplinary working to provide the best care and greatest choice for patients in a clinical setting.

References

  1. UK BEAM Trial Team. United Kingdom back pain exercise and manipulation (UK BEAM) randomised trial: effectiveness of physical treatments for back pain in primary care. BMJ. 2004, 329(7479):1377. [Full text]
  2. Savigny P, Kuntze S, Watson P, Underwood M, Ritchie G , Cotterell M, Hill D, Browne N, Buchanan E, Coffey P, Dixon P, Drummond C, Flanagan M, Greenough,C, Griffiths M, Halliday-Bell J, Hettinga D, Vogel S, Walsh D. Low Back Pain: Early Management of Persistent Non-specific Low Back Pain. London: National Collaborating Centre for Primary Care and Royal College of General Practitioners, 2009. [Full text]  

Mandara A, Fusaro A, Musicco M et al.  A randomised trial of the effectiveness of osteopathic manipulative treatment of chronic low back pain. International Journal of Osteopathic Medicine. 2008, 11:156.


Information provided in this abstract from a study presented at the International Conference for Advances in Osteopathic Research (ICAOR) is severely limited. This lack of published findings and greater accompanying detail makes it difficult to evaluate this study in any meaningful way.

The study involved 94 patients with chronic low back pain who were recruited from the orthopaedic department of Bassini Hospital in Italy. The study aimed to compare the effects of osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) with sham manipulative treatment (SMT) and assess the effect on patient’s self reported measures of pain and disability. Patients were randomly assigned to either usual care plus OMT (n=44), or usual care plus SMT (n=50). Information concerning the consent process and the manner of randomisation are notably lacking. Nothing is know about what type of sham intervention was used and how close or distinct this was to active OMM. Clear information concerning what is involved in “usual care” and how this may vary to what is experienced as “usual care” external to a clinical trial is also unknown. 

Outcomes for participants involved in the trial have focussed on self-reported pain using a 10cm visual analogue scale (VAS), and disability using the Oswestry Disability Index (ODI). No information is given concerning when outcome data was collected. 
The study results reported a decrease in pain and disability scores for participants receiving OMT compared with SMT. The change in the VAS for participants receiving OMT was -2.8±1.4 for OMT and 0±0.9 for SMT. The change in ODI for OMT was -8.4±8.5 for OMT, and 0.3±7.2 for SMT. No adverse events were reported from either intervention during the study. 

The discussion section suggests that this trial supports the findings of the work of Licciardone et al1 who investigated the management of chronic low back using SMT and OMT. There is no information concerning the number of sessions provided for participants or cost-utility analysis which would have been helpful. The authors conclude that future studies should use less subjective outcome measures and focus on the mechanisms of OMT. The collection of data to facilitate cost-utility analysis would also be beneficial to future studies to provide information to commissioners about the cost-effectiveness of OMT as an intervention for chronic low back pain which represents a significant cost to the public purse in addition to a high personal cost to patients.

References

  1. Licciardone JC, Brimhall AK, King LN. Osteopathic manipulative treatment for low back pain: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. BMC Musculoskeletal Disorders. 2005, 6:43. [Full text]

Thomson O, Haig L, Mansfield L. The effects of high-velocity low amplitude thrust manipulation and mobilisation techniques on pressure pain threshold in the lumbar spine.  International Journal of Osteopathic Medicine. 2009, 12:56-62.


Osteopaths use a wide variety of different techniques in clinical practice depending on the patient and their state of wellbeing, the particular symptoms reported and their aetiology. Spinal manipulation is the technique most commonly cited in research studies and was reviewed for inclusion in the recent NICE guidelines examining the early intervention for chronic non-specific low back pain.

Thomson et al aimed in their study to compare the changes in pain pressure thresholds that occur when using spinal manipulation and spinal mobilisation; the latter being a less researched technique. Spinal mobilisation involves repetitive and oscillatory movements performed against a restrictive barrier. Single and multiple segments can undergo mobilisation techniques; the force and amplitude of the mobilisation can be controlled and it generally takes place at low velocity. In contrast, spinal manipulation delivered using high velocity low amplitude (HVLA) thrust techniques is directed to single joints with a very short amplitude and is associated with a “clicking” sensation or sound known as cavitation.

The physiological effects of both techniques have been investigated.  It has been proposed that spinal manipulation produces a stretching of thickened peri-articular soft tissue resulting in an increase in the range of joint motion and reducing both oedema and pain. A number of theories have been suggested for the hypoalgesic effect observed following spinal manipulation. These include the activation of the endogenous descending pathways in the brain inhibitory systems mediated through the midbrain dorsal periaqueductal grey region producing profound selective analgesia. Other theories have suggested that pain reduction is produced due to the activation of the endogenous antinociceptive system subserved by plasma ß-endorphins. The physiological effects of spinal mobilisation have been less well researched, but some authors have suggested that mobilisation has an immediate excitatory effect on the sympathetic nervous system.

In order to investigate the effect of both techniques more closely, a sample of 50 asymptomatic subjects from a student cohort were recruited for this study. Clear inclusion and exclusion criteria were applied and subjects were additionally screened by questionnaire to identify any patients for whom spinal manipulation would be contraindicated. Ethical approval was gained for the study. 
The measurement of pressure pain threshold (PPT) was selected for investigation of both techniques since this has been shown to be a reliable and relatively inexpensive way to measure soft tissue tenderness. PPT can be defined as the least stimulus intensity at which a subject perceives pain upon the application of pressure or force. It was measured in this situation using a hand held pressure algometer. Two researchers were involved in the study; one tried to identify (and mark) the most tender lumbar spinous process using an osteopathic springing technique. Three PPT measurements were taken by the same researcher with a short interval between each measurement. A second researcher entered the room to perform the selected intervention and then left; the first researcher returned, blind to the intervention performed, and measured the post intervention PPT. A sham group was also employed to control for any placebo effect. This group received 30 seconds of “laser acupuncture” with a laser pointer; the laser was actually turned off during the intervention.

Statistical analysis of recorded readings showed that there were no significant differences across time for each of the groups. The mobilisation group showed a small increase, although not statistically significant change, in PPT. The HVLA group showed a decrease in the mean PPT, and a smaller decrease was noted in the control group. The results of this study are in contrast to earlier studies which have shown a positive effect on pain reduction. The absence of clinically or statistically significant results may be attributable to a number of limitations that have been highlighted by the research team. The choice of technique may have been a factor; the mobilisation technique selected involved rotation of the lumbar spine which is physiologically limited compared with a flexion technique where the range of movement is potentially much greater. Three of the subjects in the HVLA group did not produce cavitation on spinal manipulation although the necessity to achieve cavitation during manipulation is contested by some authors. 

The authors reflect on the need for changes to be made in future studies of this nature. Using the techniques on an asymptomatic population will impact on the results as will the small sample size.  Statistically, the small group size will increase the likelihood of producing non-significant results. The use of measurement equipment would need to be addressed in future studies. Mechanical algometers do not possess the facility to control the rate of pressure application; electronic algometers have this facility and would be more likely to produce accurate and more reliable results. The comparison of single techniques used in isolation is very different to clinical settings. Some minor reactions to the techniques were reported, commonly termed treatment or rebound reactions. These minor, transient effects are well-documented in research literature; this response may have accounted for the slight reduction in PPT following the HVLA  intervention.

Overall this is an ambitious study and there is good awareness on the part of the research team on how this study could be improved. Osteopathic research in a lab-based setting is growing steadily: there is sometimes a lack of appreciation by commentators of the complexity involved in investigating this type of technique and the many difficulties that can arise.  


Hallengraeff HJM, de Greef M, Winters JC et al. Manipulative therapy and clinical prediction criteria in treatment of acute non-specific low back pain.  Perceptual and Motor Skills.  2009, 108:196-208.


Spinal manipulation is increasingly featuring in clinical guidelines for the management of low back pain; both acute and chronic. It is advocated as part of a package of care which evidence suggests is likely to produce the best long term outcome for patients. One of the most significant features in the management of patients with low back pain is to provide pain relief, restore normal levels of mobility, and prevent, where possible, their need for referral into secondary care and development of chronic symptom states.

The researchers in this study have devised a regime using a control group receiving physical therapy and an experimental group receiving manipulative therapy and physical therapy. In addition, consideration is given to the clinical prediction rule1,2 focussing on patients who have experienced symptoms of acute non-specific low back pain for less than 16 days, have no pain distal to the knee joint, and are aged 35 years or over. It was hypothesised that the addition of four sessions of manipulative therapy to standard physical therapy would be more effective than standard physical therapy alone for this patient group. Outcome measures assessing pain, mobility of the lumbar spine, and disability were used. A visual analogue scale (VAS) was used to record pain measures; the Oswestry Disability Index was used to measure disability; and mobility of the lower spine was evaluated using the sit and reach test.

A randomised unblinded clinical trial was used with local ethical approval. A total of 64 participants were recruited using explicit inclusion and exclusion criteria. Patients were included who had had previous episodes, but no information is provided on how recent those episodes were to the start of the study. Physical examination was carried out prior to treatment and local areas of dysfunction at either the lumbosacral or sacroiliac joints were identified for treatment by designated manual therapists. There is no information that other lumbar spine joints could be manipulated at the therapists’ discretion. A total of four treatment sessions were provided within a period of two and a half weeks. No other manual therapy techniques were applied. Patients in the control group received only standard physical therapy which included gradually increasing levels of activity and physical functions using exercise, increasing muscle strength, and improving mobility. Coping strategies were also discussed with patients. 

Data was collected at baseline and at two and a half weeks into the treatment programme. In addition to the outcome measures described earlier, patients were asked at the end of their fourth treatment if they felt they had “improved” or “not improved”. No long term follow up data was collected. Data was analysed by a researcher who was blind to the treatment allocation, but measures used to assess effectiveness were administered by the same therapists performing the treatments.

The addition of manipulative therapy showed a statistically significant benefit over physical therapy alone on the disability rating. No significant difference was found in the decrease in pain levels between the experimental group and the control group. In addition, no significant difference was found between each group in terms of mobility. The responses to the subjective assessment of being “improved” or “not improved” was found to be the same for both groups. 

The study supports the addition of manipulative therapy to normal care for its beneficial effect in terms of mobility; but challenges its use when considering pain and mobility. There are, however, a number of methodological issues within the study which the research team mention very briefly. The chief concern is the sample size which would have produced low statistical power and increases the significance of producing non-significant results. The lack of blinding can potentially produce bias and the use of the same therapist to deliver treatment and administer measure to assess effectiveness is surprising. The possibility of self-report bias from subjects using the selected self-reported outcome measures is acknowledged by the study team. Additionally, the study does not support the conclusions of Fritz et al2 that a clinical prediction rule based on just two criteria is a strong indicator for a rapid response to manipulation for patients in a mainstream healthcare setting. The lack of long term follow up of patients is an unhelpful aspect to this study: it is this consideration and the necessity for patients to be referred to secondary care or enter long term disability states that is a key concern in the management of low back pain.


References

  1. Childs JD, Fritz JM, Flynn TW et al.  A clinical prediction rule to identify patients with low back pain more likely to benefit from spinal manipulation: a validation study. Annals of Internal Medicine. 2004, 141(12):920-928. [PubMed abstract]
  2. Fritz JM, Childs JD, Flynn TW. Pragmatic application of a clinical prediction rule in primary care to identify patients with low back pain with a good prognosis following a brief spinal manipulation intervention. BMC Family Practice. 2005, 6:29. [Full text]

Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain

 

]]>

111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Other therapies

The following relevant studies have been published since July 2008.

These studies have met our selection criteria. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.


Feldenkrais

Systematic review

Rondoni A, Bertozzi L. Effectiveness of the Feldenkrais method in the improvement of health status in adult patients with low back pain or at risk of developing it. Scienza Riabilitativa. 2009, 11(3):5-15. [Italian]


Pilates

Systematic review

La Touche R, Escalante K, Linares MT. Treating non-specific chronic low back pain through the Pilates Method. Journal of Bodywork and Movement Therapies. 2008, 12(4):364-70. [PubMed abstract] 

Randomised controlled trial

da Fonseca JL, Magini M, de Freitas TH. Laboratory gait analysis in patients with low back pain before and after a pilates intervention. Journal of Sport Rehabilitation. 2009, 18(2):269-82. [PubMed abstract]


Alexander technique

Economic evaluation

Hollinghurst S, Sharp D, Ballard K, Barnett J, Beattie A, Evans M, Lewith G, Middleton K, Oxford F, Webley F, Little P. Randomised controlled trial of Alexander technique lessons, exercise, and massage (ATEAM) for chronic and recurrent back pain: economic evaluation. BMJ. 2008, 337:a2656. [PubMed abstract] [NHS EED abstract]


Naturopathy

Economic evaluation

Herman PM, Szczurko O, Cooley K, Mills EJ. Cost-effectiveness of naturopathic care for chronic low back pain. Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine. 2008, 14(2):32-9. [PubMed abstract] [NHS EED provisional abstract]


Yoga

Randomised controlled trials

Tekur P, Singphow C, Nagendra HR, Raghuram N. Effect of short-term intensive yoga program on pain, functional disability and spinal flexibility in chronic low back pain: a randomized control study. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2008, 14(6):637-44. [PubMed abstract]

Williams K, Abildso C, Steinberg L, Doyle E, Epstein B, Smith D, et al. Evaluation of the effectiveness and efficacy of Iyengar yoga therapy on chronic low back pain. Spine. 2009, 34(19):2066-76. [PubMed abstract]

111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Results

The following relevant studies on this topic have been published between July 2008 and September 2009.


These studies have met our selection criteria. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.


NICE Guideline

Savigny P, Kuntze S, Watson P, Underwood M, Ritchie G , Cotterell M, Hill D, Browne N, Buchanan E, Coffey P, Dixon P, Drummond C, Flanagan M, Greenough,C, Griffiths M, Halliday-Bell J, Hettinga D, Vogel S, Walsh D. Low Back Pain: Early Management of Persistent Non-specific Low Back Pain. London: National Collaborating Centre for Primary Care and Royal College of General Practitioners, 2009. [Full text]

Systematic reviews and meta-analyses 

  1. Chrubasik C, Black A, Muller-Ladner U, Chrubasik S. Impact of herbal medicines on physical impairment. Phytomedicine. 2008, 15(6-7):536-9. [PubMed abstract]
  2. Dagenais S, Roffey DM, Wai EK, Haldeman S, Caro J. Can cost utility evaluations inform decision making about interventions for low back pain? A systematic review. Spine J 2009 Sep 11. [PubMed abstract]

    (Duplicate publication of Cochrane review)
  5. La Touche R, Escalante K, Linares MT. Treating non-specific chronic low back pain through the Pilates Method. Journal of Bodywork and Movement Therapies. 2008, 12(4):364-70. [PubMed abstract] 
  6. Machado LA, Kamper SJ, Herbert RD, Maher CG, McAuley JH. Analgesic effects of treatments for non-specific low back pain: a meta-analysis of placebo-controlled randomized trials. Rheumatology (Oxford). 2009,48(5):520-7. [PubMed abstract] 
  7. Machado LAC, Kamper SJ, Herbert RD, Maher CG, McAuley JH. Imperfect placebos are common in low back pain trials: A systematic review of the literature. European Spine Journal. 2008, 17(7):889-904. [Full text] 
  8. May S, Rosedale R. Prescriptive Clinical Prediction Rules in Back Pain Research: A Systematic Review. Journal of Manual and Manipulative Therapy. 2009, 17(1):36-45.
  9. Rondoni A, Bertozzi L. Effectiveness of the Feldenkrais method in the improvement of health status in adult patients with low back pain or at risk of developing it. Scienza Riabilitativa. 2009, 11(3):5-15. [Italian]
  10. Vlachojannis JE, Cameron M, Chrubasik S. A systematic review on the effectiveness of willow bark for musculoskeletal pain. Phytotherapy Research. 2009, 23(7):897-900. [PubMed abstract] 
  11. Yuan J, Kerr D, Park J, Liu XH, McDonough S. Treatment regimens of acupuncture for low back pain--a systematic review. Complementary Therapies in Medicine. 2008, 16(5):295-304. [PubMed abstract]
  12. Yuan J, Purepong N, Kerr DP, Park J, Bradbury I, McDonough S. Effectiveness of acupuncture for low back pain: a systematic review. Spine. 2008, 33(23):E887-900. [PubMed abstract]   

Systematic overviews of primary and secondary research

Lawrence DJ, Meeker W, Branson R, Bronfort G, Cates JR, Haas M, et al. Chiropractic management of low back pain and low back-related leg complaints: a literature synthesis. Journal of Manipulative Physiological Therapeutics. 2008, 31(9):659-74. [PubMed abstract] 

Selected randomised controlled trials (RCTs) and economic evaluations

  1. Cherkin DC, Sherman KJ, Avins AL, Erro JH, Ichikawa L, Barlow WE et al. A randomized trial comparing acupuncture, simulated acupuncture, and usual care for chronic low back pain. Archives of Internal Medicine. 2009, 169(9):858-66. [PubMed abstract]
  2. Chown M, Whittamore L, Rush B et al. A prospective study of patients with chronic back pain randomised to group exercise, physiotherapy or osteopathy. Physiotherapy. 2008, 94:21-28. [Abstract]
  3. da Fonseca JL, Magini M, de Freitas TH. Laboratory gait analysis in patients with low back pain before and after a pilates intervention. Journal of Sport Rehabilitation. 2009, 18(2):269-82. [PubMed abstract]
  4. Hallegraeff JM, de Greef M, Winters JC, Lucas C. Manipulative therapy and clinical prediction criteria in treatment of acute nonspecific low back pain. Perceptual and Motor Skills. 2009, 108(1):196-208. [PubMed abstract]
  5. Herman PM, Szczurko O, Cooley K, Mills EJ. Cost-effectiveness of naturopathic care for chronic low back pain. Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine. 2008, 14(2):32-9. [PubMed abstract] [NHS EED provisional abstract]
  6. Hollinghurst S, Sharp D, Ballard K, Barnett J, Beattie A, Evans M, Lewith G, Middleton K, Oxford F, Webley F, Little P. Randomised controlled trial of Alexander technique lessons, exercise, and massage (ATEAM) for chronic and recurrent back pain: economic evaluation. BMJ. 2008, 337:a2656. [PubMed abstract] [NHS EED abstract]
  7. Hondras MA, Long CR, Cao Y, Rowell RM, Meeker, WC. A randomized controlled trial comparing 2 types of spinal manipulation and minimal conservative medical care for adults 55 years and older with subacute or chronic low back pain. Journal of Manipulative & Physiological Therapeutics. 2009, 32(5):330-43. [PubMed abstract]
  8. Kawchuk GN, Haugen R, Fritz J. A true blind for subjects who receive spinal manipulation therapy. Archives of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation. 2009, 90(2):366-8. [PubMed abstract]
  9. Mandara A, Fusaro A, Musicco M et al. A randomised trial of the effectiveness of osteopathic manipulative treatment of chronic low back pain. International Journal of Osteopathic Medicine. 2008, 11:156. [Conference abstract]
  10. Thomson O, Haig L, Mansfield L. The effects of high-velocity low amplitude thrust manipulation and mobilisation techniques on pressure pain threshold in the lumbar spine. International Journal of Osteopathic Medicine. 2009, 12:56-62. [Abstract]
  11. Tekur P, Singphow C, Nagendra HR, Raghuram N. Effect of short-term intensive yoga program on pain, functional disability and spinal flexibility in chronic low back pain: a randomized control study. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2008, 14(6):637-44. [PubMed abstract]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Spinal manipulation
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,CHIROPRACTIC,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,BACK PAIN,CONDITIONS A-B,NOVEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Spinal manipulation

Prof Alan Breen, Anglo-European College of Chiropractic


Introduction

Most guidelines and reviews up to June 2008 have supported spinal manipulation for use in an evidence-based package of care for patients who are not recovering from episodes of low back pain, provided the therapy is delivered by professionals with competent skills. This update considers additional relevant high quality RCTs and systematic reviews that have been published since the previous update. 

Summary of findings

Two high quality systematic reviews were found; one which was conducted to inform a new UK clinical practice guideline aimed at functional improvement for people with chronic back pain1,2 and one meta-analysis that considered manipulation among a number of interventions on the basis of their analgesic effects alone3. Both reviews supported spinal manipulation for chronic non-specific low back pain (NSLBP). The first review also found benefit in adding manipulation to exercise, as did a further narrative review4 and a subsequent RCT5. The latter trial also addressed back pain in the over 55’s, and provided a comparison of manipulation and mobilisation. These were found to be equivalent.


There is still a lack of evidence about the effectiveness or manipulation for nerve root pain, as well as defined subgroups to help identify which patients may respond better to different treatment approaches. This may account for the modest effects found in RCTs of interventions for back pain generally. Consideration is shifting from manipulation as a single technique in isolation to part of a package of care for back pain.


The evidence

One new evidence based guideline has been published that addresses manipulation for non-specific low back pain (NSLBP) 2. This focuses on episodes of 6 weeks to 12 months duration and on the potential of interventions to prevent long-term withdrawal from normal activities, including work. Its evidence review considered a total of seven RCTs of manipulation relevant to this symptom duration6-14 and to the effectiveness of manual therapy, including manipulation compared with usual care to reduce pain, functional disability or psychological distress. Two of the 7 trials were considered to be both high quality and with low risk of bias. The review concluded that there is some evidence of reduction in pain and disability when manipulation is used in addition to usual care, but no evidence of benefit in psychological outcomes. These effects were modest but at least equivalent to usual care. Manipulation combined with exercise was considered the most cost-effective option.


One systematic review and meta-analysis of 34 treatments that included manipulation3 focused on analgesic efficacy alone and considered only randomised trials that were placebo-controlled. This review reported small to moderate positive effects for spinal manipulation both for acute (4 trials) and chronic NSLBP (1 trial). The review may however have been limited by having included trials regardless of their quality ratings and at the first assessment point, which may have reported short-term outcomes only. Kawchuk et al15 investigated a potential method for blinding manipulation trial subjects by anaesthetising them in order to obtain true placebo-control.


A narrative review of the chiropractic management of low back and leg complaints4 concluded that adding exercise to manipulation probably speeds up and improves outcomes and minimises the likelihood of recurrence. However, less evidence was found for manipulation for back pain with leg pain or radiculopathy.


A further high quality RCT of manipulation for subacute and chronic NSLNP compared high and low velocity manipulation with usual medical care in people over 55 with low levels of back pain disability5. Overall, this found the effects of manipulation to be significantly greater. (All arms of this trial also had home exercise instruction.) This trial also compared the possible differential effects of high-velocity and mobilisation-types of manipulation on outcome.  No difference was detected despite adequate statistical power for this. 


A current lack of clinically meaningful sub-groupings of patients with NSLBP has prompted attempts to develop clinical prediction rules to indicate which patients will benefit most from manipulation. However, a recent systematic review of research to date16 found limited evidence for the clinical utility of these.


References

  1. Savigny P, Kuntze S, Watson P, Underwood M, Ritchie G , Cotterell M, Hill D, Browne N, Buchanan E, Coffey P, Dixon P, Drummond C, Flanagan M, Greenough,C, Griffiths M, Halliday-Bell J, Hettinga D, Vogel S, Walsh D. Low Back Pain: Early Management of Persistent Non-specific Low Back Pain. London: National Collaborating Centre for Primary Care and Royal College of General Practitioners, 2009. [Full text]
  2. Savigny P, Watson, P., Underwood, M. Early management of persistent non-specific low back pain: Summary of NICE guidance. BMJ. 2009, 338(b1805):1441-5. [Abstract]
  3. Machado LA, Kamper SJ, Herbert RD, Maher CG, McAuley JH. Analgesic effects of treatments for non-specific low back pain: a meta-analysis of placebo-controlled randomized trials. Rheumatology (Oxford). 2009,48(5):520-7. [PubMed abstract] 
  4. Lawrence DJ, Meeker W, Branson R, Bronfort G, Cates JR, Haas M, et al. Chiropractic management of low back pain and low back-related leg complaints: a literature synthesis. Journal of Manipulative Physiological Therapeutics. 2008, 31(9):659-74. [PubMed abstract] 
  5. Hondras MA, Long CR, Cao Y, Rowell RM, Meeker, WC. A randomized controlled trial comparing 2 types of spinal manipulation and minimal conservative medical care for adults 55 years and older with subacute or chronic low back pain. Journal of Manipulative & Physiological Therapeutics. 2009, 32(5):330-43. [PubMed abstract]
  6. Andersson HI, Ejlertsson G, Leden I, Rosenberg C. Chronic pain in a geographically defined general population: studies of differences in age, gender, social class, and pain localization. The Clinical Journal of Pain. 1993, 9:174-82. [PubMed abstract] 
  7. Cherkin DC, Deyo RA, Battie M, Street J, Barlow W. A comparison of physical therapy, chiropractic manipulation and provision of an educational booklet for the treatment of patients with low back pain. The New England Journal of Medicine. 1998, 339(15):1021-29. [PubMed abstract] 
  8. Doran DML, Newell DJ. Manipulation in treatment of low back pain: a multicentre study. British Medical Journal. 1975;2 (5964):161-4. [Full text]
  9. UK BEAM Trial Team. United Kingdom back pain exercise and manipulation (UK BEAM) randomised trial: effectiveness of physical treatments for back pain in primary care. BMJ. 2004, 329(7479):1377. [Full text]
  10. UK BEAM Trial Team. United Kingdom back pain exercise and manipulation (UK BEAM) randomised trial: cost effectiveness of physical treatments for back pain in primary care. BMJ. 2004, 329(7479):1381-1385. [Full text] [NHS EED structured abstract]. 
  11. Goldby LJ, Moore AP, Doust J, Trew M. A randomised controlled trial investigating the efficiency of musculoskeletal physiotherapy on chronic low back disorder. Spine. 2006, 31(10):1083-93. [PubMed abstract]
  12. Hurwitz EL, Morgenstern H, Harber P, Kominski GF, Belin TR, Yu F, Adams AH. A randomized trial of medical care with and without physical therapy and chiropractic care with and without physical modalities for patients with low back pain: 6-month follow-up outcomes from the UCLA low back pain study. Spine. 2002, 27(20):2193-204. [PubMed abstract] 
  13. Hurwitz EL, Morgenstern H, Kominski GF, Yu F, Chiang L-M. A randomized trial of chiropractic and medical care for patients with low back pain: eighteen-month follow-up outcomes from the UCLA low back pain study. Spine. 2006, 31(6):611-21. [PubMed abstract] 
  14. Triano JJ, McGregor M, Hondras MA, Brennan PC. Manipulative therapy versus education programs in chronic low back pain. Spine. 1995, 20(8):948-55. [PubMed abstract]
  15. Kawchuk GN, Haugen R, Fritz J. A true blind for subjects who receive spinal manipulation therapy. Archives of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation. 2009, 90(2):366-8. [PubMed abstract]
  16. May S, Rosedale R. Prescriptive clinical prediction rules in back pain research: A systematic review. Journal of Manual and Manipulative Therapy. 2009, 17(1):36-45.
