document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression

Published: 5 October 2009

 

 

 

Introduction

This annual evidence update on complementary and alternative medicine for depression aims to identify, organise and present the latest information on this topic. We have searched a large number of databases for studies published or updated since the 2008 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression.

For more details about the search methods and the selection process please see the Methodology section.

This update is linked to the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on depression produced by NHS Evidence - mental health. For further information on depression including information on other treatments, see the relevant pages from the NHS Evidence - mental health specialist collection.


Highlights this year include the Cochrane reviews on exercise, relaxation and St John’s wort. The relaxation and St John’s wort reviews were published during our update week in 2008 and are now considered in more detail in the St John’s wort and Other Therapies sections respectively. The review of exercise, which includes trials of qigong and tai chi, is discussed in the editorial. 


Editorial: Exercise and mindfulness: a focus for depression?   


Contents

  • Use of CAM
  • Guidelines and general systematic reviews
  • Evidence on specific therapies and approaches
    • Acupuncture 
    • Diet and nutrition
    • Herbal medicine (excluding St John's wort)
    • Massage, aromatherapy and reflexology
    • Meditation and mindfulness
    • St John's wort (Hypericum perforatum)
    • Yoga
    • Other therapies
  • Results of the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression
  • Methodology
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Acupuncture
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS D-E,SEPTEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Acupuncture

The majority of research published since the 2008 update originates from China. Researchers from China have investigated the feasibility of producing evidence-based clinical practice guidelines on acupuncture using acupuncture in depression guidelines as an example (Guo et al. 2008a). Several systematic reviews have also been published. One of these concludes that acupuncture is ‘definitely effective’ but as it is published in Chinese it is difficult to comment on the basis for this conclusion (Guo et al. 2008b).


Another systematic review compares acupuncture with Western medicine (various antidepressants). (Sun et al. 2008) Eight studies were included in the review all of which were found using Chinese databases. The reviewers concluded that ‘Acupuncture is not inferior to western medicine, and … acupuncture is associated with few adverse reactions.’


A third systematic review (Zhang et al. 2009) focused on major depressive disorder and post-stroke depression. Twenty trials in major depressive disorder judged to be high quality were found, 14 of which had been published since 2004. For major depressive disorder, acupuncture appeared to be equivalent to antidepressants. However, acupuncture and sham acupuncture also appeared to be equivalent and there did not seem to be any difference between acupuncture plus antidepressants and antidepressants as sole therapy. There are a number of factors to consider in interpreting these results: trials of acupuncture and drug therapy cannot be blinded so that patients were aware of which treatment they were receiving, the numbers of patients may have been too small to detect differences between treatments and the acupuncture interventions varied considerably. Acupuncture did appear to offer advantages in terms of a lower incidence of adverse effects.


As highlighted in the 2008 update, many of the included studies were conducted in China and acupuncture practice in China differs from that in the UK. Consequently, the relevance of these findings is unclear and findings of studies which reflect practice in the UK, which are currently underway (Schroer and MacPherson 2009, Schroer et al. 2009) are needed.


Development of guidelines

Guo X, Liu B-Y, Zhao H. Methodology of evidence-based clinical practice guidelines for acupuncture. Chinese Journal of Evidence-Based Medicine. 2008, 8(3):203-5.

Evidence summaries and reviews

Guo X, Zhao H, Wang Y, Su W. [Advances of clinical studies on acupuncture treatment of depression] Zhen Ci Yan Jiu. 2008, 33(6):416-9. [Article in Chinese] [PubMed abstract]

Sun Y-L, Chen S-B, Gao Y, Xiong J. Acupuncture versus western medicine for depression in China: A systematic review. Chinese Journal of Evidence-Based Medicine. 2008, 8(5):340-5. [DARE provisional record]

Zhang ZJ, Chen HY, Yip KC, Ng R, Wong VT. The effectiveness and safety of acupuncture therapy in depressive disorders: Systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Affective Disorders. 2009 Jul 24. [PubMed abstract] 

Randomised controlled trial

Duan DM, Tu Y, Chen LP, Wu ZJ. [Study on electroacupuncture treatment of depression by magnetic resonance imaging] Zhongguo Zhen Jiu. 2009 Feb;29(2):139-44.[Article in Chinese] [PubMed abstract]

Ongoing trials

Schroer S, Macpherson H. Acupuncture, or non-directive counselling versus usual care for the treatment of depression: a pilot study. Trials. 2009,10:3. [Full text]

Schroer S, MacPherson H, Adamson J. Designing an RCT of acupuncture for depression--identifying appropriate patient groups: a qualitative study. Family Practice. 2009, 26(3):188-95. [PubMed abstract]


Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression

 

]]>

document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Diet and nutrition

Diet and nutrition - general

Systematic review

A recent review of nutrition and depression has some features of a systematic review in that methods were described, comprehensive searches were conducted and studies were quality assessed (Harbottle and Schonfelder 2008). Trials of tryptophan and folic acid included in previous systematic reviews are discussed, together with 4 trials of omega 3 fatty acids and 1 trial of zinc. Searches were conducted up to July 2005 and further trials have been published subsequently.


Harbottle L, Schonfelder N. Nutrition and depression: A review of the evidence. Journal of Mental Health. 2008, 17(6):576-87. [Full text]


Omega 3 fatty acids

Randomised controlled trials

Doornbos B, van Goor SA, jck-Brouwer DA, Schaafsma A, Korf J, Muskiet FA. Supplementation of a low dose of DHA or DHA+AA does not prevent peripartum depressive symptoms in a small population based sample. Prog Neuropsychopharmacol Biol Psychiatry 2009 Feb 1;33(1):49-52. [PubMed abstract]

Freeman MP, Davis M, Sinha P, Wisner KL, Hibbeln JR, Gelenberg AJ. Omega-3 fatty acids and supportive psychotherapy for perinatal depression: a randomized placebo-controlled study. J Affect Disord 2008 Sep;110(1-2):142-8. [PubMed abstract]

Jazayeri S, Tehrani-Doost M, Keshavarz SA, Hosseini M, Djazayery A, Amini H, et al. Comparison of therapeutic effects of omega-3 fatty acid eicosapentaenoic acid and fluoxetine, separately and in combination, in major depressive disorder. Aust N Z J Psychiatry 2008 Mar;42(3):192-8. [PubMed abstract]

Lucas M, Asselin G, Merette C, Poulin MJ, Dodin S. Ethyl-eicosapentaenoic acid for the treatment of psychological distress and depressive symptoms in middle-aged women: a double-blind, placebo-controlled, randomized clinical trial. Am J Clin Nutr 2009 Feb;89(2):641-51. [PubMed abstract]

Mischoulon D, Best-Popescu C, Laposata M, Merens W, Murakami JL, Wu SL, et al. A double-blind dose-finding pilot study of docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) for major depressive disorder. Eur Neuropsychopharmacol 2008 Sep;18(9):639-45. [PubMed abstract]

Osher Y, Belmaker RH. Omega-3 fatty acids in depression: a review of three studies. CNS Neurosci Ther 2009;15(2):128-33. [PubMed abstract]

Su KP, Huang SY, Chiu TH, Huang KC, Huang CL, Chang HC, et al. Omega-3 fatty acids for major depressive disorder during pregnancy: results from a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. J Clin Psychiatry 2008 Apr;69(4):644-51. [PubMed abstract]


Vitamin B (including folic acid)

Randomised controlled trials

Ford AH, Flicker L, Thomas J, Norman P, Jamrozik K, Almeida OP. Vitamins B12, B6, and folic acid for onset of depressive symptoms in older men: results from a 2-year placebo-controlled randomized trial. J Clin Psychiatry 2008 Aug;69(8):1203-9. [PubMed abstract]

Gosney MA, Hammond MF, Shenkin A, Allsup S. Effect of micronutrient supplementation on mood in nursing home residents. Gerontology 2008;54(5):292-9. [PubMed abstract]


Vitamin D

Systematic (integrative) review

The review by Murphy and Wagner (2008) is an integrative review in that it uses systematic review methods but includes studies using both experimental and non-experimental methodologies.

Murphy PK, Wagner CL. Vitamin D and mood disorders among women: an integrative review. Journal of Midwifery & Women's Health. 2008, 53(5):440-6. [PubMed abstract]

Randomised controlled trial

Jorde R, Sneve M, Figenschau Y, Svartberg J, Waterloo K. Effects of vitamin D supplementation on symptoms of depression in overweight and obese subjects: randomized double blind trial. J Intern Med 2008 Dec;264(6):599-609. [PubMed abstract]


Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Editorial
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,OCTOBER 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Editorial

Exercise and mindfulness: a focus for depression?


Exercise and mindfulness have both received attention this year. Several systematic reviews of exercise have been conducted. These include a Cochrane review which concludes that ‘exercise seems to improve the symptoms of depression’. (Mead et al. 2009) This review included studies of conventional types of aerobic exercise such as walking, running, use of treadmills and exercise bikes and strength and resistance training. Trials of tai chi and qigong were also included. Tai chi and qigong are considered to be forms of ‘mindful exercise’. (Tsang et al. 2008) Yoga, another ‘mindful’ form of exercise, has also shown some potential in the management of depression and trials of yoga continue to be published. (2009 update - yoga section) All three incorporate a meditative or contemplative component and have traditionally been placed under complementary and alternative medicine in both the UK and the USA (HL report 2003, NCCAM website). 


Population studies have shown physical activity and depression to be closely related, providing a rationale for exercise therapy (Roshanaei-Moghaddam et al. 2009). The authors of the Cochrane review list a number of reasons why exercise might improve mood. It may act as a diversion from negative thoughts while learning a new skill and social contact may be positive factors and exercise may induce beneficial physiological effects. But does a mindfulness component offer any additional benefit in conditions such as depression? Trials of other interventions incorporating mindfulness, such as mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT), have reported positive results (2009 update - mindfulness section). Consequently, MBCT is recommended in the NICE guidance on depression for people who have had several previous episodes of depression (NICE guidelines). But it is difficult to disentangle the specific components of complex interventions such as yoga. This question remains unanswered for now, along with the question of whether aerobic or anaerobic exercise is likely to be more effective for depression.


The NICE guidelines recommend structured and supervised exercise programmes for patients of all ages with mild depression. Until there is evidence on which forms of exercise are most effective perhaps, as suggested in the Cochrane review, ‘a pragmatic approach would be to recommend that patients choose a form of exercise which they will enjoy’. Moreover to address potential problems with motivation, perhaps consideration of which type of exercise best fits individual lifestyles and preferences is also of value.


Systematic reviews of exercise for depression

Bauer K, Felder H. Sport therapy for depressive disorders: systematic review [German]. Zeitschrift Fuer Physiotherapeuten. 2008; 60(1):16-27.

Mead GE, Morley W, Campbell P, Greig CA, McMurdo M, Lawlor DA. Exercise for depression. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2009, Issue 3. Art. No.: CD004366. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004366.pub4. [Full text]

Rethorst CD, Wipfli BM, Landers DM. The antidepressive effects of exercise: a meta-analysis of randomized trials.  Sports Medicine. 2009, 39(6):491-511. doi: 10.2165/00007256-200939060-00004.  [PubMed abstract]

Roshanaei-Moghaddam B, Katon WJ, Russo J. The longitudinal effects of depression on physical activity. General Hospital Psychiatry. 2009, 31(4):306-15. [PubMed abstract]


Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Guidelines and general systematic reviews
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,SEPTEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Guidelines and general systematic reviews

Guidelines

As mentioned in the 2008 update, St John’s wort (Hypericum perforatum) is the only complementary therapy mentioned in current NICE guidelines. Guidelines on the non-pharmacological management of depression, which will address a number of CAM approaches, are currently being developed by the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN). These are due to be published in Spring 2010. A revised version of the British Association for Psychopharmacology guidelines was published in 2008 (Anderson et al. 2008). St John’s wort and omega-3 fatty acids are both included in the recommendations on complementary and other treatments. St John’s wort extracts are not recommended as first line treatment but ‘could be considered for mild and moderate major depression where first line treatments are not possible or not tolerated provided a recognised standardised preparation is used’. The guidelines also state that ‘Omega-3 fatty acids are not recommended as a monotherapy for major depression.’


Anderson IM, Ferrier IN, Baldwin RC, Cowen PJ, Howard L, Lewis G, Matthews K, McAllister-Williams RH, Peveler RC, Scott J, Tylee A. Evidence-based guidelines for treating depressive disorders with antidepressants: a revision of the 2000 British Association for Psychopharmacology guidelines. Journal of Psychopharmacology. 2008, 22(4):343-96. [PubMed abstract] [Full text]


General overviews and systematic reviews

As described in the 2008 update, people suffering with depression often do not consult a health professional choosing instead to self-treat their condition. A huge variety of potential self-care interventions is available as revealed in a large Delphi consensus study (Morgan and Jorm 2009). The initial literature search identified 2214 possible self-help interventions which were finally organised into 282 strategies. These strategies fell under the headings physical and sensory methods, psychological methods, interpersonal strategies, lifestyle and other, substances, dietary changes, medicines/dietary supplements, vitamins and minerals, plant or herbal remedies, homoeopathic remedies, and combined preparations. International panels of depression consumers and professionals were then involved in assessing the usefulness of these strategies.


Several differences between consumers and health professionals were found. Consumers endorsed more strategies than health professionals while health professionals generally rated self-help as easier in practice than consumers. Approaches including aromatherapy, massage, listening to music and taking vitamin supplements were rated much more highly by consumers. CAM-based strategies endorsed by at least 80% of both groups included relaxation methods such as progressive muscle relaxation, autogenic training, breathing exercises and self-hypnosis, and practicing mindfulness or meditation.


At present, there is no research evidence on the majority of self-help interventions and many of the trials that have been conducted are poor quality (Morgan and Jorm 2008). The authors concluded that those with the best evidence of efficacy in depressive disorders include S-adenosylmethionine, St John's wort, bibliotherapy, computerised interventions, relaxation training, exercise, sleep deprivation, and light therapy. Other interventions show promise but have yet to be researched. In non-clinical samples, there is research suggesting benefits of exercise and music. Possible beneficial longer-term effects were found for interventions including autogenic training, light therapy and omega 3 fatty acids.


Morgan AJ, Jorm AF. Self-help interventions for depressive disorders and depressive symptoms: a systematic review. Annals of General Psychiatry. 2008, 7:13. [Full text] 

Morgan AJ, Jorm AF. Self-help strategies that are helpful for sub-threshold depression: A Delphi consensus study. Journal of Affective Disorders. 2009, 115(1-2):196-200. [PubMed abstract]


Overviews focused on special populations

A Cochrane review of interventions (other than pharmacological, psychosocial or psychological) for treating antenatal depression was published in 2008 (Dennis and Allen 2008). Only one trial of 62 women was included. This trial compared depression-specific acupuncture, non-specific acupuncture and maternal massage. The review concluded that ‘the included trial was too small with a non-generalisable sample, to make any recommendations’.


Dennis CL, Allen K. Interventions (other than pharmacological, psychosocial or psychological) for treating antenatal depression. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2008, Issue 4. Art. No.: CD006795. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD006795.pub2. [Full text]


Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Herbal medicine (excluding St John's wort)
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS D-E,SEPTEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Herbal medicine (excluding St John's wort)

Chinese herbs

This year has seen the publication of a systematic review and meta-analysis of the evidence on traditional Chinese medicine for depression (Zhao et al. 2009). The review focused on treatment in China and searches for studies were carried out on the China National Knowledge Infrastructure medical database. Eighteen trials were included in which participants suffered from depression as the primary diagnosis, post-stroke depression, menopausal-related depression and depression associated with cancer. Chinese herbs were used alone or in combination with acupuncture or antidepressants and were compared against active treatments and against ‘blank’ control treatments. The reviewers suggested that the low quality of the studies may have contributed to the lack of measured effect but it is unclear how the meta-analysis was conducted or the reported figures derived.

See also 2008 summary on Chinese herbal medicine


Zhao H, Wan X, Chen JX. A mini review of traditional chinese medicine for the treatment of depression in china. American Journal of Chinese Medicine. 2009, 37(2):207-13. [PubMed abstract]
 

Crocus sativus

A further study on Crocus sativus has been published by the research group from Iran who have previously investigated its antidepressant potential (Akhondzadeh et al. 2008). In this trial, the effects of Crocus sativus petal and the stigma (saffron) were compared. The aim was to assess whether a less expensive preparation of Crocus sativus had similar effects to the more costly saffron extract. This was a double-blind randomised trial, but as in previous studies, the sample was small (44 patients) and the treatment duration relatively short (6 weeks). No differences were found in either efficacy or safety between the two products.

See also 2008 summary on Crocus sativus.


Akhondzadeh BA, Choreishi SA, Noorbala AA, Akhondzadeh SH, Rezazadeh S. Petal and stigma of Crocus sativus L. in the treatment of depression: A pilot double - blind randomized trial. Journal of Medicinal Plants. 2008, 7(SUPPL. 4):29-36.


Herbs not included in 2008 update

Bacopa monnieri (Brahmi)

Bacopa monnieri is a herb used in Ayurvedic medicine that has been used for a range of conditions. Its effects on depression in the elderly were investigated in a trial conducted in the USA. (Calabrese et al. 2008) A range of outcomes were assessed in the trial, the primary measure being cognitive performance. CES Depression scores were found to reduce in the group on Bacopa but not in the placebo group. However, further confirmation of these preliminary results are needed.


Calabrese C, Gregory WL, Leo M, Kraemer D, Bone K, Oken B. Effects of a standardized Bacopa monnieri extract on cognitive performance, anxiety, and depression in the elderly: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2008, 14(6):707-13. [PubMed abstract]


Lepidium meyenii (Maca)

One trial tested different doses of the root of a Peruvian plant, maca, in the management of selective-serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI)-induced sexual dysfunction. (Dording et al. 2008) Maca appeared to be well-tolerated and to have some beneficial effects, which were dose-related. Again, further confirmation of this small study is required.


Dording CM, Fisher L, Papakostas G, Farabaugh A, Sonawalla S, Fava M, et al. A double-blind, randomized, pilot dose-finding study of maca root (L. meyenii) for the management of SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction. CNS Neuroscince & Therapeutics. 2008, 14(3):182-91. [PubMed abstract]


Piper methysticum (Kava)

A 2009 systematic review of kava for anxiety and depressive disorders confirmed that there was no evidence on its effect in depression (Sarris and Kavanagh 2009). Kava (Piper methysticum) has traditionally been used in treatment of anxiety. It was withdrawn from use in herbal and dietary products in the UK in 2003 due to concern over reports of liver toxicity. It was also withdrawn in Europe and Canada. A review of the evidence was carried out in 2005 in the UK but the result was a continuation of the ban. (MHRA website) This year a group of researchers from Australia reported a randomised controlled trial using a combination of St. John's wort and kava for the treatment of major depressive disorder with comorbid anxiety (Sarris et al. 2009a). The same group also report a trial assessing the anxiolytic and antidepressant efficacy of an aqueous extract of kava (Sarris et al. 2009b and 2009c). Both trials reported preliminary positive findings but the safety issues surrounding kava are yet to be resolved.


Systematic review

Sarris J, Kavanagh DJ. Kava and St. John's Wort: current evidence for use in mood and anxiety disorders. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2009, 15(8):827-36. [PubMed abstract]

Randomised controlled trials

Sarris J, Kavanagh DJ, Adams J, Bone K, Byrne G. (2009a) Kava Anxiety Depression Spectrum Study (KADSS): a mixed methods RCT using an aqueous extract of Piper methysticum. Complementary Therapies in Medicine. 2009, 17(3):176-8. [PubMed abstract]

Sarris J, Kavanagh DJ, Deed G, Bone KM. (2009b) St. John's wort and Kava in treating major depressive disorder with comorbid anxiety: a randomised double-blind placebo-controlled pilot trial. Human Psychopharmacology. 2009, 24(1):41-8. [PubMed abstract]

Sarris J, Kavanagh DJ, Byrne G, Bone KM, Adams J, Deed G. (2009c) The Kava Anxiety Depression Spectrum Study (KADSS): a randomized, placebo-controlled crossover trial using an aqueous extract of Piper methysticum. Psychopharmacology (Berl). 2009, 205(3):399-407. [PubMed abstract]


Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Massage, aromatherapy and reflexology
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ AROMATHERAPY,CONDITIONS A-Z,REFLEXOLOGY,MASSAGE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,OCTOBER 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Massage, aromatherapy and reflexology

One systematic review of massage therapy has been published since the 2008 update. (Coelho et al. 2008) This is based on the previous review by Coelho et al. included in the 2008 update. On this occasion, the authors focused on anxiety and depression in the perinatal period. Studies were not limited to those in patients with clinically significant anxiety or depression and single session as well as multiple session massage therapy was included. Despite this change in focus, the conclusions were similar to the previous review, that there is a lack of good quality evidence.

The review of aromatherapy included 6 studies, 3 of which were uncontrolled. (Yim et al. 2009) Two studies were in patients with depression, 3 in depressive symptoms in cancer patients and 1 in postnatal depression. In all cases, aromatherapy was combined with massage and the controls included massage with an inert oil, no massage or usual care. The essential oils used included lavender, chamomile and mixtures of several oils.  With such a mixed group of studies, it is difficult to come to any firm conclusions. The authors suggest that aromatherapy continue to be used in these groups and that further research is needed.

No reviews or trials of reflexology in depression were located since the 2008 update.


Systematic reviews

Coelho HF, Boddy K, Ernst E. A systematic review of classical European massage for alleviating perinatal depression and anxiety. Focus on Alternative and Complementary Therapies. 2008, 13(3):150-6. [Full text]

Yim VW, Ng AK, Tsang HW, Leung AY. A review on the effects of aromatherapy for patients with depressive symptoms. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2009. Feb 13. [PubMed abstract]

Randomised controlled trial

Field T, Figueiredo B, Hernandez-Reif M, Diego M, Deeds O, Ascencio A. Massage therapy reduces pain in pregnant women, alleviates prenatal depression in both parents and improves their relationships. J Bodyw Mov Ther 2008 Apr;12(2):146-50. [PubMed abstract]


Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Meditation and mindfulness
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,MEDITATION,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS D-E,MINDFULNESS-BASED STRESS REDUCTION (MBSR),OCTOBER 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Meditation and mindfulness

Mindfulness in the context of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) has again received considerable research attention. Williams et al. (2008) respond to various issues raised in the systematic review of MBCT included in the 2008 update. A DARE appraisal of the same review has also been published. Further trials of the effects of MBCT in depression are reported while several studies specifically investigate the role of mindfulness. Michalak and colleagues (2008) point out that although empirical evidence for the effectiveness of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) is encouraging, there is a lack of data on the role of mindfulness in its relapse preventive effect. The results of their study suggest that levels of mindfulness do predict the risk of relapse/recurrence. Raes et al. (2009) assessed whether mindfulness practices in MBCT have an effect on the process of cognitive reactivity. A further aspect, that of the patient’s perspective, is addressed by Allen et al. (2009) who interviewed 20 patients who had participated in MBCT classes 12 months previously. The main themes related to control, acceptance, relationships and struggle.


Comment on a systematic review

Williams JM, Russell I, Russell D. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy: further issues in current evidence and future research. Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology. 2008, 76(3):524-9. [PubMed abstract]


Randomised controlled trials

Barnhofer T, Crane C, Hargus E, Amarasinghe M, Winder R, Williams JM. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy as a treatment for chronic depression: A preliminary study. Behav Res Ther 2009 May;47(5):366-73. [PubMed abstract]

Butler LD, Waelde LC, Hastings TA, Chen XH, Symons B, Marshall J, et al. Meditation with yoga, group therapy with hypnosis, and psychoeducation for long-term depressed mood: a randomized pilot trial. J Clin Psychol 2008 Jul;64(7):806-20. [PubMed abstract]

Hepburn SR, Crane C, Barnhofer T, Duggan DS, Fennell MJ, Williams JM. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy may reduce thought suppression in previously suicidal participants: findings from a preliminary study. Br J Clin Psychol 2009 Jun;48(Pt 2):209-15. [PubMed abstract]

Huffziger S, Kuehner C. Rumination, distraction, and mindful self-focus in depressed patients. Behav Res Ther 2009 Mar;47(3):224-30. [PubMed abstract]

Kitsumban V, Thapinta D, Sirindharo PB, Anders RL. Effect of cognitive mindfulness practice program on depression among elderly thai women. Thai Journal of Nursing Research 2009;13(2):95-108.

Kuyken W, Byford S, Taylor RS, Watkins E, Holden E, White K, et al. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy to prevent relapse in recurrent depression. J Consult Clin Psychol 2008 Dec;76(6):966-78. [PubMed abstract]


Related studies

Crane C, Barnhofer T, Duggan DS, Hepburn S, Fennell MV, Williams JMG. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy and self-discrepancy in recovered depressed patients with a history of depression and suicidality. Cognitive Therapy and Research 2008;32(6):775-87.

Eisendrath SJ, Delucchi K, Bitner R, Fenimore P, Smit M, McLane M. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy for treatment-resistant depression: a pilot study. Psychother Psychosom 2008;77(5):319-20.

Ernst S, Welke J, Heintze C, Gabriel R, Zollner A, Kiehne S, et al. Effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction on quality of life in nursing home residents: a feasibility study. Forsch Komplementmed 2008 Apr;15(2):74-81. [PubMed abstract]

Michalak J, Heidenreich T, Meibert P, Schulte D. Mindfulness predicts relapse/recurrence in major depressive disorder after mindfulness-based cognitive therapy. J Nerv Ment Dis 2008 Aug;196(8):630-3. [PubMed abstract]

Raes F, Dewulf D, Van HC, Williams JM. Mindfulness and reduced cognitive reactivity to sad mood: evidence from a correlational study and a non-randomized waiting list controlled study. Behav Res Ther 2009 Jul;47(7):623-7. [PubMed abstract]

Schreiner I, Malcolm JP. The benefits of mindfulness meditation: Changes in emotional states of depression, anxiety, and stress. Behaviour Change 2008;25(3):156-68.


Qualitative study

Allen M, Bromley A, Kuyken W, Sonnenberg SJ. Participants' experiences of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy: "It changed me in just about every way possible". Behavioural and Cognitive Psychotherapy. 2009, 37(4):413-30. [PubMed abstract]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Methodology
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,SEPTEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Methodology

The aim of the Annual Evidence Update (AEU) on CAM for Depression is to identify, organise and present the most up-to-date evidence for this topic. As this is the second update, we have comprehensively searched a large number of databases, covering the period from January 2008 to August 2009. Studies included in the 2008 update have been excluded.


This update is linked to the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Depression hosted by the NHS Evidence – mental health specialist collection.

It also builds on work previously conducted as part of the CAMEOL project. For more information about the rationale for inclusion of specific CAM therapies see Methodology section for the 2008 Annual evidence update.


Search strategy

Based on the above work, the search strategy included text words and terms for CAM in general and for specific CAM therapies. These were combined with text word and terms for depression. Methodological filters for specific study types were not used.
The search strategy can be found here. This strategy has been modified for NHS Search 2.


Sources searched

The Cochrane Library (CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHS EED), PubMed (and MEDLINE), EMBASE, AMED, CINAHL, PsycINFO
NHS Evidence – mental health specialist collection


Search process

The searches were carried out between 29 July and 5 August 2009 and were limited to articles published since January 2008. Studies included in the 2008 update have been excluded.


Selection criteria

 - Study types: guidance/guidelines, systematic reviews, meta-analyses, HTA reports, cost effectiveness and economic evaluation studies, RCTs, qualitative studies.
 - Focused on depression

To identify systematic reviews the definition of a systematic review from the Glossary of Cochrane Collaboration and research terms was used:

“A review of a clearly formulated question that uses systematic and explicit methods to identify, select, and critically appraise relevant research, and to collect and analyse data from the studies that are included in the review. Statistical methods (meta-analysis) may or may not be used to analyse and summarise the results of the included studies.”

Exclusion criteria

 - The study is not one of the types specified above
 - The main focus is not on depression (e.g., a systematic review on specific therapy, which may include a range of conditions)  
 - Bipolar disorder
 - Depression related to other medical conditions

Note
Studies likely to be of particular interest but not meeting the inclusion criteria above have been included where relevant and listed under ‘Other studies of interest’.

Search results

The total number of records retrieved was 6074. After removing the duplicates there were 3163 citations. Of these, 167 were selected as potentially relevant studies. The final selection includes 21 systematic reviews and 34 RCTs.
A list of the relevant guidelines, systematic reviews and meta-analyses and RCTs is given in the Results section.
 

Link back to 2009 Annual evidence update on CAM in depression

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Other therapies
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,HYPNOSIS,HOMEOPATHY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DEPRESSION,RELAXATION TECHNIQUES,MUSIC THERAPY,TAI CHI,CONDITIONS D-E,LIGHT THERAPY,QI GONG,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),OCTOBER 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Other therapies

Homeopathy

Randomised controlled trial

Adler UC, Paiva NM, Cesar AT, Adler MS, Molina A, Padula AE, Calil HM. Homeopathic individualized Q-potencies versus fluoxetine for moderate to severe depression: Double-blind, randomized non-inferiority trial. Evidence-based Complementary and Alternative Medicine. 2009, Aug 17. [PubMed abstract]

Hypnosis

Randomised controlled trial

Butler LD, Waelde LC, Hastings TA, Chen XH, Symons B, Marshall J, et al. Meditation with yoga, group therapy with hypnosis, and psychoeducation for long-term depressed mood: a randomized pilot trial. J Clin Psychol 2008 Jul;64(7):806-20. [PubMed abstract]

Partially randomised preference study

Dobbin A, Maxwell M, Elton R. A benchmarked feasibility study of a self-hypnosis treatment for depression in primary care. Int J Clin Exp Hypn 2009 Jul;57(3):293-318. [PubMed abstract]


Light therapy

Ongoing randomised controlled trial
Lieverse R, Nielen MM, Veltman DJ, Uitdehaag BM, van Someren EJ, Smit JH, et al. Bright light in elderly subjects with nonseasonal major depressive disorder: a double blind randomised clinical trial using early morning bright blue light comparing dim red light treatment. Trials 2008;9:48. [Full text]


Music therapy

The meta-analysis by Gold et al (2009) demonstrated a significant dose-effect relationship for depressive symptoms: small effect sizes are seen with a few therapy sessions, but longer courses or more frequent sessions are needed to achieve more substantial benefits.

Systematic review

Gold C, Solli HP, Kruger V, Lie SA. Dose-response relationship in music therapy for people with serious mental disorders: systematic review and meta-analysis. Clinical Psychology Review. 2009, 29(3):193-207. [PubMed abstract]

Randomised controlled trials

Chang MY, Chen CH, Huang KF. Effects of music therapy on psychological health of women during pregnancy. J Clin Nurs 2008 Oct;17(19):2580-7. [PubMed abstract]

Deshmukh AD, Sarvaiya AA, Nayak AS. Effect of Indian classical music on quality of sleep in depressed patients: a randomized controlled trial. Nordic Journal of Music Therapy 2009;18(1):70-9.

Ongoing randomised controlled trial

Erkkila J, Gold C, Fachner J, la-Ruona E, Punkanen M, Vanhala M. The effect of improvisational music therapy on the treatment of depression: protocol for a randomised controlled trial. BMC Psychiatry 2008;8:50. [Full text]


Relaxation

A recent Cochrane review found that, based on self-rated scales, relaxation was better than no treatment or minimal treatment (Jorm et al. 2008). However, relaxation was not as effective as psychological therapies and findings based on clinician-rated depressive symptoms were less conclusive. Studies included patients with a high level of depressive symptoms as well as those diagnosed with depression. The most frequently used technique (10 of 15 studies) was progressive muscle relaxation which, as the authors point out, is a relatively simple psychological technique that can be administered after brief training. Also included were a trial of autogenic training, one of relaxation imagery and three that evaluated various combined methods: muscle relaxation and modified pain-reduction procedure, progressive muscle relaxation and yoga exercises, and progressive muscle relaxation plus psychoeducation including mental imagery and breathing.

Systematic review

Jorm AF, Morgan AJ, Hetrick SE. Relaxation for depression. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2008, Issue 4. Art. No.: CD007142. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD007142.pub2. [Full text]

Randomised controlled trial

Krogh J, Saltin B, Gluud C, Nordentoft M. The DEMO trial: a randomized, parallel-group, observer-blinded clinical trial of strength versus aerobic versus relaxation training for patients with mild to moderate depression. J Clin Psychiatry 2009 Jun;70(6):790-800. [PubMed abstract]


Tai chi and qigong

Systematic review

One systematic review included trials of tai chi and qigong in people over 55 years of age. Five trials assessed effects on depression or depressive symptoms. The 2 trials in people with depression (1 qigong and 1 tai chi) are included in the Cochrane review of exercise (see Editorial). The remaining trials are of tai chi in osteoarthritis patients and in healthy older adults, and a trial of qigong in patients with Parkinson’s disease. The authors point out that these forms of exercise are worth further investigation in this age group because of potential benefits on balance and therefore fall reduction.  

Rogers CE, Larkey LK, Keller C. A review of clinical trials of tai chi and qigong in older adults. Western Journal of Nursing Research. 2009, 31(2):245-79. [Full text]

Randomised controlled trial
Cho KL. Effect of Tai Chi on depressive symptoms amongst Chinese older patients with major depression: the role of social support. Med Sport Sci 2008;52:146-54. [PubMed abstract]


Traditional Chinese Medicine

Systematic review – see commentary under Chinese herbal section

Zhao H, Wan X, Chen JX. A mini review of traditional chinese medicine for the treatment of depression in china. American Journal of Chinese Medicine. 2009, 37(2):207-13. [PubMed abstract]


Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression

]]>

document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Results

The following relevant studies on this topic have been published between July 2008 and August 2009.

These studies have met our selection criteria. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.


Guidelines

Evidence-based guidelines for treating depressive disorders with antidepressants: a revision of the 2000 British Association for Psychopharmacology guidelines. Journal of Psychopharmacology. 2008, 22(4):343-96. [Full text]

  10. Mead GE, Morley W, Campbell P, Greig CA, McMurdo M, Lawlor DA. Exercise for depression. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2009, Issue 3. Art. No.: CD004366. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004366.pub4. [Full text]

  14. Rethorst CD, Wipfli BM, Landers DM. The antidepressive effects of exercise: a meta-analysis of randomized trials.  Sports Medicine. 2009, 39(6):491-511. doi: 10.2165/00007256-200939060-00004.  [PubMed abstract]
  15. Rogers CE, Larkey LK, Keller C. A review of clinical trials of tai chi and qigong in older adults. Western Journal of Nursing Research. 2009, 31(2):245-79. [Full text]
  16. Roshanaei-Moghaddam B, Katon WJ, Russo J. The longitudinal effects of depression on physical activity. General Hospital Psychiatry. 2009, 31(4):306-15. [PubMed abstract]

  18. Sun Y-L, Chen S-B, Gao Y, Xiong J. Acupuncture versus western medicine for depression in China: A systematic review. Chinese Journal of Evidence-Based Medicine. 2008, 8(5):340-5. [DARE provisional record]
  19. Yim VW, Ng AK, Tsang HW, Leung AY. A review on the effects of aromatherapy for patients with depressive symptoms. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2009. Feb 13. [PubMed abstract]
  20. Zhang ZJ, Chen HY, Yip KC, Ng R, Wong VT. The effectiveness and safety of acupuncture therapy in depressive disorders: Systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Affective Disorders. 2009 Jul 24. [PubMed abstract]
  21. Zhao H, Wan X, Chen JX. A mini review of traditional chinese medicine for the treatment of depression in china. American Journal of Chinese Medicine. 2009, 37(2):207-13. [PubMed abstract]

Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)

  1. Adler UC, Paiva NM, Cesar AT, Adler MS, Molina A, Padula AE, Calil HM. Homeopathic individualized Q-potencies versus fluoxetine for moderate to severe depression: Double-blind, randomized non-inferiority trial. Evidence-based Complementary and Alternative Medicine. 2009, Aug 17. [PubMed abstract]
  2. Akhondzadeh BA, Choreishi SA, Noorbala AA, Akhondzadeh SH, Rezazadeh S. Petal and stigma of Crocus sativus L. in the treatment of depression: A pilot double - blind randomized trial. Journal of Medicinal Plants. 2008, 7(SUPPL. 4):29-36.
  3. Barnhofer T, Crane C, Hargus E, Amarasinghe M, Winder R, Williams JM. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy as a treatment for chronic depression: A preliminary study. Behav Res Ther 2009 May;47(5):366-73. [PubMed abstract]
  4. Butler LD, Waelde LC, Hastings TA, Chen XH, Symons B, Marshall J, et al. Meditation with yoga, group therapy with hypnosis, and psychoeducation for long-term depressed mood: a randomized pilot trial. J Clin Psychol 2008 Jul;64(7):806-20. [PubMed abstract]
  5. Calabrese C, Gregory WL, Leo M, Kraemer D, Bone K, Oken B. Effects of a standardized Bacopa monnieri extract on cognitive performance, anxiety, and depression in the elderly: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2008, 14(6):707-13. [PubMed abstract]
  6. Chang MY, Chen CH, Huang KF. Effects of music therapy on psychological health of women during pregnancy. J Clin Nurs 2008 Oct;17(19):2580-7. [PubMed abstract]
  7. Chen KM, Chen MH, Chao HC, Hung HM, Lin HS, Li CH. Sleep quality, depression state, and health status of older adults after silver yoga exercises: Cluster randomized trial. Int J Nurs Stud 2008 Oct 21. [PubMed abstract]
  8. Cho KL. Effect of Tai Chi on depressive symptoms amongst Chinese older patients with major depression: the role of social support. Med Sport Sci 2008;52:146-54. [PubMed abstract]
  9. Deshmukh AD, Sarvaiya AA, Nayak AS. Effect of Indian classical music on quality of sleep in depressed patients: a randomized controlled trial. Nordic Journal of Music Therapy 2009;18(1):70-9.
  10. Dobbin A, Maxwell M, Elton R. A benchmarked feasibility study of a self-hypnosis treatment for depression in primary care. Int J Clin Exp Hypn 2009 Jul;57(3):293-318. [PubMed abstract]
  11. Doornbos B, van Goor SA, jck-Brouwer DA, Schaafsma A, Korf J, Muskiet FA. Supplementation of a low dose of DHA or DHA+AA does not prevent peripartum depressive symptoms in a small population based sample. Prog Neuropsychopharmacol Biol Psychiatry 2009 Feb 1;33(1):49-52. [PubMed abstract]
  12. Dording CM, Fisher L, Papakostas G, Farabaugh A, Sonawalla S, Fava M, et al. A double-blind, randomized, pilot dose-finding study of maca root (L. meyenii) for the management of SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction. CNS Neuroscince & Therapeutics. 2008, 14(3):182-91. [PubMed abstract]
  13. Duan DM, Tu Y, Chen LP, Wu ZJ. [Study on electroacupuncture treatment of depression by magnetic resonance imaging] Zhongguo Zhen Jiu. 2009 Feb;29(2):139-44. [Article in Chinese] [PubMed abstract]
  14. Field T, Figueiredo B, Hernandez-Reif M, Diego M, Deeds O, Ascencio A. Massage therapy reduces pain in pregnant women, alleviates prenatal depression in both parents and improves their relationships. J Bodyw Mov Ther 2008 Apr;12(2):146-50. [PubMed abstract]
  15. Ford AH, Flicker L, Thomas J, Norman P, Jamrozik K, Almeida OP. Vitamins B12, B6, and folic acid for onset of depressive symptoms in older men: results from a 2-year placebo-controlled randomized trial. J Clin Psychiatry 2008 Aug;69(8):1203-9. [PubMed abstract]
  16. Franzblau SH, Echevarria S, Smith M, Van Cantfort TE. A preliminary investigation of the effects of giving testimony and learning yogic breathing techniques on battered women's feelings of depression. J Interpers Violence 2008 Dec;23(12):1800-8. [PubMed abstract]
  17. Freeman MP, Davis M, Sinha P, Wisner KL, Hibbeln JR, Gelenberg AJ. Omega-3 fatty acids and supportive psychotherapy for perinatal depression: a randomized placebo-controlled study. J Affect Disord 2008 Sep;110(1-2):142-8. [PubMed abstract]
  18. Gosney MA, Hammond MF, Shenkin A, Allsup S. Effect of micronutrient supplementation on mood in nursing home residents. Gerontology 2008;54(5):292-9. [PubMed abstract]

  20. Huffziger S, Kuehner C. Rumination, distraction, and mindful self-focus in depressed patients. Behav Res Ther 2009 Mar;47(3):224-30. [PubMed abstract]
  21. Javnbakht M, Hejazi KR, Ghasemi M. Effects of yoga on depression and anxiety of women. Complement Ther Clin Pract 2009 May;15(2):102-4. [PubMed abstract]
  22. Jazayeri S, Tehrani-Doost M, Keshavarz SA, Hosseini M, Djazayery A, Amini H, et al. Comparison of therapeutic effects of omega-3 fatty acid eicosapentaenoic acid and fluoxetine, separately and in combination, in major depressive disorder. Aust N Z J Psychiatry 2008 Mar;42(3):192-8. [PubMed abstract]
  23. Jorde R, Sneve M, Figenschau Y, Svartberg J, Waterloo K. Effects of vitamin D supplementation on symptoms of depression in overweight and obese subjects: randomized double blind trial. J Intern Med 2008 Dec;264(6):599-609. [PubMed abstract]
  24. Kasper S, Volz HP, Moller HJ, Dienel A, Kieser M. Continuation and long-term maintenance treatment with Hypericum extract WS 5570 after recovery from an acute episode of moderate depression--a double-blind, randomized, placebo controlled long-term trial. Eur Neuropsychopharmacol 2008 Nov;18(11):803-13. [PubMed abstract]
  25. Kitsumban V, Thapinta D, Sirindharo PB, Anders RL. Effect of cognitive mindfulness practice program on depression among elderly thai women. Thai Journal of Nursing Research 2009;13(2):95-108.
  26. Krogh J, Saltin B, Gluud C, Nordentoft M. The DEMO trial: a randomized, parallel-group, observer-blinded clinical trial of strength versus aerobic versus relaxation training for patients with mild to moderate depression. J Clin Psychiatry 2009 Jun;70(6):790-800. [PubMed abstract]
  27. Kuyken W, Byford S, Taylor RS, Watkins E, Holden E, White K, et al. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy to prevent relapse in recurrent depression. J Consult Clin Psychol 2008 Dec;76(6):966-78. [PubMed abstract]

  30. Osher Y, Belmaker RH. Omega-3 fatty acids in depression: a review of three studies. CNS Neurosci Ther 2009;15(2):128-33. [PubMed abstract]
  31. Sarris J, Kavanagh DJ, Adams J, Bone K, Byrne G. Kava Anxiety Depression Spectrum Study (KADSS): a mixed methods RCT using an aqueous extract of Piper methysticum. Complementary Therapies in Medicine. 2009, 17(3):176-8. [PubMed abstract]
  32. Sarris J, Kavanagh DJ, Byrne G, Bone KM, Adams J, Deed G. The Kava Anxiety Depression Spectrum Study (KADSS): a randomized, placebo-controlled crossover trial using an aqueous extract of Piper methysticum. Psychopharmacology (Berl). 2009, 205(3):399-407. [PubMed abstract]
  33. Sarris J, Kavanagh DJ, Deed G, Bone KM. St. John's wort and Kava in treating major depressive disorder with comorbid anxiety: a randomised double-blind placebo-controlled pilot trial. Human Psychopharmacology. 2009, 24(1):41-8. [PubMed abstract] 
  34. Sharma VK, Das S, Mondal S, Goswami U. Effect of Sahaj yoga on autonomic functions in healthy subjects and patients of major depression. Biomedicine 2008;28(2):139-41.

Excluded systematic review

Martensson B, Ekselius L, Pettersson A. [Treatment of depression with light therapy. A systematic literature review. SBU summary and conclusions]. Lakartidningen. 2008 Jul 9;105(28-29):2024-5.
Reason for exclusion: Article in Swedish; no English abstract is available.


Systematic reviews published in the period 2004-2008 are listed here.

Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression

document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - St John's wort (Hypericum perforatum)
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ST JOHN'S WORT (HYPERICUM PERFORATUM),CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS D-E,HERBS R-Z,OCTOBER 2009,2009,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - St John's wort (Hypericum perforatum)

The latest version of the Cochrane review by Linde et al. was published during our 2008 update and was therefore only briefly mentioned although there was considerable press coverage at the time. In this version a number of significant changes had been made. The review now focuses on patients suffering from major depression so that 16 studies included in the previous version were excluded and 8 new trials added.  A total of 29 trials were evaluated, 18 comparisons with placebo and 17 with a standard antidepressant (six three-armed trials). One particularly interesting finding is that more favourable results were reported in studies from German-speaking countries where these products have a long tradition and are often prescribed by physicians. The authors suggest this could either be due to the inclusion of patients with slightly different types of depression or that some of the smaller studies were flawed. The major change is that the conclusions are now slightly more favourable, i.e.:

The available evidence suggests that the hypericum extracts tested in the included trials a) are superior to placebo in patients with major depression; b) are similarly effective as standard antidepressants; c) and have fewer side effects than standard antidepressants. The association of country of origin and precision with effects sizes complicates the interpretation.

A recent meta-analysis comparing the effects of St John’s wort and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)  reported similar findings to those of the Cochrane review: similar effectiveness but less frequent adverse effects (Rahimi et al. 2009). Other aspects of St John’s wort as an antidepressant have also been investigated including safety in long-term use (Kasper et al. 2008, Brattstrom 2009) and pregnancy (Moretti et al. 2009), and the potential interaction with oral contraceptives (Will-Shahab et al. 2009). Labelling of products in the USA was assessed and found to be inadequate in many cases (Clauson et al. 2008). Two studies provided an insight into the reasons for self-treatment of depression with St John’s wort. In the USA, it appears that the cost of conventional therapies plays a role (Wu et al. 2008) while in Germany, patients who buy St John’s wort for self treatment report ‘pronounced and persistent depressive symptoms’ (Linden et al. 2008). These factors are obviously affected by the local health care provision and an equivalent study in the UK seems warranted.


Systematic reviews

Linde K, Berner MM, Kriston L. St John's wort for major depression. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2008, Issue 4. Art. No.: CD000448. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD000448.pub3. [Full text]

Rahimi R, Nikfar S, Abdollahi M. Efficacy and tolerability of Hypericum perforatum in major depressive disorder in comparison with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors: a meta-analysis. Progress in Neuropsychopharmacology & Biological Psychiatry. 2009, 33(1):118-27. [PubMed abstract] [DARE provisional record]

Sarris J, Kavanagh DJ. Kava and St. John's Wort: current evidence for use in mood and anxiety disorders. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2009, 15(8):827-36. [PubMed abstract]


Randomised controlled trial

Kasper S, Volz HP, Moller HJ, Dienel A, Kieser M. Continuation and long-term maintenance treatment with Hypericum extract WS 5570 after recovery from an acute episode of moderate depression--a double-blind, randomized, placebo controlled long-term trial. Eur Neuropsychopharmacol 2008 Nov;18(11):803-13. [PubMed abstract]


Other relevant studies

Interactions
Will-Shahab L, Bauer S, Kunter U, Roots I, Brattstrom A. St John's wort extract (Ze 117) does not alter the pharmacokinetics of a low-dose oral contraceptive. Eur J Clin Pharmacol 2009 Mar;65(3):287-94.

Safety
Brattstrom A. Long-term effects of St. John's wort (Hypericum perforatum) treatment: a 1-year safety study in mild to moderate depression. Phytomedicine 2009 Apr;16(4):277-83. [PubMed abstract]

Clauson KA, Santamarina ML, Rutledge JC. Clinically relevant safety issues associated with St. John's wort product labels. BMC Complement Altern Med 2008;8:42. [Full text]

Moretti ME, Maxson A, Hanna F, Koren G. Evaluating the safety of St. John's Wort in human pregnancy. Reprod Toxicol 2009 Jul;28(1):96-9. [PubMed abstract]

Use
Linden M, Wurzendorf K, Ploch M, Schaefer M. Self medication with St. John's wort in depressive disorders: an observational study in community pharmacies. J Affect Disord 2008 Apr;107(1-3):205-10. [PubMed abstract]

Wu CW, Kennedy J, Sclar DA. Factors associated with the use of St. John's Wort among adults with depressive symptoms. Journal of Dietary Supplements 2008;5(4):341-9. [Abstract]


Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression 

]]>

document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Use of CAM
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,OCTOBER 2009,CAM GENERAL,USE OF CAM]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Use of CAM

Surveys included in the 2008 update indicated that use of CAM for depression was significant and increasing over time. The data to support this was provided mainly by large scale surveys in Australia, Canada and the USA with one qualitative study from the UK. Since 2008, a number of surveys have been published on patterns of use of CAM in depression. These include use of CAM in special populations in the USA, including African American and Hispanic patients (Bazargan et al. 2008) and older adults (Keaton et al. 2009).  Two surveys set in Taiwan highlight differences between inpatients and outpatients (Hsu et al. 2008, 2009). One survey from Finland reveals the patterns of use of CAM and mental health services by people with various mental disorders including depression (Wahlstrom et al. 2008). The final study from the USA attempts to provide some insight into the choices made by people with mental disorders. (Russinova et al. 2009) This study focused on 255 individuals with a serious mental illness who experienced CAM as having a positive impact on their mental health. Data were gathered from responses to open-ended questions embedded in a postal survey. The benefits were perceived to be related to both the improvement of psychiatric symptomatology and the promotion of functional recovery. These studies all provide some insight into the use of CAM for depression but the lack of studies from the UK leaves some questions unanswered.


Bazargan M, Ani CO, Hindman DW, Bazargan-Hejazi S, Baker RS, Bell D, Bell D, Rodriquez M. Correlates of complementary and alternative medicine utilization in depressed, underserved african american and Hispanic patients in primary care settings. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2008, 14(5):537-44. [PubMed abstract]

Hsu MC, Creedy D, Moyle W, Venturato L, Tsay SL, Ouyang WC. Use of Complementary and Alternative Medicine among adult patients for depression in Taiwan. Journal of Affective Disorders. 2008, 111(2-3):360-5. [PubMed abstract]

Hsu MC, Moyle W, Creedy D, Venturato L, Ouyang WC, Tsay SL. Use of antidepressants and complementary and alternative medicine among outpatients with depression in Taiwan. Archives of Psychiatric Nursing. 2009, 23(1):75-85. [PubMed abstract]

Keaton D, Lamkin N, Cassidy KA, Meyer WJ, Ignacio RV, Aulakh L, et al. Utilization of herbal and nutritional compounds among older adults with bipolar disorder and with major depression. International Journal of Geriatric Psychiatry. 2009, 24(10):1087-93. [PubMed abstract]

Russinova Z, Cash D, Wewiorski NJ. Toward understanding the usefulness of complementary and alternative medicine for individuals with serious mental illnesses: Classification of perceived benefits. Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease. 2009, 197(1):69-73.

Wahlstrom M, Sihvo S, Haukkala A, Kiviruusu O, Pirkola S, Isometsa E. Use of mental health services and complementary and alternative medicine in persons with common mental disorders. Acta Psychiatrica Scandinavica. 2008, 118(1):73-80. [PubMed abstract]


Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression

]]>

document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ YOGA,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,OCTOBER 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Yoga

The review by da Silva et al. (2009) updated and expanded on an earlier systematic review of yoga for depression (Pilkington et al. 2005). Controlled trials published since the 2005 review were identified and included as were open (uncontrolled) studies. The focus was also extended to include mood disorders and anxiety. The authors concluded that ‘Reasonable evidence supports the benefit of yoga in specific depressive disorders’ although further research is still encouraged.


Systematic review

da Silva TL, Ravindran LN, Ravindran AV. Yoga in the treatment of mood and anxiety disorders: A review. Asian Journal of Psychiatry. 2009, 2(1):6-16. [Abstract]

Randomised controlled trials

Butler LD, Waelde LC, Hastings TA, Chen XH, Symons B, Marshall J, et al. Meditation with yoga, group therapy with hypnosis, and psychoeducation for long-term depressed mood: a randomized pilot trial. J Clin Psychol 2008 Jul;64(7):806-20. [PubMed abstract]

Chen KM, Chen MH, Chao HC, Hung HM, Lin HS, Li CH. Sleep quality, depression state, and health status of older adults after silver yoga exercises: Cluster randomized trial. Int J Nurs Stud 2008 Oct 21. [PubMed abstract]

Franzblau SH, Echevarria S, Smith M, Van Cantfort TE. A preliminary investigation of the effects of giving testimony and learning yogic breathing techniques on battered women's feelings of depression. J Interpers Violence 2008 Dec;23(12):1800-8. [PubMed abstract]

Javnbakht M, Hejazi KR, Ghasemi M. Effects of yoga on depression and anxiety of women. Complement Ther Clin Pract 2009 May;15(2):102-4. [PubMed abstract]

Sharma VK, Das S, Mondal S, Goswami U. Effect of Sahaj yoga on autonomic functions in healthy subjects and patients of major depression. Biomedicine 2008;28(2):139-41.


Link back to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression
