document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy

Published: 15 June 2009

 

 

 

 

Introduction 

The 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy aims to identify, organise and present all relevant systematic reviews and randomised controlled trials (RCTs) published between May 2008 and May 2009.

Previously published studies have been included in the 2008 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy or can be found by searching this website.

We have searched a large number of databases and used strict selection criteria for the identified studies, in order to base the annual update on the best current evidence available. The studies included in this update have met our selection criteria but have not been fully appraised. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

For more details about the search methods and the selection process for this annual update see the methodology section.

For a brief overview of the topic of Homeopathy, including information on clinical uses and safety, see the introductory article.

 

Contents

  • Methodology
  • Results of the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy
  • Commentary on the results of the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy - Expert commentary
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HOMEOPATHY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,JUNE 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy - Expert commentary

Summary of systematic reviews, meta-analyses, RCTs and other studies

Dr Peter Fisher, Clinical Lead, NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine


Systematic reviews and meta-analysis


Cochrane review of homeopathic medicines for adverse effects of cancer treatments

Kassab S, Cummings M, Berkovitz S, van Haselen R, Fisher P. Homeopathic medicines for adverse effects of cancer treatments. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2009, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD004845. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004845.pub2. [Full text] 


This Cochrane review evaluated the effectiveness and safety of homeopathic medicines to prevent or treat adverse effects of cancer treatments. Homeopathic medicines are used by patients with cancer, often alongside conventional treatment. Cancer treatments can cause considerable morbidity and one of the reasons patients use homeopathic medicines is to help with adverse effects. 

A wide search including standard electronic databases and hand searching of specialised literature was conducted for randomised controlled trials (RCTs) of homeopathic medicines in participants with cancer where the intervention was aimed at preventing or treating symptoms associated with cancer treatments. All age groups, and all stages of disease were included.

Eight controlled trials (seven placebo controlled and one against active treatment) with a total of 664 participants were included. Three trials studied adverse effects of radiotherapy, three adverse effects of chemotherapy and two menopausal symptoms associated with breast cancer treatment. Two studies with low risk of bias demonstrated benefit: one with 254 participants demonstrated superiority of topical calendula over trolamine (a topical agent not containing corticosteroids) for prevention of radiotherapy-induced dermatitis, and another with 32 participants demonstrated superiority of Traumeel S (a proprietary complex homeopathic medicine) over placebo as a mouthwash for chemotherapy-induced stomatitis. Two other studies reported positive results, although the risk of bias was unclear, and four further studies reported negative results. No serious adverse effects or interactions were reported.

The authors concluded that there is preliminary data in support of the efficacy of topical calendula for prophylaxis of acute dermatitis during radiotherapy and Traumeel S mouthwash in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced stomatitis. These trials need replicating. There is no convincing evidence for the efficacy of homeopathic medicines for other adverse effects of cancer treatments. Further research is required. 


Traditional Indian medicine and homeopathy for HIV/AIDS

Fritts M, Crawford CC, Quibell D, Gupta A, Jonas WB, Coulter I, et al. Traditional Indian medicine and homeopathy for HIV/AIDS: a review of the literature. AIDS Research and Therapy. 2008, 5:25.  [Full text]
 

This is a systematic review of traditional Indian medicine and homeopathy (TIMH) for HIV/AIDS. TIMH comprises Ayurveda, Unani and Siddha medicine, yoga, naturopathy and homeopathy. TIMH is used up to two-thirds of the population and an estimated 2.5 million Indians have HIV/AIDS. But little is known about the use, safety or efficacy of TIMH in HIV/AIDS.

The review assessed the quality of peer-reviewed, published literature on TIMH for HIV/AIDS care and treatment. 206 original articles were reviewed, identifying 21 laboratory and 17 clinical studies, and 6 literature reviews. Most studies were on Ayurveda or homeopathy. Seven studies of homeopathy were found of which 2 were randomised, double-blind placebo controlled trials. 

RCTs of homeopathy were conducted by Rastogi et al. and Brewitt et al. Rastogi et al. evaluated the role of homeopathy in 100 HIV-positive patients  in a 6-month randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial. Participants were stratified into two groups: Asymptomatic HIV-infected (Center for Disease Control (CDC) Stage II, n=50) and HIV-infected with Persistent Generalized Lymphadenopathy (PGL; CDC Stage III, n=50). Individualized homeopathic medicines were prescribed.

Within the PGL stratum, there were statistically significant increases in CD4 and CD8 T-lymphocytes after treatment. The placebo group showed no significant increases in either parameter. Comparison between the control and the intervention arm did not reveal a significant p value. In the asymptomatic stratum, differences within and between the groups were not statistically significant. Criticisms included the small sample size and high loss to follow-up and that subjects with poor compliance, or who developed life threatening conditions or adverse effects which required intervention were not included in the final analysis.

Brewitt conducted two RCTs of similar double-blind placebo-controlled design to assess the use of homeopathic growth factors (hoGFs) as treatment for HIV infection. Growth factors are important to immune responsiveness, wound healing, tissue repair and cell growthThe trials included a total of 76 patients and a found a statistically significant weight gain in patients taking hoGFs (p=0.009 versus placebo at three months, p=0.0004 versus placebo at four months). Weaknesses include that very few statistical significance values were given, and much important information was absent.

The overall conclusion of the review was that there is a large gap between the widespread use of TIMH therapies for HIV/AIDS, and the lack of high-quality data supporting their effectiveness and safety. A rigorous research agenda to investigate the potential risks and benefits of TIMH and to identify its role in the management of HIV/AIDS and associated illnesses in India is required. 


Re-analysis of a meta-analysis

Ludtke R, Rutten AL. The conclusions on the effectiveness of homeopathy highly depend on the set of analyzed trials. Journal of Clinical Epidemiology. 2008, 61(12):1197-204. [PubMed abstract]

Rutten AL, Stolper CF. The 2005 meta-analysis of homeopathy: the importance of post-publication data. Homeopathy. 2008, 97(4):169-77. [PubMed abstract]


A pair of papers re-analysed Shang's meta-analysis* of homeopathic medicines published in the Lancet in 2005. The conclusions of Shang's meta-analysis were based on a subset of eight ‘larger’ trials of 21 ‘high quality’ trials, compared to a subset of 6 ‘larger’ of 14 ‘high quality’ trials of conventional medicine, of a total 110 trials each of homeopathy and conventional medicine. The identity of the trials analysed was not revealed. In this re-analysis, the 21 higher quality trials of homeopathy were identified, re-extracted and analysed  with sensitivity analysis for the influence of single indications and other meaningful subsets of the high quality trials. Subsets were defined according to sample size, type of homeopathy, type of publication, and treated condition. The overall odds ratios (ORs) were estimated using random effect meta-analyses.

The results show that the ‘larger high quality’ trials of homeopathy on which the original conclusions were based were highly heterogeneous, comprising 8 trials on 8 different indications, and were not matched by indication with those of conventional medicine. The method of assessment of trial quality was unclear and differed from previous meta-analyses. However the quality of trials of homeopathy is better than of trials conventional of conventional medicine. Based on all high-quality studies, homeopathy had a significant effect beyond placebo. When the set of analyzed trials was successively restricted to larger patient numbers, the ORs varied and the P-values increased. Shang's negative results were largely due to one trial on preventing muscle soreness in 400 long-distance runners.

The authors concluded that the results of the meta-analysis are very sensitive to the threshold defining ‘large’ clinical trials and that, because of the heterogeneity between the trials and methodological issues, Shang's results and conclusions are less definite than had been presented.


*Shang A, Huwiler-Müntener K, Nartey L, Jüni P, Dörig S, Sterne JA, Pewsner D, Egger M. Are the clinical effects of homoeopathy placebo effects? Comparative study of placebo-controlled trials of homoeopathy and allopathy. Lancet. 2005 Aug 27-Sep 2;366(9487):726-32. [PubMed abstract]


Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)


Homotoxicology for bed-wetting

Ferrara P, Marrone G, Emmanuele V, Nicoletti A, Mastrangelo A, Tiberi E, Ruggiero A, Fasano A, Paolini Paoletti F. Homotoxicological remedies versus desmopressin versus placebo in the treatment of enuresis: a randomised, double-blind, controlled trial. Pediatric Nephrology. 2008, 23(2):269-74. [PubMed abstract]


Homotoxicology is a variant of homeopathy based on interpreting disease as an expression of the defensive effort of the organism against pathogenic toxins and detoxification with homeopathic medicines. A randomised, double-blind, double-dummy, controlled trial compared the safety and efficacy of the homotoxicological complexes Solidago compositum drops and Biopax tablets (combined) with placebo and desmopressin (dDAVP) in the treatment of monosymptomatic nocturnal enuresis (MNE). 151 children with MNE were randomly assigned to receive oral homotoxicological remedies, dDAVP or placebo. The primary outcomes were: the reduction of wet nights per week; numbers of responders; the number of children relapsing after initial response and attaining 14 consecutive dry nights during the treatment. The secondary outcome was adverse effects.

Baseline clinical characteristics were similar between the three groups of patients. After the 3 months there was a significant difference between the three groups (P < 0.001) in the mean number of wet nights per week. dDAVP produced a statistically significant decrease (62.9%) in wet nights compared to placebo (2.4%) and compared to homotoxicological remedies (30.0%). The decrease in wet nights in the homotoxicology group was a significant compared to placebo. Complete resolution was significantly more frequent with homotoxicological remedies (20%) than placebo (0%), and in terms of the number of children with 14 consecutive dry nights.

The authors conclude that homotoxicology is safe and effective compared to placebo, but significantly less effective than dDAVP in MNE.   


The homeopathic medicine Ignatia for oral lichen planus

Mousavi F, Sherafati S, Mojaver YN. Ignatia in the treatment of oral lichen planus. Homeopathy. 2009, 98(1):40-4. [PubMed abstract]  


A randomised placebo-controlled single (patient) blind study conducted in Tehran aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of homeopathic Ignatia 30C in oral lichen planus (OLP). Only patients who met the prescribing criteria for Ignatia were eligible. Of 100 patients with erosive and/or atrophic OLP screened, 30 were eligible and consented. They were treated for 4 months.

Mean lesion sizes and mean pain measures differed between control and treatment groups favouring Ignatia. Mean lesion size reduced from 3.9 to 2.2 cm with active but remained constant at 4.3 cm with placebo. Mean VAS pain scores improved from 50 to 13mm with active and 48 to 40mm with placebo (p<0.05 for both). The authors concluded that their results suggest that Ignatia has a beneficial effect in treatment of OLP in selected patients. Weaknesses of the study include its small scale and lack of assessor blinding.


Effect of a homeopathic complex medicine on morphine requirements after knee surgery

Paris A, Gonnet N, Chaussard C, Belon P, Rocourt F, Saragaglia D, et al. Effect of homeopathy on analgesic intake following knee ligament reconstruction: a phase III monocentre randomized placebo controlled study. British Journal of Clinical Pharmacology. 2008, 65(2):180-7. [Full text]  


This clinical trial compared an homeopathic complex (Arnica montana 5 CH, Bryonia alba 5 CH, Hypericum perforatum 5 CH and Ruta graveolens 3 DH) with placebo after knee ligament reconstruction. The main outcome measure was consumption of less or more than 10mg of morphine in the 24h post surgery delivered by patient controlled analgesia (PCA). It was an add-on randomized controlled study with three parallel groups: a double-blind homeopathic or placebo arm and a control group who received PCA morphine but no homeopathy or placebo. Treatment was administered the evening before surgery and continued for 3 days.

158 patients were randomized: 66 placebo, 67 homeopathic, 25 in the control group (recruitment to the control group was delayed and eventually terminated before target recruitment had been met). There was no difference between the treated and the placebo group for primary end-point (mean 48% and 56% respectively required less than 10 mg morphine/24h). The homeopathic complex had no effect on morphine intake between 24 and 72 h or on the visual analogue pain scale, or on quality of life assessed by the SF36 questionnaire, nor were these parameters significantly different in patients in the control group.

The authors concluded that the homeopathic complex tested was not superior to placebo in reducing 24h morphine consumption after knee ligament reconstruction.


An homeopathic package of care for Fibromyalgia

Relton C, Smith C, Raw J, Walters C, Adebajo AO, Thomas KJ, Young TA. Healthcare provided by a homeopath as an adjunct to usual care for Fibromyalgia (FMS): results of a pilot randomised controlled trial. Homeopathy. 2009, 98(2):77-82. [PubMed abstract]


This is a feasibility study for a Randomised Controlled Trial (RCT) comparing usual care with usual care plus adjunctive care by a homeopath for patients with Fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS). The study was of pragmatic parallel group design. Adults with a diagnosis of FMS (American College of  Rheumatology criteria) were randomly allocated to the two regimes. ‘Adjunctive care’ consisted of five in depth interviews and individualised homeopathic medicines. The primary outcome measure was the difference in Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire (FIQ) total score at 22 weeks.

47 patients were recruited. Drop out rate in the usual care group was higher than the adjunctive care group (8/24 vs 3/23), an intention to treat analyses was presented. There was a significantly greater improvement in the FIQ total score in the homeopath care group compared to usual care (-7.62 vs 3.63), and in the FIQ fatigue, tiredness upon waking and McGill pain scores. The effect size on pain score was small (0.21), but on function, large (0.81). There were no reported adverse events. The authors conclude that there is a need for a definitive study to assess the clinical and cost effectiveness of adjunctive care by a homeopath for patients with FMS.


Other publications of interest

Does homoeopathy work?

Chanda P, Furnham A. Does homoeopathy work? Part II: A review of recent scientific papers. Focus on Alternative and Complementary Therapies. 2008, 13(3):157-67. [Full text]


Chanda and Furnham took an overview of homeopathy based on systematic reviews of RCTs and other literature. They conclude that clinical outcome studies show the effectiveness of homoeopathy in terms of patient and practitioner assessment is generally high and that conventional treatment may be integrated successfully with homoeopathy. But the concepts of like cures like and potentisation are not supported by current scientific evidence. Current RCT evidence neither definitively proves or disproves homoeopathy’s efficacy over placebo. The appropriateness of RCTs for evaluating homoeopathy has been questioned.

Outcome studies and meta-analyses should be viewed in conjunction. An analysis of the placebo effect as a possible mechanism for homoeopathy shows that the ‘narrative consultation process’ may be implicated in psychoneuroimmunology. Although the placebo effect usually carries a negative connotation it is also part of other medical treatments. Socio-demographic data show that homoeopathic patients tend to be largely female and well educated. The efficacy of homoeopathy is context-specific.

Homoeopathy is likely to remain popular despite its lack of scientific plausibility. Decisions regarding the effectiveness of homoeopathy will remain difficult and are likely to be made according to individual experiences and beliefs. Scientists may deny that homoeopathy is a clinically valuable, as exemplified by the Lancet’s ‘end of homoeopathy’ editorial and Shang et al.'s review in 2005. The effectiveness of homoeopathy remains a topic of debate surrounded by scientific, political, economic, social and emotional factors.


Homeopathic Rhus toxicodendron as an adjuvant in tumour therapy

Heine H. Are homeopathic preparations of Rhus toxicodendron L. (Toxicodendron quercifolium Greene) suitable for adjuvant tumor therapy? A systematic review. Schweizerische Zeitschrift Fur Ganzheitsmedizin. 2008, 20(1):35-40. [Abstract] 


Historically plants of the Rhus (sumach) family have been used in the treatment of tumours. Currently homeopathic preparations of Rhus toxicodendron are used only in the treatment of inflammation. This systematic review of in vitro and animal studies from 1966-2007 aimed to assess whether homeopathic preparations of Rhus toxicodendron are suitable for adjuvant tumour therapy. It examined antitumour activity and inhibition of proinflammatory tumour metalloproteinases by various Rhus species especially Rhus toxicodendron.

Antineoplastic effects have been found in numerous tumour cell lines treated with diluted preparations of Rhus species. In a metabolic competent tumour cell line (Hep G2) as well as in animal experiments a statistically significant effect of homeopathically diluted Rhus toxicodendron was demonstrated. In vitro experiments showed inhibitory effects on tumour metalloproteinases. The review concluded that the literature shows that homeopathic preparations of Rhus toxicodendron have antineoplastic effects, and might be considered as an adjuvant in the treatment of tumours. One problem with this study concerns the name of the plant. According to the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature, the plant traditionally known as Rhus toxicodendron in homeopathy should be known as Toxicodendron pubescens, not Toxicodendron quercifolium as in this paper. Its common name is poison ivy, and it is toxic.


Link to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy - Methodology
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HOMEOPATHY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,JUNE 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy - Methodology

Sources searched:

The Cochrane Library (CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHS EED), CRD databases (DARE, NHS EED, HTA), PubMed (and MEDLINE), EMBASE, AMED, CINAHL, PsycINFO

Selection criteria (at screening stage)

Inclusion criteria:

  1. Systematic reviews and meta-analyses - statement of methodology and explicit description of search process (at least 2 sources must have been searched and there must be a statement of methodology)
  2. HTA reports and cost-effectiveness studies 
  3. Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)
  4. Topic relevance (studies should focus on homeopathy or include homeopathy as one of the investigated interventions)

Exclusion criteria:

  1. The study is not a systematic review, meta-analysis, HTA report, cost-effectiveness study or RCT. 
  2. The study does not focus on homeopathy or include homeopathy as one of the investigated interventions.
  3. The study is published in a language other than English and English abstract is not available.

Search process

The searches were carried out between 15 and 20 May 2009 and were limited to articles published since 1 January 2008. To identify relevant systematic reviews the information specialist searched the sources listed above using the CAM specialist collection systematic reviews filter, which emphasizes specificity (precision) over sensitivity. The PubMed Clinical Queries systematic review filter was also used.
More details of search terms and filters used are available by contacting the information specialist. 

Results

The totals number of records retrieved was 104. After removing the duplicates there were 46 to screen. Of these 6 were selected as potential systematic reviews or meta-analyses. If any uncertainty existed records were still included in the list. The final selection includes two systematic review, two meta-analyses, one overview of systematic reviews and an additional systematic review of in vitro and animal studies.

In addition a search for relevant randomised controlled trials (RCTs) was carried out. The total number of records retrieved was 12. After removing the duplicates there were nine studies to screen. The final selection includes five RCTs.


Link to 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy

 

]]>

document.title: 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy - Results

document.topics: <![CDATA[ HOMEOPATHY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,JUNE 2009]]>
document.body:
111-12009 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy - Results

The following relevant studies on this topic have been published between May 2008 and May 2009.

document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,MARCH 2010]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture

Published: 19 April 2010

 

 

Introduction


The 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture aims to identify, organise and present all relevant systematic reviews and large-scale randomised controlled trials (RCTs) published between February 2009 and February 2010.

Previously published studies have been included in the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture or can be found by searching this website.


We have searched a large number of databases and used strict selection criteria for the identified studies, in order to base the annual update on the best current evidence available. The studies included in this update have met our selection criteria but have not been fully appraised. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

For more details about the search methods and the selection process for this annual update see the methodology section.

For a brief overview of the topic of Acupuncture, including information on clinical uses and safety, see the introductory article.

 

Contents

  • Clinical commentary 
  • Results of the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture
    • Systematic reviews and meta-analyses categorised by health topic
      • General reviews of acupuncture
      • Allergies/ENT 
      • Cancer
      • Gastrointestinal diseases
      • Male urogenital diseases
      • Mental health
      • Musculoskeletal diseases 
      • Neurological disorders
      • Obesity
      • Pain
      • Respiratory diseases 
      • Skin disorders
      • Stroke
      • Surgery/Anaesthesia
      • Women’s health/Pregnancy and childbirth
    • Systematic reviews and meta-analyses (all topics)
    • Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)
    • Additional resources - systematic reviews and guidelines covering a range of interventions including acupuncture
  • Methodology

Acknowledgement

The CAM specialist collection project team would like to thank the topic editor Dr Mike Cummings for his contribution to the development of the 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture - Clinical commentary
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,APRIL 2010]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture - Clinical commentary

Dr Mike Cummings, Medical Director of the British Medical Acupuncture Society


Since the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture several interesting RCTs and systematic reviews have been published. However, I would like to start by mentioning two reviews from the last update,1,2 on which I did not comment. These Cochrane reviews updated a previous review on acupuncture for idiopathic headache.3 The review of acupuncture for tension-type headache found statistically significant and clinically relevant effects beyond control, and small but statistically significant effects beyond sham acupuncture.1 The review of acupuncture for migraine prophylaxis by contrast showed no effect beyond sham, but still recommended acupuncture in this condition.2 This is principally because when compared to proven prophylactic drug treatment, acupuncture was associated with slightly better outcomes and fewer adverse effects. We already have data in the UK of cost effectiveness of acupuncture in idiopathic headache.4 This may create a dilemma for commissioners who generally require positive data from placebo controlled trials, as well as data on safety and cost effectiveness before recommending provision in the health service.


I would like to highlight two further Cochrane reviews from the 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture. The first is an update on stimulation of the acupuncture point P6 for preventing post operative nausea and vomiting (PONV).5 This review was positive, and suggested that there was no difference between P6 stimulation and antiemetic medication for any outcome assessed. Side effects associated with P6 stimulation were minor. The first systematic review reporting a positive result for acupuncture in PONV was published 15 years ago.6 Since then all reviews have been positive in this area (to the knowledge of this reviewer). So why is this safe, cheap and effective intervention not in routine use in the NHS?


The review by Manheimer et al. on acupuncture for peripheral joint osteoarthritisis is well conducted,7 but reproduces an increasingly common misinterpretation of the results of meta-analysis in acupuncture reviews. The review comments on the clinical relevance of the difference between acupuncture and sham acupuncture. This comparison is only meaningful if acupuncture is associated with significant risk and if sham acupuncture is an inactive intervention (ie a placebo). We can be fairly sure that some sham acupuncture interventions are active since in at least one very large RCT sham acupuncture outperformed guideline based conventional care.8 In Manheimer et al., acupuncture had clinically relevant effects compared to non-acupuncture controls, and small but statistically significant effects beyond sham acupuncture.


The RCTs I would like to highlight are the first two large pragmatic trials of acupuncture for the treatment of menopausal hot flushes.9,10 Both trials demonstrated a statistically and clinically significant reduction in the frequency of hot flushes in the women treated with acupuncture compared with self-care or usual care controls. Previous trials have generally failed to demonstrate significant differences between acupuncture and sham acupuncture interventions in this condition, which leads to further dilemmas in interpretation of the results, and decisions on implementation. Pragmatists will no doubt advise that we use such an intervention since it is safe and effective. Commissioners often get stuck on the question of efficacy beyond placebo – something that is of rather more importance when balancing the risks and benefits of pharmaceutical interventions.


References

  1. Linde K, Allais G, Brinkhaus B, Manheimer E, Vickers A, White AR. Acupuncture for tension-type headache. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2009, Issue 1. Art. No.: CD007587. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD007587. [Full text]
  2. Linde K, Allais G, Brinkhaus B, Manheimer E, Vickers A, White AR. Acupuncture for migraine prophylaxis. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2009, Issue 1. Art. No.: CD001218. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD001218.pub2. [Full text] (Updated Cochrane review)
  3. Melchart D, Linde K, Fischer P, Berman B, White A, Vickers A, Allais G. Acupuncture for idiopathic headache. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews. 2001;(1):CD001218. [PubMed abstract]
  4. Wonderling D, Vickers AJ, Grieve R, McCarney R. Cost effectiveness analysis of a randomised trial of acupuncture for chronic headache in primary care. BMJ. 2004 Mar 27;328(7442):747. [Full text]
  5. Lee A, Fan LTY. Stimulation of the wrist acupuncture point P6 for preventing postoperative nausea and vomiting. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2009, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD003281. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD003281.pub3. New search for studies and content updated (conclusions changed) [Full text]
  6. Vickers A J.  Can acupuncture have specific effects on health: a systematic review of acupuncture antiemesis trials. Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 1996; 89(6):303-311. [Full text]
  7. Manheimer E, Cheng K, Linde K, Lao L, Yoo J, Wieland S, van der Windt DAWM, Berman BM, Bouter LM. Acupuncture for peripheral joint osteoarthritis. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2010, Issue 1. Art. No.: CD001977. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD001977.pub2. [Full text]
  8. Haake M, Müller HH, Schade-Brittinger C, Basler HD, Schäfer H, Maier C, Endres HG, Trampisch HJ, Molsberger A.German Acupuncture Trials (GERAC) for chronic low back pain: randomized, multicenter, blinded, parallel-group trial with 3 groups. Archives of Internal Medicine. 2007; 167(17):1892-8. [PubMed abstract]
  9. Borud EK, Alraek T, White A, Fonnebo V, Eggen AE, Hammar M, Astrand LL, Theodorsson E, Grimsgaard S. The Acupuncture on Hot Flushes Among Menopausal Women (ACUFLASH) study, a randomized controlled trial. Menopause. 2009; 16(3):484-93. [PubMed abstract]
  10. Kim KH, Kang KW, Kim DI, Kim HJ, Yoon HM, Lee JM, Jeong JC, Lee MS, Jung HJ, Choi SM. Effects of acupuncture on hot flashes in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women--a multicenter randomized clinical trial. Menopause. 2010; 17(2):269-80. [PubMed abstract]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture - Methodology
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MARCH 2010]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture - Methodology

Sources searched:

The Cochrane Library (CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHS EED), CRD databases (DARE, NHS EED, HTA), PubMed (and MEDLINE), EMBASE, AMED, CINAHL, PsycINFO

NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine specialist collection

Selection criteria (at screening stage)

Inclusion criteria:

  1. Systematic reviews - explicit description of search process and statement of methodology (at least 2 sources must have been searched and there must be a statement of methodology)
  2. HTA reports and cost-effectiveness studies 
  3. Large randomised controlled trials (RCTs) – with more than 100 participants. 
  4. Topic relevance (studies should focus on acupuncture or include acupuncture as one of the investigated interventions)

Exclusion criteria:

  1. The study is not a systematic review, meta-analysis, HTA report, cost-effectiveness study or a large RCT. 
  2. The study does not focus on acupuncture or include acupuncture as one of the investigated interventions.
  3. The study is published in a language other than English and English abstract is not available.

Search process

The searches were carried out on 15 February 2010 and were limited to articles published since 1 January 2009. To identify relevant systematic reviews the information specialist searched the sources listed above using the CAM specialsit collection systematic reviews filter, which emphasizes specificity (precision) over sensitivity. The PubMed Clinical Queries systematic review filter was also used.
More details of search terms and filters used are available by contacting the information specialist. 

Results

The totals number of records retrieved was 538. After removing the duplicates there were 210 to screen. Of these 59 were selected as potential systematic reviews. If any uncertainty existed records were still included in the list. The titles and abstracts of the potential systematic reviews were then screened by the topic editor and categorised by medical specialty, condition or symptom. The final selection includes 39 systematic reviews with a main focus on acupuncture. A separate section lists 7 systematic reviews and a guideline that cover a range of interventions including acupuncture.

In addition a search for relevant, large-scale (100 or more participants) randomised controlled trials (RCTs) was carried out. The totals number of records retrieved was 682. After removing the duplicates there were 386 to screen. The final selection includes 57 RCTs.


 

2010 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture - Contents page

 

]]>

111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture - Obesity

The following relevant studies on this topic have been published between February 2009 and February 2010.

These studies have met our selection criteria but have not been fully appraised. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Lin XM, Li B, Du YH, Xiong J, Sun P. [Systematic evaluation of therapeutic effect of acupuncture for treatment of simple obesity]. Zhongguo Zhen Jiu. 2009;29(10):856-60. [PubMed abstract]

2010 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture - Contents page

111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture - Pain

The following relevant studies on this topic have been published between February 2009 and February 2010.

These studies have met our selection criteria but have not been fully appraised. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

***Editor's picks

  1. Capili B, Anastasi JK, Geiger JN. Adverse event reporting in acupuncture clinical trials focusing on pain. Clinical Journal of Pain. 2010;26(1):43-8. [PubMed abstract]
  2. Langhorst J, Klose P, Musial F, Irnich D, Häuser W. Efficacy of acupuncture in fibromyalgia syndrome--a systematic review with a meta-analysis of controlled clinical trials. Rheumatology (Oxford). 2010;49(4):778-88. [PubMed abstract]
  3. Lin H-L, Song H-M, Zhong W-H, Chen S-Q, Wang S-Z. Effects of different acupuncture and moxibustion treatments on cervical spondylotic radiculopathy: A systematic evaluation. Journal of Clinical Rehabilitative Tissue Engineering Research. 2009;13(46):9017-21.
  4. *** Manheimer E, Cheng K, Linde K, Lao L, Yoo J, Wieland S, van der Windt DAWM, Berman BM, Bouter LM. Acupuncture for peripheral joint osteoarthritis. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2010, Issue 1. Art. No.: CD001977. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD001977.pub2. [Full text]
  5. Martin-Sanchez E, Torralba E, Díaz-Domínguez E, Barriga A, Martin JL. Efficacy of acupuncture for the treatment of fibromyalgia: systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized trials. Open Rheumatology Journal. 2009;3:25-9. [Full text]

2010 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture - Contents page

111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture - Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)

The following relevant studies on this topic have been published between February 2009 and February 2010.

These studies have met our selection criteria but have not been fully appraised. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

***Editor's picks

  1. ***Borud EK, Alraek T, White A, Fonnebo V, Eggen AE, Hammar M, Astrand LL, Theodorsson E, Grimsgaard S. The Acupuncture on Hot Flushes Among Menopausal Women (ACUFLASH) study, a randomized controlled trial. Menopause. 2009; 16(3):484-93. [PubMed abstract]

  8. Chen ZX. [Control study on acupuncture and medication for treatment of primary simple premature ejaculation] Zhongguo Zhen Jiu. 2009; 29(1):13-5. [PubMed abstract]
  9. Chen ZX. [Observation on therapeutic effect of warm needle moxibustion on chronic non-bacterial prostatitis] Zhongguo Zhen Jiu. 2009;29(4):275-8. [PubMed abstract]

A randomized trial comparing acupuncture, simulated acupuncture, and usual care for chronic low back pain. Archives of Internal Medicine. 2009; 169(9):858-66. [PubMed abstract]

  30. Ouyang MW, Qin ZS, Lin CS, Gu MN. [Prophylactic effect of acupuncture on nausea and vomiting after laparoscopic operation] Zhongguo Zhen Jiu. 2009; 29(11):915-8. [PubMed abstract]

  36. Sherman KJ, Cherkin DC, Ichikawa L, Avins AL, Barlow WE, Khalsa PS, Deyo RA. Characteristics of patients with chronic back pain who benefit from acupuncture. BMC Musculoskeletal Disorders. 2009;10:114. [Full text]

  39. Tong FM, Chow SK, Chan PY, Wong AK, Wan SS, Ng RK, Chan G, Chan WS, Ng A, Law CK. A prospective randomised controlled study on efficacies of acupuncture and steroid in treatment of idiopathic peripheral facial paralysis. Acupuncture in Medicine. 2009;27(4):169-73. [PubMed abstract]

  41. Wang JF. [Effect of acupuncture combined with TDP on estrogen and bone metabolism in postmenopausal patients with deficiency of liver and kidney syndrome] Zhongguo Zhen Jiu. 2009; 29(8):623-5. [PubMed abstract]
  42. Wang ZX. [Clinical observation on electroacupuncture at acupoints for treatment of senile radical sciatica] Zhongguo Zhen Jiu. 2009; 29(2):126-8. [PubMed abstract]

111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture - Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

The following relevant studies on this topic have been published between February 2009 and February 2010.

These studies have met our selection criteria but have not been fully appraised. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

 

Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

***Editor's picks

  1. Cao H, Pan X, Li H, Liu J. Acupuncture for treatment of insomnia: a systematic review of randomized controlled trials. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2009;15(11):1171-86. [PubMed abstract]

111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma

Published: 4 May 2010

 

 

 

Introduction

The 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma aims to identify, organise and present the latest information on this topic. We have searched a large number of databases for studies published or updated between March 2009 and March 2010. For more details about our methods, please see the methodology section.

Previously published studies have been included in the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma or can be found by searching this website.

For further information on asthma see the relevant pages from the NHS Evidence - respiratory specialist collection.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma - Commentary
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CHIROPRACTIC,ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,OSTEOPATHY,REFLEXOLOGY,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS A-B,ASTHMA,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,VITAMINS,OMEGA-3 FATTY ACIDS,APRIL 2010,LIPIDS]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma - Commentary

Dr Karen Pilkington, Senior Research Fellow, University of Westminster


In the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in asthma, the focus was primarily on diet and nutritional supplements. This year, the main focus is again on diet and on spinal manipulation including chiropractic and osteopathy. Other therapies covered include acupuncture and reflexology.


Vitamins

One systematic review investigated whether there is a link between asthma and dietary intake or blood levels of vitamins A, C and E (Allen et al. 2009). Following an extensive search, 40 studies were identified. All were observational and comprised 23 case-control, 15 cross-sectional and 2 cohort studies. The participants included adults and children and the research was carried out in a wide range of different countries. The authors carried out a meta-analysis and calculated odds-ratios. They found that low dietary intakes of vitamins A and C were associated with a higher risk of asthma and wheeze. Vitamin E levels did not seem to be related to asthma risk although intake was lower in people with severe asthma than in those with mild asthma.

The findings for vitamins C and E contradict those of a previous meta-analysis (Gao et al. 2009). However, only 10 studies of vitamin C were identified in Gao et al.’s review compared with 32 identified by Allen et al. Initially, it appears that this is due to the exclusion of studies in children but Allen et al. located 22 studies solely in adults. It is more likely to be because, as discussed in the 2009 CAM in Asthma update, searches were limited to MEDLINE (and PubMed although these are essentially the same database). The limitations of a strategy such as this are clear.

Overall, it seems that the conclusions of Allen et al.’s meta-analysis are more likely to be reliable. These suggest that ensuring vitamin C (and vitamin A) intake is adequate is beneficial and may reduce the risk of developing asthma. As yet, based on the conclusions of the current Cochrane review, it is unclear whether vitamin C has a role in the treatment of asthma. 


Omega 3 fatty acids

Two systematic reviews took slightly differing approaches to assess whether omega 3 has a beneficial effect in asthma.

Kremmyda et al. (2009) assessed observational studies of maternal fish intake during pregnancy, lactation and in infancy /early childhood as well as trials of supplementation at the same stages. The overall findings for fish intake were of protective associations in pregnancy, no significant association in lactation and inconsistent findings in infancy/childhood. In the case of fish oil supplements, studies in pregnancy and lactation suggest a possible protective effect. Only two small trials (39 and 29 participants respectively) on fish oil supplementation in children with asthma were identified. These reported conflicting results and the latter trial was conducted in Japan where diet is likely to differ from that in the UK. The review is described as systematic but few details of the methods are provided. MEDLINE and EMBASE were used to search for observational studies but only MEDLINE (plus PubMed) to search for trials. Data from the studies was tabulated but the approach was primarily descriptive.

Anandan et al. (2009) conducted apparently comprehensive searches for randomised controlled trials of omega 3 and omega 6 supplements in the primary prevention of allergic conditions. Four studies assessing the influence of omega 3 supplements on asthma incidence were found, 2 in pregnant women, 1 in women who were breast-feeding and 1 in newborns. Studies in those with existing allergic conditions were excluded. Thus a different group of studies were analysed compared with those in the review described above. Meta-analysis revealed no consistent or clear benefits from the use of omega 3 supplements in preventing asthma. The authors point out that this is contrary to the evidence from basic science and epidemiological studies. It is also contrary to the findings of the review by Kremmyda et al. (2009). However, it does reflect the conclusions of a comprehensive review by the US Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality published in 2004 (Schachter et al.).


Spinal manipulation

The three reviews of spinal manipulation and related treatment approaches varied in their approach but reached similar conclusions.

The first of these is a systematic review of randomised controlled trials (RCTs) of spinal manipulation in asthma (Ernst 2009). Only 3 studies were located, all of which were considered high quality. Manipulation was compared against sham-manipulation and treatment was provided by a chiropractor. None of the studies showed that manipulation was more effective than sham-manipulation.

A second review took a more inclusive approach in searching for studies specifically on chiropractic in patients with asthma. Eight articles of varying design and quality were located (Kaninskyj et al. 2010). The studies showed that although improvements in subjective measures were reported, effects based on objective measures were smaller and none were statistically significant.

The third review addressed a broad area, that of the overall effectiveness of manual therapies, not specifically in asthma (Bronfort et al. 2010). The authors carried out a comprehensive search for systematic reviews, RCTs and evidence-based clinical guidelines.  Four systematic reviews including a Cochrane review were found on manual therapy for asthma. Five RCTs had evaluated various manual therapies including chiropractic (2 trials) and osteopathic manipulative/manual therapy (1 trial). The conclusions for spinal manipulation were similar to those above – that spinal manipulation was not effective for asthma in adults or children when compared with sham manipulation.

The findings are similar to those of the Cochrane review which concludes that ‘There is insufficient evidence to support the use of manual therapies for patients with asthma.’


Acupuncture

Only one systematic review on acupuncture has been published since the 2009 CAM in Asthma update. This focuses on studies in respiratory disease and particularly aimed to identify studies conducted in Japan (Suzuki et al. 2009). The rationale was that these studies are not easily accessible as they are written in Japanese and not listed in MEDLINE. The authors report that 14 trials in asthma were found but these were in fact mainly case series and case reports. Only one trial was located, an N of 1 study. Therefore the findings of this review, while of interest and of value in raising the profile of the Japanese medical databases, is unlikely to affect the conclusion of the Cochrane review on acupuncture in chronic asthma, which is that there is not enough research evidence to make recommendations.


Reflexology

Two systematic reviews published this year included studies of reflexology in asthma. The review of manual therapies (Bronfort et al. 2010) included one study on reflexology which was also mentioned in the 2009 CAM in Asthma update. The review by Ernst (2009) included this study plus an older study. The studies showed no difference between reflexology and no treatment or sham treatment. Thus, all 3 reviews concluded that there is currently insufficient evidence supporting the use of reflexology to treat asthma symptoms.


Other reviews of interest

An integrative review of biological therapies in children was asthma was also published in 2009 (Kealoha). Some details of the methods were provided but the review is primarily descriptive.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma - Methodology
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-B,ASTHMA,APRIL 2010]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma - Methodology

Sources searched

The Cochrane Library (CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHS EED), PubMed (and MEDLINE), EMBASE, AMED, CINAHL, PsycINFO

NHS Evidence - respiratory specialist collection


Selection criteria

Inclusion criteria:

  • Explicit description of search process and statement of methodology (a meta-analysis or a systematic review)
  • Topic relevance (systematic reviews should be focused on asthma or include primary studies on asthma if focus is on specific intervention)
  • Study types: guidance/guidelines, systematic reviews, meta-analyses, HTA reports, cost effectiveness and economic evaluation studies.

Exclusion criteria:

  • The study is not one of the types specified above. 
  • The study is published in a language other than English and English abstract is not available.

Search strategy

The search strategy included terms for asthma, general text words and terms for CAM and selected CAM therapies, including dietary and nutritional therapies, and a methodological filter for systematic reviews. The searches were carried out on 8 April 2010 and were limited to articles published since 1 January 2009.

To identify relevant systematic reviews the information specialist has searched the sources listed above using the CAM specialist collection systematic reviews filter, which emphasizes specificity (precision) over sensitivity. In addition a search of PubMed using the systematic reviews subset was conducted.

More details of the search terms and filters used are available by contacting the information specialist.


Search results

The total number of records retrieved was 147. After removing the duplicates there were 89 citations for screening. Of these 11 were selected as potential systematic reviews. The titles and abstracts were further screened for relevance. The final selection includes 8 systematic reviews and 1 narrative review. As there were few systematic reviews published in the last 12 months, we have also included reviews where the main focus is on a on specific therapy if trials on asthma were included.


2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Asthma - Contents page

]]>

111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain

Published: 13 December 2010

 

 

 

Introduction

This annual evidence update on complementary and alternative medicine for low back pain aims to identify, organise and present the latest information on this topic. We have searched a large number of databases for studies published or updated between September 2009 and September 2010. Previously published studies have been included in the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain or can be found by searching this collection.


For more details about the search methods and the selection process please see the methodology section.

For further information on low back pain see also 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Spinal Diseases and the relevant pages from the NHS Evidence - trauma and orthopaedics and the NHS Evidence - musculoskeletal specialist collections.

 

Contents

  • Evidence on specific therapies and approaches
    • Acupuncture
    • Chiropractic
    • Herbal medicine
    • Other therapies
  • Results of the 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain STOP PRESS: new evidence report
  • Methodology


Acknowledgements

The CAM specialist collection project team would like to acknowledge the contribution made by a number of people to the development of this annual evidence update and thank them for all their efforts. In particular Prof Alan Breen and Dr Mike Cummings who wrote the expert commentaries.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Acupuncture
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,SPINAL PROBLEMS,CONDITIONS,MUSCULOSKELETAL,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,COMPLEMENTARY/ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,BACK PAIN,CONDITIONS A-B,DECEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Acupuncture

Mike Cummings, Medical Director of the British Medical Acupuncture Society


Since the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain there has been one further systematic review of acupuncture for chronic low back pain.1 This review found that acupuncture can be superior to usual care, and that the recommendation of the recent NICE guideline for a course of acupuncture as a treatment option for chronic low back pain, offered according to patient preference, is justified.2 Two more general reviews confirm but do not add to the existing evidence for acupuncture in low back pain.3,4


No new large clinical trials of efficacy or effectiveness have been published since the 2009 update, however, some papers investigated the patient and therapist characteristics that predict response to acupuncture in large studies where the main results have already been published. Sherman and colleagues found little evidence for the existence of subgroups that responded differently to acupuncture in a population of 638 participants from a previous clinical trial.5 In a further paper derived from analysis of the same clinical trial data, Sherman and colleagues found that pre-treatment expectations and preferences did not predict response to acupuncture.6 This runs somewhat contrary to the existing data on expectation in acupuncture trials, and suggests that expectation, preference and patient practitioner interactions may be more complex than anticipated.


When it comes to practitioner characteristics, Witt and colleagues have reported some interesting results from analysis of data from 9990 patients with a variety of chronic pain conditions (including low back pain) treated by 2781 physicians in Germany.7 They found that neither the physicians’ length of training nor duration of experience in acupuncture predicted outcomes; however, they did find a difference between the results of internist as compared with othopedists – the results of the former group being significantly better.


References

  1. Trigkilidas D. Acupuncture therapy for chronic lower back pain: a systematic review. Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England. 2010, 92(7):595-8. [PubMed abstract]
  2. Savigny P, Kuntze S, Watson P, Underwood M, Ritchie G , Cotterell M, Hill D, Browne N, Buchanan E, Coffey P, Dixon P, Drummond C, Flanagan M, Greenough,C, Griffiths M, Halliday-Bell J, Hettinga D, Vogel S, Walsh D. Low Back Pain: Early Management of Persistent Non-specific Low Back Pain. London: National Collaborating Centre for Primary Care and Royal College of General Practitioners, 2009. [Full text]
  3. Hopton A, MacPherson H. Acupuncture for chronic pain: is acupuncture more than an effective placebo? A systematic review of pooled data from meta-analyses. Pain Practice. 2010, 10(2):94-102. [PubMed abstract]
  4. Rubinstein SM, van Middelkoop M, Kuijpers T, Ostelo R, Verhagen AP, de Boer MR, Koes BW, van Tulder MW. A systematic review on the effectiveness of complementary and alternative medicine for chronic non-specific low-back pain. European Spine Journal. 2010, 19(8):1213-28. [PubMed abstract]
  5. Sherman KJ, Cherkin DC, Ichikawa L, Avins AL, Barlow WE, Khalsa PS, Deyo RA. Characteristics of patients with chronic back pain who benefit from acupuncture. BMC Musculoskeletal Disorders. 2009 Sep 21;10:114. [Full text]
  6. Sherman KJ, Cherkin DC, Ichikawa L, Avins AL, Delaney K, Barlow WE, Khalsa PS, Deyo RA. Treatment expectations and preferences as predictors of outcome of acupuncture for chronic back pain. Spine (Phila Pa 1976). 2010, 35(15):1471-7. [PubMed abstract]
  7. Witt CM, Lüdtke R, Wegscheider K, Willich SN. Physician characteristics and variation in treatment outcomes: are better qualified and experienced physicians more successful in treating patients with chronic pain with acupuncture? Journal of Pain. 2010 May;11(5):431-5. [PubMed abstract]

Link back to 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Chiropractic
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CHIROPRACTIC,SPINAL PROBLEMS,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,COMPLEMENTARY/ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,BACK PAIN,CONDITIONS A-B,DECEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Chiropractic

Prof Alan Breen, Anglo-European College of Chiropractic


Evidence, Education, Safety and Guidelines

This commentary will focus on some pragmatic aspects of the potential contribution of chiropractic to the public’s health needs. 


Chiropractic as it is Practised

Chiropractic is often mistakenly represented as being synonymous with spinal manipulation and evaluated accordingly. A recent Cochrane review1 attempted to address this discrepancy by systematically reviewing trials of the combined interventions for low back pain that are used by chiropractors (e.g. manipulation, exercise, lifestyle advice, education, orthotics) compared with other common treatment approaches, which sometimes also included these. 

The study identified 12 randomised trials (2887 participants). Its meta-analysis found that the chiropractic interventions were only slightly better than those to which they were compared, and only in the short-term, although many of the studies reportedly had a high risk of bias. The authors identified a need for further studies “examining the relative effects of different frequencies of visits to chiropractors and research to identify diagnostic subsets within non-specific low-back pain that may more favourably respond to chiropractic interventions so that chiropractic may be better directed”. In other words, research needs to more closely reflect day to day practice.


Education and Safety  

In light of a large increase in use of chiropractic in developing and developed countries, the World Health Organisation published guidance on basic training and safety in chiropractic2. This was the result of a WHO Consultation meeting held in Milan in December 2004, which brought together experts, national authorities and professional organizations from all over the world. This resulted in a guideline on the minimum requirement for chiropractic education, as a reference for use in examining and licensing. It also provided a review of contraindications to minimize the risk of accidents.

Two main educational paths were recommended. The first starts either at university entrance level or as a conversion from other prior medical or health care professional education. This pathway leads to a full chiropractic qualification at extended bachelors or masters level, that can be recommended to national accrediting agencies. Essential skills are those of a primary contact health practitioner and include the ability to make a differential diagnosis based on knowledge of the health sciences, to plan care, to apply the patient management and psychomotor skills of a practitioner of neuromusculoskeletal rehabilitation and to consult and refer appropriately.

The second path does not lead to a full qualification, but to a minimal registerable standard, meant as a temporary measure for countries or regions without regulations, but intending to introduce legislation governing the practice of chiropractic.

The Guideline also addressed patient safety. Despite recognising that chiropractic is not synonymous with, or limited to, the application of specific manipulative techniques, only the risks of manipulation were considered. These risks were almost exclusively linked to failure to recognise serious underlying pathologies and post-traumatic risks. However, the guideline also identified the failure to differentiate patients with psychogenic complaints as inappropriate for manipulation as a primary therapy and the risk of delaying appropriate referral.


Care Guidance

Two new evidence-based guidelines for the early management of persistent back and neck pain that address the interventions used by chiropractors have recently emerged: 

NICE Guidance

The NICE back pain guideline3 is a primary care guideline that emphasises patient-centred care and shared decision-making.  It identifies a ‘window of opportunity’ to immediately help patients with persistent non-specific back pain of 6 week to 12 months duration by first offering them advice on self-management, then referring them early from general practice to a service which can provide a structured exercise program, manual therapy, including manipulation, and/or a course of acupuncture needling – each of up to 12 weeks’ duration as necessary. If these are not effective, a more intensive, but shorter (8 week) combined physical and psychological treatment programme can be considered. Referral for possible surgery is only recommended if these have been tried and failed. Imaging, in the form of an MR scan, is only recommended for this group of patients if surgical referral is contemplated.

All of the NICE guideline’s initial interventions are available within the treatment options of most chiropractors.

Canadian Guidance

The Canadian Guideline on the evidence-based treatment of adult neck pain that is not due to whiplash4 is specifically for chiropractors. It proposes a management algorithm that incorporates a system of triage, management, referral and discharge, dependent on findings. It is strongly focussed on case review, reassessment and adaptation of care to suit a patient’s changing needs. 

The main treatment recommendations are based on the evidence for short, medium and long term effects of education, manual treatment, exercise and other interventions used by chiropractors. It also balances these against the evidence in relation to the natural history of acute and chronic neck pain and makes helpful distinctions between the different types of elective continued care termed ‘support’, ‘maintenance’ and ‘wellness’.

This Canadian Guideline incorporates advice on risk management in relation to neck pain, identifying areas for heightened vigilance, with a separate care path relating to the exclusion of patients with suspected cerebro-basilar or cervical arterial dissection. It is also one of the few guidelines that ends with a section on ‘frequently-asked questions’ that practitioners may be inclined to ask.


A UK Service Guideline

The UK Musculoskeletal Services Framework5, published in 2006, advocates a ‘joined-up’ approach for the management of common musculoskeletal disorders in the NHS. It proposes the introduction of multidisciplinary Musculoskeletal Clinics as ‘Shared Services’ between primary health care and hospitals. These include chiropractors, along with a number of other musculoskeletal health professionals, and are designed to provide non-hospital specialist help across the breadth of these disorders. This is to provide patients with ‘speedy pain control and clear access to services to meet their day-to-day needs at times of difficulty’. A subsequent evaluation of musculoskeletal services by the patient forum, the Arthritis and Musculoskeletal Alliance6, reported poor adoption of the Framework, which is considered to be unsatisfactory progress for patients in the UK during the WHO Bone and Joint Decade.


Conclusion

The slow pace of integration of chiropractic into UK mainstream health care, despite its having become publicly regulated, appears to parallel that of the adoption of back pain guidelines. Both require changes in patient management techniques and referral routes7. A similar situation seems to have occurred for depression guidelines8. This contrasts sharply with the adoption of new evidence for the treatment of asthma9, where only changes in prescribing were required. Despite offering care that meet evidence-based and guideline-consistent criteria, therefore, chiropractic in the UK over the past 10 years has apparently moved little from the crossroads between mainstream and alternative health care10.


References

  1. Walker BF, French SD, Grant W, Green S. Combined chiropractic interventions for low-back pain. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2010, Issue 4. Art. No.: CD005427. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD005427.pub2. [Full text]
  2. World Health Organisation. WHO guidelines on basic training and safety in chiropractic. Geneva: World Health Organization, 2005. [Full text]
  3. Savigny P, Kuntze S, Watson P, Underwood M, Ritchie G , Cotterell M, Hill D, Browne N, Buchanan E, Coffey P, Dixon P, Drummond C, Flanagan M, Greenough,C, Griffiths M, Halliday-Bell J, Hettinga D, Vogel S, Walsh D. Low Back Pain: Early Management of Persistent Non-specific Low Back Pain. London: National Collaborating Centre for Primary Care and Royal College of General Practitioners, 2009. [Full text]
  4. Canadian Chiropractic Association (CCA) atCFoCRB. Chiropractic clinical practice guideline: evidence-based treatment of adult neck pain not due to whiplash. Journal of the Canadian Chiropractic Association. 2005, 49:158-209. [Full text]
  5. Department of Health. The Musculoskeletal Services Framework. London: Department of Health, 2006:1-67. [Full text]
  6. ARMA. Joint Working? An audit of the implementation of the Department of Health's musculoskeletal services framework: Arthritis and Musculoskeletal Alliance, 2009:54. [Full text]
  7. Barnett AG, Underwood MR, Vickers MR. Effect of UK national guidelines on services to treat patients with acute low back pain: follow up questionnaire survey. British Medical Journal. 1999, 318:919-20. [Full text]
  8. Thompson C, Kinmonth AL, Stevens L, Peveler RC, Stevens A, Ostler KJ, Pickering RM, Baker NG, Henson A, Preece J, Cooper D, Campbell MJ. Effects of a clinical-practice guideline and practice-based education on detection and outcome of depression in primary care: Hampshire Depression Project randomised controlled trial. The Lancet. 2000, 355:185-91. [PubMed abstract]
  9. Dennis SM, Vickers MR, Frost CD, Price JF, Barnes PJ. Effect of the asthma management guidelines on recruitment to a RCT of early introduction of inhaled steriods in asthma. Thorax. 1997, 52:A18.
  10. Meeker WC, Haldeman S. Chiropractic: A profession at the crossroads of mainstream and alternative medicine. Annals of Internal Medicine. 2002,136:216-27. [PubMed abstract]

Link back to 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain

 

]]>

111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Herbal medicine

The following relevant studies have been published since September 2009.

These studies have met our selection criteria. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.


Systematic reviews

No systematic reviews with a major focus on herbal medicine have been published in the last year. The following review covers a number of CAM therapies including herbal medicine.

Rubinstein SM, van Middelkoop M, Kuijpers T, Ostelo R, Verhagen AP, de Boer MR, Koes BW, van Tulder MW. A systematic review on the effectiveness of complementary and alternative medicine for chronic non-specific low-back pain. European Spine Journal. 2010, 19(8):1213-28. [PubMed abstract]


Overviews of primary and secondary research

The following review covers a number of natural health products including herbal medicines.

Gagnier JJ. Evidence based review of natural health products for non-specific low back pain. Open Pain Journal. 2010, 3(1):52-9. [Full text]


Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)

da Silva AG, de Sousa CP, Koehler J, Fontana J, Christo AG, Guedes-Bruni RR. Evaluation of an extract of Brazilian arnica (Solidago chilensis Meyen, Asteraceae) in treating lumbago. Phytotherapy Research. 2010, 24(2):283-7. [PubMed abstract]

Giannetti BM, Staiger C, Bulitta M, Predel HG. Efficacy and safety of comfrey root extract ointment in the treatment of acute upper or lower back pain: results of a double-blind, randomised, placebo controlled, multicentre trial. British Journal of Sports Medicine. 2010, 44(9):637-41. [PubMed abstrract]

Staiger C, Giannetti BM, Tschaikin M. Comfrey root extract ointment in the treatment of acute upper or lower back pain: Results of a double-blind, randomised, placebo-controlled, multicenter trial. Planta Medica. 2009, 75(9). [Duplicate publication] 


For more information on this topic see the expert commentary from the 2009 AEU on CAM for Low Back Pain.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Methodology
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DECEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Methodology

The annual evidence update on CAM for Low Back Pain aims to identify, organise and present the latest information on this topic. We have searched comprehensively a large number of databases, covering the period from September 2009 to September 2010. Previously published studies have been included in the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain.


Sources searched


The Cochrane Library (CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHS EED), PubMed (and MEDLINE), EMBASE, AMED, CINAHL, PsycINFO, the NHS Evidence - musculoskeletal and NHS Evidence - trauma and orthopaedics specialist collections.


Selection criteria
Inclusion criteria:

- Study types: guidance/guidelines, systematic reviews, meta-analyses, HTA reports, cost effectiveness and economic evaluation studies, RCTs
- Focused on low back pain
- CAM interventions

To identify systematic reviews the definition of a systematic review from the Cochrane Collaboration Glossary was used:

“A review of a clearly formulated question that uses systematic and explicit methods to identify, select, and critically appraise relevant research, and to collect and analyse data from the studies that are included in the review. Statistical methods (meta-analysis) may or may not be used to analyse and summarise the results of the included studies.”

Exclusion criteria:

- Main focus is not on low back pain
- Not CAM
- Other study/publication types – e.g., animal studies, in vitro studies, narrative reviews, editorials, letters, comments
- The study is published in a language other than English and English abstract is not available


Search strategy

The search strategy included text words and indexing terms for low back pain, for CAM in general and for specific CAM therapies, and methodological filters for systematic reviews and randomised controlled trials (RCTs).

The search strategy for low back pain is based on the Cochrane Back Group strategy.

Below is an example of the strategy used to search the MEDLINE database (NHS Search 2). 

1. (acupuncture OR acupressure OR electroacupuncture OR "auricular therapy" OR auriculotherapy).ti,ab
2. exp ACUPUNCTURE/ OR exp ACUPUNCTURE THERAPY/
3. ("Alexander technique" OR "Alexander principle").ti,ab
4. (aromatherapy OR "aroma therapy" OR "essential oil*" OR "volatile oil*").ti,ab
5. exp OILS, VOLATILE/ OR exp AROMATHERAPY/
6. (chiropractic OR "spinal manipulation").ti,ab
7. exp CHIROPRACTIC/ OR exp MANIPULATION, CHIROPRACTIC/
8. exp MANIPULATION, SPINAL/
9. (homeop* OR homoeop*).ti,ab
10. exp HOMEOPATHY/
11. (hypnosis OR hypnotiz* OR hypnotis* OR hypnotherapy OR "hypnotic susceptibility" OR autosuggestion OR autohypnosis OR self-hypnosis).ti,ab
12. exp HYPNOSIS/
13. exp SUGGESTION/
14. massage.ti,ab
15. exp MASSAGE/
16. meditat*.ti,ab
17. exp MEDITATION/
18. osteopath*.ti,ab
19. exp OSTEOPATHIC MEDICINE/
20. exp MANIPULATION, OSTEOPATHIC/
21. (reflexolog* OR "zone therapy" OR reflexotherapy).ti,ab
22. (yoga OR yogic OR asanas OR dhyana OR pranayama).ti,ab
23. exp YOGA/
24. (herb* OR phyto* OR "plant extract").ti,ab
25. exp PLANTS, MEDICINAL/ OR exp PHYTOTHERAPY/ OR exp PLANT EXTRACTS/ OR exp DRUGS, CHINESE HERBAL/ OR exp HERB-DRUG INTERACTIONS/
26. ("art therapy" OR "autogenic training" OR Ayurved* OR mindfulness OR mbsr OR "music therapy" OR naturopath* OR relaxation OR "tai chi" OR "therapeutic touch" OR "Chinese medicine" OR TCM OR "traditional medicine").ti,ab
27. exp ART THERAPY/
28. exp AUTOGENIC TRAINING/
29. exp MEDICINE, AYURVEDIC/
30. exp MUSIC THERAPY/
31. exp NATUROPATHY/
32. exp TAI JI/
33. exp THERAPEUTIC TOUCH/ OR exp MENTAL HEALING/
34. exp MEDICINE, CHINESE TRADITIONAL/
35. exp MEDICINE, TRADITIONAL/
36. ("alternative medicine*" OR "alternative therap*" OR "complementary medicine*" OR "complementary therap*").ti,ab;
37. exp COMPLEMENTARY THERAPIES/
38. 1 OR 2 OR 3 OR 4 OR 5 OR 6 OR 7 OR 8 OR 9 OR 10 OR 11 OR 12 OR 13 OR 14 OR 15 OR 16 OR 17 OR 18 OR 19 OR 20 OR 21 OR 22 OR 23 OR 24 OR 25 OR 26 OR 27 OR 28 OR 29 OR 30 OR 31 OR 32 OR 33 OR 34 OR 35 OR 36 OR 37
39. diet*.ti,ab
40. exp DIET/
41. "nutrition* therap*".ti,ab
42. exp NUTRITION THERAPY/
43. food.ti,ab
44. exp FOOD/
45. exp BEVERAGES/
46. (micronutrient* OR mineral* OR vitamin*).ti,ab
47. exp MICRONUTRIENTS/ OR exp VITAMINS/
48. exp MINERALS/
49. antioxidant*.ti,ab
50. exp ANTIOXIDANTS/
51. ((diet* OR nutrition* OR nutraceuti* OR nutriceuti*) AND supplement*).ti,ab
52. exp DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS/
53. 39 OR 40 OR 41 OR 42 OR 43 OR 44 OR 45 OR 46 OR 47 OR 48 OR 49 OR 50 OR 51 OR 52
54. 38 OR 53
55. "back pain".ti,ab
56. exp BACK PAIN/
57. backache.ti,ab
58. dorsalgia.ti,ab
59. "lumbar pain".ti,ab
60. lumbago.ti,ab
61. sciatica.ti,ab
62. exp SCIATICA/
63. 55 OR 56 OR 57 OR 58 OR 59 OR 60 OR 61 OR 62
64. 54 AND 63
65. 64 [Limit to: Publication Year 2009-2010]

More details of the search terms and filters used are available by contacting the information specialist. 


Search results

The total number of records retrieved was 1615. After removing the duplicates there were 766 citations. Of these, 135 were selected as potential systematic reviews or other relevant study types. The titles and abstracts were further screened for relevance. Studies with a main focus on non-clinical topics, narrative reviews and protocols of on-going systematic reviews were excluded at this stage.

The final selection includes 26 systematic reviews, meta-analyses, systematic overviews of primary and secondary research, and randomised controlled trials (RCTs). Based on the identified studies several topics were selected for preparing commentaries on the evidence about the use of specific therapies in the management of low back pain.

A list of all relevant studies is given in the Results page.

 

Link back to 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain

 

]]>

Qualitative study

Yoga

111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM for Low Back Pain - Results

The following relevant studies on this topic have been published between September 2009 and September 2010.


These studies have met our selection criteria. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.


Systematic reviews and meta-analyses

  4. Kent P, Mjøsund HL, Petersen DH. Does targeting manual therapy and/or exercise improve patient outcomes in nonspecific low back pain? A systematic review. BMC Medicine. 2010 Apr 8;8:22. [Full text]

  4. Kapitza KP, Passie T, Bernateck M, Karst M. First non-contingent respiratory biofeedback placebo versus contingent biofeedback in patients with chronic low back pain: a randomized, controlled, double-blind trial. Applied Psychophysiology and Biofeedback. 2010, 35(3):207-17. [PubMed abstract]

Other studies of interest

document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression

Published: 4 October 2010

 

 

 

Introduction

This annual evidence update on complementary and alternative medicine for depression aims to identify, organise and present the latest information on this topic. We have searched a large number of databases for studies published or updated since the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression.

For more details about the search methods and the selection process please see the Methodology section.

This update is linked to the 2010 Annual Evidence Update on depression produced by NHS Evidence - mental health. For further information on depression including information on other treatments, see the relevant pages from the NHS Evidence - mental health specialist collection.


Contents

  • Use of CAM
  • Guidelines and general systematic reviews
  • Evidence on specific therapies and approaches
    • Acupuncture 
    • Diet and nutrition
    • Herbal medicine (excluding St John's wort)
    • Massage
    • Meditation and mindfulness
    • St John's wort (Hypericum perforatum)
    • Yoga
    • Other therapies
  • Results of the 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression
  • Methodology
