document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Acupuncture
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Acupuncture

Dr Karen Pilkington, Senior Research Fellow, University of Westminster


Since the 2009 Annual Evidence Update, an updated version of the Cochrane review of acupuncture for depression has been published (Smith et al 2010). The number of trials included has increased substantially, from 7 to 30 (with a total of 2,812 participants). The scope has broadened as trials of acupuncture in post stroke depression (PSD) have also been included. Various types of acupuncture such as manual acupuncture, electro-acupuncture and laser acupuncture were tested. The majority of trials compared manual or electro-acupuncture with medication and found no difference in effect between groups. The authors found that ‘There was insufficient evidence of a consistent beneficial effect from acupuncture compared with a wait list control or sham acupuncture control. Two trials found acupuncture may have an additive benefit when combined with medication compared with medication alone. A subgroup of participants with depression as a co-morbidity experienced a reduction in depression with manual acupuncture compared with SSRIs (RR 1.66, 95%CI 1.03, 2.68) (three trials, 94 participants).’ Overall, the authors found insufficient evidence to recommend acupuncture for the treatment of people with depression.


A second systematic review included 35 trials in major depressive disorder and PSD (Zhang et al 2010). The authors concluded that acupuncture was comparable to antidepressants in improving clinical response and symptoms in major depression, but that it was not different from sham acupuncture. Acupuncture was superior to antidepressants and waitlist controls in improving both response and symptom severity of PSD. The incidence of side effects appeared lower with acupuncture than with antidepressants. A further systematic review came to similar conclusions (Xiong et al 2010).


References

Systematic reviews

Smith CA, Hay PPJ, MacPherson H. Acupuncture for depression. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2010, Issue 1. Art. No.: CD004046. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004046.pub3. [Full text]

Xiong J, Du YH, Liu JL, Lin XM, Sun P, Xiao L, et al. Acupuncture versus western medicine for depression neurosis: A systematic review. Chinese Journal of Evidence Based Medicine. 2009, 9(9):969-975. [DARE provisional record]

Zhang ZJ, Chen HY, Yip K, Ng R, Wong VT. The effectiveness and safety of acupuncture therapy in depressive disorders: systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Affective Disorders. 2010, 124(1-2):9-21. [PubMed abstract]

Other systematic reviews

Randomised controlled trials

Fu WB, Fan L, Zhu XP, He Q, Wang L, Zhuang LX, et al. Depressive neurosis treated by acupuncture for regulating the liver--a report of 176 cases. J Tradit Chin Med 2009 Jun;29(2):83-6. [PubMed abstract] 

Manber R, Schnyer RN, Lyell D, Chambers AS, Caughey AB, Druzin M, et al. Acupuncture for depression during pregnancy: a randomized controlled trial. Obstet Gynecol 2010 Mar;115(3):511-20. [PubMed abstract] 

Wang XJ, Wang LL, Qiao HF, Li JB. [Observation on effective characteristics of acupuncture combined with medicine on depression of different syndrome types]. Zhongguo Zhen Jiu 2009 Sep;29(9):699-702. [PubMed abstract] 

Xie YC, Li YH. [Observation on therapeutic effect of acupuncture at Zhongwan (CV 12) and Si-guan points combined with reinforcing-reducing manipulation of respiration for treatment of depression]. Zhongguo Zhen Jiu 2009 Jul;29(7):521-4. [PubMed abstract] 

Zhang WJ, Yang XB, Zhong BL. Combination of acupuncture and fluoxetine for depression: a randomized, double-blind, sham-controlled trial. J Altern Complement Med 2009 Aug;15(8):837-44. [PubMed abstract] 

Other trials

Chang Y, Liu YP, Liu CF. The effect on serotonin and MDA levels in depressed patients with insomnia when far-infrared rays are applied to acupoints. Am J Chin Med 2009;37(5):837-42.

Liu LY, Lu Q, Wang LL. Influence of electro-acupuncture on the side effects of fluoxetine on depression patients. J Tradit Chin Med 2009 Dec;29(4):271-4.

Sun H, Zhao H, Zhang J, Bao F, Wei J, Wang DH, et al. [Effect of acupuncture at Baihui (GV 20) and Zusanli (ST 36) on the level of serum inflammatory cytokines in patients with depression]. Zhongguo Zhen Jiu 2010 Mar;30(3):195-9.

document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Diet and nutrition
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Diet and nutrition

Dr Karen Pilkington, Senior Research Fellow, University of Westminster


A large number of studies have been published that examine various aspects of the effects of diet on mental health. Many are observational studies or surveys that attempt to assess whether there is an association between the development of depression and intake of particular nutrients. The studies selected for this Annual Evidence Update consist of systematic reviews and randomised controlled trials of nutrient supplements specifically in depression.

Numerous reviews of omega 3 fatty acids and depression have been published. Due to differing inclusion criteria and search strategies, varied numbers of trials are evaluated. One of the more comprehensive reviews included a total of 35 RCTs in which depressed mood was assessed (Appleton et al 2010). After conducting a series of meta-analyses, the authors reported that although trial evidence of the effects of omega 3 fatty acids had increased, it was difficult to summarise because of the variation in the trials and the findings. The overall conclusion was that ‘The evidence available provides some support of a benefit of n-3 PUFAs in individuals with diagnosed depressive illness’.


Systematic reviews


Appleton KM, Rogers PJ, Ness AR. Updated systematic review and meta-analysis of the effects of n-3 long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids on depressed mood. American Journal of Clinical Nutrition. 2010, 91(3):757-70. [PubMed abstract]
Eight databases searched up to April 2009 for trials that randomly assigned participants to receive n-3 PUFAs/fish, measured depressed mood, used human participants, and included a comparison group. Conclusions: see above


Lin PY, Huang SY, Su KP. A meta-analytic review of polyunsaturated fatty acid compositions in patients with depression. Biological Psychiatry. 2010, 68(2):140-7. [PubMed abstract]
Meta-analysis of 14 trials. Conclusion: The results showed lower levels of EPA, DHA, and total n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids in patients with depression, thus implying that n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids play a role in the pathogenesis of depression.


Kraguljac NV, Montori VM, Pavuluri M, Chai HS, Wilson BS, Unal SS. Efficacy of omega-3 Fatty acids in mood disorders - a systematic review and metaanalysis. Psychopharmacology Bulletin. 2009, 42(3):39-54. [PubMed abstract]
Searches up to 2008, trials in mood disorders, 21 located, 13 of these eligible for meta-analysis. Conclusions: The available evidence suggests that omega-3 fatty acids are a potential treatment of depressive disorders, but not mania. The unexplained between-study inconsistency and imprecision of the pooled estimates mitigate this suggestion.


Martins JG. EPA but not DHA appears to be responsible for the efficacy of omega-3 long chain polyunsaturated fatty acid supplementation in depression: evidence from a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. Journal of the American College of Nutrition. 2009, 28(5):525-42. [PubMed abstract]
Searches of PubMed only


Murakami K, Sasaki S. Dietary intake and depressive symptoms: a systematic review of observational studies. Molecular Nutrition & Food Research. 2010, 54(4):471-88. [PubMed abstract]
Search of PubMed for observational studies only


Rocha Araujo DM, Vilarim MM, Nardi AE. What is the effectiveness of the use of polyunsaturated fatty acid omega-3 in the treatment of depression? Expert Review of Neurotherapeutics. 2010,  10(7):1117-29. [PubMed abstract]
19 studies identified (four double-blind randomized studies, four cohort, two cross-sectional and nine case-control studies). Findings: 13 showed a significant positive association between omega-3 and depression, while six studies did not show a relationship between the referred variables.


Randomised controlled trials


Folic acid and vitamin B12

Walker JG, Mackinnon AJ, Batterham P, Jorm AF, Hickie I, McCarthy A, et al. Mental health literacy, folic acid and vitamin B12, and physical activity for the prevention of depression in older adults: randomised controlled trial. Br J Psychiatry 2010 Jul;197(1):45-54. [PubMed abstract]

Basoglu C, Ates MA, Algul A, Ipcioglu OM, Gecici O, Yilmaz O, et al. Adjuvant folate with escitalopram treatment and homocystein, folate, vitamin B-12 levels in patients with major depressive disorder. Klinik Psikofarmakoloji Bulteni. 2009, 19:135-142. [In Turkish]


Micronutrients

Nguyen PH, Grajeda R, Melgar P, Marcinkevage J, DiGirolamo AM, Flores R, et al. Micronutrient supplementation may reduce symptoms of depression in Guatemalan women. Arch Latinoam Nutr 2009 Sep;59(3):278-86. [PubMed abstract] 


Omega 3 fatty acids

Anon. [Public title] The Beyond Ageing Project: Phase II: A selective prevention trial using novel pharmacotherapies in an older age cohort at risk for depression; [Scientific title] In older adults (60+ years) at risk for depression, can sertraline and/or omega-3 fatty acids compared with a placebo, reduce or prevent depressive symptoms, incidence of new cases of depression and/or cognitive decline. WHO. 2010. [Ongoing trial ACTRN12610000032055]

Lesperance F, Frasure-Smith N, St-Andre E, Turecki G, Lesperance P, Wisniewski SR. The efficacy of omega-3 supplementation for major depression: a randomized controlled trial. J Clin Psychiatry 2010 Jun 15. [PubMed abstract]

Mischoulon D, Papakostas GI, Dording CM, Farabaugh AH, Sonawalla SB, Agoston AM, et al. A double-blind, randomized controlled trial of ethyl-eicosapentaenoate for major depressive disorder. Journal of Clinical Psychiatry. 2009 Dec;70(12):1636-44. [Full text]

Rondanelli M, Giacosa A, Opizzi A, Pelucchi C, La VC, Montorfano G, et al. Effect of omega-3 fatty acids supplementation on depressive symptoms and on health-related quality of life in the treatment of elderly women with depression: a double-blind, placebo-controlled, randomized clinical trial. J Am Coll Nutr 2010 Feb;29(1):55-64. [PubMed abstract]


SAMe

Papakostas GI, Mischoulon D, Shyu I, Alpert JE, Fava M. S-Adenosyl Methionine (SAMe) Augmentation of Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors for Antidepressant Nonresponders With Major Depressive Disorder: A Double-Blind, Randomized Clinical Trial. Am J Psychiatry 2010, 167(8):942-8. [PubMed abstract]


Selenium

Mokhber N, Namjoo M, Tara F, Boskabadi H, Rayman MP, Ghayour-Mobarhan M, et al. Effect of supplementation with selenium on postpartum depression: a randomized double-blind placebo-controlled trial. J Matern Fetal Neonatal Med 2010 Jun 8. [PubMed abstract]


Zinc

Sawada T, Yokoi K. Effect of zinc supplementation on mood states in young women: a pilot study. Eur J Clin Nutr 2010 Mar;64(3):331-3. [PubMed abstract]

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Guidelines and general systematic reviews
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS D-E,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Guidelines and general systematic reviews

Dr Karen Pilkington, Senior Research Fellow, University of Westminster


Guidelines

Guidelines on the non-pharmacological management of depression developed by the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) were published this year. These guidelines cover a number of herbs, nutritional supplements, and complementary therapies. The former groups included folate, Hypericum extract (St John’s wort), inositol, polyunsaturated fatty acids, S-adenosyl-L-methionine (SAMe) and others. For all except St John’s wort, insufficient evidence of benefit was found to support use in depression. Recommendations for St John’s wort are as follows:

  • Healthcare professionals should not advise use of extract of Hypericum (St John’s wort) for patients with depression due to the lack of standardisation of dose and the risk of interactions with several common medications including the contraceptive pill.
  • Where individual patients are using extract of Hypericum (St John’s wort) for treatment of depression, the general practitioner should facilitate full consideration of potential drug interactions.

The section on complementary and alternative therapies covers acupuncture, animal assisted therapy, homeopathy, light therapy, massage therapy, yoga and other therapies. For each of these, the guidelines group found that ‘There is insufficient evidence on which to base a recommendation’. Hypnotherapy, mindfulness-based cognitive therapy and music therapy are included in the section on psychological therapies.


The Canadian Network for Mood and Anxiety Treatments (CANMAT) clinical guidelines for the management of major depressive disorder in adults published in 2009 (Anderson and Haddad, Kennedy et al) also include a section on CAM (section 5) (Ravindran et al 2009). These guidelines are based on a question-answer format and on updated systematic reviews. Recommendations were graded according to Level of Evidence using pre-defined criteria. The relevant recommendations are as follows:

  • There is Level 1 evidence to support light therapy in seasonal MDD (major depressive disorder) and St. John's wort in mild to moderate MDD. 
  • There is also some evidence for the use of exercise, yoga and sleep deprivation, as well as for omega-3 fatty acids and SAM-e. 
  • Support for other natural health products and therapies is still limited

The overall conclusion was that ‘Some CAM treatments have evidence of benefit in MDD. However, problems with standardization and safety concerns may limit their applicability in clinical practice’.


General systematic reviews 

A review of 13 national and international guidelines with additional literature searches was published this year (Dirmaier et al 2010). Limited details of the methods are available as the paper was published in German but the aim was to evaluate the evidence on a range of treatments. Those considered to be supported by an adequate level of evidence included relaxation techniques, art therapies (music, dance), body-oriented therapies and massage.

The American Psychiatric Association's Task Force on Complementary and Alternative Medicine also conducted a review of the evidence for CAM in major depressive disorder (Freeman et al 2010a). The report was based on a review of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) for commonly used CAM treatments such as omega-3 fatty acids, St John's wort (Hypericum), folate, S-adenosyl-l-methionine (SAMe), acupuncture, light therapy, exercise, and mindfulness psychotherapies. Promising results were revealed but larger, more rigorous trials were also recommended.

Another review focused on examining patient characteristics, placebo-response rates, and outcome differences in RCTs of CAM and standard antidepressants for major depressive disorder (Freeman et al 2010b). It appears that, although patients had similar levels of depression, participants in CAM trials were more likely to be female and to have a lower placebo-response rate compared to those in standard antidepressant trials. This is likely to be of relevance when considering applying the results of trials in clinical practice.

The final review in this section addressed the question of whether adjuvant use of herbal medicines or nutritional supplements had the potential to increase the efficacy of conventional drug therapy and decrease their side-effects by allowing lower doses to be prescribed (Sarris et al 2010). The authors found ‘encouraging evidence for the use of omega-3 fatty acids, SAMe, folic acid and l-tryptophan adjuvantly with antidepressants to enhance response and improve efficacy’. However, adjuvant use of herbal therapies had not been sufficiently studied to date.


Overall conclusions

There is currently considerable interest in the potential of complementary therapies in the management of depression. Exercise is in general recommended in guidelines and one could consider whether some of the ‘complementary’ forms of exercise such as qigong, tai chi or yoga might be beneficial in or preferred by some people (as discussed in the 2009 Annual Evidence Update). There is good evidence for light therapy in seasonal affective disorder but a lack of consistent evidence of benefit in non-seasonal depression. St John’s wort is now supported by a considerable body of evidence on its antidepressive effects. However, health professionals are advised not to recommend its use due potential interactions and variation in the products that are available. It does appear that there are a number of other promising therapies, several of which have a relatively low risk associated with use. Further investigation of each of these appears to be required. In addition, as many people with depression choose to use complementary therapies, either in place of or in addition to conventional treatment, increased patient education about potential benefits and harms is also likely to be beneficial.  


References

Anderson IM, Haddad PM. CANMAT guidelines for depression: Clear and user-friendly. Journal of Affective Disorders. 2009, 117(Suppl 1):S3-S4. [PubMed record] Commentary on guidelines

Dirmaier J, Krattenmacher T, Watzke B, Koch U, Schulz H, Barghaan D. [Evidence-based treatments in the rehabilitation of patients with depression--a literature review] Psychotherapie Psychosomatik Medizinische Psychologie. 2010, 60(3-4):83-97. [PubMed abstract]

Freeman MP, Mischoulon D, Tedeschini E, Goodness T, Cohen LS, Fava M, et al. Complementary and alternative medicine for major depressive disorder: a meta-analysis of patient characteristics, placebo-response rates, and treatment outcomes relative to standard antidepressants. Journal of Clinical Psychiatry. 2010, 71(6):682-8. [PubMed abstract]

Freeman MP, Fava M, Lake J, Trivedi MH, Wisner KL, Mischoulon D. Complementary and alternative medicine in major depressive disorder: the American Psychiatric Association Task Force report. Journal of Clinical Psychiatry. 2010, 71(6):669-81. [PubMed abstract]

Kennedy SH, Lam RW, Parikh SV, Patten SB, Ravindran AV. Canadian Network for Mood and Anxiety Treatments (CANMAT) clinical guidelines for the management of major depressive disorder in adults. Journal of Affective Disorders 2009;117(Suppl 1):S1-S2. [PubMed record] Commentary on guidelines

Ravindran AV, Lam RW, Filteau MJ, Lesperance F, Kennedy SH, Parikh SV, et al. Canadian Network for Mood and Anxiety Treatments (CANMAT). Clinical guidelines for the management of major depressive disorder in adults. V. Complementary and alternative medicine treatments. Journal of Affective Disorders. 2009, 117 Suppl 1:S54-S64. [PubMed abstract]

Sarris J, Kavanagh DJ, Byrne G. Adjuvant use of nutritional and herbal medicines with antidepressants, mood stabilizers and benzodiazepines. Journal of Psychiatric Research. 2010, 44(1):32-41. [PubMed abstract]

Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network. Non-pharmaceutical management of depression in adults. 2010. SIGN National Clinical Guideline 114. [Full text]

]]>

document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Herbal medicine (excluding St John's wort)

Dr Karen Pilkington, Senior Research Fellow, University of Westminster


Very few studies of herbs other than St John’s wort in depression have been published this year. In one trial, patients were randomised to treatment with Rheum ribes extract or placebo for 6 weeks (Sayyah et al 2009). Rheum ribes or ‘Syrian rhubarb’ is a plant found mainly in Western Asia and Pakistan. The trial suggested beneficial effects of the extract on depression but, as the authors point out, the trial was small (33 participants) and further studies are needed.


Sayyah M, Boostani H, Pakseresht S, Malayeri A. Efficacy of hydroalcoholic extract of Rheum ribes L. in treatment of major depressive disorder. Journal of Medicinal Plant Research. 2009, 3(8):573-575. [Full text]

]]>

document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Massage

Dr Karen Pilkington, Senior Research Fellow, University of Westminster


Few studies have been carried in this area over the past year. A meta-analysis of massage therapy in depression was published which included 17 clinical trials (Hou et al 2010). The meta-analysis showed a significant effectiveness of massage but there was variation in the interventions used. Only one RCT published since the 2009 Annual Evidence Update was located (Field et al 2009). In this trial combined massage therapy with psychotherapy was tested against psychotherapy alone in depressed pregnant women. Effects on depression and attendance appeared to be better in the combined group but these findings need further confirmation.


Systematic review

Hou WH, Chiang PT, Hsu TY, Chiu SY, Yen YC. Treatment effects of massage therapy in depressed people: a meta-analysis. Journal of Clinical Psychiatry. 2010, 71(7):894-901. [PubMed abstract]


Randomised controlled trial

Field T, Deeds O, Diego M, Hernandez-Reif M, Gauler A, Sullivan S, et al. Benefits of combining massage therapy with group interpersonal psychotherapy in prenatally depressed women. J Bodyw Mov Ther 2009 Oct;13(4):297-303.  [PubMed abstract]

]]>

document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Meditation and mindfulness

Dr Karen Pilkington, Senior Research Fellow, University of Westminster


The potential of mindfulness-related practices in depression continues to be a focus of research. Two systematic reviews have been published this year. The first attempted to identify trials of mindfulness-based therapy for anxiety and mood symptoms in clinical samples (Hofmann et al 2010). Thirty-nine studies (1,140 participants) were located and effect sizes were calculated. The effect size in patients with mood disorders was 0.95 and that for anxiety 0.97. However, uncontrolled trials were included in the analysis. An appraisal of this review by DARE suggests that although the conclusions were supported by the data, they should be interpreted with caution due to the limitations in the review methods and reporting (DARE appraisal).


The second review again had a broad scope, in assessing mindfulness meditation as a healthcare intervention (Mars et al 2010). Limiting the analysis to higher quality studies the authors concluded that there are ‘replicated statistically significant improvements in spirituality and positive health measures and decreases in depressive relapse, depressive recurrence and psychological distress’ associated with mindfulness meditation. However, they do point out that there is currently a lack of specific, reliable and validated measures with which to measure outcomes and that larger, longer duration trials are still needed.


Systematic reviews

Hofmann SG, Sawyer AT, Witt AA, Oh D. The effect of mindfulness-based therapy on anxiety and depression: A meta-analytic review. Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology. 2010, 78(2):169-83. [Full text]

Mars TS, Abbey H. Mindfulness meditation practise as a healthcare intervention: A systematic review. International Journal of Osteopathic Medicine. 2010, 13(2):56-66. [Abstract]


Randomised controlled trials 

Biegel GM, Brown KW, Shapiro SL, Schubert CM. Mindfulness-based stress reduction for the treatment of adolescent psychiatric outpatients: A randomized clinical trial. J Consult Clin Psychol 2009 Oct;77(5):855-66. [PubMed abstract]

Bondolfi G, Jermann F, Van d, Gex FM, Bizzini L, Weber RB, et al. Depression relapse prophylaxis with mindfulness-based cognitive therapy: a replication randomized controlled study. World Psychiatry 2009;8:198.

Bondolfi G, Jermann F, der Linden MV, Gex-Fabry M, Bizzini L, Rouget BW, et al. Depression relapse prophylaxis with Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy: replication and extension in the Swiss health care system. J Affect Disord 2010 May;122(3):224-31. [Full text]

Britton WB, Haynes PL, Fridel KW, Bootzin RR. Polysomnographic and subjective profiles of sleep continuity before and after mindfulness-based cognitive therapy in partially remitted depression. Psychosom Med 2010 Jul;72(6):539-48. [PubMed abstract] 

de Jong-Meyer R, Parthe T, Projektgruppe. The influence of mindfulness exercises and decentring on rumination and specificity of autobiographical memory. Zeitschrift fur Klinische Psychologie und Psychotherapie: Forschung und Praxis 2009;38(4):240-9.

Godfrin KA, Van HC. The effects of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy on recurrence of depressive episodes, mental health and quality of life: A randomized controlled study. Behav Res Ther 2010 Apr 18. [PubMed abstract]

Hargus E, Crane C, Barnhofer T, Williams JM. Effects of mindfulness on meta-awareness and specificity of describing prodromal symptoms in suicidal depression. Emotion 2010 Feb;10(1):34-42. [PubMed abstract]

Liehr P, Diaz N. A pilot study examining the effect of mindfulness on depression and anxiety for minority children. Arch Psychiatr Nurs 2010 Feb;24(1):69-71. [PubMed record]

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Methodology
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Methodology

The aim of the Annual Evidence Update (AEU) on CAM for Depression is to identify, organise and present the most up-to-date evidence for this topic. As this is the third update, we have comprehensively searched a large number of databases, covering the period from January 2009 to July 2010. Studies included in the 2009 update have been excluded.


This update is linked to the 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Depression hosted by the NHS Evidence – mental health specialist collection.

It also builds on work previously conducted as part of the CAMEOL project. For more information about the rationale for inclusion of specific CAM therapies see Methodology section for the 2008 Annual evidence update.


Search strategy

Based on the above work, the search strategy included text words and terms for CAM in general and for specific CAM therapies. These were combined with text words and terms for depression. Methodological filters for specific study types were not used.
The search strategy can be found here. This strategy has been modified for NHS Search 2.


Sources searched

The Cochrane Library (CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHS EED), PubMed (and MEDLINE), EMBASE, AMED, CINAHL, PsycINFO
NHS Evidence – mental health specialist collection


Search process

The searches were carried out between 26-28 July 2010 and were limited to articles published since January 2009. Studies included in the 2009 update have been excluded.


Selection criteria

 - Study types: guidance/guidelines, systematic reviews, meta-analyses, RCTs.
 - Focused on depression

To identify systematic reviews the definition of a systematic review from the Glossary of Cochrane Collaboration and research terms was used:

“A review of a clearly formulated question that uses systematic and explicit methods to identify, select, and critically appraise relevant research, and to collect and analyse data from the studies that are included in the review. Statistical methods (meta-analysis) may or may not be used to analyse and summarise the results of the included studies.”

Exclusion criteria

 - The study is not one of the types specified above
 - The main focus is not on depression (e.g., a systematic review on specific therapy, which may include a range of conditions)  
 - Bipolar disorder
 - Depression related to other medical conditions

Note
Studies likely to be of particular interest but not meeting the inclusion criteria above have been included where relevant and listed under ‘Other studies of interest’.

Search results

The total number of records retrieved was 7592. After removing the duplicates there were 4070 citations. Of these, 170 were selected as potentially relevant studies. The final selection includes 2 guidelines, 22 systematic reviews and 44 RCTs.
A list of the relevant guidelines, systematic reviews and meta-analyses and RCTs is given in the Results section.

]]>

Music therapy

Reiki

Prayer

Tai chi

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Results
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Results

The following relevant studies on this topic have been published between August 2009 and July 2010.

These studies have met our selection criteria. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - St John's wort (Hypericum perforatum)
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,ST JOHN'S WORT (HYPERICUM PERFORATUM),COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,HERBS R-Z,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - St John's wort (Hypericum perforatum)

Dr Karen Pilkington, Senior Research Fellow, University of Westminster


There is now a good evidence base from randomised controlled trials for the effects of St John’s wort (Hypericum perforatum) in mild to moderate depression. Consequently, the focus is on characterising its effects and assessing safety. There have also been studies assessing effects in related conditions such as atypical depression (e.g. Mannel et al 2010).


Data from non-interventional studies of about 50,000 patients treated with Hypericum extracts were collated in one study (Seelinger 2009). The analysis showed that St John’s wort extract LI 160 was effective for all the common symptoms of depression such as sleep disturbance, anxiety and somatic symptoms. A second study used data from 1,778 patients from 304 centres in Germany to investigate how use of St John’s wort in practice differs from that in trials (Melzer et al 2010). Lower age and shorter duration of depression appeared to be associated with significantly better outcomes.  A low rate of adverse drug reactions was observed (3.54%) and serious adverse drug reactions did not occur. While these findings are of interest, patterns of use of St John’s wort differ between the UK and Germany, and there may be different products or formulations in use. A study of a different extract of St. John's wort extract (WS 5570) showed better tolerability than that seen with selective serotonin receptor inhibitors (SSRIs) (Kasper et al 2010).


Safety remains an issue related to use, particularly the potential for St John’s wort to interact with other drugs. An updated systematic review of interactions between a range of herbal medicines and prescribed drugs included a section on St John’s wort and a list of interactions that have been reported (Izzo and Ernst 2009). A potential interaction with oxycodone has also recently been reported (Nieminen et al 2010). A possible association between St John’s wort and cataracts has also been investigated (Booth and McGwin 2009). The authors suggest that because of limitations in the study design, which used data from a national US survey, further investigation of this is required.


Systematic review

Izzo AA, Ernst E. Interactions between herbal medicines and prescribed drugs: An updated systematic review. Drugs. 2009, 69(13):1777-1798. [Abstract]


Randomised controlled trials 

Mannel M, Kuhn U, Schmidt U, Ploch M, Murck H. St. John's wort extract LI160 for the treatment of depression with atypical features - A double-blind, randomized, and placebo-controlled trial. J Psychiatr Res 2010 Feb 22. [PubMed abstract] 

Nieminen TH, Hagelberg NM, Saari TI, Neuvonen M, Laine K, Neuvonen PJ, et al. St John's wort greatly reduces the concentrations of oral oxycodone. Eur J Pain 2010 Jan 25. [PubMed abstract]


Other studies

Booth JN, III, McGwin G. The association between self-reported cataracts and St. John's Wort. Curr Eye Res 2009 Oct;34(10):863-6. [PubMed abstract]

Kasper S, Gastpar M, Moller HJ, Muller WE, Volz HP, Dienel A, et al. Better tolerability of St. John's wort extract WS 5570 compared to treatment with SSRIs: a reanalysis of data from controlled clinical trials in acute major depression. Int Clin Psychopharmacol 2010 Jul;25(4):204-13. [PubMed abstract]

Melzer J, Brignoli R, Keck ME, Saller R. A hypericum extract in the treatment of depressive symptoms in outpatients: an open study. Forsch Komplementmed 2010;17(1):7-14. [PubMed abstract]

]]>

document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Use of CAM

Dr Karen Pilkington, Senior Research Fellow, University of Westminster


Two studies published in the past year have attempted to provide further insight into the use of CAM by people with depression. One of the studies was conducted in Taiwan and it is unclear exactly how relevant the findings are for the UK health care system (Hsu et al 2010). However, the findings raised some points worthy of further consideration. This study relied on face-to-face survey interviews with around 200 people. Many of the participants expressed a willingness to try any potential treatment for depression but admitted that they had very little knowledge about CAM treatments. The authors suggest that education of patients and their families may help in optimising treatment and avoiding adverse drug interactions. The second study (Zizzamia 2009) was a small qualitative study conducted in the USA but limited details of results were available as only an abstract has been published.


Hsu MC, Moyle W, Creedy D, Venturato L, Ouyang WC, Sun GC. Attitudes toward and education about complementary and alternative medicine among adult patients with depression in Taiwan. Journal of Clinical Nursing. 2010, 19(7-8):988-97. [PubMed abstract]

Zizzamia A. The use of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM): A qualitative exploration of women's experiences in treating symptoms of depression, anxiety, and stress. Dissertation Abstracts International: Section B: The Sciences and Engineering 2009;70(1-B).

]]>

document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on CAM in Depression - Yoga

Dr Karen Pilkington, Senior Research Fellow, University of Westminster


Hatha yoga is the form of yoga most commonly used in the West. A review has been published this year of the evidence from clinical trials on Hatha yoga in depression (Uebelacker et al 2010). Eight controlled trials were located, 5 in people with diagnosed depression and three in people with depressive symptoms. Five studies compared yoga with no or minimal treatment. Four of these trials found some evidence that yoga was more effective although effect sizes varied widely. Yoga interventions also varied in duration (from 3 days to 12 weeks), frequency (daily to once a week) and type of yoga. The potential contribution of the various components of yoga including mindfulness and physical activity are discussed along with possible mechanisms of action. Overall, the authors suggest that further research is needed for definitive conclusions.


Systematic review

Uebelacker LA, Epstein-Lubow G, Gaudiano BA, Tremont G, Battle CL, Miller IW. Hatha yoga for depression: critical review of the evidence for efficacy, plausible mechanisms of action, and directions for future research. J Psychiatr Pract 2010 Jan;16(1):22-33. [PubMed abstract]

document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy

Published: 14 June 2010

 

 

 

 

Introduction 

The 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy aims to identify, organise and present all relevant systematic reviews and randomised controlled trials (RCTs) published between May 2009 and May 2010.

Previously published studies have been included in the 2009 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy or can be found by searching this website.

We have searched a large number of databases and used strict selection criteria for the identified studies, in order to base the annual update on the best current evidence available. The studies included in this update have met our selection criteria but have not been fully appraised. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

For more details about the search methods and the selection process for this annual update see the methodology section. 

 

Contents

  • Methodology
  • Results of the 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy
  • Commentary on the results of the 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy
]]>

document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy - Commentary

Dr Peter Fisher, Clinical Lead, NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine


New publications in the last year, both systematic reviews and randomised clinical trials (RCTS), focus on two main clinical areas: Fibromyalgia and Insomnia.


Fibromyalgia

Three systematic reviews (SRs) of RCTs of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM), including homeopathy for Fibromyalgia have been published since the last evidence update. One of these examined the efficacy of all forms of CAM, including homeopathy, one focussed on the efficacy of homeopathy alone and a third evaluated the quality of RCTs of CAM for Fibromyalgia.

In addition one RCT of homeopathy for Fibromyalgia was published, this was incorporated in the SR on the efficacy of homeopathy, but not in the other two SRs. There is some concern about the literature searching since the three SRs all found different numbers of RCTs of homeopathy, varying from 1-4. 

The conclusions of the SRs however are broadly congruent. The SR on the efficacy of homeopathy included four RCTs. Two of these involved individualised homeopathy, but with a limited range of homeopathic medicines, versus placebo, one used fully individualised homeopathy also controlled against placebo. The fourth looked at ‘care by a homeopath’, including the consultation and medicine, compared to normal care alone. The conclusion was that all RCTs reported evidence supporting the effectiveness of homeopathy compared to placebo or to usual care. But there were important caveats including small sample sizes, lack of replication and lack of placebo control in one study (Perry et al.).

The SR on the efficacy of all CAMs was conducted by the Arthritis Research Campaign’s working on CAM. This SR included three studies of homeopathy (all of them also covered by the SR on efficacy of homeopathy), concluding that ‘There is insufficient evidence on any CAM, taken orally or applied topically, for FM. The small number of positive studies lack replication. Further high-quality trials are necessary.’ (De Silva et al.)

The third SR found 23 RCTs, but only one of these was of homeopathy. The reason for the disparity with the other SRs is not immediately obvious. The main objective was to assess the quality of studies, the RCT of homeopathy scored 57.5/100 for quality, compared to the mean of 51/100 for all trials. Criticisms of the RCTs included small numbers of patients and short duration, inadequate control and blinding, inadequate follow up, and variable outcome measures. The authors recommend visual analogue scores to evaluate pain and the Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire (FIQ) for overall assessment. There was no specific comment on the RCT of homeopathy. (Baranowsky et al.)

The RCT was a feasibility study for a trial of usual care versus usual care plus adjunctive care by a homeopath for patients with Fibromyalgia in a UK NHS setting. It was randomised, but not controlled for attention. The results showed a large positive effect of homeopathic care on function and a small one on pain, as measured by the FIQ. The drop out rate was higher in the group which did not receive homeopathic care. The authors concluded that there is a need for a definitive study of this design. (Relton et al.)

Baranowsky J, Klose P, Musial F, Haeuser W, Dobos G, Langhorst J. Qualitative systemic review of randomized controlled trials on complementary and alternative medicine treatments in fibromyalgia. Rheumatology International. 2009;30(1):1-21. [Abstract]

De Silva V, El-Metwally A, Ernst E, Lewith G, Macfarlane GJ; Arthritis Research Campaign working group on complementary and alternative medicines. Evidence for the efficacy of complementary and alternative medicines in the management of fibromyalgia: a systematic review. Rheumatology (Oxford). 2010;49(6):1063-8. [PubMed abstract]

Perry R, Terry R, Ernst E. A systematic review of homoeopathy for the treatment of fibromyalgia. Clinical Rheumatology. 2010;29(5):457-64. [PubMed abstract] 

Relton C, Smith C, Raw J, Walters C, Adebajo AO, Thomas KJ, Young TA. Healthcare provided by a homeopath as an adjunct to usual care for Fibromyalgia (FMS): results of a pilot Randomised Controlled Trial. Homeopathy. 2009;98(2):77-82. [PubMed abstract]

Insomnia

An SR and an RCT (not included in the SR because of timing) on homeopathy for insomnia have been published in the last year. The SR found four randomised controlled trials (RCTs) that compared homeopathy to placebo. Three of them used commercial complexes or a single homeopathic medicine, one used individualised homeopathy, none examined ‘care by a homeopath’. All were small scale and of low methodological quality. None demonstrated a statistically significant difference in outcomes between groups, although two showed a trend favouring homeopathy. One cohort study, three case series and over 2600 case studies were also identified.

The cohort study reported significant improvements from baseline. The SR concluded that well-conducted studies of homeopathic medicines and of the homeopathic package of care are required (Cooper et al).

In contrast the RCT on insomnia reported in the year did report significant differences favouring individualised homeopathic treatment, compared to placebo, although the study was small. (Naudé et al.)

Cooper KL, Relton C. Homeopathy for insomnia: A systematic review of research evidence. Sleep Medicine Reviews. 2010 Mar 9. [Epub ahead of print] [PubMed abstract]

Naudé DF, Stephanie Couchman IM, Maharaj A. Chronic primary insomnia: efficacy of homeopathic simillimum. Homeopathy. 2010;99(1):63-8. [PubMed abstract]

Homeopathy for vulvovaginal candidiasis

An RCT compared classical homeopathy with itraconazole plus intravaginal lactobacilli and itraconazole without lactobacilli in recurrent vulvovaginal candidiasis (RVVC) in 150 women. Itraconazole treatment was given intensively at the beginning then at a lower maintenance dose for 6 months, the patients were followed for a further 6 months. Homeopathy was given for 12 months. The authors concluded that cycle-dependent itraconazole is significantly more effective than classical homeopathy in the treatment of RVVC, and that lactobacilli do not confer an additional benefit over itraconazole alone. (Witt et al.)

Witt A, Kaufmann U, Bitschnau M, Tempfer C, Ozbal A, Haytouglu E, Gregor H, Kiss H. Monthly itraconazole versus classic homeopathy for the treatment of recurrent vulvovaginal candidiasis: a randomised trial. BJOG. 2009;116(11):1499-505. [PubMed abstract]

Cost effectiveness of a homeopathic complex in Sinusitis

This is one of the few RCTs of homeopathy to incorporate economic analysis. It compared a complex homeopathic medicine, Sinfrontal, to placebo in 113 patients with Acute Maxillary Sinusitis (AMS) over 11 weeks Economic data were collected and indirect comparison made to placebo-controlled trials of antibacterial agents. Sinfrontal was associated with significant cost savings compared to placebo, mostly due to reduced absence from work.  Indirect comparison with antibacterials suggested that the homeopathic complex was associated with a significantly higher cure rate at similar or lower cost. The conclusion was that Sinfrontal may be a cost-effective treatment for AMS. (Kneis et al.)

Kneis KC, Gandjour A. Economic evaluation of Sinfrontal in the treatment of acute maxillary sinusitis in adults. Applied Health Economics and Health Policy. 2009; 7(3):181-191. [PubMed abstract] [EED provisional record]

Homeopathy in minor aphthous ulceration

A randomised, single blind placebo-controlled RCT of 100 patients with minor aphthous ulceration was reported from the University of Tehran Medical School, Iran.  Individualised homeopathic treatment was given, and the patients followed-up for 6 days. The group receiving homeopathic had statistically and clinically significant greater improvements in terms of pain and ulcer size. An obvious source of bias in this study is its lack of observer blinding. (Mousavi et al.)

Mousavi F, Mojaver YN, Asadzadeh M, Mirzazadeh M. Homeopathic treatment of minor aphthous ulcer: a randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trial. Homeopathy. 2009;98(3):137-41. [PubMed abstract] 

Homeopathic Pathogenetic Trials

Homeopathic Pathogenetic Trials (HPTs), also known as ‘Provings’ are a basic method in homeopathy. They are studies to determine the effects that potential medicinal substances cause in healthy volunteers. This is fundamental to homeopathic clinical practice since it is based on ‘Like cures like’. A cluster of three double-blind, randomised controlled HPTs of similar, cross-over, design were reported in the year. All were of small size (25-30 volunteers each).

One of these aimed at determining whether the symptoms experienced by healthy volunteers taking homeopathic Aconitum napellus 30c were qualitatively different from those they experienced when taking placebo, in a cross-over study. The results revealed a statistically-significant difference, enabling discrimination between the two treatments. (Piltan et al.)

Another HPT examined whether volunteers taking homeopathic Arsenicum album 30c or Natrum muriaticum 30c developed more symptoms typical of these medicines when taking them, compared to placebo, in a 3-arm study. The judgement on the specificity or otherwise of symptoms was made by a blinded homeopathic expert using decision support software. It concluded that while taking these homeopathic medicines, significantly more symptoms specific to the respective medicines were reported. The total number of symptoms was highest when taking placebo, but these symptoms were mostly non-specific. (Möllinger et al.)

In both these studies, the authors concluded that the symptoms of volunteers were qualitatively different and specific to the medicine when they took active homeopathic medicine compared to placebo.

A third HPT measured the effect of homeopathic Antimony D6/6x on blood coagulation in healthy volunteers. It showed borderline statistical significance in terms of decreased clotting time and increased clot firmness in the group receiving active treatment. (Heusser et al.)

Heusser P, Berger S, Stutz M, Hüsler A, Haeberli A, Wolf U. Efficacy of homeopathically potentized antimony on blood coagulation. A randomized placebo controlled crossover trial. Forschende Komplementärmedizin. 2009;16(1):14-8. [PubMed abstract]

Möllinger H, Schneider R, Walach H. Homeopathic pathogenetic trials produce specific symptoms different from placebo. Forschende Komplementärmedizin. 2009;16(2):105-10. [PubMed abstract]

Piltan D, Rist L, Simões-Wüst P, Saller R. Test of a homeopathic dilution of Aconitum napellus. A clinical, randomized, double-blind, controlled crossover study in healthy volunteers. Forschende Komplementärmedizin. 2009;16(3):168-73. [PubMed abstract]

Link to 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy - Methodology
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HOMEOPATHY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,JUNE 2010]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy - Methodology

Sources searched:

The Cochrane Library (CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHS EED), CRD databases (DARE, NHS EED, HTA), PubMed (and MEDLINE), EMBASE, AMED, CINAHL, PsycINFO


Selection criteria (at screening stage)

Inclusion criteria:

  1. Systematic reviews and meta-analyses - statement of methodology and explicit description of search process (at least 2 sources must have been searched and there must be a statement of methodology)
  2. HTA reports and cost-effectiveness studies 
  3. Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)
  4. Topic relevance (studies should focus on homeopathy or include homeopathy as one of the investigated interventions)

Exclusion criteria:

  1. The study is not a systematic review, meta-analysis, HTA report, cost-effectiveness study or RCT. 
  2. The study does not focus on homeopathy or include homeopathy as one of the investigated interventions.
  3. The study is published in a language other than English and English abstract is not available.

Search process

The searches were carried out on 12 May 2010 and were limited to articles published since 1 January 2009. To identify relevant systematic reviews the information specialist searched the sources listed above using the CAM specialist collection systematic reviews filter, which emphasizes specificity (precision) over sensitivity. The PubMed Clinical Queries systematic review filter was also used. In addition a search for relevant randomised controlled trials (RCTs) was carried out.
More details of search terms and filters used are available by contacting the information specialist. 

Results

The totals number of records retrieved was 211. After removing the duplicates there were 77 records to screen. The final selection includes 4 systematic reviews and 8 randomised controlled trials (RCTs). 
 

Link to 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy

 

]]>

  7. Relton C, Smith C, Raw J, Walters C, Adebajo AO, Thomas KJ, Young TA. Healthcare provided by a homeopath as an adjunct to usual care for Fibromyalgia (FMS): results of a pilot Randomised Controlled Trial. Homeopathy. 2009;98(2):77-82. [PubMed abstract]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: A combination of systematic review and clinicians' beliefs in interventions for subacromial pain
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,MASSAGE,CONDITIONS A-Z,NOVEMBER 2006,CONDITIONS P-R,SHOULDER IMPINGEMENT SYNDROME,SHOULDER PAIN,CONDITIONS S,PAIN,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Johansson K, Oberg B, Adolfsson L, Foldevi M. A combination of systematic review and clinicians' beliefs in interventions for subacromial pain. British Journal of General Practice. 2002, 52(475):145-52.

Authors' objectives

The aim of the study is to determine which treatments for patients with subacromial pain are trusted by general practitioners (GPs) and physiotherapists, and to compare trusted treatments with evidence from a systematic critical review of the scientific literature.

Authors' conclusions

The trust in corticosteroids, injected in the subacromial bursa, was supported by definitive evidence for short-term efficacy. Acupuncture had tentative evidence for short-term efficacy in patients with subacromial pain. Ultrasound therapy was ineffective for subacromial pain. This is supported by tentative evidence and, together with earlier reviews, this questions both the trust in the treatment and its use. The clinicians' trust in treatments had a weak association with available scientific evidence.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of massage therapy research
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MASSAGE,CONDITIONS A-Z,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,COMPLEMENTARY & ALTERNATIVE THERAPIES,CONDITIONS P-R,STRESS,CONDITIONS S,ANXIETY,PAIN,DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS F-H,CONDITIONS D-E,CONDITIONS A-B,HYPERTENSION,HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE]]>
document.body:
Citation

Moyer CA, Rounds J, Hannum JW. A meta-analysis of massage therapy research. Psychological Bulletin. 2004, 130(1): 3-18.

Authors' objectives

To evaluate the effectiveness of massage therapy (MT) by conducting a meta-analysis of studies that used random assignment.

Authors' conclusions

Single applications of MT reduced state anxiety, blood pressure, and heart rate but not negative mood, immediate assessment of pain, and cortisol level. Multiple applications reduced delayed assessment of pain. Reductions of trait anxiety and depression were MT's largest effects, with a course of treatment providing benefits similar in magnitude to those of psychotherapy.

 

]]>

document.title: A mini review of traditional Chinese medicine for the treatment of depression in China
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),MARCH 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Zhao H, Wan X, Chen JX. A mini review of traditional chinese medicine for the treatment of depression in china. American Journal of Chinese Medicine. 2009, 37(2):207-13.

Authors' objectives

To systematically evaluate the effectiveness of Chinese herbal medicine for treating depression in China.

Authors' conclusions

The results showed there is no evidence to support that traditional Chinese medicine for depression has improved, which may be due to the low quality in all the trials. Therefore, more qualified, randomized controlled clinical trials are warranted to assure its efficacy.

document.title: A Modern Herbal
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,JULY 2006,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body: A Modern Herbal, first published in 1931, by Mrs. M. Grieve, contains information on the "medicinal, culinary, cosmetic and economic properties, cultivation and folklore of herbs". It consists of three indexes: the Plant & Herb Index covering more than 800 varieties of herbs and plants, the Index of Recipes and the Index of Poisons with information on 44 plants that are listed as poisonous.]]>

document.title: A review of controlled trials of acupuncture for women's reproductive health care
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,ACUPRESSURE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,CONDITIONS A-Z,INFERTILITY,MENOPAUSAL SYMPTOMS,CONDITIONS I-L,DYSMENORRHOEA,CONDITIONS F-H,CONDITIONS D-E,CONDITIONS M-O,HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE,HYPERTENSION]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

White AR. A review of controlled trials of acupuncture for women's reproductive health care. Journal of Family Planning and Reproductive Health Care. 2003, 29(4): 233-236.

Authors' objectives

This study aims to review the scientific literature on the effectiveness of acupuncture and acupressure for gynaecological conditions.

Authors' conclusions

In view of the small number of studies and their variable quality, doubt remains about the effectiveness of acupuncture for gynaecological conditions. Acupuncture and acupressure appear promising for dysmenorrhoea, and acupuncture for infertility, and further studies are justified.

 

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,JANUARY 2011,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY]]>

Citation

Authors' objectives

To conduct a review of side effects of psychotherapy, bodywork (without high-energy manipulations), mind-body medicine, body-psychotherapy, sexology, clinical holistic medicine and complementary and alternative medicine (CAM).

Authors' conclusions

Non-drug (non-pharmaceutical) medicine seems to be safe even for seriously physically and mentally ill patients and, whenever efficient, therefore recommended as treatment of choice.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: A review of studies of garlic (Allium sativum) on serum lipids and blood pressure before and after 1994: does the amount of allicin released from garlic powder tablets play a role?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,HIGH CHOLESTEROL,HYPERTENSION,HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE,CONDITIONS F-H,GARLIC (ALLIUM SATIVUM),HERBS D-G,DATE ADDED,JULY 2007,2007]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

McRae M. A review of studies of garlic (Allium sativum) on serum lipids and blood pressure before and after 1994: does the amount of allicin released from garlic powder tablets play a role? Journal of Chiropractic Medicine. 2005, 4(4):182-190.

Authors' objectives

To identify studies measuring garlic powder tablets effects on systolic and diastolic blood pressure and to investigate if studies published prior to January 1994 would perform better than those published later. 

Authors' conclusions

Publications published prior to January 1994 performed better than those published after January 1994, suggesting that allicin may be responsible for the antihypertensive effects of garlic powder tablets. However, a lack of correlation between changes in total serum cholesterol and blood pressure suggests that other organo-sulfur compounds may also play a role in the antihypertensive mechanisms of garlic.

 

]]>

document.title: A review of the effect of peppermint oil in various gastrointestinal conditions
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS F-H,PEPPERMINT (MENTHA PIPERITA),GASTROINTESTINAL DISEASES,HERBS H-P,DECEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Khvorova Y, Neill J. A review of the effect of peppermint oil in various gastrointestinal conditions. J.GENCA. 2008, 18(3): 6-15.

Authors' objectives

To consider the effect of peppermint oil in various gastrointestinal conditions, including as an alternative to morphine for colon spasm after colorectal surgery when the pain is identified as due to colon spasm.

Authors' conclusions

Peppermint oil is inexpensive and safe for oral (enteric-coated capsules) and intraluminal (peppermint oil solution) administration in IBS, diagnostic gastrointestinal procedures, functional dyspepsia, and post-operative nausea, with limited side effects. Research on the effect of peppermint oil for colon spasm after colorectal surgery is needed.

document.title: A review on the effects of aromatherapy for patients with depressive symptoms
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,AROMATHERAPY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS D-E,MARCH 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Yim VW, Ng AK, Tsang HW, Leung AY. A review on the effects of aromatherapy for patients with depressive symptoms. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2009, 15(2):187-195.

Authors' objectives

The authors reviewed studies from 2000 to 2008 on using essential oils for patients with depression or depressive symptoms and examined their clinical effects. 

Authors' conclusions

The authors recommend that aromatherapy could continue to be used as a complementary and alternative therapy for patients with depression and secondary depressive symptoms arising from various types of chronic medical conditions. More controlled studies with sound methodology should be conducted in the future to ascertain its clinical effects and the underlying psychobiologic mechanisms.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: A systematic literature review of nonsurgical treatment in adult scoliosis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CHIROPRACTIC,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,MUSCULOSKELETAL DISEASES,CONDITIONS M-O,FEBRUARY 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Everett CR, Patel RK. A systematic literature review of nonsurgical treatment in adult scoliosis. Spine. 2007, 32(19 Suppl):S130-4.

Authors' objectives

To evaluate evidence for the efficacy and effectiveness of proposed conservative treatment options in adult deformity. 

Authors' conclusions

There is indeterminate, Level III/IV evidence on the effectiveness of any conservative care option. Specifically, there is Level IV evidence on the role of physical therapy, chiropractic care, and bracing. There is Level III evidence for injections in the conservative treatment of adult deformity. There is insufficient research for a treatment recommendation beyond Level 2c very weak evidence, but the available literature is supportive of further clinical research in conservative care as a treatment in adult deformity.

Conservative care in general may be a helpful option in the care of adult deformity, but evidence for this is lacking. Unfortunately, no treatment option within conservative care has support within the literature as a preferred solution. Basic clinical research at any level would be helpful to further clarify the options.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: A systematic review of classical European massage for alleviating perinatal depression and anxiety
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MASSAGE,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ANXIETY,PREGNANCY,DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS A-B,CONDITIONS D-E,CONDITIONS P-R,AUGUST 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Coelho HF, Boddy K, Ernst E. A systematic review of classical European massage for alleviating perinatal depression and anxiety. Focus on Alternative and Complementary Therapies. 2008, 13: 150–6.

Authors' objectives

The aim was to broaden a previous review by identifying and evaluating all RCTs of massage therapy for improving anxiety symptoms as well as depression symptoms, while focusing on a specific population (women during the perinatal period). 

Authors' conclusions

Despite the advantages that massage therapy may appear to have over psychopharmacological and psychological approaches for women during the perinatal period, there is currently a lack of evidence to suggest that this therapy can alleviate anxiety or depression, or improve mood, during pregnancy, labour or the postnatal period. This lack of evidence is in spite of several RCTs in this area and is mainly due to methodological and reporting deficits. 

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CHIROPRACTIC,CONDITIONS A-Z,PAIN,CONDITIONS M-O,CONDITIONS P-R,NECK PAIN,OCTOBER 2006,DATE ADDED]]>

Citation

Vernon HT, Humphreys BK, Hagino CA. A systematic review of conservative treatments for acute neck pain not due to whiplash. Journal of Manipulative and Physiological Therapeutics. 2005, 28(6):443-8.

Authors' objectives

To identify the evidence base of clinical trials of conservative treatments for acute neck pain not due to whiplash injury.

Authors' conclusions

There is limited evidence of the benefit of spinal manipulation and transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation in the treatment of acute neck pain not due to whiplash injury. There is a dearth of high-quality clinical trials of conservative treatments for this condition.

 

]]>

document.title: A systematic review of natural health product treatment for vitiligo
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),SKIN DISEASES,CONDITIONS S,JANUARY 2010,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Szczurko O, Boon H S. A systematic review of natural health product treatment for vitiligo. BMC Dermatology 2008, 8:2.

Authors' objectives

To complete a comprehensive, systematic review of the published scientific literature to identify natural health products (NHP) such as vitamins, herbs and other supplements that may have efficacy in the treatment of vitiligo. 

Authors' conclusions

Reports investigating the efficacy of NHPs for vitiligo exist, but are of poor methodological quality and contain significant reporting flaws. L-phenylalanine used with phototherapy, and oral Ginkgo biloba as monotherapy show promise and warrant further investigation.

]]>

Mindfulness meditation (MM) practices constitute an important group of meditative practices that have received growing attention. The aim of the present paper was to systematically review current evidence on the neurobiological changes and clinical benefits related to MM practice in psychiatric disorders, in physical illnesses and in healthy subjects.

Authors' conclusions

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: A systematic review of population and community dietary interventions to prevent cancer
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS C,CANCER,DATE ADDED,DECEMBER 2008]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Thorogood M, Simera I, Dowler E, Summerbell C, Brunner E. A systematic review of population and community dietary interventions to prevent cancer. Nutrition Research Reviews. 2007; 20(1): 74-88.

Authors' objectives

Diet is an important factor in the causation of cancer. Previous systematic reviews of one-to-one interventions to encourage dietary change have found that such interventions can achieve modest improvements in diet. However, such interventions are resource intensive and unlikely to be good value for money at a population level. Interventions that address groups, communities or whole populations may be less resource intensive and effect change in a wider population. The authors report a systematic review of such interventions. 

Authors' conclusions

The authors found eighteen studies based in the community, seventeen based on worksites, five based in churches and one based in a supermarket. Interventions which targeted fruit and vegetable intake were most likely to be successful, particularly in worksites and churches. There was also evidence of small positive effects on reducing fat intake in worksites and churches. Overall the community-based interventions showed little effect. The studies included in the present review were generally poorly reported. Dietary changes are reported in the relatively short-term studies reviewed here but may not be sustained in the long term. The effects that we have identified are small but the reach is potentially very wide, in some cases as wide as a whole country. The cost effectiveness of such strategies remains to be evaluated.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.title: A systematic review of valerian as a sleep aid: safe but not effective
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,SLEEP DISORDERS,VALERIAN (VALERIANA OFFICINALIS),INSOMNIA,CONDITIONS S,CONDITIONS I-L,HERBS R-Z,DECEMBER 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Taibi D M, Landis C A, Petry H, Vitiello M V. A systematic review of valerian as a sleep aid: safe but not effective. Sleep Medicine Reviews. 2007, 11(3): 209-230.

Authors' objectives

Valerian is an herb that is widely available in a variety of commercial preparations and is commonly used as a sleep aid. A recent systematic review and meta-analysis of valerian concluded that evidence in support of the effectiveness of the herb was inconclusive. Therefore, in an effort to more closely examine this issue, a systematic review was conducted to examine the evidence on the efficacy of valerian as a sleep aid with specific attention to the type of preparations tested and the characteristics of the subjects studied. 

Authors' conclusions

Overall, the evidence, while supporting that valerian is a safe herb associated with only rare adverse events, does not support the clinical efficacy of valerian as a sleep aid for insomnia.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.title: A systematic review to determine the effectiveness of Tai Chi in reducing falls and fear of falling in older adults
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS T-Z,WOUNDS AND INJURIES,TAI CHI,DECEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Harling A, Simpson JP. A systematic review to determine the effectiveness of Tai Chi in reducing falls and fear of falling in older adults. Physical Therapy Reviews. 2008, 13(4): 237-248.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this systematic review was to examine the current literature surrounding the effectiveness of Tai Chi in reducing the incidence of and fear of falling in older people.

Authors' conclusions

There is strong evidence to support the effectiveness of Tai Chi in reducing fear of falling, and weak evidence supporting its effectiveness in reducing the incidence of falls in older adults. Future research should focus on targeting defined clinical subpopulations with high-quality, well-designed randomised controlled trials of sufficient size and with long-term follow-up, to provide further evidence supporting the use of Tai Chi to reduce the incidence and fear of falling in older people.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Access to complementary medicine via general practice
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,USE OF CAM,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED,JUNE 2007,2007]]>
document.body:
Citation

Thomas KJ, Nicholl JP, Fall M. Access to complementary medicine via general practice. British Journal of General Practice. 2001, 51(462):25-30. 

Authors' objectives

To describe the scale and scope of access to complementary therapies (acupuncture, chiropractic, homoeopathy, hypnotherapy, medical herbalism, and osteopathy) via general practice in England.

Authors' conclusion

Access to complementary health care for NHS patients was widespread in English general practices in 1995. This data suggests that a limited range of complementary therapies were acceptable to a large proportion of GPs. Fundholding clearly provided a mechanism for the provision of complementary therapies in primary care. Patterns of provision are likely to alter with the demise of fundholding and existing provision may significantly reduce unless the Primary Care Groups or Primary Care Trusts are prepared to support the 'levelling up' of some services.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Acupressure and acupuncture in preventing and managing postoperative nausea and vomiting in adults
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,ACUPRESSURE,ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS M-O,NAUSEA,VOMITING,CONDITIONS T-Z,FEBRUARY 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Abraham J. Acupressure and acupuncture in preventing and managing postoperative nausea and vomiting in adults. Journal of Perioperative Practice 2008; 18(12):543-51.

Authors' objectives

This literature review sets out to investigate the effectiveness of acupressure and acupuncture in preventing and managing postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) in adult patients. 

Authors' conclusions

Overall the article suggests that acupuncture and acupressure are ineffective in preventing and managing PONV in adult patients. Further investigation of the effectiveness of acupressure and acupuncture, combined with current drug therapies, using well designed and adequately powered studies is needed. Published studies predominantly examined the use of P6 as the pressure point. Further studies should examine other 'acupoint' sites, to ascertain whether these are effective dependent upon the operative site.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.title: Acupressure for nausea and vomiting in cancer patients receiving chemotherapy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPRESSURE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS C,CONDITIONS M-O,CANCER,VOMITING,NAUSEA,CONDITIONS T-Z,DATE ADDED,FEBRUARY 2008]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Klein J, Griffiths P. Acupressure for nausea and vomiting in cancer patients receiving chemotherapy. British Journal of Community Nursing. 2004, 9(9):383-8.

Authors' objectives

Practitioners working with patients undergoing chemotherapy regularly encourage them to use acupressure in the form of Sea Bands for the relief of treatment-related nausea and vomiting. This mini-review sets out to uncover and examine the evidence base for this recommendation. 

Authors' conclusions

The results suggest that acupressure may decrease nausea among patients undergoing chemotherapy but further work is required before conclusively advising patients on the efficacy of acupressure in preventing and treating chemotherapy-induced nausea.

Access
