document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Acupuncture
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DATE ADDED,DECEMBER 2006]]>
document.body:
NIH Consensus statements and State-of-the-Science statements (formerly known as technology assessment statements) are prepared by a nonadvocate, non-Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) panels, based on (1) presentations by investigators working in areas relevant to the consensus questions during a 2-day public session; (2) questions and statements from conference attendees during open discussion periods that are part of the public session; and (3) closed deliberations by the panel during the remainder of the second day and morning of the third.

Citation

Acupuncture. NIH Consensus Statement 1997 Nov 3-5; 15(5):1-34.

Objective

To provide health care providers, patients, and the general public with a responsible assessment of the use and effectiveness of acupuncture for a variety of conditions.

Conclusions

Acupuncture as a therapeutic intervention is widely practiced in the United States. While there have been many studies of its potential usefulness, many of these studies provide equivocal results because of design, sample size, and other factors. The issue is further complicated by inherent difficulties in the use of appropriate controls, such as placebos and sham acupuncture groups. However, promising results have emerged, for example, showing efficacy of acupuncture in adult postoperative and chemotherapy nausea and vomiting and in postoperative dental pain. There are other situations such as addiction, stroke rehabilitation, headache, menstrual cramps, tennis elbow, fibromyalgia, myofascial pain, osteoarthritis, low back pain, carpal tunnel syndrome, and asthma, in which acupuncture may be useful as an adjunct treatment or an acceptable alternative or be included in a comprehensive management program. Further research is likely to uncover additional areas where acupuncture interventions will be useful.

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Acupuncture and herbal medicine in in vitro fertilisation: a review of the evidence for clinical practice
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,ACUPUNCTURE,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,INFERTILITY,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),CONDITIONS I-L,JULY 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Cheong Y, Nardo LG, Rutherford T, Ledger W. Acupuncture and herbal medicine in in vitro fertilisation: a review of the evidence for clinical practice. Human Fertility (Camb). 2010, 13(1):3-12.

Authors' objectives

The objectives of this systematic review were to determine the effectiveness of (a) acupuncture and (b) Chinese herbal medicine on the treatment of male and female subfertility by assisted reproductive technologies (ART). 

Authors' conclusions

The results provided no evidence of benefit in the use of acupuncture during assisted conception. Further studies should attempt to explore the potential placebo, as well as treatment, effects of this complimentary therapy. Essential elements for a quality RCT will be the size of the trial, the use of a standardised acupuncture method and of placebo needles.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Acupuncture application for neurological disorders
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS M-O,DATE ADDED,MAY 2008,NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Lee H, Park HJ, Park J, Kim MJ, Hong M, Yang J, Choi S, Lee H. Acupuncture application for neurological disorders. Neurological Research. 2007, 29 Suppl 1:S49-54.

Authors' objectives

This review was designed to summarize and to evaluate the available evidence of acupuncture for neurological disorders.

Authors' conclusions

Owing to paucity and poor quality of the primary studies, no firm conclusion could be drawn on the use of acupuncture for epilepsy, Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, ataxic disorders, multiple sclerosis, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and spinal cord injury. For stroke rehabilitation, the evidence from recent high-quality trials and previous systematic reviews is not convincing. More rigorous trials are warranted to establish acupuncture's role in neurological disorders.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Acupuncture evidence update 2008: Search methodology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,APRIL 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-1Acupuncture evidence update 2008: Search methodology

Sources searched:

The Cochrane Library (CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHS EED), PubMed (and MEDLINE), EMBASE, AMED, CINAHL, PsycINFO.

Selection criteria (at screening stage) 

Inclusion criteria:

  1. Explicit description of search process and statement of methodology (at least 2 sources must have been searched and there must be a statement of methodology, meta-analysis or systematic review)
  2. Large RCTs – with more than 100 participants.
  3. Topic relevance (studies should address acupuncture or CAM in general, including acupuncture as one of the investigated interventions)

Exclusion criteria:

  1. The study is not a systematic review, meta-analysis or a large RCT.
  2. The study does not focus on acupuncture (could include a range of interventions, including CAM; acupuncture-like TENS; acupuncture is a comparison intervention)
  3. The study is published in a language other than English and English abstract is not available.


Search process

The searches were carried out on 5 - 6 March 2008 and were limited to articles published since 1 January 2007. To identify relevant systematic reviews the information specialist for the library searched the sources listed above using the CAM SL systematic reviews filter, which emphasizes specificity (precision) over sensitivity.
More details of search terms and filters used are available by contacting the Library's information specialist. 


Results

The totals number of records retrieved was 473. After removing the duplicates there were 181 to screen. Of these 57 were selected as potential systematic reviews. If any uncertainty existed records were still included in the list. The titles and abstracts of the potential systematic reviews were then screened by the topic editor and categorised by medical specialty, condition or symptom. The final selection includes 24 systematic reviews, health technology assessment (HTA) or economic evaluation (EED) reports with a main focus on acupuncture and 24 reviews, systematic reviews and guidelines covering a range of CAM therapies. 

In addition a search for relevant, large-scale (100 or more participants) randomised controlled trials (RCTs) was carried out. The final selection includes 60 RCTs.


 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Acupuncture evidence update April 2008
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,APRIL 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-1Acupuncture evidence update April 2008

Introduction


The CAM Specialist Library Annual Evidence Updates on acupuncture have been introduced to identify, organise and present the most up-to-date evidence on this topic. The Library comprehensively searches a large number of databases and uses strict selection criteria for the identified studies, in order to base the annual updates on the best current evidence available. 

The studies included in this evidence update have met our selection criteria but have not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

For more details about the search methods and the selection process for this annual update see the methodology section.

For a brief overview of the topic of Acupuncture, including information on clinical uses and safety, see the introductory article.


Contents


Systematic reviews, HTA reports and selected large RCTs with a main focus on acupuncture categorised by specialty, condition or symptom

  • General reviews of acupuncture 

  • Allergies / ENT 

  • Eye diseases

  • Gastrointestinal diseases

  • Mental health

  • Musculoskeletal diseases

  • Pain/ Palliative care

  • Neurological disorders

  • Virus infections

  • Women’s health/ Pregnancy and childbirth

List of all references


A list of systematic reviews and guidelines covering a range of CAM therapies including acupuncture can be viewed here.


Researchers may be also interested in the full list of large-scale (100 or more participants) randomised controlled trials (RCTs) published since 1 January 2007 which can be viewed here.


Acknowledgement

The CAM Specialist Library project team would like to thank the topic editor Dr Mike Cummings for his contribution to the development of the 2008 Annual Evidence Update on Acupuncture.  

]]>

document.body:
This is the protocol for a Cochrane systematic review. This record will be updated when the review has been completed.

Citation

Wong V, Cheuk DKL, Lee S, Chu V. Acupuncture for acute management and rehabilitation of traumatic brain injury (Protocol). Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2009, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD007700. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD007700.

Authors' objectives

To determine the efficacy and safety of acupuncture in the acute management or rehabilitation (or both) of patients with a traumatic brain injury (TBI). This includes cognitive, neurological, motor, emotional, or behavioral complications, or a combination of such complications.

document.title: Acupuncture for autistic spectrum disorder (Cochrane protocol)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-B,AUTISTIC DISORDER,CAM GENERAL,MAY 2009,RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
This is the protocol for a Cochrane systematic review. This record will be updated when the review has been completed.

Citation

Cheuk DKL, Wong V, Chen WX. Acupuncture for autistic spectrum disorder (Protocol). Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2009, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD007849. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD007849.

Authors' objectives

The objectives of this systematic review are to determine the effectiveness and safety of acupuncture therapy in patients with autism spectrum disorder. The authors intend to assess whether acupuncture:

  1. is effective in reducing social, communication and behavioural impairments;
  2. can improve the quality of life and overall functioning;
  3. is associated with any adverse effects.
]]>

document.title: Acupuncture for back pain: meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials and an update with data from the most recent studies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-B,BACK PAIN,NOVEMBER 2006,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
Citation

Ernst E, White AR, Wider B. Acupuncture for back pain: meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials and an update with data from the most recent studies. [Akupunktur bei Ruckenschmerzen: Metaanalyse randomisierter kontrollierter Studien und update unter Berucksichtigung neuester Daten]. Schmerz. 2002, 16(2):129-39. (Article in German)

Authors' objectives

To compare a previous meta-analysis of trials of acupuncture for the treatment of back pain with a qualitative review and the most recent studies on the subject.

Authors' conclusions

Collectively, these data imply that acupuncture is superior to various control interventions, although there is insufficient evidence to state whether it is superior to placebo.

 

]]>

Citation

Zhang MM, He J, Ai CL, Li J. Acupuncture for children with cerebral palsy. (Protocol) Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2008, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD007127. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD007127.

Authors' objectives

The objective of this systematic review is to determine the efficacy and safety of acupuncture therapy for children with cerebral palsy including spastic cerebral palsy, athetoid cerebral palsy and ataxic cerebral palsy. The authors intend to test the following hypotheses:

(1) Acupuncture can improve movement function and activities of daily living.
(2) Acupuncture can improve cognitive ability.
(3) Acupuncture can improve quality of life.
(4) Acupuncture is associated with adverse effects.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Acupuncture for chronic pain in Japan: a review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,CONDITIONS A-Z,PAIN,CONDITIONS P-R,MOXIBUSTION,DATE ADDED,MAY 2008,2008]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Itoh K, Kitakoji H. Acupuncture for chronic pain in Japan: a review. Evidence-based Complementary & Alternative Medicine. 2007, 4(4):431-8.

Authors' objectives

Many Japanese reports of acupuncture and moxibustion for chronic pain are not listed in medical databases such as Medline. Therefore, they are not easily accessible to researchers outside of Japan. The aim of this reviews is to complement existing reviews of acupuncture and moxibustion for chronic pain and to provide more detailed discussion and analysis.

Authors' conclusions

The authors conclude that there is limited evidence that acupuncture is more effective than no treatment, and inconclusive evidence that trigger point acupuncture is more effective than placebo, sham acupuncture or standard care.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Acupuncture for low back pain: 2008 Annual evidence update
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,CONDITIONS A-Z,SPINAL PROBLEMS,MUSCULOSKELETAL,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,CONDITIONS,COMPLEMENTARY/ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,CONDITIONS A-B,BACK PAIN,DATE ADDED,SEPTEMBER 2008]]>
document.body:
111-1Acupuncture for low back pain: 2008 Annual evidence update

Mike Cummings, Medical Director of the British Medical Acupuncture Society


Since the 2007 National Knowledge Week on CAM for Low Back Pain several RCTs and three systematic reviews1-3 have been published. None of the reviews updated the meta-analyses performed by Furlan et al. or Manheimer et al.4,5 so they do not add much to the literature. Only one of the recently published RCTs deserves comment.


Haake et al. is the largest sham controlled RCT of acupuncture for back pain to date (n=1162).6 Subjects were aged 18 to 86 years (50±15 years) with a history of chronic low back pain for a mean of 8 years. It compared true acupuncture (10 to 15 sessions of manual needling to acupuncture points in the back and legs) with sham acupuncture (minimal needling to ‘non-points’ in the back and legs) and with a third group who received guideline based conventional care (a multimodal treatment program including physiotherapy, physical exercise, back to school program, mud packs, and heat therapy; supported by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or pain medication). The primary outcome was response after six months, defined as 33% improvement or better on three pain related items on the Von Korff Chronic Pain Grade Scale questionnaire or 12% improvement or better on the back specific Hanover Functional Ability Questionnaire. At 6 months, response rate was 47.6% in the true acupuncture group, 44.2% in the sham acupuncture group, and 27.4% in the conventional therapy group. The differences between groups were as follows: true vs sham acupuncture, 3.4% (95% confidence interval, -3.7% to 10.3%; P=0.39); true acupuncture vs conventional therapy, 20.2% (95% confidence interval, 13.4% to 26.7%; P<0.001); and sham acupuncture vs conventional therapy, 16.8% (95% confidence interval, 10.1% to 23.4%; P<0.001.


This is an interesting result. It tells us that there is little difference between classical acupuncture and minimal needling in the chronic low back pain population, but that both these interventions appear to be much better than multimodal conventional care (in a population recruited to an acupuncture trial). Some interpret the results of this trial as indicating that acupuncture is no better than placebo, however, it is hard to imagine that a true placebo (physiologically inactive treatment) would be so much better than conventional care. The effectiveness of sham acupuncture in this trial should certainly tell us that it is inappropriate to draw estimates of the clinical effectiveness and cost utility of acupuncture from the difference between real and sham acupuncture in explanatory RCTs.


This reviewer’s interpretation of the data so far on acupuncture for low back pain is that deep needling at classical acupuncture points has demonstrable (from meta-analysis) but small advantage over less specific needling in the same broad area, and that needling in general (true or sham acupuncture) is an effective and cost effective treatment in chronic low back pain.


References

1.  Ammendolia C, Furlan AD, Imamura M, Irvin E, van TM. Evidence-informed management of chronic low back pain with needle acupuncture. Spine Journal. 2008, 8(1):160-72. [Full text on journal website] 


2.  Chou R, Huffman LH. Nonpharmacologic therapies for acute and chronic low back pain: a review of the evidence for an American Pain Society/American College of Physicians clinical practice guideline. Annals of Internal Medicine. 2007, 147(7):492-504. [Full text]


3.  Itoh K, Kitakoji H. Acupuncture for chronic pain in Japan: A review. Evidence-based Complementary and Alternative Medicine. 2007, 4:-438. [Full text] 


4.  Furlan AD, van Tulder MW, Cherkin DC, Tsukayama H, Lao L, Koes BW, Berman BM. Acupuncture and dry-needling for low back pain. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2005, Issue 1. Art. No.: CD001351. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD001351.pub2. [Full text]


5.  Manheimer E, White A, Berman B, Forys K, Ernst E. Meta-analysis: acupuncture for low back pain. Annals of Internal Medicine. 2005, 142:651-63. [Full text] [DARE structured abstract].  


6.  Haake M, Müller HH, Schade-Brittinger C, Basler HD, Schäfer H, Maier C, Endres HG, Trampisch HJ, Molsberger A. German Acupuncture Trials (GERAC) for chronic low back pain: randomized, multicenter, blinded, parallel-group trial with 3 groups. Archives of Internal Medicine. 2007, 167(17):1892-8. [PubMed abstract]


 

Link back to Annual evidence update on CAM for low back pain 2008

 

]]>

document.title: Acupuncture for lowering blood pressure: systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS F-H,HYPERTENSION,HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE,MAY 2009]]>
document.body:

Citation

Lee H, Kim SY, Park J, Kim YJ, Lee H, Park HJ. Acupuncture for lowering blood pressure: systematic review and meta-analysis. Am J Hypertens. 2009 Jan;22(1):122-8. 

Authors' objectives

To conduct a systematic review to estimate the effect of acupuncture on blood pressure (BP) in hypertensive patients.

Authors' conclusions

Considering the limitation of the four positive noninferiority studies and the results of the meta-analysis of the three sham-controlled studies, the notion that acupuncture may lower high BP is inconclusive. More rigorous trials are warranted.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Acupuncture for Parkinson's Disease (Cochrane protocol)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS P-R,PARKINSON’S DISEASE,NOVEMBER 2006,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED,RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
This is the protocol for a Cochrane systematic review. This record will be updated when the review has been completed.

Citation

Wang L, Xie Y, Zhang S, Wu T. Acupuncture for Parkinson's Disease. (Protocol) Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2006, Issue 4. Art. No.: CD006236. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD006236.

Authors' objectives

To compare the efficacy, safety, tolerability, and cost of acupuncture versus any other conventional therapy, or no treatment, for patients with idiopathic PD. The following points will be addressed:

  • Does acupuncture decrease the morbidity and mortality associated with PD in the long-term?
  • Does acupuncture improve levels of disability and, impairment in patient with PD in the short-term?
  • Does the use of acupuncture therapy lead to a reduction in the use of anti-Parkinsonian medication or the number of referrals for surgery?
  • Does acupuncture improve the quality of life for people with PD?
  • Are people with PD satisfied with acupuncture therapy, is it acceptable and tolerable for them?
  • What adverse effects are associated with acupuncture therapy?
  • What are the costs associated with acupuncture therapy, particularly when compared to conventional therapy costs?
]]>

document.title: Acupuncture for premenstrual syndrome (Cochrane protocol)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,PREMENSTRUAL SYNDROME,CONDITIONS P-R,CAM GENERAL,RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
This is the protocol for a Cochrane systematic review. This record will be updated when the review has been completed.

Citation

Yu J, Robinson VA, Liu B, Liu Z, Wu T. Acupuncture for premenstrual syndrome. (Protocol) The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2005, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD005290. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD005290. 

Authors' objectives

To evaluate the effectiveness and safety of acupuncture or electroacupuncture in the treatment of women with premenstrual syndrome.

Comparisons between groups intended for treatment with any type of acupuncture and groups allocated to 'sham' acupuncture, no treatment, Chinese medicine, Western medicine or other treatments. The following hypotheses will be tested:
(1) acupuncture is superior to 'sham' acupuncture or no treatment in treating PMS;
(2) acupuncture is superior to other treatments or Western medicine or Chinese medicine in treating PMS;
(3) there are less adverse events in the acupuncture group than in the Chinese medicine or Western medicine groups.

]]>

document.title: Acupuncture for the alleviation of lateral epicondyle pain: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,PAIN,TENNIS ELBOW,CONDITIONS T-Z,CONDITIONS P-R]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Trinh K V, Phillips S D, Ho E, Damsma K. Acupuncture for the alleviation of lateral epicondyle pain: a systematic review. Rheumatology. 2004, 43(9): 1085-1090.

Full-text online access to this journal is available to NHS staff via ATHENS passwords.

Authors' objectives

This review evaluates the effectiveness of acupuncture as a treatment for lateral epicondylitis.

Authors' conclusions

There is strong evidence suggesting that acupuncture is effective in the short-term relief of lateral epicondyle pain.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Acupuncture for the treatment of post-operative pain (Cochrane protocol)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,NEUROPATHIC PAIN,BONE PAIN,PAIN MANAGEMENT,VISCERAL PAIN,COMPLEMENTARY & ALTERNATIVE THERAPIES,PAIN,CONDITIONS P-R,JULY 2006,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This is the protocol for a Cochrane systematic review. This record will be updated when the review has been completed.

Citation

Manheimer E, Eaton K, Lao L, White A, Morozova O. Acupuncture for the treatment of post-operative pain. (Protocol) Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2006, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD006042. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD006042.

Authors' objectives

To review all randomized or quasi-randomized (not strictly randomized methods of allocation e.g., by date of birth, hospital record number or alternation) controlled trials pertaining to the efficacy of acupuncture in the treatment of acute postoperative pain. The three specific objectives of this systematic review are:
1) to assess the efficacy of acupuncture compared to sham controls (i.e., sham acupuncture and other sham treatments) for postoperative pain.
2) to assess the efficacy of acupuncture plus standard medical treatment compared to standard medical care alone for postoperative pain.
3) to assess the efficacy of acupuncture compared to standard medical treatment for postoperative pain.

]]>

Authors' objectives

The review aims to determine whether real acupuncture is more efficacious than other treatments in patients with fibromyalgia. The following comparisons will be made:
1. Real acupuncture versus non-acupuncture treatment (e.g. wait list or drug therapy).
2. Real acupuncture versus placebo or sham acupuncture.
3. Real acupuncture versus standard or usual care (e.g. physiotherapy or exercise).
4. A particular style of acupuncture versus another.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Acupuncture for vasomotor menopausal symptoms: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,CONDITIONS A-Z,MENOPAUSAL SYMPTOMS,HOT FLUSHES,CONDITIONS M-O,CONDITIONS F-H,JULY 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Cho SH, Whang WW. Acupuncture for vasomotor menopausal symptoms: a systematic review. Menopause. 2009;16(5):1065-73.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this study was to critically assess whether acupuncture therapy reduces vasomotor menopausal symptoms and to evaluate the adverse effects of acupuncture therapy on the basis of the results of randomized controlled trials (RCTs). 

Authors' conclusions

There is no evidence from RCTs that acupuncture is an effective treatment in comparison to sham acupuncture for reducing menopausal hot flashes. Some studies have shown that acupuncture therapies are better than hormone therapy for reducing vasomotor symptoms. However, the number of RCTs compared with a nonpenetrating placebo control needle or hormone therapy was too small, and the methodological quality of some of the RCTs was poor. Further evaluation of the effects of acupuncture on vasomotor menopausal symptoms based on a well-controlled placebo trial is therefore warranted.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Acupuncture in dermatology - Current state of clinical research
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,SKIN DISEASES,CONDITIONS S,JUNE 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Pfab F, Behrendt H, Darsow U, Ring J. Acupuncture in dermatology - Current state of clinical research. Deutsche Zeitschrift fur Akupunktur. 2008, 51(4):30-2. [Article in German]

Authors' objectives

To review the current state of clinical research regarding the evidence of acupuncture in the treatment of selected dermatological diseases and symptoms.

Authors' conclusions

Due to the limited number of studies so far no recommendation can be given regarding the effectiveness of acupuncture as a means to treat dermatological diseases.

However, using acupuncture to treat such symptoms as nausea, vomiting, postoperative pain and itch has shown beneficial effects. Further studies should be carried out addressing the many open questions.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Acupuncture in medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE]]>
document.body:
Acupuncture in Medicine is a quarterly scientific and clinical journal aimed at Western-trained physicians and other health professionals, and uses the prevailing understanding of neurophysiology and anatomy to interpret the effects of acupuncture. The Journal largely restricts its published articles to this western approach. Clinical reports of the effects of traditional acupuncture will be considered, and theoretical aspects that are evidence-based.

Website provides index to previous issues. Non-subscribers who register have free access to all articles published before 2006 right back to volume 1 issue 1.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Acupuncture in soft tissue injury management: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,WOUNDS AND INJURIES,CONDITIONS T-Z,DECEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Harland S, Bleakley C, McDonough SM. Acupuncture in soft tissue injury management: a systematic review. [Rehabilitation and Therapy Research Society Third Annual Conference: Collaborative research... making it a reality, held on 26-27 April 2007 at University of Ulster]. Physical Therapy Reviews. 2008, 13(2):121-123.

Authors' objectives

To carry out a systematic review to assess the clinical evidence base for the use of acupuncture in managing acute soft tissue injury.

Authors' conclusions

There is high quality evidence supporting the use of acupuncture in treating shoulder injury, and there is preliminary evidence of an optimal treatment protocol. There is no high quality evidence to support theuse of acupuncture in other types of soft tissue injury.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Acupuncture in the management of tension-type headache
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS F-H,HEADACHE,JULY 2007,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Jedel E, Carlsson J. Acupuncture in the management of tension-type headache. Physical Therapy Reviews. 2005, 10(3):131-139.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this systematic review was two-fold: to assess the efficacy of acupuncture in the management of tension-type headache, and to compare three criteria lists assessing the quality of studies.

Authors' conclusions

This systematic review shows that qualitative assessments by three criteria lists focusing on internal validity, gave the same results, and that there is limited evidence for the efficacy of acupuncture in the management of tension-type headache.  

]]>

Fink M, Rosted P, Bernateck M, Stiesch-Scholz M, Karst M. Acupuncture in the treatment of painful dysfunction of the temporomandibular joint -- a review of the literature. Forschende Komplementärmedizin (2006). 2006, 13(2):109-15.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this study was to analyze the results of randomized clinical trials on the efficacy of acupuncture in the treatment of painful dysfunction of the temporomandibular joint. 

Authors' conclusions

Acupuncture appears to be a suitable complementary treatment method in the management of craniomandibular dysfunction. However, its significance has to be further evaluated in future studies.

document.title: Acupuncture of the ear as therapeutic approach in the treatment of alcohol and substance abuse: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,CONDITIONS A-Z,ALCOHOL MISUSE,DRUG USE DISORDERS,CONDITIONS D-E,CONDITIONS A-B,OCTOBER 2006,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Kunz S, Schulz M, Syrbe G, Driessen M. Ohrakupunktur in der Therapie alkohol und substanzbezogener Storungen: eine Ubersicht [Acupuncture of the ear as therapeutic approach in the treatment of alcohol and substance abuse: a systematic review]. SUCHT. 2004, 50(3): 196–203.

Authors' objectives

Acupuncture as a treatment of substance-related disorders has reached increasing acceptance. A systematic review of the available studies is provided to determine if this trend is supported by the scientific evidence from RCTs.

Authors' conclusions

The available scientific evidence does not support the efficacy of acupuncture in the treatment of withdrawal in opiate-, cocaine- and alcohol-dependent patients.

]]>

document.title: Acupuncture treatment for chronic knee pain: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,CONDITIONS A-Z,MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,COMPLEMENTARY/ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,PAIN MANAGEMENT,SOFT TISSUE RHEUMATISM,OSTEOARTHRITIS,KNEE DISORDERS,CONDITIONS P-R,MUSCULOSKELETAL DISEASES,PAIN,CONDITIONS M-O,JUNE 2007,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

White A, Foster NE, Cummings M, Barlas P. Acupuncture treatment for chronic knee pain: a systematic review. Rheumatology (Oxford). 2007, 46(3):384-90. 

Authors' objectives

To evaluate the effects of acupuncture on pain and function in patients with chronic knee pain.

Authors' conclusions

Acupuncture that meets criteria for adequate treatment is significantly superior to sham acupuncture and to no additional intervention in improving pain and function in patients with chronic knee pain. Due to the heterogeneity in the results, however, further research is required to confirm these findings and provide more information on long-term effects.

Access

Full-text online access to this article is available to NHS staff via ATHENS password.

Citation

Jordan JB. Acupuncture treatment for opiate addiction: a systematic review. Journal of Substance Abuse Treatment. 2006, 30(4):309-14.

Authors' objectives

To assess the efficacy of acupuncture as treatment for opiate addiction.

Authors' conclusions

When well-designed clinical trials (randomized, controlled, single-blind methodologies) were used, there was no significant evidence for acupuncture being a more effective treatment than controls. Some of the current supportive evidence for efficacy came from Chinese journals that have not been translated into English yet.

Citation

Authors' objectives

To assess the efficacy of acupuncture versus western medicine in the treatment of depression in China.

Authors' conclusions

Acupuncture is not inferior to western medicine, and it is worth noting that acupuncture is associated with few adverse reactions. Further large-scale trials are required to define the role of acupuncture in the treatment of depression.

document.body:
The aim of the Complementary Therapy service provided by the Christie Hospital, NHS Foundation Trust in Manchester is to support patients and their carers through all stages of a cancer diagnosis.

This website provides information about future courses, workshops and conferences organised by the Integrative Therapies Training Unit on a range of complementary therapies such as aromatherapy, massage, reflexology and therapeutic touch.

For more information and links to course descriptions and schedule for 2008-2010 see Complementary Therapy Services pages.

document.title: Adherence to Mediterranean diet and health status: meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,NOVEMBER 2008,2008,DATE ADDED,SPECIAL DIETS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.


Citation

Sofi F, Cesari F, Abbate R, Gensini G F, Casini A. Adherence to Mediterranean diet and health status: meta-analysis. BMJ. 2008, 337: a1344. 

Authors' objectives

To systematically review all the prospective cohort studies that have analysed the relation between adherence to a Mediterranean diet, mortality, and incidence of chronic diseases in a primary prevention setting.

Authors' conclusions

Greater adherence to a Mediterranean diet is associated with a significant improvement in health status, as seen by a significant reduction in overall mortality (9%), mortality from cardiovascular diseases (9%), incidence of or mortality from cancer (6%), and incidence of Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's disease (13%). These results seem to be clinically relevant for public health, in particular for encouraging a Mediterranean-like dietary pattern for primary prevention of major chronic diseases.

]]>

document.title: Advances in heroin addiction treatment with traditional Chinese medicine: a systematic review of recent Chinese language journals
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),DRUG USE DISORDERS,CONDITIONS D-E,DECEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Jordan JB, Tu X. Advances in heroin addiction treatment with traditional Chinese medicine: a systematic review of recent Chinese language journals. American Journal of Chinese Medicine. 2008;36(3):437-47.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this review is to critically examine the clinical trial research on Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) as an intervention in treating heroin addiction in People's Republic of China. 

Authors' conclusions

Most trials were excluded because they did not declare randomization and had poor methodology or reporting. The majority of clinical evidence in the random controlled trials demonstrates good evidence for TCM patent medicines in heroin addiction treatment. When compared to typical Western medications, TCMs demonstrate fewer side-effects, in addition to equal measures of treatment efficacy and safety.

Access

document.title: Adverse consequences of Internet purchase of pharmacologic agents or dietary supplements
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,JANUARY 2011,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Kwan D, Beyene J, Shah PS. Adverse consequences of internet purchase of pharmacologic agents or dietary supplements. Journal of Pharmacy Technology. 2009, 25(6):355-360.

Authors' objectives

To systematically identify and examine reported cases of adverse events associated with the purchase of medications and dietary supplements from the Internet. 

Authors' conclusions

An unexpectedly large number of case reports were identified from the literature; however, these reports do not fully illustrate the magnitude of the problem. Life-endangering adverse consequences signify a need for increased regulation and control of Internet Web sites and a need for healthcare provider involvement. Pharmacists should know where their patients obtain medications, how to verify the validity of the sources of prescriptions, and how to report adverse consequences.

Access

document.title: Adverse drug reactions and adverse events of 33 varieties of traditional Chinese medicine injections on National Essential medicines List (2004 edition) of China: an overview on published literatures
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),SAFETY,CAM GENERAL,JANUARY 2011]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Wang L, Yuan Q, Marshall G, Cui X, Cheng L, Li Y, Shang H, Zhang B,  Li Y. Adverse drug reactions and adverse events of 33 varieties of traditional Chinese medicine injections on National Essential medicines List (2004 edition) of China: an overview on published literatures. Journal of Evidence-Based Medicine. 2010, 3:95–104.

Authors' objectives

The authors conducted a literature review on adverse drug reactions (ADRs) related to 33 kinds of traditional Chinese medicine injections (CMIs) on China's National Essential medicines List (2004 edition). The aim was to retrieve basic ADR information, identify trends related to CMIs, and provide evidence for the research, development, and application of CMIs.

Authors' conclusions

(1) Articles published on CMI-related ADRs increased over time, but overall the research is of low quality and is scattered through a large number of sources. (2) Four CMIs (Shuanghuanglian, Ciwujia, Yuxingcao, and Yinzhihuang injections) had been suspended for clinical use or sale. (3) There is an urgent need for a clear standard to grade ADRs of CMIs in order to better risk manage. (4) It is necessary to continually re-evaluate the safety of CMIs and to promote rational use of CMIs.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.title: Adverse drug reactions linked to Ciwujia injection: a systematic review of 521 cases
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,HERBAL MEDICINE,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),SAFETY,CAM GENERAL,JANUARY 2011]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Hu J, Shang H, Li J, Zhang L, Zhang J, Zheng W, Li T, Zhang B, Li Y. Adverse drug reactions linked to Ciwujia injection: a systematic review of 521 cases. Journal of Evidence-Based Medicine. 2010, 3: 37–43.

Authors' objectives

To analyze adverse drug reactions (ADRs) associated with Ciwujia injection and possible contributing factors.

Authors' conclusions

The relevant information of ADRs for Ciwujia injection was insufficiently reported in included studies. The ADR type distribution between clinical studies and ADR reports was inconsistency. Most of the reported ADRs were mild, and were treated successfully by slowing down the drip velocity or by withdrawing the drug and treating the symptoms. As Ciwujia injection was one of the highest numbers of ADR reports of traditional Chinese medicine injections, high quality ADR monitoring, standardized ADR reporting, and timely analysis risk factors of ADRs are extremely urgent.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.  

]]>

document.title: Adverse effects of spinal manipulation: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OSTEOPATHY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CHIROPRACTIC,SAFETY,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL,FEBRUARY 2008]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Ernst E. Adverse effects of spinal manipulation: a systematic review. Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 2007, 100(7):330-8.

Authors' objectives

To identify adverse effects of spinal manipulation.

Authors' conclusions

Spinal manipulation, particularly when performed on the upper spine, is frequently associated with mild to moderate adverse effects. It can also result in serious complications such as vertebral artery dissection followed by stroke. Currently, the incidence of such events is not known. In the interest of patient safety we should reconsider our policy towards the routine use of spinal manipulation.
 

]]>

document.title: Adverse effects of St. John's Wort: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,ST JOHN'S WORT (HYPERICUM PERFORATUM),COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBS R-Z,SAFETY,CAM GENERAL,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:

Citation

Knüppel L, Linde K. Adverse effects of St. John's Wort: a systematic review. Journal of Clinical Psychiatry. 2004 Nov;65(11):1470-9.

Authors' objectives

To obtain an overview of the available clinical evidence on safety and tolerability of hypericum extracts, we reviewed (1) dropout rates and adverse effects in double-blind randomized trials comparing hypericum extracts and placebo or synthetic standard antidepressants; (2) dropout rates and adverse effects in large-scale observational studies; and (3) adverse effects reported in published cases and to public drug surveillance agencies.

Authors' conclusions

The available evidence suggests that hypericum extracts are well tolerated and safe if taken under control of a physician who is aware of potentially relevant risks in specific circumstances.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Adverse event reporting in acupuncture clinical trials focusing on pain
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS P-R,PAIN,JULY 2010,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Capili B, Anastasi JK, Geiger JN. Adverse event reporting in acupuncture clinical trials focusing on pain. Clinical Journal of Pain. 2010;26(1):43-8.

Authors' objectives

To review the quality of adverse event reporting for published randomized controlled trials (RCTs) focusing on acupuncture for pain reduction. With the release of the Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials (CONSORT) in 2001, the quality of published RCTs has improved. To improve reporting on adverse events, CONSORT expanded the section on harms (adverse events) in 2004. This paper evaluates whether the updated harms guidelines have been implemented in RCTs evaluating acupuncture for pain relief.

Authors' conclusions

On the basis of the findings, acupuncture clinical trials for pain reduction have yet to comprehensively meet CONSORT's guidelines for adverse event reporting. Acupuncture is commonly used by patients experiencing pain and although typically viewed as a benign and minimally invasive therapy, serious adverse events have been reported in the literature. To effectively and comprehensively document and understand these events, routine reporting according to CONSORT's harms guidelines should become the norm. Both science and patients are served by accurately evaluating the safety of acupuncture for patient populations experiencing pain.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Adverse events associated with paediatric use of complementary and alternative medicine: Results of a Canadian Paediatric Surveillance Program survey
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,JULY 2010,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY,USE OF CAM]]>
document.body:
Citation

Vohra S, Brulotte J, Le C, Charrois T, Laeeque H. Adverse events associated with paediatric use of complementary and alternative medicine: Results of a Canadian Paediatric Surveillance Program survey. Paediatrics and Child Health. 2009, 14(6):385-7.

Objectives

To conduct a national survey to identify the frequency and severity of adverse events associated with paediatric CAM use.

Conclusions

While serious adverse events associated with paediatric CAM appear to be rare, delays in diagnosis or treatment seem more common. Given the lack of paediatrician-patient discussion regarding CAM use, our findings may under-represent adverse events. A lack of reported adverse events should not be interpreted as a confirmation of safety. Active surveillance is required to accurately assess the incidence, nature and severity of paediatric CAM-related adverse events. Patient safety demands that paediatricians routinely inquire about the use of CAM.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Adverse events of herbal food supplements for body weight reduction: systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS M-O,OBESITY,SEPTEMBER 2010,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Pittler MH, Schmidt K, Ernst E. Adverse events of herbal food supplements for body weight reduction: systematic review. Obesity Reviews. 2005, 6(2):93-111.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this systematic review was to assess all clinical evidence of adverse events of herbal food supplements for body weight reduction for which effectiveness data from rigorous clinical trials exist. We assessed Ephedra sinica, Garcinia cambogia, Paullinia cupana, guar gum, Plantago psyllium, Ilex paraguariensis and Pausinystalia yohimbe. 

Authors' conclusions

Adverse events are reported for a number of herbal food supplements, which are used for reducing body weight. Although the quality of the data does not justify definitive attribution of causality in most cases, the reported risks are sufficient to shift the risk-benefit balance against the use of most of the reviewed herbal weight-loss supplements. Exceptions are Garcinia cambogia and yerba mate, which merit further investigation.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

Authors' objectives

The aim of this review was to identify adverse events of moxibustion as reported in the medical literature.

Authors' conclusions

Moxibustion is not entirely risk free, as it has several kinds of potential adverse events such as allergy, burn and infection. Currently, the incidence of such events is not known. In the interest of patient safety, sufficiently large prospective studies should be considered to clarify this issue.

document.title: Adverse neuropsychiatric reactions to herbal and over-the-counter "antidepressants"
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,ST JOHN'S WORT (HYPERICUM PERFORATUM),CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,HERBS R-Z,CARBOHYDRATES & CARBOHYDRATE DERIVATIVES,SEPTEMBER 2010,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY,DEHYDROEPIANDROSTERONE (DHEA),NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,OTHER SUPPLEMENTS,INOSITOL,SAME (S-ADENOSYL-L-METHIONINE)]]>
document.body:
Citation

Pies R. Adverse neuropsychiatric reactions to herbal and over-the-counter "antidepressants". Journal of Clinical Psychiatry. 2000, 61(11):815-20.

Author's objectives

Many unregulated over-the-counter agents for the treatment of depression are now available to patients and consumers. The potential for adverse neuropsychiatric effects with these agents has not been systematically studied in most cases. 

Author's conclusions

Although some over-the-counter remedies for depression are probably safe and effective for as-yet unidentified subgroups of depressed individuals, more research is required before these agents can be recommended for routine use. Stricter U.S. Food and Drug Administration oversight of these agents is indicated.

document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBS H-P,HEART FAILURE,HAWTHORN (CRATAEGUS),CONDITIONS F-H,SAFETY,CAM GENERAL,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>

Citation

Authors' objectives

The aim of this article is to assess the safety data of all available human studies on hawthorn monopreparations.

Authors' conclusions

All data reviewed in this article seem to indicate that hawthorn is well tolerated even if some severe adverse events were reported; this suggests that further studies are needed to better assess the safety of hawthorn-containing preparations. Moreover, the unsupervised use of this drug can be associated with problems, especially if given with concomitant medications.

document.title: Alternative medicine and Alzheimer disease
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE,CONDITIONS A-B,DECEMBER 2009,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Kelley BJ, Knopman DS. Alternative medicine and Alzheimer disease. Neurologist. 2008, 14(5):299-306.

Authors' objectives

This paper discusses the available clinical trial evidence regarding 8 agents commonly used by people having Alzheimer disease. 

Authors' conclusions

Although many of these compounds have been associated with interesting basic science, none has shown clear clinical benefit to date. Data available for some, such as Ginkgo biloba, curcumin, and huperzine A, suggest that further evaluation is warranted. Familiarity with this literature will allow clinicians to provide meaningful recommendations to patients who wish to use these agents.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Alternative medicine research in clinical practice: a U.S. national survey
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CAM GENERAL,APRIL 2009,RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
Background and objectives

Little is known about whether federally funded complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) research is translating into clinical practice. The authors sought to describe the awareness of CAM clinical trials, the ability to interpret research results, the acceptance of research evidence, and the predictors of trial awareness among US clinicians.

Methods

The athors conducted a cross-sectional mailed survey of 2400 practicing US acupuncturists, naturopaths, internists, and rheumatologists. 

Conclusion

For clinical research in CAM to achieve its social value, concerted efforts must be undertaken to train clinicians and improve the dissemination of research results.

Citation

Tilburt JC, Curlin FA, Kaptchuk TJ, Clarridge B, Bolcic-Jankovic D, Emanuel EJ, Miller FG. Alternative medicine research in clinical practice: a US national survey. Archives of Internal Medicine. 2009, 169(7):670-7.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Alzheimer's Disease and Cognitive Decline
document.publisher: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE,DEMENTIA,CONDITIONS A-B,CONDITIONS D-E,NOVEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
Citation

Alzheimer's Disease and Cognitive Decline, Structured Abstract. April 2010. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, Rockville, MD. http://www.ahrq.gov/clinic/tp/alzcogtp.htm.

Authors' objectives

To assess whether previous research on purported risk or protective factors for Alzheimer's disease (AD) and cognitive decline is of sufficient strength to warrant specific recommendations for behavioral, lifestyle, or pharmaceutical interventions/modifications targeted to these endpoints.

Authors' conclusions

The current research on the list of putative risk or protective factors is largely inadequate to confidently assess their association with AD or cognitive decline. Further research that addresses the limitations of existing studies is needed prior to be able to make recommendations on interventions.

]]>

document.title: An evidence-based systematic review of herb and supplement interactions by the Natural Standard Research Collaboration
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,SAFETY,CAM GENERAL,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Ulbricht C, Basch E, Weissner W, Hackman D. An evidence-based systematic review of herb and supplement interactions by the Natural Standard Research Collaboration. Expert Opinion on Drug Safety. 2006, 5(5):719-28.

Abstract

Reported utilisation of prescription drug use concurrently with herbal or vitamin products have increased, placing an estimated 15 million patients at risk of potential drug-supplement interactions. This systematic review aims to consolidate relevant herb and supplement interactions data available for some of the more common classes of interactions experienced by clinicians. These classes include: hypoglycaemic/hyperglycaemics; hypotensive/hypertensives, diuretics, sedatives, cardiac glycosides, monoamine oxidase inhibitors, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, laxatives, immunomodulators, agents that may increase the risk of bleeding or clotting, agents that may be hepatotoxic, agents that may have hormonal properties, and agents with cytochrome P450 enzyme activity. The format is designed to promote use as a decision support tool for healthcare providers.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: An update on drug interactions with the herbal medicine Ginkgo biloba
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,GINKGO (GINKGO BILOBA),HERBS D-G,SAFETY,CAM GENERAL,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Abad MJ, Bedoya LM, Bermejo P. An update on drug interactions with the herbal medicine Ginkgo biloba. Current Drug Metabolism. 2010, 11(2):171-81.

Abstract

Medicinal plants are gaining in popularity due to the various advantages they offer, such as fewer side-effects, better patient compliance, relatively low cost and high accessibility as well as their high acceptability due to a long history of use. There is a widespread belief among the general public that herbal preparations are "good for humans" as they are "all natural". However, the increasing use of herbal medicinal products in the community where people are also receiving prescription medicines suggests that adverse herb-drug interactions may be have significant public health consequences. There is little understanding or appreciation of the fact that these "all natural" preparations are actually a combination of potentially biologically active compounds already existing in marketed products in unknown quantities. Among the most popular herbal products used worldwide is Ginkgo biloba, used for the treatment of cerebral insufficiency, peripheral vascular diseases, and frequently taken for the enhancement of memory function. Although the safety of Ginkgo biloba is promising, accumulated data show evidence of significant interactions with medications, which can place individual patients at great risk. In this review, we examined the literature from 2000 to 2008 and focused on the importance of the risk of drug interactions and potential side effects when Ginkgo biloba is involved. The aim of this systematic review is to assess the clinical evidence on interactions between Ginkgo biloba and drugs.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

Authors' objectives

To assess the potential benefit of silymarin (special extract from the fruits of Silybum marianum) in the treatment of liver diseases. 

Authors' conclusions

Based on the available clinical evidence it can be concluded - concerning possible risks /probable benefits - that it is reasonable to employ silymarin as a supportive element in the therapy of Amanita phalloides poisoning but also (alcoholic and grade Child 'A') liver cirrhosis. A consistent research programme, consolidating existing evidence and exploring new potential uses, would be very welcome.

Citation

Poolsup N, Suthisisang C, Prathanturarug S, Asawamekin A, Chanchareon U. Andrographis paniculata in the symptomatic treatment of uncomplicated upper respiratory tract infection: systematic review of randomized controlled trials. Journal of Clinical Pharmacy and Therapeutics. 2004, 29(1): 37-45.

document.body:
111-1Annual evidence update on CAM for asthma 2008



 

Introduction


The evidence update on CAM for asthma aims to identify, organise and present the latest information on this topic. We have searched a large number of databases for studies published or updated since January 2006. Previously published studies are addressed in sections 3.4 - 3.6 of the British Guideline on the Management of Asthma or can be found in the Library's collection. 

For more details about our methods, please see the methodology section and for further information on asthma see the relevant pages from the Respiratory Specialist Library.


Contents


Complementary and alternative medicine use in asthma in the UK: an insight from recent research 


Recent systematic reviews focusing on specific CAM interventions for the management of asthma:

  • Acupuncture
  • Breathing techniques/ Yoga
  • Dietary and nutritional therapies
  • Herbal medicine
  • Homeopathy
  • Relaxation techniques/ Hypnosis


Related events

The Children's Complementary Therapy Network will hold its 3rd Annual Children’s Complementary Therapy Network (CCTN) Conference on 17th May at the Birmingham Children’s Hospital. The conference theme is "Childhood conditions: asthma, eczema and cerebral palsy".



List of references                     Methodology

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Annual evidence update on CAM for low back pain 2008: Editorial
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DATE ADDED,AUGUST 2008]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual evidence update on CAM for low back pain 2008: Editorial

Dr George Lewith, University of Southampton


Haldeman and Dagenais’s recent editorial in The Spine Journal  beautifully illustrates the current therapeutic confusion about the treatment of back pain; a plethora of equally effective interventions, including both conventional and CAM approaches, appear to be on offer in our health “supermarkets”.1,2 Further research, rather than illuminating the problem often appears to confuse those wishing to refer patients with this pervasive, common and costly chronic benign condition.  

What can the referrer do when faced with a patient with chronic back pain? Recent evidence suggests that individuals who suffer back pain particularly in middle age, get better very slowly from the acute episodes and very often have ongoing problems. Back pain is perhaps part of the “human condition”, probably exacerbated by our 21st Century indolence and sedentary lifestyle. Therefore excluding dreadful and dangerous interventions is clearly important. Haldeman and Dagenais imply that it is almost impossible to choose the “best therapy” out there but I would suggest some very simple rules of thumb about referral for treatment in this condition.

  • Do something that is safe. That means trying to avoid long-term medication with adverse reactions and potentially dangerous surgical procedures unless absolutely necessary.
  • Do something that empowers your patient.  This probably means discussing with your patient how they think their back pain occurred and what they think might work for them. Matching the patient’s expectations with treatment is the sort of individualisation that maximises placebo effect through motivational concordance3.
  • If all treatments have relatively equal outcomes for large heterogeneous groups then individualising the approach based on patient preference and beliefs may be the most effective referral process.
  • If the problem persists, keep trying new approaches. The evidence suggests that those who suffer from back pain may engage in therapeutic experimentation until they find the approach that is effective for them.
  • Encourage self-management in association with whatever treatment the back pain sufferer is using.  It is usually safer and always cheaper!

Treating chronic low back pain in the community is rather like navigating through chaos!  Identifying the approach that best suits your patient and encouraging them and supporting them through it is probably the only sensible way forward. There is no “perfect solution” to back pain and from the evidence we have now available such a solution is unlikely to emerge.


References

1. Haldeman S, Dagenais S. A supermarket approach to the evidence-informed management of chronic low back pain. Spine Journal. 2008, 8(1):1-7. [Full text on journal website]


2. Haldeman S, Dagenais S. What have we learned about the evidence-informed management of chronic low back pain? Spine Journal. 2008, 8(1):266-77. [Full text on journal website] 


3. Hyland ME, Whalley B.  Motivational concordance: An important mechanism in self-help therapeutic rituals involving inert (placebo) substances. Journal of Psychosomatic Research (in press).

 

Link back to Annual evidence update on CAM for low back pain 2008

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Annual evidence update on CAM for low back pain 2008: Search methodology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,AUGUST 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-1Annual evidence update on CAM for low back pain 2008: Search methodologyThe annual evidence update on CAM for Low Back Pain aims to identify, organise and present the latest information on this topic. The Library has searched comprehensively a large number of databases, covering the period from June 2007 to July/August 2008. Previously published studies have been included in the 2007 National Knowledge Week (NKW) on CAM for Low Back Pain.


Sources searched


The Cochrane Library (CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHS EED), PubMed (and MEDLINE), EMBASE, AMED, CINAHL, PsycINFO, the Musculoskeletal Diseases Specialist Library and the Trauma & Orthopaedics Specialist Library.


Selection criteria


Inclusion criteria:

- Explicit description of search process and statement of methodology (at least 2 sources must have been searched and/or there must be a statement that the study is a meta-analysis or a systematic review).
- Topic relevance (studies should be focused on low back pain).
- Study types: guidance/guidelines, systematic reviews and/or meta-analyses, systematic overviews, HTA reports, cost effectiveness and economic evaluation studies, RCTs.

Exclusion criteria:

- The study is not one of the types specified above.
- The main focus is not on low back pain (e.g., a systematic review on specific therapy, which may include a range of conditions). 
- The study is published in a language other than English and English abstract is not available.


Search strategy

The search strategy included text words and indexing terms for low back pain, for CAM in general and for specific CAM therapies, and methodological filters for systematic reviews and randomised controlled trials (RCTs).

The search strategy for low back pain is based on the Cochrane Back Group strategy.

Below is an example of the strategy used to search the MEDLINE (DIALOG) database. 


1. dorsalgia.TI,AB.
2. (back ADJ pain).TI,AB.
3. BACK-PAIN#.DE
4. backache.TI,AB.
5. sciatica.TI,AB.
6. SCIATICA#.W..DE.
7. (lumbar ADJ pain).TI,AB.
8. lumbago.TI,AB.
9. OR/1-8

More details of the search terms and filters used are available by contacting the Library's information specialist. 


Search results

The total number of records retrieved was 230 (excluding RCTs). After removing the duplicates there were 101 citations. Of these, 23 were selected as potential systematic reviews or other relevant study types. The titles and abstracts were further screened for relevance. Studies with a main focus on non-clinical topics, narrative reviews and protocols of on-going systematic reviews were excluded at this stage.

The final selection included 14 systematic reviews, meta-analyses, systematic overviews of primary and secondary research and cost-effectiveness studies. Based on the identified studies several topics were selected for preparing brief commentaries on the evidence about the use of specific therapies in the management of low back pain.

In addition a search for randomised controlled trials (RCTs) was carried out on the Cochrane CENTRAL database. This was to done to identify any recent RCTs that have been published after the completion of the respective systematic reviews. This search found 24 potentially relevant studies of which 12 were included.

A list of all relevant studies is given in the Studies Found page.

 

Link back to 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM for low back pain

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Anthocyanosides of Vaccinium myrtillus (bilberry) for night vision--a systematic review of placebo-controlled trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,NOVEMBER 2006,VISION DISORDERS,CONDITIONS T-Z,BILBERRY (VACCINIUM MYRTILLUS),HERBS A-C,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Canter PH, Ernst E. Anthocyanosides of Vaccinium myrtillus (bilberry) for night vision--a systematic review of placebo-controlled trials. Survey of Ophthalmology. 2004, 49(1):38-50.

Authors' objectives

To review systematically placebo-controlled trials of V. myrtillus-extracted anthocyanosides for evidence of positive effects on night vision.

Authors' conclusions

The hypothesis that V. myrtillus anthocyanosides improves normal night vision is not supported by evidence from rigorous clinical studies. There is a complete absence of rigorous research into the effects of the extract on subjects suffering impaired night vision due to pathological eye conditions. Evidence from methodologically weaker trials and auxiliary evidence from animal studies, trials of synthetic anthocyanosides, and a recent randomized controlled trial of Ribes nigrum (black currant) anthocyanosides may warrant further trials of V. myrtillus anthocyanosides in subjects with impaired night vision.

 

]]>
