document.title: Antioxidant vitamins and the risk of endometrial cancer: a dose-response meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,VITAMINS,VITAMIN E,VITAMIN C,BETA-CAROTENE,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Bandera EV, Gifkins DM, Moore DF, McCullough ML, Kushi LH. Antioxidant vitamins and the risk of endometrial cancer: a dose-response meta-analysis. Cancer Causes & Control. 2009 Jul;20(5):699-711.

Authors' objectives

To summarize and quantify the current epidemiologic evidence of an association between antioxidant vitamin intake and endometrial cancer.

Authors' conclusions

Although the current case-control data suggest an inverse relationship of endometrial cancer risk with dietary intakes of beta-carotene, vitamin C, and vitamin E from food sources, additional studies are needed, particularly cohort studies, to confirm an association. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Antioxidants and asthma: a case report and review of the evidence
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-B,ASTHMA,DECEMBER 2009,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Karpinski C, Touger-Decker R. Antioxidants and asthma: a case report and review of the evidence. Topics in Clinical Nutrition. 2008, 23(3):259-68.

Abstract

Asthma is a chronic, nonspecific lung disease that affects 15.7 million adults in the United States. Treatment typically focuses on removing potential allergens and prescription medications. Given the potential adverse effects of many medications, some patients explore the use of alternative treatments such as antioxidants. Research exploring the role of antioxidants in the prevention and management of chronic disease has dramatically increased in 30 years. Because asthma is an inflammatory disease that has been associated with oxidative stress, it is plausible to consider the role of antioxidant supplementation as an alternative treatment of asthma. This article addresses the case of an adult woman who tried antioxidants as adjunct therapy in the management of her asthma. The scientific relevance regarding antioxidant supplement use in asthma in adults is presented using an evidence-based approach.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Antioxidants and cancer therapy: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS C,CANCER,DATE ADDED,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,JANUARY 2008]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Ladas EJ, Jacobson JS, Kennedy DD, Teel K, Fleischauer A, Kelly KM. Antioxidants and cancer therapy: a systematic review. Journal of Clinical Oncology. 2004, 22(3):517-528.

Authors' objectives

Many patients with cancer take antioxidant nutritional supplements during cancer treatment to alleviate treatment toxicities and to improve long-term outcomes, but little is known about the efficacy and safety of antioxidant use during cancer treatment. We reviewed English-language manuscripts published in the biomedical literature, reporting the results of observational studies of antioxidant status and cancer outcomes and of intervention trials of antioxidants among patients receiving chemotherapy with or without radiation for various malignancies.  

Authors' conclusions

The studies included in this review varied in study design, timing of observation/intervention, intervention protocol, malignancy, and anticancer regimen. These inconsistencies preclude a definitive conclusion as to the effect of chemotherapy on antioxidant status in patients undergoing anticancer therapy. However, our review suggests that total antioxidant status (measured by total radical antioxidant parameter) declines during cancer treatment. Adequately powered trials or observational studies among patients with a specific cancer diagnosis receiving a specific treatment regimen are needed to address patients' and physicians' concerns regarding these associations.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

 

]]>

document.title: Antioxidants and other nutrients do not interfere with chemotherapy or radiation therapy and can increase kill and increase survival, part 2
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,DATE ADDED,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,DECEMBER 2008]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Simone CB, Simone NL, Simone V, Simone CB. Antioxidants and other nutrients do not interfere with chemotherapy or radiation therapy and can increase kill and increase survival, part 2. Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine. 2007; 13(2): 40-47.

Authors' objectives

To assess all evidence concerning antioxidant and other nutrients used concomitantly with chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy. 

Authors' conclusions

Since the 1970s, 280 peer-reviewed in vitro and in vivo studies, including 50 human studies involving 8,521 patients, 5,081 of whom were given nutrients, have consistently shown that they do not interfere with therapeutic modalities for cancer. Furthermore, non-prescription antioxidants and other nutrients enhance the killing of therapeutic modalities for cancer, decrease their side effects, and protect normal tissue. In 15 human studies, 3,738 patients who took non-prescription antioxidants and other nutrients actually had increased survival.

Related article:

Simone CB 2nd, Simone NL, Simone V, Simone CB. Antioxidants and other nutrients do not interfere with chemotherapy or radiation therapy and can increase kill and increase survival, part 1. Altern Ther Health Med. 2007 Jan-Feb;13(1):22-8. [PubMed abstract]

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

Authors' objectives

To evaluate the evidence of the supplements vitamin C and vitamin E for treatment and prevention of cancer.

Authors' conclusions

The systematic review of the literature does not support the hypothesis that the use of supplements of vitamin C or vitamin E in the doses tested helps prevent and/or treat cancer in the populations tested. There were isolated findings of benefit, which require confirmation.

document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,VIRUS DISEASES,AYURVEDIC MEDICINE,CONDITIONS T-Z,HIV (HUMAN IMMUNODEFICIENCY VIRUS),HEPATITIS,CONDITIONS F-H]]>

Citation

Martin KW, Ernst E. Antiviral agents from plants and herbs: a systematic review. Antiviral Therapy. 2003, 8(2): 77-90.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this study was to examine the published literature on herbs and plants with antiviral activity, their laboratory evaluation in vitro and in vivo, and evidence of human clinical efficacy.

Authors' conclusions

Though most of the clinical trials located reported some benefits from use of antiviral herbal medicines, negative trials may not be published at all. There remains a need for larger, stringently designed, randomized clinical trials to provide conclusive evidence of their efficacy.

 

]]>

document.title: Are acupoints specific for diseases? A systematic review of the randomized controlled trials with sham acupuncture controls
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,JULY 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Zhang H, Bian Z, Lin Z. Are acupoints specific for diseases? A systematic review of the randomized controlled trials with sham acupuncture controls. Chinese Medicine. 2010; 5:1.

Authors' objectives

To investigate whether a difference in efficacy exists between ordinary acupuncture on specific acupoints and sham acupuncture controls on non-acupoints or on irrelevant acupoints.

Authors' conclusions

This review did not demonstrate the existence of acupoint specificity. Further clinical trials with larger sample sizes, optimal acupuncture treatment protocols and appropriate sham acupuncture controls are required to resolve this important issue.

]]>

document.title: Are Ayurvedic herbs for diabetes effective?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS D-E,DIABETES MELLITUS,AYURVEDIC MEDICINE,AUGUST 2007,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Shekelle PG, Hardy M, Morton SC, Coulter I, Venuturupalli S, Favreau J, Hilton LK. Are Ayurvedic herbs for diabetes effective? Journal of Family Practice. 2005, 54(10):876-86.

Authors' objectives

To evaluate and synthesize the evidence on the effect of Ayurvedic therapies for diabetes mellitus.

Authors' conclusions

There is heterogeneity in the available literature on Ayurvedic treatment for diabetes. Most studies test herbal therapy. Heterogeneity exists in the herbs and formulas tested (more than 44 different interventions identified) and in the method of their preparation. Despite these limitations, there are sufficient data for several herbs or herbal formulas to warrant further studies.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Are herbal medicines useful in the treatment of low back pain?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,COMPLEMENTARY/ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,CONDITIONS,MUSCULOSKELETAL,SPINAL PROBLEMS,DEVILS CLAW (HARPAGOPHYTUM PROCUMBENS),WHITE WILLOW (SALIX ALBA),CAYENNE PEPPER (CAPSICUM FRUTESCENS),HERBS R-Z,HERBS D-G,HERBS A-C,BACK PAIN,CONDITIONS A-B,SEPTEMBER 2007,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-1Are herbal medicines useful in the treatment of low back pain?

National Knowledge Week on CAM for Low Back Pain 2007

Dr Saul Berkovitz, Royal London Homeopathic Hospital


There are a number of systematic reviews of the use of herbal medicines in the treatment of low back pain.1-3 Overall, the evidence is promising but certainly not definitive. Methodological problems include the small number of trials and the variety of extracts used, which does not allow statistical pooling, and the variable quality of studies. In addition, positive evidence from clinical trials using high-quality, high-potency, often standardised products unavailable in the UK is not necessarily generalisable to the extracts available in the UK market.


Devil’s claw has been examined in two systematic reviews.2,3 Overall, the results are tentatively positive, although studies are heterogenous in terms of the dose and type of extract used (aqueous, ethanolic or dry powder. There are four studies in acute exacerbations of chronic low back pain over 4-6 weeks. The most convincing of these showed benefit in pain reduction from aqueous extracts standardised to 50 or 100mg of harpagoside (a quality marker) over placebo. The other studies, although all reported as positive, can be criticised for lack of sufficient statistical power, lack of double-blinding, or improvement in secondary outcome measures only. Adverse effects were generally mild and consisted largely of gastrointestinal upset; however it is relevant that a contraindication to the use of Devil’s claw is significant gastritis or peptic ulcer disease, which might apply to patients intolerant of non-steroidal inflammatory drugs seeking herbal medicine as an alternative approach.


Two studies of Salix alba (willow bark) products, standardised for their salicin content, have been performed in acute exacerbations of low back pain1. One study in 210 patients, using two doses (120 or 240mg salicin) or placebo, showed a moderate, dose-dependent effect over 4 weeks for pain relief and analgesic reduction. A second study was reported as showing equivalence of Salix 240mg/day with rofecoxib (‘Vioxx’) 12.5mg daily. Although this was randomised it was not double-blind but an open study and so carries less weight.


Topical plasters containing extracts of Capsicum frutescens (cayenne pepper) have been tested against ‘placebo’ plasters in two studies of chronic LBP in a total of 484 patients1. In both studies there was significantly better pain relief in the Capsicum group. However it is difficult to make a true placebo because of the sensation of warmth caused by initial application of the capsicum plasters (in one study this was experienced by 95% in the Capsicum group and only 48% in the placebo group). Both studies, despite being reported as being of moderate to high quality, may therefore have been subject to a degree of ‘unblinding’. There were also postitive results in two short-term (one to two-week) studies of topical capsicum preparations, one of a combined capsicum / salicylate ointment versus placebo in acute LBP and one study showing equivalence of a Capsicum gel with a homeopathic gel in mixed acute and acute-on-chronic LBP. It is debatable whether topical capsaicin products are best described as ‘complementary’ as their use is well-established in other conditions such as neuropathies and osteoarthritis.


In conclusion, moderately strong evidence exists for Devil’s Claw (Harpagophytum procumbens) in acute exacerbations of low back pain and for capsaicin plasters. There is inconsistent evidence for willow bark products. No other herbal products have been rigorously tested.


References

1. Gagnier JJ, vanTulder M, Berman B, Bombardier C. Herbal medicine for low back pain. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2006, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD004504. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004504.pub3. [Full text]


2. Brendler T, Gruenwald J, Ulbricht C, Basch E; Natural Standard Research Collaboration. Devil's Claw (Harpagophytum procumbens DC): an evidence-based systematic review by the Natural Standard Research Collaboration. J Herb Pharmacother. 2006, 6(1):89-126. [PubMed abstract]


3. Gagnier JJ, Chrubasik S, Manheimer E. Harpgophytum procumbens for osteoarthritis and low back pain: a systematic review. BMC Complement Altern Med 2004 Sep 15;4:13. [Full text] [DARE structured abstract]

 

]]>

document.title: Are manual therapies effective in reducing pain from tension-type headache?: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CHIROPRACTIC,CONDITIONS A-Z,MASSAGE,HEADACHE,CONDITIONS F-H,DECEMBER 2007,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Fernández-de-Las-Peñas C, Alonso-Blanco C, Cuadrado ML, Miangolarra JC, Barriga FJ, Pareja JA. Are manual therapies effective in reducing pain from tension-type headache?: a systematic review. Clinical Journal of Pain. 2006, 22(3):278-85.

Authors' objectives

A systematic review was performed to establish whether manual therapies have specific efficacy in reducing pain from tension-type headache (TTH). 

Authors' conclusions

The authors found no rigorous evidence that manual therapies have a positive effect in the evolution of TTH. The most urgent need for further research is to establish the efficacy beyond placebo of the different manual therapies currently applied in patients with TTH.

 

]]>

document.title: Aromatherapy for treatment of postoperative nausea and vomiting (Cochrane protocol)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ AROMATHERAPY,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS T-Z,CONDITIONS M-O,NAUSEA,VOMITING,CAM GENERAL,RESEARCH,FEBRUARY 2009]]>
document.body:
This is the protocol for a Cochrane systematic review. This record will be updated when the review has been completed.

Citation

Hines S, Steels E, Chang A, Gilshenan K. Aromatherapy for treatment of postoperative nausea and vomiting (Protocol). Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2009, Issue 1. Art. No.: CD007598. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD007598.

Authors' objectives

  • To establish what effect the use of aromatherapy has on the severity of established postoperative nausea and vomiting
  • To establish what effect the use of aromatherapy has on the duration of established postoperative nausea and vomiting
  • To establish whether aromatherapy can be used with safety, and clinical and cost effectiveness comparable to standard pharmacological treatments, to treat established postoperative nausea and vomiting.
]]>

document.title: Assessing complementary practice: Building consensus on appropriate research methods
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HEALTH MANAGEMENT,RESEARCH,NHS ACTIVITIES,RESEARCH,AUGUST 2009,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED]]>
document.description: Report of an independent advisory group
document.body:
The King’s Fund has published a report on the need for new research into the clinical and cost effectiveness of complementary therapies. This report is the work of an independent advisory group chaired by Professor Dame Carol Black. It draws on a two-day participative conference that explored the challenges of assessing complementary practice.

For more information and a link to the full text of the report see the King's Fund website.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Assessing the evidence for the use of chiropractic manipulation in paediatric health conditions: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CHIROPRACTIC,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,FEBRUARY 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Gotlib A, Rupert R. Assessing the evidence for the use of chiropractic manipulation in paediatric health conditions: A systematic review. Journal of the Canadian Paediatric Society. 2005, 10(3): 157-161.

Authors' objectives

To review the biomedical literature up to and including 2003, and determine the extent of the evidence related to the therapeutic application of chiropractic manipulation for paediatric health conditions. No critical appraisal of the evidence is undertaken. 

Authors' conclusions

Health claims made by practitioners regarding the application of chiropractic manipulation as a health care intervention for paediatric health conditions are, for the most part, supported by low levels of scientific evidence. Chiropractors, in particular, employ manipulation for the treatment of a wide variety of paediatric health conditions. The evidence rests primarily with clinical experience, descriptive case studies and a few randomized controlled trials. There is a need for more rigorous scientific inquiry to examine the value of manipulative therapy in the treatment of paediatric conditions. To advance the health interests of paediatric patients, health care decisions made on the basis of expert opinion or clinical experience must integrate the best research evidence available from high-quality, scientific studies.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Assessing the quality of reports of randomized trials in pediatric complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL,RESEARCH,SEPTEMBER 2007]]>
document.body:
Citation

Moher D, Soeken K, Sampson M, Ben-Porat L, Berman B. Assessing the quality of reports of randomized trials in pediatric complementary and alternative medicine. BMC Pediatrics. 2002, 2:2. Epub 2002 Feb 27.

Authors' objectives

To evaluate the quality of reports of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) randomized controlled trials (RCTs) in the pediatric population and to examine whether there is a change in the quality of reporting over time. 

Authors' conclusions

RCTs are an important tool for evidence based health care decisions. If these studies are to be relevant in the evaluation of CAM interventions it is important that they are conducted and reported with the highest possible standards. There is a need to redouble efforts to ensure that children and their families are participating in RCTs that are conducted and reported with minimal bias. Such studies will increase their usefulness to a board spectrum of interested stakeholders.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Assessing the quality of reports of systematic reviews in pediatric complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,RESEARCH,SEPTEMBER 2007,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:
Citation

Moher D, Soeken K, Sampson M, Ben-Porat L, Berman B. Assessing the quality of reports of systematic reviews in pediatric complementary and alternative medicine. BMC Pediatrics. 2002, 2:3. Epub 2002 Feb 27.

Authors' objectives

To examine the quality of reports of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) systematic reviews in the pediatric population. We also examined whether there were differences in the quality of reports of a subset of CAM reviews compared to reviews using conventional interventions.

Authors' conclusions

Evidence based health care continues to make important contributions to the well being of children. To ensure the pediatric community can maximize the potential use of these interventions, it is important to ensure that systematic reviews are conducted and reported at the highest possible quality. Such reviews will be of benefit to a broad spectrum of interested stakeholders.

 

]]>

document.title: Assessment of the safety of Qin Kai Ling injection: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),CAM GENERAL,SAFETY,JANUARY 2011]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Hao Y, Kong X, Wu T: Assessment of the safety of Qin Kai Ling injection: a systematic review. Journal of Evidence-Based Medicine. 2010, 3:105-116.

Authors' objectives

Qin Kai Ling (QKL) injection, which is based upon the traditional Chinese medicine formulation ‘An Gong Niu Huang Wan’, is widely used in treatment of many diseases. This review aims to assess the safety of QKL.

Authors' conclusions

Current evidence, while weak, indicates that QKL carries a low risk of ADR/AE, and some adverse events that do occur may be ascribed to improper use of the drug. Reporting of ADR/AEs needs to be greatly improved, and should follow the ‘Recommendations for reporting traditional Chinese medicine adverse drug reaction”.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Association between antioxidant vitamins and asthma outcome measures: systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-B,ASTHMA,JUNE 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Allen S, Britton JR, Leonardi-Bee JA. Association between antioxidant vitamins and asthma outcome measures: systematic review and meta-analysis. Thorax. 2009; 64(7):610-9.

Authors' objectives

Epidemiological studies suggest that dietary intake of vitamins A, C and E may be associated with the occurrence of asthma. A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted in accordance with MOOSE guidelines to determine whether vitamins A, C and E, measured as dietary intakes or serum levels, are associated with asthma.

Authors' conclusions

Relatively low dietary intakes of vitamins A and C are associated with statistically significant increased odds of asthma and wheeze. Vitamin E intake does not appear to be related to asthma status.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Atopy risk in infants and children in relation to early exposure to fish, oily fish, or long-chain omega-3 fatty acids: A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,ASTHMA,CONDITIONS A-B,CONDITIONS F-H,CONDITIONS D-E,ALLERGIES,ECZEMA,HAY FEVER,JUNE 2010,LIPIDS,FOOD AND BEVERAGES,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,OMEGA-3 FATTY ACIDS,FISH OILS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Kremmyda LS, Vlachava M, Noakes PS, Diaper ND, Miles EA, Calder PC. Atopy risk in infants and children in relation to early exposure to fish, oily fish, or long-chain omega-3 fatty acids: A systematic review. Clinical Reviews of Allergy and Immunology. 2009 Dec 9. [Epub ahead of print].

Authors' objectives

To examine the evidence from epidemiologic studies investigating associations between fish intake in pregnancy, lactation, infancy, and childhood, and atopic outcomes in infants and children and from intervention studies with fish oil supplements in pregnancy, lactation, infancy, and childhood, and atopic outcomes in infants and children.

Authors' conclusions

The evidence from epidemiological studies investigating the effects of fish intake during infancy and childhood on atopic outcomes in those infants or children is inconsistent, although the majority of the studies (nine of 14) showed a protective effect of fish intake during infancy or childhood on atopic outcomes in those infants/children. Fish oil supplementation during pregnancy and lactation or during infancy or childhood results in a higher n-3 PUFA status in the infants or children. Fish oil provision to pregnant women is associated with immunologic changes in cord blood and such changes may persist. Studies performed to date indicate that provision of fish oil during pregnancy may reduce sensitization to common food allergens and reduce prevalence and severity of atopic dermatitis in the first year of life, with a possible persistence until adolescence with a reduction in eczema, hay fever, and asthma. Fish oil provision to infants or children may be associated with immunologic changes in the blood but it is not clear if these are of clinical significance and whether they persist. Fish oil supplementation in infancy may decrease the risk of developing some manifestations of allergic disease, but this benefit may not persist as other factors come into play. It is not clear whether fish oil can be used to treat children with asthma as the two studies conducted to date give divergent results. Further studies of increased long-chain n-3 PUFA provision in during pregnancy, lactation, and infancy are needed to more clearly identify the immunologic and clinical effects in infants and children and to identify protective and therapeutic effects and their persistence.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Basic science research related to chiropractic spinal adjusting: the state of the art and recommendations revisited
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CHIROPRACTIC,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL,FEBRUARY 2008,RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Cramer G, Budgell B, Henderson C, Khalsa P, Pickar J. Basic science research related to chiropractic spinal adjusting: the state of the art and recommendations revisited. Journal of Manipulative and Physiological Therapeutics. 2006, 29(9):726-61.

Authors' objectives

The objectives of this white paper are to review and summarize the basic science literature relevant to spinal fixation (subluxation) and spinal adjusting procedures and to make specific recommendations for future research. 

Authors' conclusions

The summaries of the literature for the 6 topic sections (anatomy, biomechanics, somatic nervous system, animal models, immune system, and human studies related to the autonomic nervous system) indicated that a significant body of basic science research evaluating chiropractic spinal adjusting has been completed and published since the 1997 basic science white paper. Much more basic science research in these fields needs to be accomplished, and the recommendations at the end of each topic section should help researchers, funding agencies, and other decision makers develop specific research priorities.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Bayesian model averaging in meta-analysis: vitamin E supplementation and mortality
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,VITAMINS,VITAMIN E,SAFETY,CAM GENERAL,SEPTEMBER 2010,RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Berry D, Wathen JK, Newell M. Bayesian model averaging in meta-analysis: vitamin E supplementation and mortality. Clinical Trials. 2009 Feb;6(1):28-41.

Authors' objectives

The strength and relevance of a meta-analysis depends on the validity of the statistical methods used. Of special importance is appropriately assessing different sources of variability. Many studies including meta-analyses have evaluated the efficacy and safety of vitamin E and have yielded varying results. Illuminating and resolving these disparities requires addressing study variability and model uncertainty.

To describe Bayesian meta-analysis methods for combining data from clinical trials, using recent studies that analyzed the relationship between vitamin E dose and all-cause mortality.

Authors' conclusions

Vitamin E intake is unlikely to affect mortality regardless of dose. The Bayesian meta-analyses presented here are ideal for incorporating disparate sources of variability, including trial effect and model uncertainty.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.title: Beta-carotene in multivitamins and the possible risk of lung cancer among smokers versus former smokers: a meta-analysis and evaluation of national brands
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS I-L,LUNG CANCER,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,VITAMINS,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY,BETA-CAROTENE,JANUARY 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Tanvetyanon T, Bepler G. Beta-carotene in multivitamins and the possible risk of lung cancer among smokers versus former smokers: a meta-analysis and evaluation of national brands. Cancer. 2008, 113(1):150-7.

Authors' objectives

To investigate the risk of lung cancer associated with beta-carotene in smokers or former smokers and surveyed the beta-carotene content in national brand multivitamins. 

Authors' conclusions

High-dose beta-carotene supplementation appears to increase the risk of lung cancer among current smokers. Although beta-carotene was prevalent in multivitamins, high-dose beta-carotene was observed among multivitamin formulas sold to promote visual health.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Beta-carotene supplementation and cancer risk: a systematic review and metaanalysis of randomized controlled trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,OCTOBER 2010,BETA-CAROTENE,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,VITAMINS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Druesne-Pecollo N, Latino-Martel P, Norat T, Barrandon E, Bertrais S, Galan P, Hercberg S. Beta-carotene supplementation and cancer risk: a systematic review and metaanalysis of randomized controlled trials. International Journal of Cancer. 2010 Jul 1;127(1):172-84.

Authors' objectives

The effect of beta-carotene supplementation on cancer incidence has been investigated in several randomized controlled trials. The objective was to review the effect of beta-carotene supplementation on cancer incidence in randomized trials by cancer site, beta-carotene supplementation characteristics and study population. 

Authors' conclusions

Beta-carotene supplementation has not been shown to have any beneficial effect on cancer prevention. Conversely, it was associated with increased risk not only of lung cancer but also of gastric cancer at doses of 20-30 mg day(-1), in smokers and asbestos workers. This study adds to the evidence that nutritional prevention of cancer through beta-carotene supplementation should not be recommended.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

Citation

Leach MJ, Moore V. Black cohosh (Cimicifuga spp.) for menopausal symptoms (Protocol). Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2008, Issue 3. Art. No.: CD007244. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD007244.

Authors' objectives

The objective of this systematic review is to evaluate the clinical effectiveness of black cohosh (Cimicifuga racemosa or Actaea racemosa) in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women.

The specific review questions to be addressed are:
- How effective is black cohosh in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women at reducing the frequency or intensity of menopausal symptoms?
- How safe is black cohosh in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women when taken to alleviate the symptoms of menopause?

document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,HYPERTENSION,HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE,CONDITIONS F-H,MINERALS,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,DATE ADDED,CALCIUM,JANUARY 2008]]>

Citation

van Mierlo LA, Arends LR, Streppel MT, Zeegers MP, Kok FJ, Grobbee DE, Geleijnse JM. Blood pressure response to calcium supplementation: a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. Journal of Human Hypertension. 2006, 20(8):571-580.

Authors' objectives

We conducted a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials to determine the effect of calcium supplementation on blood pressure.

Authors' conclusions

This study suggests that an adequate intake of calcium should be recommended for the prevention of hypertension. More research on blood pressure in people with calcium-deficient diets is warranted.

Citation

Authors' objectives

To assess effects of Transcendental Meditation on blood pressure using objective quality assessments and meta-analyses.

Authors' conclusions

The regular practice of Transcendental Meditation may have the potential to reduce systolic and diastolic blood pressure by approximately 4.7 and 3.2 mm Hg, respectively. These are clinically meaningful changes.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Botanicals used in complementary and alternative medicine treatment of cancer: clinical science and future perspectives
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,MARCH 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Miller S, Stagl J, Wallerstedt DB, Ryan M, Mansky PJ. Botanicals used in complementary and alternative medicine treatment of cancer: clinical science and future perspectives. Expert Opin Investig Drugs. 2008 Sep;17(9):1353-64.

Authors' objectives

This article reviews the published evidence for the safety and clinical benefit of botanicals used in the treatment of cancer and cancer symptom management and describes the continuing clinical trials of botanicals with applications in oncology.

Authors' conclusions

A number of botanicals have shown promise for cancer symptom management but need further study. A limited number of multi-agent nutritional supplement approaches are being explored in clinical trials. Botanical immunomodulators and botanical products shown to affect pathways of angiogenesis, apoptosis and cell signaling in vitro have stimulated research interest and may broaden the range of available cancer treatments. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Calcium supplementation and incident kidney stone risk: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS I-L,JANUARY 2011,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY,CALCIUM,KIDNEY DISEASES,MINERALS,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Heaney RP. Calcium supplementation and incident kidney stone risk: a systematic review. Journal of the American College of Nutrition. 2008, 27(5):519-27.

Authors' objectives

To reassess kidney stone risk in postmenopausal women using data accumulated in calcium supplement trials, bone active agent registration trials, and in unpublished WHI data available online; and to compare these estimates with formal published epidemiological studies of stone risk.

Authors' conclusions

Stone risk in postmenopausal women has increased substantially in the past 40 years, but absolute population incidence estimates vary widely from a low of about 70 incidents/100,000/yr for Olmsted County, MN, today, to a concurrent high of approximately 190/100,000/yr for the Nurses' Health Study II. Reported WHI incidence rates are higher still, with values around 300/100,000/yr for various WHI subgroupings. The reasons for these discordances are unclear. Despite this uncertainty about background rate, most of the studies show no increase in stone risk with high calcium intake (from either diet or supplements). Contrariwise there is a substantial body of evidence, both from controlled trials and from observational studies, indicating that there is an inverse relationship between calcium intake and stone risk. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Calcium supplements in healthy children do not affect weight gain, height, or body composition
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,OBESITY,CONDITIONS M-O,MINERALS,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,DATE ADDED,CALCIUM,NOVEMBER 2008]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Winzenberg T, Shaw K, Fryer J, Jones G. Calcium supplements in healthy children do not affect weight gain, height, or body composition. Obesity. 2007, 15(7):1789-1798.

Authors' objectives

Calcium intake is a potential factor influencing weight gain and may reduce body weight, but the evidence for this in children is conflicting. The aim of this study was to use data from randomized controlled trials to determine whether calcium supplementation in healthy children affects weight or body composition. 

Authors' conclusions

There is no evidence to support the use of calcium supplementation as a public health intervention to reduce weight gain or body fat in healthy children. Although our results do not rule out an effect of dietary supplementation with dairy products on weight gain or body composition, there is little evidence to support this hypothesis.

]]>

document.title: Calendula officinalis and wound healing: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,WOUNDS AND INJURIES,CONDITIONS T-Z,DECEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Leach MJ. Calendula officinalis and wound healing: a systematic review. Wounds: A Compendium of Clinical Research & Practice. 2008, 20(8):236-244.

Authors' objectives

To assess the effect of Calendula on wound healing.

Authors' conclusions

This review indicated that there is only weak evidence to support the topical administration of Calendula in acute and chronic wounds. Further investigation is needed to establish whether Calendula has a place in mainstream wound care.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: CAM for low back pain: other therapies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,YOGA,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,MEDITATION,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,HOMEOPATHY,BACK PAIN,CONDITIONS A-B,ALEXANDER TECHNIQUE,HERBS D-G,DEVILS CLAW (HARPAGOPHYTUM PROCUMBENS),SEPTEMBER 2007,2007,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-1CAM for low back pain: other therapies

National Knowledge Week on CAM for Low Back Pain 2007


Dr George Lewith, University of Southampton


The evidence for this briefing document is based on two recent reviews: one by Ernst et al.1 and a systematic reviews by Quinn et al.2   

Ernst et al.1 compared a systematic review completed in 2000 with a subsequent re-analysis carried out in 2005 and published in 2007.  Their definition of CAM is interesting in that it includes exercise and water injections, neither of which would reasonably be classed as CAM by any of the major taxonomies. Quinn et al.2 analysed therapies other than acupuncture, massage and spinal manipulation.

The evidence for acupuncture has been summarised in a separate article. 


The Alexander Technique has not been previously evaluated so currently (based on published evidence to date) the evidence is weak although a recently completed MRC study appears to provide strong positive evidence (based on a conference abstract) supported by a large (n = 590) factorially designed RCT which appears to demonstrate substantial improvement on the Roland Scale from both brief (6 sessions) and long Alexander Technique (24 sessions) with a one year follow-up (Paul Little, RCGP Conference Abstract, 2006). Devil’s Claw has been thoroughly reviewed and much of the primary evidence is provided by Quinn et al2; both Quinn et al.2 and Ernst et al.1 suggest that the evidence is tentatively positive although largely unchanged from 2000.  (For more details see article on herbal medicine for low back pain)


There is moderate evidence that massage is effective and increasing evidence from 2 randomised controlled trials that yoga appears to be effective (in the long term) for chronic low back pain. Two studies report homeopathic treatment of back pain, one using a transdermal gel and the other a classical homeopathic approach with oral medicines3,4 Both these studies suggest that homeopathy is as good as conventional medicine in treating these conditions but both are small with questionable methodology. One small study on hypnotherapy suggested that this approach was better than placebo but this must be interpreted with caution. Carson et al.5 report that a mindfulness meditation programme was able to provide a substantially enhanced outcome for pain intensity.


The evidence for spinal manipulation (osteopathy and chiropractic) is tentatively positive for both chronic and acute back pain involving now a large number of clinical trials that have been systematically reviewed and are available through the Cochrane database.  (For more details see articles on spinal manipulation and osteopathic manipulative treatment)


Clearly there is a need for further research but there appears to be promising and slowly growing evidence for various CAM interventions into both chronic and acute low back pain. These treatments appear to be safe from the limited evidence we have available, by and large as effective as conventional medicine. These conclusions are currently tentative and may need to be revised in the light of further research.


References

1. Ernst E, Pittler MH, Wider B, Boddy K. Complementary therapies for back pain: is the evidence getting stronger? Clinical Rheumatology. 2007, 26(5):736-8. [PubMed abstract] 


2. Quinn F, Hughes C, Baxter GD. Complementary and alternative medicine in the treatment of low back pain: a systematic review. Physical Therapy Reviews. 2006, 11(2):107-16. [Abstract]


3. Stam C, Bonnet MS, Haselen RA. The efficacy and safety of a homeopathic gel in the treatment of acute low back pain: a multi-centre, randomised, double-blind comparative clinical trial. British Homoeopathic Journal. 2001, 90(1):21-8. [PubMed abstract]


4. Gmunder R, Kissling R. The efficacy of homeopathy in the treatment of chronic low back pain compared to standardized physiotherapy. Zeitschrift für Orthopädie und ihre Grenzgebiete. 2002, 140(5):503-508. [PubMed abstract]


5. Carson JW, Keefe FJ, Lynch TR, Carson KM, Goli V, Fras AM et al.  Loving-kindness meditation for chronic low back pain. Journal of Holistic Nursing. 2005, 23(3):287-304. [PubMed abstract]

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: CAMbase - a XML-based bibliographical database on Complementary and Alternative Medicine (CAM)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED,SEPTEMBER 2007,RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
Citation

Ostermann T, Zillmann H, Raak CK, Buessing A, Matthiessen PF. CAMbase - a XML-based bibliographical database on Complementary and Alternative Medicine (CAM). Biomedical Digital Libraries. 2007, 4:2. 

Authors' objectives

Although there appears to be a growing number of scientific publications on CAM, the complete spectrum of complementary therapies still requires more information about published evidence. A majority of these research publications are still not listed in electronic bibliographical databases such as MEDLINE. However, with a growing demand by patients for such therapies, physicians increasingly need an overview of scientific publications on CAM. Bearing this in mind, CAMbase, a bibliographical database on CAM was launched in order to close this gap.

Results

The user can peruse more than 80,000 records from over 30 journals and periodicals on CAM, which are stored in CAMbase. A special search engine performing syntactical and semantical analysis of textual phrases allows the user quickly to find relevant bibliographical information on CAM. Between August 2003 and July 2006, 43,299 search queries, an average of 38 search queries per day, were registered focussing on CAM topics such as acupuncture, cancer or general safety aspects. Analysis of the requests led to the conclusion that CAMbase is not only used by scientists and researchers but also by physicians and patients who want to find out more about CAM.

]]>

document.title: Cancer CAM Researcher Directory
document.publisher: Office of Cancer Complementary and Alternative Medicine (OCCAM)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS C,CANCER,RESEARCH,FEBRUARY 2008,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
The Office of Cancer Complementary and Alternative Medicine (OCCAM) at the U.S. National Cancer Institute has recently launched the Cancer CAM Researcher Directory.

This database compiles information on researchers who have published original research on cancer and CAM. The purpose of the directory is to make it easier for people working in the field to identify others with similar or related research interests and to facilitate the exchange of ideas and information as well as collaboration among such researchers.

]]>

document.title: Cardiovascular adverse effects of herbal medicines: a systematic review of the recent literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,SEPTEMBER 2010,SAFETY,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Ernst E. Cardiovascular adverse effects of herbal medicines: a systematic review of the recent literature. Canadian Journal of Cardiology. 2003, 19(7):818-27.

Author's objectives

This article summarizes recent evidence regarding the serious or potentially serious cardiovascular adverse effects of herbal medicines. 

Author's conclusions

Herbal medicinal products are regularly associated with serious cardiovascular adverse events but the size of this problem cannot be estimated at present. Vigilance and research seem to be the best way forward.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Cereal grains, legumes, and weight management: a comprehensive review of the scientific evidence
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS M-O,OBESITY,MARCH 2009,FOOD AND BEVERAGES,SPECIAL DIETS]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Williams PG, Grafenauer SJ, O'Shea JE. Cereal grains, legumes, and weight management: a comprehensive review of the scientific evidence. Nutrition Reviews. 2008, 66(4): 171-182.

Authors' objectives

To assess the evidence on the effect of cereal grains and legumes on weight management.

Authors' conclusions

There is strong evidence that a diet high in whole grains is associated with lower body mass index, smaller waist circumference, and reduced risk of being overweight; that a diet high in whole grains and legumes can help reduce weight gain; and that significant weight loss is achievable with energy-controlled diets that are high in cereals and legumes. There is weak evidence that high intakes of refined grains may cause small increases in waist circumference in women. There is no evidence that low-carbohydrate diets that restrict cereal intakes offer long-term advantages for sustained weight loss. There is insufficient evidence to make clear conclusions about the protective effect of legumes on weight.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.creator: Williams PG, Grafenauer SJ, O'Shea JE

document.title: Cerebrovascular complications associated with spinal manipulation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CHIROPRACTIC,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,OSTEOPATHY,FEBRUARY 2008,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED,SAFETY]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Ernst E. Cerebrovascular complications associated with spinal manipulation. Physical Therapy Reviews. 2004, 9(1): 5-15.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this systematic review was to summarise the recent (1995–2003) evidence on the safety of spinal manipulation as a form of manual therapy employed by chiropractors, osteopaths, medical doctors, physiotherapists and other healthcare professionals.

Authors' conclusions

It is concluded that serious cerebrovascular complications of spinal manipulation continue to be reported. Their incidence is unknown. Large and rigorous prospective studies are necessary in order to define the risks of spinal manipulation accurately.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.  

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Characteristics and quality of systematic reviews of acupuncture, herbal medicines, and homeopathy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,HOMEOPATHY,HERBAL MEDICINE,RESEARCH,SEPTEMBER 2007,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:
Citation

Linde K, ter Riet G, Hondras M, Melchart D, Willich SN. Characteristics and quality of systematic reviews of acupuncture, herbal medicines, and homeopathy. Forschende Komplementärmedizin und klassische Naturheilkunde. 2003, 10(2):88-94. 

Authors' objectives

To describe the approaches and characteristics of systematic reviews on three major complementary therapies and to assess their methodological quality.

Authors' conclusions

Systematic reviews tend to approach different complementary therapies in different manner. Compared to a set of reviews on analgesic interventions methodological quality was slightly better on the average, but there is ample room for improvement in future complementary medicine reviews.

 

]]>

Authors' objectives

  1. To determine the effect of Chinese herbal medicines (with or without phototherapy) compared to placebo or conventional treatment (phototherapy or exchange transfusion) on bilirubin levels, the need for phototherapy or exchange transfusion and the incidence of bilirubin encephalopathy and long-term neurodevelopmental impairment.

document.title: Chiropractic care for patients with asthma: A systematic review of the literature
document.publisher: Journal of the Canadian Chiropractic Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CHIROPRACTIC,CONDITIONS A-B,ASTHMA,JUNE 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Kaminskyj A, Frazier M, Johnstone K, Gleberzon BJ. Chiropractic care for patients with asthma: A systematic review of the literature. Journal of the Canadian Chiropractic Association. 2010; 54(1):24-32.

Authors' objectives

To provide a review of the literature and rate the quality of published studies regarding chiropractic care, including spinal manipulation, for asthmatic patients. 

Authors' conclusions

Results of the eight retrieved studies indicated that chiropractic care showed improvements in subjective measures and, to a lesser degree objective measures, none of which were statistically significant. It is evident that some asthmatic patients may benefit from this treatment approach; however, at this time, the evidence suggests chiropractic care should be used as an adjunct, not a replacement, to traditional medical therapy.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Chiropractic clinical practice guideline: evidence-based treatment of adult neck pain not due to whiplash
document.publisher: Journal of the Canadian Chiropractic Association
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CHIROPRACTIC,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS M-O,NECK PAIN,FEBRUARY 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
Citation

The Canadian Chiropractic Association and the Canadian Federation of Chiropractic Regulatory Boards, Clinical Practice Guidelines Development Initiative, Guidelines Development Committee (GDC) comprising, Anderson-Peacock E, Blouin JS, Bryans R, Danis N, Furlan A, Marcoux H, Potter B, Ruegg R, Gross Stein J, White E. Chiropractic clinical practice guideline: evidence-based treatment of adult neck pain not due to whiplash. JCCA. Journal of the Canadian Chiropractic Association. 2005 Sep;49(3):158-209.

Authors' objectives

To provide an evidence-based clinical practice guideline for the chiropractic cervical treatment of adults with acute or chronic neck pain not due to whiplash. 

Authors' recommendations
Summary in pdf format


The GDC developed treatment, risk-management and research recommendations using the available evidence.

Treatment recommendations addressing 13 treatment modalities revolved around a decision algorithm comprising diagnosis (or assessment leading to diagnosis), treatment and reassessment. Several specific variations of modalities of treatment were not recommended.

For adverse events not associated with a treatment modality, but that occur in the clinical setting, there was evidence to recommend reconsideration of treatment options or referral to the appropriate health services. For adverse events associated with a treatment modality, but not a known or observable risk factor, there was evidence to recommend heightened vigilance when a relevant treatment is planned or administered. For adverse events associated with a treatment modality and predicted by an observable risk factor, there was evidence to recommend absolute contraindications, and requirements for treatment modality modification or caution to minimize harm and maximize benefit. For managing the theoretic risk of dissection, there was evidence to recommend a systematic risk-management approach. For managing the theoretic risk of stroke, there was support to recommend minimal rotation in administering any modality of upper-cervical spine treatment, and to recommend caution in treating a patient with hyperhomocysteinemia, although the evidence was especially ambiguous in both of these areas.

Research recommendations addressed the poor caliber of many of the studies; the GDC concluded that the scientific base for chiropractic cervical treatment of neck pain was not of sufficient quality or scope to "cover" current chiropractic practice comprehensively, although this should not suggest other disciplines are more evidence-based.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Chiropractic manipulation for non-spinal pain--a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,CHIROPRACTIC,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,PAIN,CONDITIONS P-R,DATE ADDED,DECEMBER 2007]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Ernst E. Chiropractic manipulation for non-spinal pain--a systematic review. The New Zealand Medical Journal. 2003, 116(1179):U539.

Authors' objectives

Chiropractic manipulation is mostly used for spinal problems but, in an increasing number of cases, also for non-spinal conditions. This systematic review is aimed at critically evaluating the evidence for or against the effectiveness of this approach. 

Authors' conclusions

Only very few randomised clinical trials of chiropractic manipulation as a treatment of non-spinal conditions exist. The claim that this approach is effective for such conditions is not based on data from rigorous clinical trials.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Chiropractic manipulation in pediatric health conditions - an updated systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CHIROPRACTIC,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,NOVEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Gotlib A, Rupert R. Chiropractic manipulation in pediatric health conditions - an updated systematic review. Chiropractic & Osteopathy. 2008, 16:11.

Authors' objectives

To review the biomedical literature from January 2004 to June 2007 inclusive to determine the extent of new evidence related to the therapeutic application of manipulation for pediatric health conditions.

Authors' conclusions

There has been no substantive shift in this body of knowledge during the past 3 1/2 years. The health claims made by chiropractors with respect to the application of manipulation as a health care intervention for pediatric health conditions continue to be supported by only low levels of scientific evidence. Chiropractors continue to treat a wide variety of pediatric health conditions. The evidence rests primarily with clinical experience, descriptive case studies and very few observational and experimental studies. The health interests of pediatric patients would be advanced if more rigorous scientific inquiry was undertaken to examine the value of manipulative therapy in the treatment of pediatric conditions.

]]>

document.title: Chiropractic treatment of pregnancy-related low back pain: a systematic review of the evidence
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CHIROPRACTIC,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS A-B,BACK PAIN,PREGNANCY,CONDITIONS P-R,JANUARY 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Stuber KJ, Smith DL. Chiropractic treatment of pregnancy-related low back pain: a systematic review of the evidence. Journal of Manipulative and Physiological Therapeutics. 2008, 31(6):447-54.

Authors' objectives

This study systematically reviewed the published evidence regarding chiropractic care, including spinal manipulation, for pregnancy-related low back pain (LBP). 

Authors' conclusions

Results from the 6 included studies showed that chiropractic care is associated with improved outcomes in pregnancy-related LBP. However, the low-to-moderate quality of evidence of the included studies preclude any definitive statement as to the efficacy of such care because all studies lacked both randomization and control groups. Given the relatively common use of chiropractic care during pregnancy, there is need for higher quality observational studies and controlled trials to determine efficacy.

Access

]]>

document.title: Chiropractic treatment of upper extremity conditions: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,CHIROPRACTIC,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MUSCULOSKELETAL DISEASES,CONDITIONS M-O,DECEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

McHardy A, Hoskins W, Pollard H, Onley R, Windsham R. Chiropractic treatment of upper extremity conditions: a systematic review. Journal of Manipulative and Physiological Therapies. 2008, 31(2):146-59.

Authors' objectives

This study investigates the scope, type, and quality of chiropractic research conducted on the management of upper limb peripheral conditions. 

Authors' conclusions

There is a small amount of chiropractic research into upper limb conditions that is comprised mostly of case studies (level 4 evidence) and a small number of higher-level publications (level 1-3 evidence). Most treatments are multimodal in nature, which address both spinal and peripheral structures, with joint and soft tissue methods. There is a need for future research to be directed at higher-level evidence, in particular, randomized controlled trials for the chiropractic treatment of upper limb conditions.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.  

]]>

document.body:
Clinical Evidence Concise is a publication of BMJ Publishing Group which aims to provide a summary about the prevention and treatment of clinical conditions based on the best available current evidence from systematic reviews, RCTs and observational studies.

 

Background

This summary provides a brief overview of chronic back pain, including definition, incidence, aetiology and prognosis. Treatments are ranked according to their effectiveness.

Conclusion

This review found that acupuncture and spinal manipulative therapy are likely to be beneficial for non-specific chronic low back pain.

Topic search date: November 2004 

]]>

Authors' objectives

The purpose of this systematic review was to investigate the association between dietary intake of citrus fruits and pancreatic cancer risk.

Authors' conclusions

Pooled results from observational studies showed an inverse association between intake of citrus fruits and the risk of pancreatic cancer, although results vary substantially across studies, and the apparent effect is restricted to the weaker study design (case-control studies).

document.title: Clinical effects of colonic cleansing for general health promotion: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS F-H,GASTROINTESTINAL DISEASES,JULY 2010]]>
document.body:

Citation

Acosta RD, Cash BD. Clinical effects of colonic cleansing for general health promotion: a systematic review. American Journal of Gastroenterology. 2009 Nov;104(11):2830-6.

Authors' objectives

This report describes a systematic review of the published literature of both the traditional and complementary and alternative medicine arenas that was performed in an attempt to qualify and quantify the value of colonic cleansing. 

Authors' conclusions

The investigators concluded that there are no methodologically rigorous controlled trials of colonic cleansing to support the practice for general health promotion. Conversely, there are multiple case reports and case series that describe the adverse effects of colonic cleansing. The practice of colonic cleansing to improve or promote general health is not supported in the published literature and cannot be recommended at this time.

document.title: Clinical studies of red clover (Trifolium pratense) dietary supplements in menopause: a literature review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS F-H,CONDITIONS M-O,OSTEOPOROSIS,HERBS R-Z,MENOPAUSAL SYMPTOMS,RED CLOVER (TRIFOLIUM PRATENSE),HOT FLUSHES,DECEMBER 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Booth NL, Piersen C E, Banuvar S, Geller SE, Shulman LP, Farnsworth NR. Clinical studies of red clover (Trifolium pratense) dietary supplements in menopause: a literature review. Menopause. 2006, 13(2):251-264.

Authors' objectives

To review the evidence from clinical studies of red clover botanical dietary supplements in menopause. 

Authors' conclusions

Clinical evidence is presently lacking to support the efficacy of semipurified red clover isoflavone extracts for alleviation of climacteric vasomotor symptoms or reduction of low-density lipoprotein levels in the blood. Furthermore, the safety of use of red clover isoflavone supplements in patients with breast or endometrial cancer has not been established. Limited evidence suggests possible efficacy in maintenance of bone health and improvement of arterial compliance, a risk factor for atherosclerosis. This literature review covers red clover botanical dietary supplement clinical studies having a possible impact on the health care of mature and menopausal women, and provides historical perspective regarding the traditional uses of red clover.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

Ospina MB, Bond K, Karkhaneh M, Buscemi N, Dryden DM, Barnes V, Carlson LE, Dusek JA, Shannahoff-Khalsa D. Clinical trials of meditation practices in health care: characteristics and quality. J Altern Complement Med. 2008 Dec;14(10):1199-213.

Authors' objectives

To provide an overview of the clinical trials assessing meditation practices for health care. 

Authors' conclusions

Most clinical trials on meditation practices are generally characterized by poor methodological quality with significant threats to validity in every major quality domain assessed. Despite a statistically significant improvement in the methodological quality over time, it is imperative that future trials on meditation be rigorous in design, execution, analysis, and the reporting of results.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Clinically based evidence of drug-herb interactions: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,SEPTEMBER 2010,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Kennedy DA, Seely D. Clinically based evidence of drug-herb interactions: a systematic review. Expert Opinion on Drug Safety. 2010, 9(1):79-124.

Authors' objectives

Healthcare practitioners are deeply concerned about drug-herb interactions and how concurrent administration may affect both the safety and effectiveness of prescribed drugs. Interactions between botanical medicines and synthetic drugs can be clinically relevant and it is important to understand what kinds of interactions are possible. Better knowledge in this area will help avoid negative interactions and may also help enable synergistic interactions.

Authors' conclusions

Knowledge of drug-herb interactions is limited and much more research needs to be done to further document clinically relevant interactions. Even though preclinical data are often poorly generalizable to the human situation, caution must be taken in the absence of clinical evidence especially where drugs with narrow therapeutic windows are concerned.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Complementary alternative medicine (CAM) use in Ireland: a secondary analysis of SLAN data
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,SEPTEMBER 2010,CAM GENERAL,USE OF CAM]]>
document.body:
Citation

Fox P, Coughlan B, Butler M, Kelleher C. Complementary alternative medicine (CAM) use in Ireland: a secondary analysis of SLAN data. Complementary Therapies in Medicine. 2010, 18(2):95-103. 

Aim

National prevalence studies on CAM use have been undertaken internationally, however, to date no such studies have been performed in Ireland. The aim of this study was to estimate the prevalence of CAM use among the general population in Ireland and to identify characteristics of typical Irish CAM users.

Conclusions

Use of CAM is increasing among the Irish general population and predictors of CAM use in this study are broadly similar to those found internationally. The profile constructed from our study should assist health professionals to identify those persons who may wish to use CAM so that appropriate verbal/written guidance may be provided.

]]>
