document.title: Herbal medicine for low back pain: 2008 Annual evidence update
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,SPINAL PROBLEMS,CONDITIONS,MUSCULOSKELETAL,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,COMPLEMENTARY/ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,BACK PAIN,CONDITIONS A-B,SEPTEMBER 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-1Herbal medicine for low back pain: 2008 Annual evidence update

Commentary by Michael McIntyre, European Herbal Practitioners Association

Update of 2007 evidence summary by Saul Berkovitz, Royal London Homoeopathic Hospital


There are a number of systematic reviews of the use of herbal medicines in the treatment of low back pain.1-4 Overall, the evidence is promising but certainly not definitive. Methodological problems include the small number of trials admitted for review because of the variable quality of studies. For example, a recent overview of the evidence included only one systematic review and one further RCT on herbal medicines for chronic lower back pain.1 This clearly says more about the poor quality of research into herbal interventions than the efficacy or otherwise of herbal treatment itself. 


Further methodological difficulties are posed by the variety of extracts used, which does not allow statistical pooling and by the lack of clarity about plant species used. In two of the reviews1,2 several herbal medicines are reported as treatments for low back pain but there appears to be confusion with regard to their names. For example Camphora momol would appear to confuse Commiphora molmol, (myrrh) and Cinnamomum camphora (camphor), Maleluca alternifolia should be Melaleuca alternifolia (Ti Tree), Menthe peperita should be Mentha piperita (peppermint) and Tancaetum parthenium should be Tanacetum parthenium (feverfew). In addition, positive evidence from clinical trials using high-quality, high-potency, often standardised products unavailable in the UK is not necessarily generalisable to the extracts available in the UK market.


There are also important questions unanswered. As mentioned below, studies into the efficacy of Harpogophytum (Devil’s claw) used specific doses of harpagoside, the purported active constituent of H. procumbens, as a marker but there is certainly a possibility that this constituent does not account for the action of the whole plant. In addition, some herbal traditions use mixtures of herbs together rather than individual plants on their own. Angelica sinensis, reported as used in the treatment of low back pain1,2 is rarely used on its own in the Chinese herbal tradition from which it comes. What herbal practitioners do in practice clearly needs evaluation or the benefits of traditional treatments may be missed.


Devil’s claw has been examined in two systematic reviews.3,4 Overall, the results are tentatively positive, although studies are heterogeneous in terms of the dose and type of extract used (aqueous, ethanolic or dry powder. There are four studies in acute exacerbations of chronic low back pain over 4-6 weeks. The most convincing of these showed benefit in pain reduction from aqueous extracts standardised to 50 or 100mg of harpagoside (a supposed quality marker) over placebo. The other studies, although all reported as positive, can be criticised for lack of sufficient statistical power, lack of double-blinding, or improvement in secondary outcome measures only. Adverse effects were generally mild and consisted largely of gastrointestinal upset; however it is relevant that a contraindication to the use of Devil’s claw is significant gastritis or peptic ulcer disease, which might apply to patients intolerant of non-steroidal inflammatory drugs seeking herbal medicine as an alternative approach. This said, a recent systematic review of the safety of Harpogophytum preparations identified 28 double-blind clinical trials involving 6,892 patients who received this herbal medicine. In none of double-blind trials was the incidence of adverse effects during treatment with Harpogophytum higher than that observed during placebo treatment.5


Two studies of Salix alba (willow bark) products, standardised for their salicin content, have been performed in acute exacerbations of low back pain2. One study in 210 patients, using two doses (120 or 240mg salicin) or placebo, showed a moderate, dose-dependent effect over 4 weeks for pain relief and analgesic reduction. A second study was reported as showing equivalence of Salix 240mg/day with rofecoxib (‘Vioxx’) 12.5mg daily. Although this was randomised it was not double-blind but an open study and so carries less weight.


Topical plasters containing extracts of Capsicum frutescens (cayenne pepper) have been tested against ‘placebo’ plasters in two studies of chronic LBP in a total of 484 patients2. In both studies there was significantly better pain relief in the Capsicum group. However it is difficult to make a true placebo because of the sensation of warmth caused by initial application of the capsicum plasters (in one study this was experienced by 95% in the Capsicum group and only 48% in the placebo group). Both studies, despite being reported as being of moderate to high quality, may therefore have been subject to a degree of ‘unblinding’. There were also positive results in two short-term (one to two-week) studies of topical capsicum preparations, one of a combined capsicum / salicylate ointment versus placebo in acute LBP and one study showing equivalence of a Capsicum gel with a homeopathic gel in mixed acute and acute-on-chronic LBP. It is debatable whether topical capsaicin products are best described as ‘complementary’ as their use is well-established in other conditions such as neuropathies and osteoarthritis.


In conclusion, moderately strong evidence exists for Devil’s Claw (Harpagophytum procumbens) in acute exacerbations of low back pain and for capsaicin plasters. There is inconsistent evidence for willow bark products. No other herbal products have been rigorously tested and there are clearly some significant problems with the designs of trials which need addressing before more research is undertaken. 


References


1. Gagnier JJ. Evidence-informed management of chronic low back pain with herbal, vitamin, mineral, and homeopathic supplements. Spine Journal. 2008, 8(1):70-9. [Full text on journal website]


2. Gagnier JJ, vanTulder M, Berman B, Bombardier C. Herbal medicine for low back pain. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2006, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD004504. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004504.pub3. [Full text]


3. Brendler T, Gruenwald J, Ulbricht C, Basch E; Natural Standard Research Collaboration. Devil's Claw (Harpagophytum procumbens DC): an evidence-based systematic review by the Natural Standard Research Collaboration. J Herb Pharmacother. 2006, 6(1):89-126. [PubMed abstract]


4. Gagnier JJ, Chrubasik S, Manheimer E. Harpgophytum procumbens for osteoarthritis and low back pain: a systematic review. BMC Complement Altern Med 2004 Sep 15;4:13. [Full text] [DARE structured abstract]


5. Vlachojannis J, Roufogalis BD, Chrubasik S. Systematic review on the safety of Harpagophytum preparations for osteoarthritic and low back pain. Phytotherapy Research. 2008, 22(2):149-52. [PubMed abstract]

 

Link back to 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM for low back pain 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Herbal medicines in the treatment of psychiatric disorders: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS D-E,CONDITIONS A-B,DEPRESSION,ANXIETY,ANXIETY DISORDERS,SAFETY,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED,OCTOBER 2008,2008]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Sarris J. Herbal medicines in the treatment of psychiatric disorders: a systematic review. Phytotherapy Research. 2007, 21(8):703-16.

Authors' objectives

This paper reports a critical review of 27 herbal medicines and formulas in treating a broad range of psychiatric disorders (in addition to anxiety and depression), including obsessive-compulsive, seasonal affective, bipolar depressive, psychotic, phobic and somatoform disorders. 

Authors' conclusions

While depression and anxiety are commonly researched, the efficacy of herbal medicines in other mental disorders requires attention. The review addresses current issues in herbal psychotherapy: herbal safety, future areas of application, the relationship of herbal medicine with pharmaceuticals and the potential prescriptive integration of phytomedicines with synthetic psychotropic medicines. Particular attention is given to clinical and safety issues with St John's wort and kava.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.title: Herbal medicines regulation and safety
document.publisher: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED,REGULATION,SAFETY,PATIENT INFORMATION,MAY 2007,2007]]>
document.body:
The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) is the government agency which is responsible for ensuring that medicines and medical devices work, and are acceptably safe.

 

This section of the MHRA website is aimed at anyone placing herbal medicines on the UK market and for consumers who want to access safety information on herbal medicines. It provides general and product specific safety advice on herbal medicines and outlines the different regulatory requirements for companies wishing to place herbal medicines on the market.

 ]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Herbal safety advice
document.publisher: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,DISORDERS,SKIN DISORDERS,COMPLEMENTARY & ALTERNATIVE TREATMENTS,DRUG ERUPTIONS & REACTIONS,PROFESSIONS & SPECIALTIES,PHARMACY,TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT,DRUG & TREATMENT COMPLICATIONS,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),AYURVEDIC MEDICINE,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY,DECEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) is the government agency which is responsible for ensuring that medicines and medical devices work, and are acceptably safe.


This section provides useful safety information for anyone using herbal medicines. The information provided will also be of use to anyone operating in the herbal medicines sector, including manufacturers, herbal practitioners, suppliers and retailers.

The information provided in this section covers for example, general advice on the Traditional Herbal Medicines Registration Scheme, potential side effects and interaction with other medicines, safety issues linked to the use of heavy metals, mis-identification of herbal ingredients and poor quality.

 

]]>

This section of the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) website is dedicated to safety issues associated with herbal medicines and is regularly updated to ensure that the most relevant information is available to as wide an audience as possible.

It provides useful safety information for anyone using herbal medicines and anyone operating in the herbal medicines sector, including manufacturers, herbal practitioners, suppliers and retailers.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Herbal-drug therapy interactions: a focus on dementia
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,ST JOHN'S WORT (HYPERICUM PERFORATUM),CONDITIONS A-Z,DEMENTIA,GINKGO (GINKGO BILOBA),KAVA (PIPER METHYSTICUM),CONDITIONS D-E,GINSENG (PANAX GINSENG),VALERIAN (VALERIANA OFFICINALIS),HERBS D-G,HERBS H-P,HERBS R-Z,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY,JANUARY 2011]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Gold JL, Laxer DA, Dergal JM, Lanctôt KL, Rochon PA. Herbal-drug therapy interactions: a focus on dementia. Current Opinion in Clinical Nutrition and Metabolic Care. 2001, 4(1):29-34.

Authors' objectives

Older people with dementia are often prescribed numerous medications. Use of herbal therapies in addition to these conventional drug therapies may lead to interactions that result in an adverse drug event. The authors have conducted a systematic review to identify all studies that examined interactions between herbal and conventional drug therapies (i.e. prescription or over-the-counter). 

Authors' conclusions

The authors identified a series of potential interactions between herbal and conventional drug therapy that place older people at risk for an adverse drug event. Health care professionals need to be aware of these potential interactions.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Herb-drug interactions: A review and study based on assessment of clinical case reports in literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ST JOHN'S WORT (HYPERICUM PERFORATUM),HERBAL MEDICINE,HERBS R-Z,SAFETY,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL,OCTOBER 2008,2008]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Gohil KJ, Patel JA. Herb-drug interactions: A review and study based on assessment of clinical case reports in literature. Indian Journal of Pharmacology. 2007, 39(3):129-39.

Authors' objectives

To conduct a systematic review of literature on interactions between conventional drugs and various herbs. 

Authors' conclusions

Herb-drug interactions are a stark reality today. Hence, proper reporting of cases, careful vigilance, evidence-based appraisal and constantly updated reviews of such herb-drug interactions are very important to promote systematic research.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Herb-drug interactions: review and assessment of report reliability
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,SAFETY,CAM GENERAL,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Fugh-Berman A, Ernst E. Herb-drug interactions: review and assessment of report reliability. British Journal of Pharmacology. 2001, 52(5):587-95.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this systematic review was to assess the published clinical evidence on interactions between herbal and conventional drugs.

Authors' conclusions

Herb–drug interactions undoubtedly do occur and may put individuals at risk. However our present knowledge is incomplete and more research is urgently needed.
]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Heterogeneity and lack of good quality studies limit association between folate, vitamins B-6 and B-12, and cognitive function
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS C,COGNITION DISORDERS,DECEMBER 2008,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,VITAMINS,DATE ADDED,VITAMIN B 6,VITAMIN B 12,FOLIC ACID]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Raman G, Tatsioni A, Chung M, Rosenberg IH, Lau J, Lichtenstein AH, Balk EM. Heterogeneity and lack of good quality studies limit association between folate, vitamins B-6 and B-12, and cognitive function. Journal of Nutrition. 2007; 137(7): 1789-1794.

Authors' objectives

To conduct a systematic review to evaluate the association between folate, vitamin B-6, vitamin B-12, and cognitive function in the elderly.

Authors' conclusions

Although the majority of studies indicated that low blood folate concentrations predicted poorer cognitive function, data supporting this association were limited because of the heterogeneity in cognition-assessment methodology, and scarcity of good quality studies and standardized threshold levels for categorizing low B-vitamin status. 

]]>

document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Grabia S, Ernst E. Homeopathic aggravations: a systematic review of randomised, placebo-controlled clinical trials. Homeopathy. 2003, 92(2): 92-98.

Authors' objectives

This systematic review aimed at comparing the frequency of homeopathic aggravations in the placebo and verum groups of double-blind, randomised clinical trials.

Authors' conclusions

This systematic review does not provide clear evidence that the phenomenon of homeopathic aggravations exists.

 

]]>

document.body:
111-1Homeopathy Annual Evidence Update: June 2008

Introduction


The 2008 Annual Evidence Update on Homeopathy aims to identify, organise and present the most up-to-date evidence on this topic. We have carried out searches in a large number of databases. The searches aimed to identify all relevant systematic reviews and randomised controlled trials (RCTs) published since April 2007. Previously published studies have been included in the 2007 Homeopathy National Knowledge Week (NKW).

The studies included in this evidence update have met our selection criteria but have not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.


For more details about the search methods and the selection process for this annual update see the methodology section.


For a brief overview of the topic of Homeopathy, including information on clinical uses and safety, see the introductory article.


Contents

document.body:
111-1Homeopathy for allergic, ENT and respiratory conditions

Homeopathy Annual Evidence Update 2008

The following relevant studies on this topic have been published since April 2007.

These studies have met our selection criteria. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.


Friese KH, Zabalotnyi DI. [Homeopathy in acute rhinosinusitis: a double-blind, placebo controlled study shows the efficiency and tolerability of a homeopathic combination remedy]. HNO 2007, 55(4):271-7.

Background: The efficacy and tolerability of a homeopathic combination remedy for the treatment of acute rhinosinusitis was investigated.

Patients and methods: A total of 144 patients with acute rhinosinusitis were treated in a randomized, double-blind study either with a homeopathic remedy (n=72) or placebo (n=72). At the control examinations after 7, 14 and 21 days, five sinusitis-typical symptoms were measured with scores from 0 (absent) to 4 (very strong). The change of sum score of the sinusitis-typical symptoms (max. 20 points) during the treatment served as the primary efficacy criterion.

Results: In the homeopathic treatment group, the average sum score dropped from initially 12.1+/-1.6 to 5.9+/-2.0 points after 7 days. In the placebo group it decreased from 11.7+/-1.6 to 11.0+/-2.9 points (p<0.0001). The homeopathic treatment resulted in freedom from complaints in 90.3% of the patients and improvement in a further 8.3%, whereas in the placebo group, the complaints remained unchanged or became worse in 88.9% of the patients. Only one adverse event occurred in one patient from the placebo group.

Conclusion: The homeopathic product allows an effective and tolerable treatment of acute rhinosinusitis.


Steinsbekk A, Lewith G, Fønnebø V, Bentzen N. An exploratory study of the contextual effect of homeopathic care. A randomised controlled trial of homeopathic care vs. self-prescribed homeopathic medicine in the prevention of upper respiratory tract infections in children. Preventive Medicine. 2007, 45(4):274-9.

Objectives: The aim of this study was to explore the contextual effect of homeopathic consultation by investigating the effect of homeopathic care compared to self-treatment with self prescribed homeopathic medicine in the prevention of childhood upper respiratory tract infections (URTI).

Methods: Randomised parallel group trial with 208 children below the age of 10. The children were randomly assigned to receive either homeopathic care (HC: individual homeopathic consultations with any homeopathic medicine in any potency being prescribed) or one of three self-prescribed homeopathic medicines (SPH) in C-30 administered twice weekly, for 12 weeks.

Results: There were no significant differences in clinical effects between SPH and HC for primary outcomes. Mean URTI scores over 12 weeks were 39.0 in the HC group and 43.9 in the SPH group (p=0.782, difference -5.0 points (95% C.I.; -20.5 to +10.5)). The mean number of days where the parents rated their child as 'ill with URTI' was 10.0 in the HC group and 13.7 in the SPH group (p=0.394). There was a trend in favour of HC for other outcomes.

Conclusions: In this innovative and exploratory study, there was no evidence for a clinically relevant effect of homeopathic care vs. a homeopathic medicine given by the child's parents and based on a pre-agreed homeopathic treatment protocol.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Homeopathy for anxiety and anxiety disorders: a systematic review of the research
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,HOMEOPATHY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-B,ANXIETY,ANXIETY DISORDERS,DATE ADDED,JUNE 2007]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Pilkington K, Kirkwood G, Rampes H, Fisher P, Richardson J. Homeopathy for anxiety and anxiety disorders: a systematic review of the research. Homeopathy 2006, 95(3):151-62.

Authors' objectives

To conduct a systematic review of the clinical research evidence on homeopathy in the treatment of anxiety and anxiety disorders.

Authors' conclusions

A comprehensive search demonstrates that the evidence on the benefit of homeopathy in anxiety and anxiety disorders is limited. A number of studies of homeopathy in such conditions were located but the randomised controlled trials report contradictory results, are underpowered or provide insufficient details of methodology. Several uncontrolled and observational studies reported positive results including high levels of patient satisfaction but because of the lack of a control group, it is difficult to assess the extent to which any response is due to homeopathy. Adverse effects reported appear limited to 'remedy reactions' and included temporary worsening of symptoms and reappearance of old symptoms. On the basis of this review it is not possible to draw firm conclusions on the efficacy or effectiveness of homeopathy for anxiety. However, surveys suggest that homeopathy is quite frequently used by people suffering from anxiety. If shown to be effective, it is possible that homeopathy may have benefits in terms of adverse effects and acceptability to patients. Consequently, further investigation is indicated. Future research should be of pragmatic design and include qualitative studies.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Homeopathy for attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder or hyperkinetic disorder
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HOMEOPATHY,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS A-B,ATTENTION DEFICIT / HYPERACTIVITY DISORDER,JUNE 2008,2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-1Homeopathy for attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder or hyperkinetic disorder

Homeopathy Annual Evidence Update 2008

Dr Peter Fisher, Royal London Homoeopathic Hospital


The authors of the Cochrane review1 conclude that: ‘There is currently little evidence for the efficacy of homeopathy for the treatment of ADHD. Development of optimal treatment protocols is recommended prior to further randomised controlled trials being undertaken’.

There are two recent, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trials of good quality of homeopathic treatment of ADHD. 2,3 The former had a positive result, the latter showed no difference between homeopathy and placebo. The  apparent conflict between the outcomes may be explicable in terms of differences of design  between the two studies. 

Both studies used individualised homeopathic prescribing, but only one of the 6 most frequently prescribed homeopathic medicines is common to both studies. Yet this is not the most important difference. The Swiss group led by Frei has extensive documented experience of the treatment of this condition, including a 115 participant observational study.2 Their RCT was of unusual design, it was a trial not of treatment, but of treatment withdrawal. In an initial open label run-in period the optimal homeopathic treatment was determined, on the basis of a predetermined definition of response (50% improvement in Connor’s Global Index). It took a mean of three attempts to determine the optimal treatment. Responders (84%) were then entered into the double-blind RCT. Jacobs et al.’s trial was of conventional double-blind placebo-controlled design, with randomisation prior to starting homeopathic treatment.3

In a post-hoc analysis Frei et al.4 showed that, had they randomised before obtaining a treatment response, as did Jacobs et al., they too would have found no difference between placebo and verum homeopathic treatment.

The results of the two RCTs are thus not necessarily incompatible, they could reflect the fact that homeopathic treatment of this condition is difficult and that, as the Cochrane review concludes, improved treatment protocols are required.


References


1. Coulter MK, Dean ME. Homeopathy for attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder or hyperkinetic disorder. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2007, Issue 4. Art. No.: CD005648. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD005648.pub2. [Full text]


2. Frei H, Everts R, von Ammon K, Kaufmann F, Walther D, Hsu-Schmitz S, Collenberg M, Fuhrer K, Hassink R, Steinlin M, Thurneysen A. Homeopathic treatment of children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder: a randomised double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover trial. European Journal of Pediatrics. 2005, 164(12):758-767. [PubMed abstract] 


3. Jacobs J, Williams A, Girard C, Njike VY, Katz D. Homeopathy for attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder: a pilot randomized controlled trial. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2005;11(5):799-806. [PubMed abstract]


4. Frei H, Everts R, von Ammon K, Kaufmann F, Walther D, Schmitz SF, Collenberg M, Steinlin M, Lim C, Thurneysen A. Randomised controlled trials of homeopathy in hyperactive children: treatment procedure leads to an unconventional study design. Experience with open-label homeopathic treatment preceding the Swiss ADHD placebo controlled, randomised, double-blind, cross-over trial.
Homeopathy. 2007, 96(1):35-41. [PubMed abstract]

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Homeopathy for cancer
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HOMEOPATHY,CONDITIONS A-Z,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,JUNE 2007,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-1Homeopathy for cancer

Homeopathy National Knowledge Week, 11-15 June 2007


The following relevant study on this topic has been identified:


Milazzo S, Russell N, Ernst E. Efficacy of homeopathic therapy in cancer treatment. European Journal of Cancer. 2006, 42:282-9. [PubMed abstract] [DARE appraisal]


Authors' objectives

The authors' objective was to evaluate the effectiveness of any type of homeopathic therapy in the treatment of patients with cancer.

Authors' conclusions

Although the evidence for homeopathy was encouraging, there was insufficient evidence to support the use of homeopathy in patients with cancer. Further research is required.

CRD commentary

The review addressed a clear question that was defined in terms of the participants, intervention, outcomes and study design. Several relevant conventional and complementary medicine databases were searched, but it was unclear whether attempts were made to reduce publication and language bias. Methods were used to minimise reviewer errors and bias in the validity assessment and dat extraction, but it was not clear whether similar steps were taken in the study selection process. Validity was assessed using criteria appropriate for RCTs and the results of this assessment were reported. Adequate information on the individual studies was provided. Given the diversity of the studies, the narrative synthesis was appropriate. Limitations of the review were the restricted search and lack of full reporting of review methods. Overall, the authors' conclusions about the limitations of the evidence are likely to be reliable.

 

]]>

document.title: Homeopathy for children's health problems
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,HOMEOPATHY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,RESPIRATORY TRACT INFECTIONS,DIARRHOEA,CONDITIONS P-R,ATTENTION DEFICIT / HYPERACTIVITY DISORDER,CONDITIONS D-E,CONDITIONS A-B,ASTHMA,2007,DATE ADDED,JUNE 2007]]>
document.body:
111-1Homeopathy for children's health problems

Homeopathy National Knowledge Week, 11-15 June 2007

Dr Michael Emmans Dean, University of York


Homeopathy remains a popular choice for children’s health problems, often used by parents because it is believed to be safe. A recent systematic review of randomised double-blind placebo-controlled trials for different clinical conditions found 16 eligible studies for 9 different conditions.1 Only two conditions were represented by three trials each: attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, and acute diarrhoea.


Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)

Three ADHD trials all used variants of the Conners’ Global Index - Parent Scale as the primary outcome. Two were individualised according to different prescribing protocols, and provided conflicting evidence.2,3  There were important differences between the design of the trials which could account for the differences.4 A trial of a formula prescription reported positive results for two of six outcomes.5


Diarrhoea

Standard treatment (oral rehydration therapy: ORT) plus individualised homeopathy or placebo was tested in three similar trials which measured the time to fewer than three unformed stools on two consecutive days.6-8 The evidence conflicted when the trials were considered individually, although there was a significant overall reduction of time to recovery in the homeopathy group when the results of all three were pooled: 3.3 days compared with 4.1 days in the placebo group.8 A fourth study published since the systematic review tested a formula preparation plus ORT and found no difference from placebo.9


Other conditions

Two trials each of homeopathy for adenoid growths10,11, asthma12,13 and upper respiratory tract infection14,15 found no benefit from homeopathy compared with placebo. Treatments were not comparable in either of the trials for each of the three conditions.

Single trials of individualized treatment for acute otitis media16 and a formula (Aconite) for postoperative agitation syndrome17 both reported significant benefits from homeopathy. Euphrasia used preventively for conjunctivitis18 and individualised homeopathy for warts19 showed no difference from placebo.


Conclusion

Pooled evidence from a series of three trials with similar designs and treatment protocols, conducted by one group of investigators suggests that individualised homeopathy for acute childhood diarrhoea may be a clinically relevant addition to standard treatment (ORT), but independent replication is required. Other conditions and homeopathic treatments have yet to be systematically investigated to the same extent, making it difficult to draw firm conclusions about homeopathy’s efficacy in child health.


References


1. Altunc U, Pittler MH, Ernst E. Homeopathy for childhood and adolescence ailments: systematic review of randomized clinical trials. Mayo Clinic proceedings. 2007, 82(1):69-75. [PubMed abstract] 


2. Frei H, Everts R, von Ammon K, Kaufmann F, Walther D, Hsu-Schmitz SF, et al. Homeopathic treatment of children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder: a randomised, double blind, placebo controlled crossover trial. European Journal of Pediatrics. 2005, 164(12):758-67. [PubMed abstract]


3. Jacobs J, Williams AL, Girard C, Njike VY, Katz D. Homeopathy for attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder: a pilot randomized-controlled trial. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2005, 11(5):799-806. [PubMed abstract]


4. Frei H,  Everts R, von Ammon K et al. Randomised controlled trials of homeopathy in hyperactive children: treatment procedure leads to an unconventional study design: Experience with open-label homeopathic treatment preceding the Swiss ADHD placebo controlled, randomised, double-blind, cross-over trial
Homeopathy. 2007,  96(1) 35-41.


5. Strauss LC. The efficacy of a homeopathic preparation in the management of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Biomedical Therapy. 2000, 18(2):197-201.


6. Jacobs J, Jimenez LM, Gloyd SS, Gale JL, Crothers D. Treatment of acute childhood diarrhea with homeopathic medicine: a randomized clinical trial in Nicaragua. Pediatrics. 1994, 93(5):719-25. [PubMed abstract]


7. Jacobs J, Jimenez LM, Malthouse S, Chapman E, Crothers D, Masuk M, et al. Homeopathic treatment of acute childhood diarrhea: Results from a clinical trial in Nepal. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2000, 6(2):131-9. [PubMed abstract]


8. Jacobs J, Jonas WB, Jimenez-Perez M, Crothers D. Homeopathy for childhood diarrhea: combined results and metaanalysis from three randomized, controlled clinical trials. Pediatric Infectious Disease Journal. 2003, 22(3):229-34. [PubMed abstract]


9. Jacobs J, Guthrie BL, Montes GA, Jacobs LE, Mickey-Colman N, Wilson AR, et al. Homeopathic combination remedy in the treatment of acute childhood diarrhea in Honduras. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2006, 12(8):723-32. [PubMed abstract]


10. Furuta SE, Weckx LLM, Figueiredo CR. Prospective, randomized, double-blind clinical trial about efficacy of homeopathic treatment in children with obstructive adenoid. Revista Brasileira de Otorrinolaringologia. 2003, 69(3):343-7.


11. Friese KH, Feuchter U, Moeller H. [Homeopathic treatment of adenoid vegetations. Results of a prospective, randomized double-blind study]. HNO. 1997, 45(8):618-24. [PubMed abstract]

13. White A, Slade P, Hunt C, Hart A, Ernst E. Individualised homeopathy as an adjunct in the treatment of childhood asthma: a randomised placebo controlled trial. Thorax. 2003, 58(4):317-21. [PubMed abstract]

Self treatment with one of three self selected, ultramolecular homeopathic medicines for the prevention of upper respiratory tract infections in children. A double-blind randomized placebo controlled trial. British Journal of Clinical Pharmacology. 2005, 59(4):447-55. [PubMed abstract]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Homeopathy for headache
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,HOMEOPATHY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS F-H,CONDITIONS M-O,MIGRAINE,HEADACHE,2007,MAY 2007,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-1Homeopathy for headache

Homeopathy National Knowledge Week, 11-15 June 2007

Robert T Mathie, PhD
British Homeopathic Association


The entire research evidence for homeopathic treatment of headache (tension-type, cervicogenic or migraine) was systematically reviewed by Owen & Green (2004).1  No new studies in this area have been published since that review. Six original research papers were identified: 4 randomised controlled trials (RCT) and 2 prospective observational (non-randomised non-controlled) studies (POS). The 4 RCTs were all placebo-controlled. All 6 studies investigated individualised (classical) homeopathy, though one of the RCTs limited prescription to a selection of just 8 medicines. 

The key research data are summarised in the table below (adapted from Table 2 of the review by Owen & Green): 

 

First author, date of publication

Headache type

Study design

Sample size

Study duration (months)

Outcome

Brigo, 19912

Migraine

RCT

60

4

+

Walach, 19973

Chronic

RCT

98

3

+/-

Whitmarsh, 19974

Migraine

RCT

60

4

+/-

Straumsheim, 20005

Migraine

RCT

73

4

+/-

Muscari-Tomaioli, 20016

All

POS

53

4-6

+

Walach, 20017

Chronic

POS

18

12

+

+ Positive findings (homeopathy superior to placebo [RCT]; clear proportion of patients with symptom improvement [POS]).
+/- Non-statistically significant differences between homeopathy and placebo.


Improvement in headache symptoms was observed in all 6 studies. However, 3 of the RCTs found no significant difference between homeopathy and placebo – symptoms improved in both groups of patients. The fourth RCT, where homeopathic prescribing was limited to one of just 8 options, found homeopathy was superior to placebo.  In common with most such research in homeopathy, both studies of POS design found clear improvement in symptoms. Thus, the overall evidence suggests that the homeopathy might benefit headache patients, but it does not convincingly indicate it is more effective than placebo. In no study was homeopathy found to be less effective than placebo, or harmful.


The review led the authors to conclude there is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of homeopathy for managing headache. However, they also noted several flaws in the design of studies published to date, and recommended further investigation, highlighting the challenges that exist in finding a rigorous research model that is also relevant to homeopathic practice.


References

1. Owen JM, Green BN. Homeopathic treatment of headaches: A systematic review of the literature. Journal of Chiropractic Medicine 2004; 3: 45–52. [Abstract]


2. Brigo B, Serpelloni G. Homoeopathic treatment of migraines – A randomized double-blind controlled study of sixty cases - (homoeopathic remedy versus placebo). Berlin Journal of Research in Homeopathy 1991; 1: 98–106.


3. Walach H, Häusler W, Lowes T, Mussbach D, Schamell U, Springer W, Stritzl G, Gaus W, Haag G. Classical homeopathic treatment of chronic headaches. Cephalalgia 1997; 17: 119–126. [Abstract]


4. Whitmarsh TE, Coleston-Shields DM, Steiner TJ. Double-blind randomised placebo-controlled study of homoeopathic prophylaxis of migraine. Cephalalgia 1997; 17: 600–604. [Abstract]


5. Straumsheim P, Borchgrevink C, Mowinckel P, Kierulf H, Hafslund O. Homeopathic treatment of migraine: A double blind, placebo controlled trial of 68 patients. British Homeopathic Journal 2000; 89: 4–7. [PubMed abstract]


6. Muscari-Tomaioli G, Allegri F, Miali E, Pomposelli R, Tubia P, Targhetta A, Castellini M, Bellavite P. Observational study of quality of life in patients with headache, receiving homeopathic treatment. British Homeopathic Journal 2001; 90: 189–197. [PubMed abstract]


7. Walach H, Lowes T, Mussbach D, Schamell U, Springer W, Stritzl G, Haag G. The long term effects of homeopathic treatment of chronic headaches: one year follow-up and single case time series analysis. British Homeopathic Journal 2001; 90: 63–72. [PubMed abstract]


 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Homeopathy for trauma
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HOMEOPATHY,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS T-Z,WOUNDS AND INJURIES,DATE ADDED,JUNE 2007,2007]]>
document.body:
111-1Homeopathy for trauma

Homeopathy National Knowledge Week, 11-15 June 2007

Robert T Mathie, PhD
British Homeopathic Association


The treatment of trauma and injury often involves the use of Arnica montana, for which the main homeopathic symptom indication is ‘painful bruising’. A wide range of specific conditions has been the subject of published research on the efficacy of homeopathic Arnica, and it is this diverse literature that was systematically reviewed by Lüdke & Hacke in 2005.1 All prospective, controlled trials on homeopathic Arnica were included in the review.  Overall effectiveness was assessed by meta-analysis and meta-regression techniques.  Sixty-eight comparisons from 49 clinical trials showed significant effectiveness of Arnica in traumatic injuries in meta-analysis (odds ratio (OR), 0.36; 95% confidence interval (CI), 0.24-0.55), but not in meta-regression models (OR, 0.37; CI, 0.11-1.24).  There was no evidence for publication bias.  Studies from MEDLINE-listed journals and high-quality studies were less likely to report positive results. The authors were unable either to accept or to reject the hypothesis that homeopathic Arnica is effective. 


Four new research articles in this area have been published in the peer-review literature since the above review: Oberbaum et al., 20052;  Brinkhaus et al., 2006 (reporting 3 separate trials)3;  Seeley et al., 2006 4;  Robertson et al., 2007 4.   If these recent studies are included in an overview of just the peer-reviewed research literature of perioperative trauma where Arnica was the only homeopathic medicine used (as opposed to being part of a complex formulation of two or more medicines), and restricting the review to placebo-controlled trials that were explicitly randomised and double-blinded, the following more detailed picture emerges. Trials on Arnica for stroke 6, 7,   and for muscle soreness 8, 9, 10, 11 have been omitted from this specific update:

Total number of trials:  12

No. with positive findings:  3 3, 5, 4 
No. with negative findings:  1 15
No. with non-statistically significant differences:  8 3, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18 

Thus, the positive evidence for homeopathic Arnica in perioperative trauma comprises 25% of the research literature in this area, and is limited to postoperative swelling and pain after cruciate ligament reconstruction 3, post-tonsillectomy analgesia 5, and postoperative haematoma (ecchymosis) 4.  The effectiveness of Arnica in other perioperative situations is equivocal.


References

1. Lüdtke R, Hacke D. [On the effectiveness of the homeopathic remedy Arnica montana]. Wiener medizinische Wochenschrift. 2005, 155: 482–490. [PubMed abstract]


2. Oberbaum M, Galoyan N, Lerner-Geva L, Singer SR, Grisaru S, Shashar D, Samueloff A. The effect of the homeopathic remedies Arnica and Bellis perennis on mild postpartum bleeding – a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study –preliminary results. Complementary Therapies in Medicine. 2005, 13(2): 87–90. [PubMed abstract]


3. Brinkhaus B, Wilkens JM, Lüdtke R, Hunger J, Witt CM, Willich SN. Homeopathic arnica therapy in patients receiving knee surgery: results of three randomised double-blind trials. Complementary Therapies in Medicine. 2006, 14(4): 237–246. [PubMed abstract]


4. Seeley BM, Denton AB, Ahn MS, Maas CS. Effect of homeopathic Arnica montana on bruising in face-lifts: results of a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial. Archives of Facial Plastic Surgery. 2006, 8(1): 54–59. [PubMed abstract]


5. Robertson A, Suryanarayanan R, Banerjee A. Homeopathic Arnica montana for post-tonsillectomy analgesia: a randomised placebo control trial. Homeopathy. 2007, 96(1): 17–21. [PubMed abstract]


6. Savage RH, Roe PF. A double blind trial to assess the benefit of Arnica montana in acute stroke illness. British Homeopathic Journal. 1977, 66: 207–220.


7. Savage RH, Roe PF. A further double blind trial to assess the benefit of Arnica montana in acute stroke illness. British Homeopathic Journal. 1978, 67: 210–222.


8. Tveiten D, Bruseth S, Borchgrevink CF, Norseth J. Effects of the homoeopathic remedy Arnica D30 on marathon runners: a randomized, double-blind study during the 1995 Oslo Marathon. Complementary Therapies in Medicine. 1998, 6: 71–74.


9. Tveiten D, Bruseth S, Borchgrevink CF, Løhne K. [Effect of Arnica D30 on hard physical exertion. A double-blind randomized trial during the 1990 Oslo Marathon]. Tidsskrift for den Norske Lœgeforening. 1991, 111(30): 3630–3631. [PubMed abstract]


10. Vickers AJ, Fisher P, Smith C, Wyllie SE, Lewith GT. Homoeopathy for delayed onset muscle soreness: a randomized double blind placebo controlled trial. British Journal of Sports Medicine. 1997, 31(4): 304–307. [PubMed abstract]


11. Vickers AJ, Fisher P, Smith C, Wyllie SE, Rees R. Homeopathic Arnica 30X is ineffective for muscle soreness after long-distance running: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Clinical Journal of Pain. 1998, 14(3): 227–231. [PubMed abstract]


12. Kaziro GS. Metronidazole (Flagyl) and Arnica montana in the prevention of post-surgical complications, a comparative placebo controlled clinical trial. British Journal of Oral & Maxillofacial Surgery. 1984, 22(1): 42–49. [PubMed abstract]


13. Hofmeyr GJ, Piccioni V, Blauhof P. Postpartum homoeopathic Arnica Montana: a potency-finding pilot study. British Journal of Clinical Practice. 1990, 44(12): 619–621. [PubMed]


14. Hart O, Mullee MA, Lewith G, Miller J. Double-blind, placebo-controlled, randomized clinical trial of homoeopathic arnica C30 for pain and infection after total abdominal hysterectomy. Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 1997, 90(2): 73–78. [Full text]


15. Kennedy CO. A controlled trial. British Homeopathic Journal. 1971, 60: 120–127.


16. Ramelet AA, Buchheim G, Lorenz P, Imfeld M. Homoeopathic arnica in postoperative haematomas: a double-blind study. Dermatology. 2000, 201(4): 347–348. [PubMed abstract]


17. Stevinson C, Devaraj VS, Fountain-Barber A, Hawkins S, Ernst E.  Homeopathic arnica for prevention of pain and bruising: randomized placebo-controlled trial in hand surgery. Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 2003, 96(2): 60–65. [Full text]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Homeopathy in people with diabetes
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,HOMEOPATHY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIABETES MELLITUS,CONDITIONS D-E,DATE ADDED,JUNE 2008,2008]]>
document.body:
111-1Homeopathy in people with diabetes

Homeopathy Annual Evidence Update 2008

Karen Pilkington, School of Integrated Health, University of Westminster


Extent of use

Limited information is available on the extent of use of homeopathy by people with diabetes in the UK. A survey in 1997 of the use of complementary medicine by people with diabetes who attended a UK diabetic clinic revealed that homeopathy was the second most frequently used therapy.1 However, the survey was conducted in a relatively small sample of patients and the overall prevalence of use was only 17%. In a considerably larger survey of over 2400 people with diabetes in the USA, use of homeopathy was reported as part of a broader category of ‘other therapies’.2 A second survey of similar size focusing on affordability of complementary medicine reported low use of homeopathy (approximately 1.5% of responders) compared with use of herbs (over 15%).3 This possibly reflects the low use of homeopathy in general in the USA. In contrast, rates of homeopathy use in Europe and particularly in Germany are much higher. A survey of patients attending paediatric diabetic centres in 4 cities in Germany, found that homeopathy was the most commonly used therapy being used by 14.5% patients.4 Overall rate of use of complementary therapies was 18.4%. Little research has been published on the reasons why people with diabetes choose to use specific therapies including homeopathy although data from US studies suggests that female gender, higher education and having at least two chronic conditions were associated with higher complementary therapy use while most use is for non-diabetes conditions.5


Effectiveness

Similarly, few studies have been published on the effectiveness of homeopathy in diabetes. A systematic review of homeopathy in 1991 found a single low quality trial reported at a conference.6 A more recent systematic review 7 did not locate any further randomised trials and only two controlled studies. One study aimed to assess the effect of homeopathy on hyperglycaemia in 85 type 1 and type 2 diabetic patients over a one month period. The use of non-diabetic patients as controls and the fact that a variety of homeopathic, indigenous and allopathic treatments were given prevent useful conclusions being drawn. The second study investigated the effect of a proprietary product containing 17 substances in homoeopathic concentrations combined with alpha-lipoic acid on diabetic neuropathy. Beneficial effects were reported but small numbers of patients were involved and further studies confirming these findings were not found.


Conclusion

There is currently insufficient evidence to assess homeopathic treatment in people with diabetes.


References:


1. Leese GP, Gill GV, Houghton GM. Prevalence of complementary medicine usage within a diabetes clinic. Practical Diabetes International. 1997, 14(7): 207–208. [Abstract]


2. Garrow D, Egede LE. National patterns and correlates of complementary and alternative medicine use in adults with diabetes. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2006, 12(9):895-902. [PubMed abstract]


3. Pagán JA, Tanguma J. Health care affordability and complementary and alternative medicine utilization by adults with diabetes. Diabetes Care. 2007, 30(8):2030-1. [Full text]


4. Dannemann K, Hecker W, Haberland H, Herbst A, Galler A, Schäfer T, Brähler E, Kiess W, Kapellen TM. Use of complementary and alternative medicine in children with type 1 diabetes mellitus - prevalence, patterns of use, and costs. Pediatric Diabetes. 2008 Mar 5. [Epub ahead of print] [PubMed abstract]


5. Bell RA, Suerken CK, Grzywacz JG, Lang W, Quandt SA, Arcury TA. Complementary and alternative medicine use among adults with diabetes in the United States. Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine. 2006, 12(5):16-22. [PubMed abstract]


6. Kleijnen J, Knipschild P, ter Riet G. Clinical trials of homoeopathy. BMJ. 1991, 302(6772):316-23. [Full text]


7. Pilkington K, Stenhouse E, Kirkwood G, Richardson J. Diabetes and complementary therapies: Mapping the evidence. Practical Diabetes International. 2007, 24(7):371-6. [Abstract] 

 

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,ST JOHN'S WORT (HYPERICUM PERFORATUM),DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS D-E,HERBS R-Z]]>

Authors' objectives

Authors' conclusions

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: How objective are systematic reviews? Differences between reviews on complementary medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HOMEOPATHY,ACUPUNCTURE,HERBAL MEDICINE,RESEARCH,SEPTEMBER 2007,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:
Citation

Linde K, Willich SN. How objective are systematic reviews? Differences between reviews on complementary medicine. Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine. 2003, 96(1):17-22. 

Authors' objectives

Systematic reviews are considered the most reliable tool to summarize existing evidence. To determine whether reviews that address the same questions can produce different answers we examined systematic reviews of herbal medicine, homeopathy, and acupuncture taken from a previously established database.

Authors' conclusions

This analysis shows that, at least in the three areas examined, systematic reviews often differ considerably. Readers should be aware that apparently minor decisions in the review process can have major impact. 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Huangqi preparations for unstable angina (Cochrane protocol)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-B,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),ANGINA,CAM GENERAL,RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
This is the protocol for a Cochrane systematic review. This record will be updated when the review has been completed.

Citation

Liu G, Chen X, Wu T. Huangqi preparations for unstable angina. (Protocol) The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2005, Issue 1. Art. No.: CD005153. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD005153.

Authors' objectives

To assess the effect (harms and benefits) of Huangqi injection or other drug types of Huangqi for unstable angina. Specific comparisons will be made between Huangqi (in monotherapy compared to placebo or no intervention or other anti-anginal medicine; or in combination with other antianginal therapies compared to other anti-anginal therapies) in the treatment of unstable angina pectoris. If possible, we are also interested in comparing the effect of different routes and timing of administration.

Other anti-anginal medicine include the commonly used chemical drugs like aspirin, Clopidogrel, heparin, nitroglycerin, beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, ACE inhibitors and so on. Widely used Medicinal herbs like Danshen may also be compared with Huangqi.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Iberogast: a modern phytotherapeutic combined herbal drug for the treatment of functional disorders of the gastrointestinal tract (dyspepsia, irritable bowel syndrome)--from phytomedicine to "evidence based phytotherapy." A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,NOVEMBER 2006,CONDITIONS D-E,CONDITIONS F-H,IRRITABLE BOWEL SYNDROME,DYSPEPSIA,GASTROINTESTINAL DISEASES,CONDITIONS I-L,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
Citation

Saller R, Pfister-Hotz G, Iten F, Melzer J, Reichling J. [Iberogast: a modern phytotherapeutic combined herbal drug for the treatment of functional disorders of the gastrointestinal tract (dyspepsia, irritable bowel syndrome)--from phytomedicine to "evidence based phytotherapy." A systematic review]. Forschende Komplementarmedizin und Klassische Naturheilkunde. 2002 Dec;9 Suppl 1:1-20. (German)

Authors' objectives

To investigate the clinical effectiveness of Iberogast.

Authors' conclusions

As shown in controlled (according GCP standard) as well as supportive and uncontrolled clinical studies, the symptoms of functional dyspepsia and of irritable bowel syndrome (one controlled study and one observational study) could be significantly reduced by these herbal preparation in comparison to placebo. Two trials comparing Iberogast with the prokinetics metoclopramide and cisapride demonstrated a comparable therapeutic effectiveness of the herbal preparation and the prokinetics in the treatment of dyspepsia. Adverse events were rare and, with respect to frequency and spectrum, partly the same as found with placebo. Another advantage of Iberogast is that it targets only the gastrointestinal tract and the enteral nervous system, but not the central nervous system. Because of its special dual action, its clinically proven effectiveness, and its good tolerability, Iberogast may be a drug of first choice in the treatment of functional gastrointestinal diseases and their corresponding symptoms.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Immunology and homeopathy. 4. Clinical studies: part 1
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HOMEOPATHY,CONDITIONS A-B,ALLERGIES,DATE ADDED,JANUARY 2008]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Bellavite P, Ortolani R, Pontarollo F, Piasere V, Benato G, Conforti A. Immunology and homeopathy. 4. Clinical studies: part 1. Evidence-Based Complementary and Alternative Medicine. 2006;3(3):293-301.

Authors' objectives

To review the evidence-based research of the effectiveness of homeopathic medicines in common immunologic disorders.

Authors' conclusions (in part 2, see citation below):

The evidence demonstrates that in some conditions homeopathy shows significant promise, e.g. Galphimia glauca (low dilutions/potencies) in allergic oculorhinitis, classical individualized homeopathy in otitis and possibly in asthma and allergic complaints, and a few low-potency homeopathic complexes in sinusitis and rhinoconjunctivitis. A general weakness of evidence derives from lack of independent confirmation of reported trials and from presence of conflicting results, as in case of homeopathic immunotherapy and of classical homeopathy for URTI. The suitable methods to evaluate homeopathy effectiveness, without altering the setting of cure, are also analyzed.

Bellavite P, Ortolani R, Pontarollo F, Piasere V, Benato G, Conforti A. Immunology and homeopathy. 4. Clinical studies-part 2. Evidence-based Complementary and Alternative Medicine: eCAM. 2006, 3(4):397-409. [Full text]

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Immunology and Homeopathy. 4. Clinical Studies—Part 2
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HOMEOPATHY,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS M-O,CONDITIONS F-H,CONDITIONS A-B,ASTHMA,ALLERGIES,RESPIRATORY TRACT INFECTIONS,CONDITIONS P-R,HAY FEVER,OTITIS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Bellavite P, Ortolani R, Pontarollo F, Piasere V, Benato G, Conforti A. Immunology and homeopathy. 4. Clinical studies-part 2. Evidence-based Complementary and Alternative Medicine: eCAM. 2006, 3(4):397-409.

Authors' objectives

To evaluate the literature of common immunologic disorders including also upper respiratory tract infections (URTI) and otorhinolaryngology.

Authors' conclusions

The evidence demonstrates that in some conditions homeopathy shows significant promise, e.g. Galphimia glauca (low dilutions/potencies) in allergic oculorhinitis, classical individualized homeopathy in otitis and possibly in asthma and allergic complaints, and a few low-potency homeopathic complexes in sinusitis and rhinoconjunctivitis. A general weakness of evidence derives from lack of independent confirmation of reported trials and from presence of conflicting results, as in case of homeopathic immunotherapy and of classical homeopathy for URTI. The suitable methods to evaluate homeopathy effectiveness, without altering the setting of cure, are also analyzed.

Related studies

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Impact of antioxidant supplementation on chemotherapeutic toxicity: a systematic review of the evidence from randomized controlled trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS C,CANCER,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,MARCH 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Block KI, Koch AC, Mead MN, Tothy PK, Newman RA, Gyllenhaal C. Impact of antioxidant supplementation on chemotherapeutic toxicity: a systematic review of the evidence from randomized controlled trials. Int J Cancer. 2008 Sep 15;123(6):1227-39.

Authors' objectives

The objective of this study is to systematically review the randomized, controlled clinical trial evidence evaluating the effects of concurrent use of antioxidants with chemotherapy on toxic side effects. 

Antioxidants evaluated were: glutathione (11), melatonin (7), vitamin A (1), an antioxidant mixture (2), N-acetylcysteine (2), vitamin E (5), selenium (2), L-carnitine (1), Co-Q10 (1) and ellagic acid (1).

Authors' conclusions

This review provides the first systematically reviewed evidence that antioxidant supplementation during chemotherapy holds potential for reducing dose-limiting toxicities. However, well-designed studies evaluating larger populations of patients given specific antioxidants defined by dose and schedule relative to chemotherapy are warranted.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Impact of herbal medicines on physical impairment
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,BACK PAIN,CONDITIONS A-B,DEVILS CLAW (HARPAGOPHYTUM PROCUMBENS),WHITE WILLOW (SALIX ALBA),HERBS D-G,HERBS R-Z,MARCH 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Chrubasik C, Black A, Muller-Ladner U, Chrubasik S. Impact of herbal medicines on physical impairment. Phytomedicine. 2008, 15(6-7):536-9.

Abstract

The usefulness of recording physical impairment during intervention studies in chronic low back patients has been questioned. A re-analysis of  studies investigating aqueous extracts of Harpagophytum procumbens and a proprietary ethanolic Salix extract for chronic non-specific low back pain revealed that the "physical impairment" component of the Arhus low back pain index changed very little during treatment despite appreciable changes in the other two components, "pain" and "disability", over time. For comparison, the authors also extracted data from the literature on the topical use of capsaicin, which showed the same thing. There may be little to lose from omitting the time-consuming assessments of "physical impairment" in studies of the (primarily analgesic) effectiveness of herbal preparations.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Imperfect placebos are common in low back pain trials: A systematic review of the literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CHIROPRACTIC,ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,MASSAGE,CONDITIONS A-B,BACK PAIN,MARCH 2010,RESEARCH,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Machado LAC, Kamper SJ, Herbert RD, Maher CG, McAuley JH. Imperfect placebos are common in low back pain trials: A systematic review of the literature. European Spine Journal. 2008, 17(7):889-904.

Authors' objectives

The purpose of this systematic review was to evaluate the adequacy of placebo interventions used in low back pain trials.

Authors' conclusion

Most trials that assessed patients' expectations showed that the placebo generated lower expectations than the experimental intervention. Taken together, these results demonstrate that imperfect placebos are common in low back pain trials; a result suggesting that many trials provide potentially biased estimates of treatment efficacy. This finding has implications for the interpretation of published trials and the design of future trials. Implementation of strategies to facilitate blinding and balance expectations in randomised groups need a higher priority in low back pain research.

]]>

document.title: In vitro fertilization and acupuncture: clinical efficacy and mechanistic basis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,PREGNANCY,CONDITIONS P-R,DATE ADDED,MAY 2008]]>
document.body:

Citation

Anderson BJ, Haimovici F, Ginsburg ES, Schust DJ, Wayne PM. In vitro fertilization and acupuncture: clinical efficacy and mechanistic basis. Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine. 2007, 13(3):38-48.

Authors' objectives

To provide an overview of the use of acupuncture as an adjunct therapy for in vitro fertilization (IVF), including an evidence-based evaluation of its efficacy and safety and an examination of possible mechanisms of action.

Authors' conclusions

More high-quality randomized, controlled trials incorporating placebo acupuncture controls, authentic acupuncture interventions, and a range of outcome measures representative of both clinical outcomes and putative mechanistic processes are required to better assess the efficacy of acupuncture as an adjunct for IVF.

document.title: Intake of fruit, vegetables, and antioxidants and risk of type 2 diabetes: Systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS D-E,DIABETES MELLITUS,ENDOCRINE DISORDERS,DIABETES,NUTRITION,FOOD,DETERMINANTS,OUTCOMES,FOOD & NUTRITION,PUBLIC HEALTH,FEBRUARY 2009,AUGUST 2010,MONTHLY ADDITIONS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Hamer M. and Chida Y. Intake of fruit, vegetables, and antioxidants and risk of type 2 diabetes: Systematic review and meta-analysis. Journal of Hypertension. 2007, 25 (12), 2361-2369.

Authors' objectives

The public health recommendation is to consume five or more servings of fruit and vegetables daily, but the association between the intake of fruit and vegetables and the risk of type 2 diabetes is unclear. 

Authors' conclusions

The consumption of three or more daily servings of fruit or vegetables was not associated with a substantial reduction in the risk of type 2 diabetes. The intake of antioxidants was associated with a 13% reduction in risk, mainly attributed to vitamin E. These results are not supported by randomized, controlled trials of vitamin supplements, therefore the findings might not be causal, and the discrepancy remains unclear.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.  

]]>

Authors' conclusions

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Integrating complementary medicine into cardiovascular medicine. A report of the American College of Cardiology Foundation Task Force on Clinical Expert Consensus Documents
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,ACUPUNCTURE,MEDITATION,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS C,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,JULY 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
Authors' objectives

The purpose of this Clinical Expert Consensus Document (CECD) is to put the emerging area of CAM treatment and investigation into focus in order to enable the physician to provide better patient care in a meaningful and safe manner. The document is concerned with the most recent advances and utilization of CAMs and therapies in a traditional cardiovascular practice.


Authors' conclusions

This consensus statement covers nutrition and supplements, herbal medicine, acupuncture, mind/body and energy therapies, and spirituality.

"Topics chosen for coverage by CECDs are so designated because the evidence base and experience with technology or clinical practice are not considered sufficiently well developed to be evaluated by the formal American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) Practice Guidelines process. 

The Task Force on CECDs recognizes that considerable debate exists regarding the clinical utility of alternative medicine practices. By their nature, alternative medicine practices differ widely in their scientific support. Despite this varying evidence base, these practices are widely employed by patients, including those with CVD. Many practitioners are not familiar with many alternative medicine techniques. Thus, the reader should view this CECD as the best attempt of the ACCF to inform and guide clinical practice in an area where rigorous evidence is not yet available or the evidence to date is not widely accepted. Where feasible, CECDs include indications or contraindications. The ACC/AHA Practice Guidelines Committee may subsequently address some topics covered by CECDs."


Citation

Vogel JHK, Bolling SF, Costello RB, Guarneri EM, Krucoff MW, Longhurst JC, Olshansky B, Pelletier KR, Tracy CM, Vogel RA. Integrating complementary medicine into cardiovascular medicine: a report of the American College of Cardiology Foundation Task Force on Clinical Expert Consensus Documents (Writing Committee to Develop an Expert Consensus Document on Complementary and Integrative Medicine). Journal of the American College of Cardiology. 2005, 46(1):184–221.

 

]]>

Authors' objectives
