document.body:
111-1Introduction to Osteopathy

Contents

  • Definition
  • Some terms used in osteopathy
  • Introduction
  • Clinical uses
  • Safety
  • Regulation of osteopathy
  • Professional bodies and organisations
  • Other relevant information

Definition


Osteopathy is an established system of diagnosis and treatment emphasising the structural and functional integrity of the body. It recognises that the human body functions as a unit and has an inherent ability to self-regulate and self-heal. The profession believes that much of the physical pain and disability we experience stems from abnormalities in the function of the body structure as well as damage caused to it by disease.

Osteopathic examination aims to identify abnormalities/dysfunctions within the human structure and function. In response to this, osteopathic treatment aims to facilitate the body's inherent ability to self-heal by addressing the physical, bio-chemical, mental and environmental factors that may be causing, pre-disposing or maintaining a state of disease. Knowledge and skills can be passed on to the patient to promote wellbeing and aim to prevent the recurrence of future episodes.

Osteopathic practitioners work closely with other healthcare and medical practitioners to provide complete and integrated healthcare to their patients.

Related therapies/approaches: manipulative physiotherapy and chiropractic

Some terms used in osteopathy

Articulation/stretching: A low velocity technique to try and increase the range or freedom of movement of a joint. This is accomplished by moving a joint through its complete range of motion in a gentle and repetitive manner.


Contraindications: Any therapeutic technique in healthcare is contraindicated when its potential benefit is outweighed by the risk of harming a patient. A small number of absolute contraindications exist for certain osteopathic techniques; these include, for example, the presence of fracture, acute inflammatory disease, osteoporosis, clotting disorders and neoplasms.


Cranial osteopathy: This is a refined and subtle system of diagnosis and treatment developed by William G Sutherland in the 1900’s.


Effleurage: A slow, gentle and rhythmic stroke movement performed along the long axis. This aims to increase local circulation and reduce local tissue swelling.


Facilitated oscillatory release: A technique developed by Zachary Comeaux whereby a manual oscillatory force is applied to attempt to normalise neuromuscular function. This technique can be combined with other techniques, particularly myofascial techniques.


Functional technique: This is also known as facilitated positional release. The affected area of the body is examined to identify restriction in all planes of movement; a combination of movements is applied to place and hold the affected area into a neutral position. This allows tissue release to occur; the affected area is then examined to evaluate changes in range of movement and tissue tension.


High velocity low amplitude (HVLA) technique: This is a direct technique that uses a combination of high velocity and low amplitude forces to increase the range of movement of a specified joint. This is a skilled technique which can be very effective when applied by suitably trained practitioners.


High velocity thrust (HVT): See HVLA.


Inhibition: This involves a steady and sustained pressure to a muscular area in the body. This technique attempts to reduce reflex activity thereby producing relaxation.


Lymphatic pump technique: Early osteopathic physicians used their knowledge to develop a variety of lymphatic pumping techniques employing gentle compression and relaxation forces. Early studies suggest that these techniques can increase the immune response. 


Muscle energy: This is a direct technique where a patient deliberately contracts a specified muscle against a force carefully applied by a practitioner. This isometric contraction procedure is repeated three to four times and ultimately produces a relaxation response in the affected muscular area.


Myofascial release: Restricted tissue or joint movement is identified in this technique. Movement is slowly applied to affected parts of the body until tissue release is achieved.


Osteopathic manipulative technique (OMT): See HVLA.


Soft tissue: Gentle work to the soft tissue (commonly the muscles) is carried out by osteopaths using a variety of different techniques. This can involve stretching the muscle longitudinally, stretching the muscle across its fibres (kneading) and inhibition (a sustained pressure to the muscle).


Strain/counterstrain: Lawrence H Jones developed this form of diagnosis and treatment. It was based on the premise that dysfunction is a continuing, inappropriate strain reflex; this strain reflex can be inhibited by applying a position of mild strain in the direction exactly opposite to that of the reflex.


Traction: This is the application of a pulling force applied to an area of the body.  Manual traction is used therapeutically by osteopaths; in this manner the pulling force can be carefully controlled by the practitioner in response to tissue feedback.


Visceral osteopathy: Gentle techniques can be applied to the viscera to act diagnostically and attempt to improve physiological function.

Definitions have been adapted from The Pocket Manual of Osteopathic Manipulative Treatment for Physicians. Essig-Beatty DR. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins, 2005 and the Glossary of Osteopathic Terminology (http://www.aacom.org/resources/Pages/glossary.aspx).


Introduction


Osteopathy originated in the USA as the brainchild of Dr Andrew Taylor Still who founded the first school of osteopathy in Kirksville, Missouri in 1892. He based his beliefs on the principle that the body was created as a perfect machine and the role of osteopathy was to restore it to its perfect state. Osteopathy was introduced into the United Kingdom in 1898.

Regulation of osteopathy in the United Kingdom

The passing of the Medical Act in 1858 divided medicine from “other therapies” such as osteopathy. The process of statutory regulation of osteopathy originally began in 1931 with consideration of an osteopathy bill by a Select Committee of the House of Lords. The Bill was not taken further but the Select Committee recommended the formation of a voluntary register. The General Council and Register of Osteopaths (GCRO) was incorporated in 1936 to define standards in education and quality of practice. 

Statutory development was revisited in 1993 following the passing of The Osteopath’s Act; this established the General Osteopathic Council to provide regulation of the osteopathic profession. The title of osteopath became protected by law in May 2000.

Education and training of osteopaths

In 1917, the British School of Osteopathy was incorporated as the first college under the direction of Dr John Martin Littlejohn.  There are now 8 osteopathic educational institutions (OEIs) in the UK.  A new course is being planned at Leeds Metropolitan University and will be open for registration of students in September 2008. The Diploma of Osteopathy was originally awarded to students and carried the letters DO.  In 1990 osteopathic training underwent change and a BSc degree in osteopathy has been awarded ever since.

Post-graduate education

A growing number of osteopaths are enrolling on MSc courses both at OEIs and other higher educational institutions.  An increasing number of osteopaths have completed PhDs. 

Current status of the profession

The osteopathic profession became regulated by statute following the passing of the Osteopath’s Act in 1993. The profession is largely composed of single practitioners in private practices with only a small percentage being directly employed by the National Health Service (NHS); members of the profession encounter a number of difficulties when attempting to conduct research. Ninety per cent of the profession are in private practice. There is currently no access to scholarship opportunities for members of the profession.

Development of osteopathic research

A British Institute of Osteopathic Research was originally created in 1937. The onset of World War II brought this development to a halt and it was never revisited. Research has taken place in individual colleges during the intervening years. In 2003 the National Council for Osteopathic Research (NCOR) was created. 

The National Council for Osteopathic Research (NCOR) is based at the University of Brighton and appointed Professor Ann Moore, Professor of Physiotherapy at the University of Brighton, as its Chair. This organisation has representatives from the General Osteopathic Council (the profession’s regulator), the British Osteopathic Association (the professional association) and all of the osteopathic educational institutions (OEIs). Osteopaths in private practice and those working in the NHS also have representatives. 

NCOR created a five year strategic plan. It has produced a number of resources including the NCOR website (www.ncor.org.uk). This provides information concerning NCOR meetings, courses and conferences, research hub meetings and research opportunities. A series of evidence based practice tutorials previously published in The Osteopath are now present on the site in PDF form. A Research Governance Framework (RGF) for Osteopathy has been developed which mirrors standards that have been set within the wider health care arena. A summary guide to the RGF for practising osteopaths has also been produced; both documents are available on the NCOR website.  NCOR also aims to support osteopaths in private practice who are attempting to conduct practice-based osteopathic research.  A series of small research groups have been created around the country to this end. NCOR is also currently developing a standardised data collection tool for osteopathy to gather key baseline data about the profession. A Delphi study is also being carried out to identify priorities in osteopathic research.


Clinical uses


Osteopaths employ a number of techniques in clinical practise including spinal manipulation. It should be emphasised, however, that osteopathy and manipulation are not synonymous; manipulation is just one of a range of techniques used therapeutically. Additional techniques include articulation, soft tissue work, exercise and advice/education concerning self-care strategies and avoidance measures to prevent future occurrences. 

The conditions most commonly treated by osteopathy in the UK are low back pain1 and neck pain and headache2. Osteopathic techniques have been recommended as part of the European Back Pain Guidelines for acute simple low back pain3 and chronic simple low back pain4. Studies have been carried out to investigate the management of low back pain at a variety of stages in its development including acute5 and sub-acute6 stages. Recently osteopathy has more commonly been used as part of a package of care; this has demonstrated sound results for low back pain patients7,8. 

Peripheral joints are also frequently treated by osteopaths and a number of studies have been carried out to investigate their effectiveness. The most commonly treated peripheral joints are the shoulder joint9 and the knee joint10. This is closely followed by the ankle joint11 and elbow joint12. Other conditions are treated e.g. carpal tunnel syndrome13, and symptoms associated with pregnancy14. Cranial osteopathy remains a more esoteric treatment approach and a less well researched area; this is changing as small pilot studies are being undertaken15.


Systematic reviews

Selected systematic reviews from the CAM SL can be viewed at: http://www.library.nhs.uk/cam/SearchResults.aspx?catID=10844&tabID=289


Safety


The literature on the safety of osteopathy suggests that adverse events, mainly from spinal manipulation techniques, are extremely rare. The estimates of risk of a serious adverse event cited in the literature are between 1 in 100,00016 and 1 in 5.8million17. This estimate of risk is predominantly associated with manipulation to the upper cervical spine. Mild and transient treatment responses (up to 48 hours) are more frequent18 and can be associated with the provocation tests used by osteopaths as part of the examination process to assess a patient’s symptoms.

A call for proposals was announced by the National Council for Osteopathic Research on 20.02.2007 to invite applications to investigate four topic areas to add to the literature on safety specific to osteopathy. Details of the call can be found at www.ncor.org.uk/research_opps/index.htm.


Regulation of osteopathy


The General Osteopathic Council (GOsC) is responsible for the regulation of Osteopathy in the United Kingdom.


Professional bodies and organisations

British Osteopathic Association 
General Osteopathic Council 
Osteopathic Sports Care Association (OSCA)
The National Council for Osteopathic Research 


Other relevant information


Journals

International Journal of Osteopathic Medicine

Training establishments

British College of Osteopathic Medicine (BCOM)
British School of Osteopathy (BSO)
College of Osteopaths (COET)
European School of Osteopathy (ESO)
Leeds Metropolitan University (LMU) (First intake September 2008)
London College of Osteopathic Medicine (LCOM) – for medical practitioners only.
London School of Osteopathy (LSO) 
Oxford Brookes University (OBU) 
Surrey Institute of Osteopathic Medicine (SIOM)    


References


1. Licciardone JC, Brimhall AK, King LN. Osteopathic manipulative treatment for low back pain: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. BMC Musculoskeletal Disorders. 2005, 6:43. [Full text] [DARE provisional record]


2. Bronfort G, Assendelft W J, Evans R, Haas M, Bouter L. Efficacy of spinal manipulation for chronic headache: a systematic review. Journal of Manipulative and Physiological Therapeutics. 2001, 24(7):457-466. [PubMed abstract] 


3. European back pain guidelines recommend consideration of referral for spinal manipulation for acute low back pain patients who are failing to return to normal activities  (http://www.backpaineurope.org/).


4. European back pain guidelines recommend short courses of manipulation/mobilisation for chronic low back pain patients.
(http://www.backpaineurope.org/). 


5. Gurry B, Hopkins M, Peers C, Anderson S and Watts M. A rapid access treatment facility for acute low back pain based in the primary care setting. Journal of Orthopaedic Medicine. 2004;26(1):13-19. [Abstract]


6. Williams NH, Wilkinson C, Russell I, Edwards RT, Hibbs R, Linck P, et al. Randomized osteopathic manipulation study (ROMANS): pragmatic trial for spinal pain in primary care. Family Practice. 2003, 20(6):662-9. [Full text] [NHS EED structured abstract]


7. UK BEAM Trial Team. United Kingdom back pain exercise and manipulation (UK BEAM) randomised trial: cost effectiveness of physical treatments for back pain in primary care. BMJ. 2004, 329(7479):1381-1385. [Full text] [NHS EED structured abstract]. 


8.  UK BEAM Trial Team. United Kingdom back pain exercise and manipulation (UK BEAM) randomised trial: effectiveness of physical treatments for back pain in primary care. BMJ. 2004, 329 (7479):1377. [Full text] 


9. Goldman S. Biomechanical and osteopathic approach to shoulder pain. Journal of the American Osteopathic Association. 1989, 89(1):53-57. [PubMed abstract]


10. Rubin BR. Management of osteoarthritic knee pain. Journal of the American Osteopathic Association. 2005, 105(9 Suppl 4):S23-8. [Full text]


11. Eisenhart AW, Gaeta TJ, Yens DP. Osteopathic manipulative treatment in the emergency department for patients with acute ankle injuries. Journal of the American Osteopathic Association. 2003, 103(9):417-421. [Full text]


12. Geldschlager S. Osteopathic versus orthopaedic treatments for chronic epicondylpathia humeri radialis: a randomized controlled trial. Forschende Komplementärmedizin und klassische Naturheilkunde. 2004, 11(2):93-7. [PubMed abstract]


13. Sucher BM. Palpatory diagnosis and manipulative management of carpal tunnel syndrome. Journal of the American Osteopathic Association. 1994, 94(8):647-63. [Full text]


14. Sandler SE. The management of low back pain in pregnancy.  Manual Therapy. 1996, 1(4):178-185. [PubMed abstract]


15. Hayden C, Mullinger B. A preliminary assessment of the impact of cranial osteopathy for the relief of infantile colic. Complementary Therapies in Clinical Practice. 2006, 12(2):83-90. [PubMed abstract]


16. Rothwell DM, Bondy SJ, Williams JI. Chiropractic manipulation and stroke: a population-based case-control study. Stroke. 2001, 32(5):1054–1060. [Full text]


17. Haldeman S, Carey P, Townsend M, Papadopoulous C. Arterial dissections following cervical manipulation: the chiropractic experience. Canadian Medical Association Journal. 2001, 165(7):905-6. [Full text]


18. Cagnie B, Vinck E, Beernaert A, Cambier D. How common are side effects of spinal manipulation and can these side effects be predicted? Manual Therapy. 2004, 9(3):151-156. [PubMed abstract]


 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Introduction to Yoga
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,YOGA,MAY 2010]]>
document.body:
111-1Introduction to Yoga

Contents

  • Definition
  • Some terms used in yoga
  • Introduction
  • Clinical uses
  • Safety
  • Regulation of yoga
  • Professional bodies and organisations
  • Other relevant information

Definition


The word ‘yoga’ derives from the Sanskrit root “yuj” which can be translated as 'union' between mind, body and spirit. Different forms of yoga exist: in the West, the most widely practiced form being Hatha Yoga, which includes physical postures and exercises to stretch and improve flexibility of the body, breathing exercises, relaxation and meditation.

Related therapies/approaches: meditation, vipassana, mindfulness, mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR).


Some terms used in yoga

Asanas The literal translation of this Sanskrit word is ‘a seated posture’ but the term is generally used in Western yoga classes to mean a ‘posture’ or pose.


Ashtanga Yoga This is commonly referred to as the “eight-limbed path”. Raja Yoga and Hatha Yoga are terms used alongside Ashtanga Yoga and are both practice paths within the Ashtanga system.  Raja Yoga is concerned with developing and refining the mind through concentrative and meditative practices, which may also include hatha practices to master the mind.  Hatha Yoga primarily, although not exclusively, involves physical practices such as posture and breathing. This is the Classical System of yoga, not to be confused with the more recent style of yoga practice called Ashtanga Vinyasa Yoga.


Ashtanga Vinyasa Yoga is a branch of hatha yoga currently taught by scholar and yogi, Sri K Pattabhi Jois of Mysore, India. This vinyasa practice is guided by the synchronisation of breath and movement.


Chakra The chakras are perceived to be energy centres in the body located at seven points from the base of the spine to the top of the head. They are a particular focus of Kundalini yoga. An eighth chakra exists in Kundalini Yoga, which is the electromagnetic field, sometimes called "aura." The aura is thought to be strengthened through the practice of Kundalini Yoga.


Dhyana Meditation


Hatha Yoga The form of yoga most commonly practiced in the West where it consists mainly of asanas and breathing practices. The traditional form includes moral disciplines, physical exercises and meditation.


Iyengar Yoga, created by B.K.S. Iyengar, is a form of Hatha yoga that focuses on the precise structural alignment of the physical body and incorporates great attention to detail. It also incorporates pranayama (breathing exercises) and the use of props, such as cushions, benches, blocks and straps, as aids in performing asanas (postures). Specific programmes are developed for people with particular medical conditions.


Kundalini yoga Similar to several other yogas, Kundalini yoga links postures and movement with breath but it specifically focuses on moving energy through the chakra system, stimulating the energy in the lower chakras and moving it to the higher chakras. Kundalini yoga may include cross-legged positions, positioning of the spine (usually straight), different methods to control the breath, the use of mantras, closed eyes, and mental focus (often on the sound of the breath).


Mantra Meaning ‘protection for the mind’. A sound, word or phrase (which may be sacred) that is repeated or chanted and reflected on in order to assist concentration during meditation.


Meditation Two main forms of meditation exist. Transcendental meditation (TM) involves internally repeating a mantra or sound until the mind is still. Mindfulness meditation, in contrast, places the emphasis on awareness and detached observation of the breath, sensations in the body, thoughts or feelings that pass across the field of awareness from moment to moment without judgement or criticism.


Pranayama Breathing exercises including breath retention, use of specific inhale-exhale ratios, and different breathing frequencies aimed at maximising lung capacity and respiratory function. 


Raja Yoga Similar to Hatha yoga, the main difference is that Raja Yoga uses asanas mainly in preparing the body for prolonged meditation, and so focuses more on the meditative asanas, for example the Lotus Pose.

Introduction

Yoga originated in Indian culture and in its original form consisted of a complex system of spiritual, moral and physical practices aimed at attaining ‘self-awareness’. Hatha yoga, the system on which much of Western yoga generally consists of 3 basic components, asanas (postures), pranayama (breathing exercises) and dhyana (meditation). The specific asanas incorporated depend on the type of yoga but may involve standing, bending, twisting and balancing the body thereby improving flexibility and developing strength. Controlled breathing helps to focus the mind and achieve relaxation while meditation aims to calm the mind (Riley 2004).

Yoga has been used clinically as a therapeutic intervention and is believed to benefit physical, psychological and spiritual health. The exact mechanism of action is unclear although several explanations based on Western physiology have been proposed to account for its effects. It has been suggested that yoga modulates the stress response systems including autonomic nervous tone with consequent reduction in sympathetic tone and catecholamine levels and reduction in activation of the hypothalamic pituitary axis.  Activation of antagonistic neuromuscular systems, which may increase the relaxation response in the neuromuscular system has also been suggested (Riley 2004). Meditation is thought to stimulate the limbic system and has been shown to increase blood flow to the brain, to increase the release of endogenous dopamine, and to reduce respiratory rate. A recent study demonstrated increased levels of GABA, a neurotransmitter, as a result of practicing yoga asanas (Streeter et al. 2007).

Practice of yoga is increasing in prevalence, particularly in the Western world. A national survey conducted in the US demonstrated that 7.5% of respondents had used yoga at least once in their lifetime and 3.8% had used it in the previous year. Users tended to be female, college educated and urban dwellers and use was for improving overall well-being and for specific health conditions (Saper et al. 2004). Yoga is more widely used than therapies such as acupuncture and homeopathy but there is less coverage of yoga in the Western biomedical literature. Many of the trials of yoga are small and the results are difficult to generalise. Clinical trials have been conducted on the use of yoga for depression, anxiety, cardiovascular conditions (e.g. hypertension, heart disease), respiratory problems (e.g. asthma), diabetes and a variety of others.


References

Riley D. Hatha yoga and the treatment of illness. Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine. 2004, 10(2):20-1.

Saper RB, Eisenberg DM, Davis RB, Culpepper L, Phillips RS. Prevalence and patterns of adult yoga use in the United States: results of a national survey. Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine. 2004, 10(2):44-9. [PubMed abstract]

Streeter CC, Jensen JE, Perlmutter RM, Cabral HJ, Tian H, Terhune DB, Ciraulo DA, Renshaw PF. Yoga Asana sessions increase brain GABA levels: a pilot study. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2007, 13(4):419-26. [PubMed abstract]


Further reading

Dusek JA, Otu HH, Wohlhueter AL, Bhasin M, Zerbini LF, Joseph MG, Benson H, Libermann TA. Genomic counter-stress changes induced by the relaxation response. PLoS One. 2008, 3(7):e2576. [Full text]

Kabat-Zinn J, Massion AO, Kristeller J, Peterson LG, Fletcher KE, Pbert L, Lenderking WR, Santorelli SF. Effectiveness of a meditation-based stress reduction program in the treatment of anxiety disorders. American Journal of Psychiatry. 1992, 149(7):936-43. [PubMed abstract]

Khalsa SB. Yoga as a therapeutic intervention: a bibliometric analysis of published research studies. Indian Journal of Physiology and Pharmacology. 2004, 48(3):269-85. [PubMed abstract]

Krisanaprakornkit T, Sriraj W, Piyavhatkul N, Laopaiboon M. Meditation therapy for anxiety disorders. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2006, Issue 1. Art. No.: CD004998. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004998.pub2. [Full text]


Clinical Uses

As described above, yoga is used by people suffering a range of health-related problems as well as to improve general fitness levels. Common uses include the relief of stress, anxiety and depression, chronic pain, and as part of programmes such as mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) programmes which may be offered to, for example, cancer patients.

Systematic reviews

Selected systematic reviews from the CAM specialist collection can be viewed here.


Safety

A small number of cases of adverse psychological effects have been reported (Hansen 1980, Yorston 2001) although these appear to be related specifically to meditation. Other reports of single cases have suggested that serious adverse events are possible, particularly with certain practices applied too aggressively. For example, spontaneous pneumothorax was observed in a patient following practice of Kapalabhati Pranayama, a common breathing exercise (Johnson et al. 2004). Certain postures such as headstands and the lotus position have also been associated reports of adverse effects in individuals. Safety problems appear  to be rare based on the limited number of case reports in the literature. However, there is a lack of systematic evaluation so that adverse events may be underreported and any risks are difficult to assess. Caution, including avoidance of specific postures, is required in pregnancy and in individuals with hypertension. Other conditions may require caution or the avoidance of specific practices and the primary healthcare professional and the yoga instructor should be consulted prior to undertaking yoga.


References

Hansen W. Psychoses and meditation. Ugeskrift for Laeger. 1980, 143(1):20-2.

Johnson DB, Tierney MJ, Sadighi PJ. Kapalabhati pranayama: breath of fire or cause of pneumothorax? A case report. Chest. 2004, 125(5):1951-2. [Full text]

Yorston GA. Mania precipitated by meditation: a case report and literature review. Mental Health, Religion & Culture. 2001, 4(2):209-213.


Further information on safety issues is available at: http://www.yogascotland.org.uk/documents/asana_safety.pdf


Regulation of yoga

Regulation of yoga practitioners is currently voluntary and is provided through a number of organisations. These include the newly established Complementary and Natural Healthcare Council (CNHC). The British Council for Yoga Therapy was involved in the consultation exercise on voluntary regulation following which the CNHC was established. The British Wheel of Yoga also maintains lists of practitioners as does the British Yoga Alliance. Further details of each of these can be found in the section below.


Professional bodies and organisations

  • British Council for Yoga Therapy (BCYT)
  • British Wheel of Yoga (BWY)
  • Yoga Alliance UK
  • International Association of Yoga Therapists (IAYT)  

Other relevant information

Specialist information sources on yoga include:

  • Yoga Biomedical Trust 
  • International Journal of Yoga Therapy (annual publication)
  • Yoga and Health Bibliographies

US National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine (NCCAM)

  • Yoga for Health: An Introduction (May 2008)
  • Mind-Body Medicine (online education course)

Acknowledgements

This article was drafted by Dr Karen Pilkington, member of the project team. It was then circulated to clinical and research experts in the yoga field. We would particularly like to acknowledge the contributions of the following individuals: Dr Caroline Hoffman, Associate Editor for Mind-body therapies, Clinical Director and Research Co-ordinator, Breast Cancer Haven, Melanie Flory, previously Senior Lecturer, School of Integrated Health and yoga practitioner, Professor S.B. Khalsa, Assistant Professor of Medicine, Harvard Medical School, Director of Research, Kundalini Research Institute and Research Director, Kripalu Center for Yoga and Health.

We would be pleased to receive any feedback on this article.

]]>

Intute is a free online service providing access to high quality web resources for education and research. The service is created by a network of UK universities and partners. Resources are selected and evaluated by subject specialists.

This page provides access to a small collection of resources in the field of complementary medicine.

document.body:
This is the protocol for a Cochrane systematic review. This record will be updated when the review has been completed.

Citation

Trotti LM, Bhadriraju S, Becker LA. Iron for restless legs syndrome (Protocol). Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2009, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD007834. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD007834.

Authors' objectives

To evaluate the efficacy and safety of oral or parenteral iron for the treatment of restless legs syndrome when compared with placebo or other therapies.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Is acupuncture a risk factor for hepatitis: systematic review of epidemiological studies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Ernst E, Sherman KJ. Is acupuncture a risk factor for hepatitis: systematic review of epidemiological studies. Journal of Gastroenterology and Hepatology. 2003, 18(11): 1231-1236.

Authors' objectives

Acupuncture has been repeatedly associated with infectious hepatitis. The aim of the present systematic review was therefore to critically evaluate such data from epidemiological investigations.

Authors' conclusions

A modest association between hepatitis C and acupuncture has been reported in some countries. This emphasizes the importance of exclusively using disposable acupuncture needles.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Is exercise therapy and manipulation effective in low back pain?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CHIROPRACTIC,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,BACK PAIN,CONDITIONS A-B,NOVEMBER 2006,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Brox JI, Hagen KB, Juel NG, Storheim K. Is exercise therapy and manipulation effective in low back pain? [Har treningsterapi og manipulasjon effekt ved korsryggssmerter?] Tidsskrift for Den Norske Laegeforening. 1999, 119(14):2042-50. [Norwegian]

Authors' objectives

To evaluate the effectiveness of exercises and manipulation on pain, disability and sick leave in a systematic review of randomized controlled trials including patients with low back pain.

Authors' conclusions

On the basis of 11 studies, no additional benefits from exercises and manipulation were found in patients with acute complaints (0-4 weeks); thus, our results do not support guidelines that prescribe manipulation in the acute stage. One study found reduced disability and sick leave in the subacute stage (4-12 weeks) when patients were told that it was safe to move and this strategy was reinforced by a graded exercise program and visits to the workplace. Seven studies evaluated manipulation; the effectiveness was no better than other treatments or placebo. Based on seven studies in patients with chronic low back pain (> 12 weeks), there is strong evidence that exercises reduce disability and pain, but their effectiveness on sick leave is not documented. Four studies compared different exercise regimens, but found no evidence in favour of one particular method. The effectiveness of manipulation in patients with chronic pain is poorly documented.

]]>

document.title: Is ginger a clinically relevant antiemetic? A systematic review of randomized controlled trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS P-R,GINGER (ZINGIBER OFFICINALE),CONDITIONS T-Z,HERBS D-G,VOMITING,NAUSEA,PREGNANCY,CONDITIONS M-O,OCTOBER 2006,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Betz O, Kranke P, Geldner G, Wulf H, Eberhart LH. Ist Ingwer ein klinisch relevantes Antiemetikum: eine systematische Ubersicht randomisierter kontrollierter Studien [Is ginger a clinically relevant antiemetic? A systematic review of randomized controlled trials]. Forschende Komplementärmedizin und klassische Naturheilkunde. 2005,  12(1):14-23.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this systematic review was to evaluate the clinical impact of ginger (Zingiber officinale) as an antiemetic.

Authors' conclusions

There is no clear evidence for the efficacy of ginger in the treatment of postoperative nausea and vomiting and of kinetosis. The results for the treatment of nausea and vomiting in pregnancy are encouraging, however, ginger should be applied for the time being only in controlled clinical studies. Applied in daily doses up to 6 g ginger seems to be a drug with few side effects.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Is homeopathy useful for the treatment of people with mental health concerns?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HOMEOPATHY,CONDITIONS A-Z,ANXIETY,DEMENTIA,DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS A-B,CONDITIONS D-E,ANXIETY DISORDERS,JUNE 2007,DATE ADDED,2007]]>
document.body:
111-1Is homeopathy useful for the treatment of people with mental health concerns?

Homeopathy National Knowledge Week, 11-15 June 2007

Kate Chatfield, University of Central Lancashire


There is much detailed information in the homeopathic literature to suggest that patients with a broad spectrum of mental health concerns seek homeopathic treatment but there is currently no available data to indicate the full range of conditions that are treated and how commonly they are seen. It is apparent however that many patients seek help for depression and a recent outcome study1 at the Bristol Homeopathic Hospital demonstrated that this is one of the 10 most commonly referred diagnoses. In addition a survey of homeopathic general practitioners in France demonstrated that stress and anxiety was one of the most common reasons for seeking treatment.2  Research to date has primarily focused upon the treatment of these two forms of mental health concerns, depression and anxiety disorders.


For the purpose of this summary a search was carried out to find research data published between 2001 and April 2007 on the use of homeopathy in the treatment of people with mental health concerns. Recent systematic reviews of the research evidence for homeopathy in the treatment of anxiety3 and in the treatment of depression4  were found that comprehensively examined available data both controlled and uncontrolled and these reviews are summarised below.


Whilst there has been an additional recent review of the evidence base for all CAM therapies in depression5 this review includes only one RCT in homeopathy which is also included in the systematic review by Pilkington et al.4.


One further review that falls into the category of mental health was discovered, a Cochrane review of the evidence for homeopathy in the treatment of dementia.6  No studies identified by the reviewers fulfilled criteria for inclusion and as such the conclusion was drawn that there is no evidence that homeopathy is effective in treating dementia.


Anxiety

The main focus of the review by Pilkington et al.3 was evidence from controlled studies and in total eight randomised controlled trials were identified. Other evidence included four uncontrolled studies, one pragmatic outcome study, many single case reports and a number of survey or patient outcome studies.


The total amount of available evidence proved difficult to interpret primarily because of the heterogeneity of diagnoses and patient groups, different types of homeopathy used in treatment, and weaknesses in methodology and reporting.


Several uncontrolled and observational studies demonstrated positive results which included high levels of patient satisfaction but the lack of control groups for comparison connotes that the beneficial outcomes in these studies cannot be assumed to be causally related to the homeopathy.


Results from the randomised controlled studies are inconclusive as some reported contradictory results, were underpowered or provided insufficient details about methodology.


The authors concluded that it is not possible to draw firm conclusions on the efficacy or effectiveness of homeopathy for anxiety but that further pragmatic research is called for.


Depression

The same authors had previously reviewed the research evidence for the homeopathic treatment of depression.5 The number of randomised controlled trials found for depression was only two, and one of these was a feasibility study. Other evidence included four uncontrolled studies, one observational survey-based study, one multivariate analysis, over fifty single case studies and a number of surveys and patient outcome studies.


Similarly this evidence had proved difficult to interpret in part due to the lack of high quality trials but also because of the number of different types of homeopathy that were used. Several uncontrolled and observational studies reported positive results including high levels of patient satisfaction but again cannot be assumed to be due to the homeopathy because of lack of control group.  The authors note that recruitment of patients in primary care for randomised controlled trials has proved to be a problem where such studies have been attempted.


The final conclusion offered by the authors is that evidence for the effectiveness of homeopathy in depression is limited due to lack of clinical trials of high quality and that further research is necessary with sufficient numbers of participants. 


Conclusion

Homeopathy research in mental health is scarce and primarily limited to the categories of depression and anxiety disorders.  Outcome studies repeatedly demonstrate positive results and high levels of patient satisfaction for the treatment of both anxiety disorders and depression. However the evidence base suffers from a lack of high quality research in spite of the well documented fact that mental health concerns are one of the most commonly stated reasons for seeking homeopathic treatment. 


References

1. Spence DS, Thompson EA, Barron SJ. Homeopathic treatment for chronic disease: a 6-year, university-hospital outpatient observational study. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2005, 11(5):793-8. [PubMed abstract]


2. Trichard M, Lamure E, Chaufferin G. Study of the practice of homeopathic general practitioners in France. Homeopathy. 2003, 92(3):135-9. [PubMed abstract]


3. Pilkington K, Kirkwood G, Rampes H, Fisher P, Richardson J. Homeopathy for anxiety and anxiety disorders: a systematic review of the research. Homeopathy 2006, 95(3):151-62. [PubMed abstract] 


4. Pilkington K, Kirkwood G, Rampes H, Fisher P, Richardson J. Homeopathy for depression: a systematic review of the research evidence. Homeopathy. 2005, 94:153-63. [PubMed abstract] [DARE appraisal]  


5. Thachil AF, Mohan R, Bhugra D. The evidence base of complementary and alternative therapies in depression. Journal of Affective Disorders. 2007,  97(1-3):23-35. [PubMed abstract] 


6. McCarney R, Warner J, Fisher P, van HR. Homeopathy for dementia. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews: Reviews 2003 Issue 1 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd Chichester, UK DOI : 10 1002 /14651858 CD003803 2003. [Full text] 


 

]]>

document.title: Is homeopathy useful in infectious conditions?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HOMEOPATHY,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS A-B,INFLUENZA,AIDS (ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY SYNDROME),CONDITIONS I-L,CONDITIONS S,SKIN DISEASES,2007,JUNE 2007,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-1Is homeopathy useful in infectious conditions?

Homeopathy National Knowledge Week, 11-15 June 2007

Dr Peter Fisher, Royal London Homoeopathic Hospital


Background

Historically the rapid growth of homeopathy in the 19th century seems to have been associated with its apparent success in epidemics, notably of cholera in the mid-19 century1 and later of influenza in the pandemic of 1918-19 2,3. The rising incidence of antibiotic resistant organisms, novel viruses, notably avian influenza and other emerging threats has lead to an interest in the exploration of possible alternative treatments.


Systematic reviews of homeopathy, or including homeopathy, in the following infectious conditions have been published: HIV/AIDS, cutaneous molluscum contagiosum and influenza. Other relevant studies include a meta-analysis of homeopathy for and childhood diarrhoea4. The latter is covered in the child health section of this National Knowledge Week and will not be discussed here.


Human Immunodeficency Virus infection and Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (HIV/AIDS)

Complementary and Alternative Medicine (CAM) is widely used by people living with HIV/AIDS: in the USA 68% used it in a 12 month period. A systematic review of  randomised clinical trials (RCTs) of complementary medicine for HIV/AIDS identified 30 trials.5 Eighteen of these were of various forms of stress management therapy, two were said to be of homeopathy, although one of these seems to be misclassified, it was in fact a trial of a cannabinoid. A literature review with a main focus on this topic identified five controlled clinical trials of homeopathy.6


The clinical trial common to both reviews was conducted in India, it was of double-blind, placebo-controlled design involving 100 patients (71 male, 29 female), stratified into asymptomatic (stage II) and Persistent Generalised Lymphadenopathy (PGL, stage III) groups.  Homeopathic treatment was individualised, the most commonly prescribed homeopathic medicines were Phosphorus and Pulsatilla.  There were statistically significant improvement in CD4 counts on comparing per and post-treatment values in the PGL group, no significant change in the asymptomatic group. 


Another body of research in the area focussed on the use of homeopathic dilutions of growth factors: insulin-like growth factor-1, platelet-derived growth factor BB, transforming growth factor ß-1 and granulocyte-macrophage colony stimulating factor. Two short term (8-16 weeks) double-blind RCTs involved 77 individuals, and two long term open-label (2.5 year) studies involved 27 individuals.  Benefits were claimed in terms of lean body mass, CD4 count and quality of life outcomes. This work has not been published in Medline-indexed journals.


A provocative finding arising from an uncontrolled study concerns sensitivity to Trimethoprim-sulphamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) in patients allergic to this drug (widely used in AIDS patients for prophylaxis of Pneumocystis carinii infection). Around 2/3 of hypersensitive patients treated with an homeopathic dilution of TMP-SMX had much reduced symptoms on rechallenge. This finding should be further investigated in an RCT.


Cutaneous molluscum contagiosum

A Cochrane Review of RCTs of treatment of the viral skin condition molluscum contagiosum  included five studies: one of these was of homeopathic Calcarea carbonica v placebo.7 The study included patients with warts as well as molluscum contagiosum. In the Molluscum contagiosum group 13/14 participants in the treatment group improved, compared to 1/6 in the placebo group. However there were serious weaknesses in the reporting of the study. The conclusion was that none of the interventions studied had been convincingly show to be effective.


Influenza

Influenza has been the subject of the largest number of RCTs of homeopathy of any infectious condition and a Cochrane Review of homoeopathic Oscillococcinum and similar homeopathic preparations for preventing and treating influenza and influenza-like syndromes has been published.8 Oscillococcinum is made from wild duck heart and liver, and wild fowl are vectors of influenza viruses. The review  found three prevention trials (n= 2265) and four treatment trials (n = 1194). There was no evidence that homoeopathic treatment can prevent influenza-like syndrome, but Oscillococcinum treatment reduced the length of influenza illness by 0.28 days and increased the chances that a patient considered treatment to be effective (RR 1.08; 95% CI 1.17 to 1.00). The authors concluded that  the data were promising, but not strong enough to make a general recommendation to use Oscillococcinum for influenza and influenza-like syndromes. Further research is warranted.


Severe sepsis

One single double-blind placebo-controlled RCT is worthy of discussion here, because it is of good quality and claimed  remarkable and provocative results in a condition associated with high mortality.9 This study examined long-term outcome in 70 patients admitted to Intensive Care with severe sepsis, a condition associated  with mortality of 40-70%.  Patients were well matched in terms of APACHE score, number of organ failures and other variables. Survival at day 180 was 76% in the homeopathy group v 50% in the placebo group. The most frequently prescribed homeopathic medicines were Lachesis and Phosphorus. This is only a single study, and no firm conclusions can be drawn, but clearly further research would be of interest. One constraint to such research is the limited number of suitably-trained homeopaths.


 

References


1. Leary B. Cholera 1854: update. British Homoeopathic Journal. 1994, 83:117–121.


2. Dewey WA .  Homeopathy in influenza: a chorus of fifty in harmony.  Journal of the American Institute of Homeopathy. 1921, 13:1038–1043.


3. Baker WF.  Research work in Gelsemium sempervirens and Bryonia alba in influenza.  Journal of the American Institute of Homeopathy. 1920, 12:695–698.


4. Jacobs J, Jonas WB, Jimenez-Perez M, Crothers D. Homeopathy for childhood diarrhea: combined results and metaanalysis from three randomized, controlled clinical trials. Pediatric Infectious Disease Journal. 2003, 22(3):229-34. [PubMed abstract] 


5. Mills E, Wu P, Ernst E. Complementary therapies for the treatment of HIV: in search of the evidence. International Journal of STD & AIDS. 2005, 16(6):395-403. [PubMed abstract] 


6. Ullman D. Controlled clinical trials evaluating the homeopathic treatment of people with human immunodeficiency virus or acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2003, 9(1):133-41. [PubMed abstract] 


7. van der Wouden JC, Menke J, Gajadin S, Koning S, Tasche MJA, van Suijlekom-Smit LWA, Berger MY, Butler CC. Interventions for cutaneous molluscum contagiosum. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2006, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD004767. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004767.pub2. [Full text]


8. Vickers AJ, Smith C. Homoeopathic Oscillococcinum for preventing and treating influenza and influenza-like syndromes. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews: Reviews 2006 Issue 3 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd Chichester, UK DOI : 10 1002 /14651858 CD001957 pub 2006. [Full text] 


9. Frass M, Linkesch M, Banyai S et al. Adjunctive homeopathic treatment in patients with severe sepsis: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in an intensive care unit. Homeopathy. 2005, 94(2):75-80. [PubMed abstract]

 


 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Is homeopathy useful in the treatment of allergic, ENT and respiratory conditions?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HOMEOPATHY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DATE ADDED,JUNE 2007,2007]]>
document.body:
111-1Is homeopathy useful in the treatment of allergic, ENT and respiratory conditions?

Homeopathy National Knowledge Week, 11-15 June 2007

Dr Bob Leckridge, Glasgow Homeopathic Hospital


There are a number of systematic reviews of the use of homeopathy in the treatment of allergic, ENT and respiratory conditions.1-7 Each review is of only a small number of individual trials, and within this small number there is considerable variation both in research methodology and in homeopathic treatment methodologies (classical, low potency, complex and isopathic prescribing). The field is also affected by conflicting results and lack of confirmatory studies.


Despite this background there have been trials strongly suggestive of benefit in allergic oculorhinitis treated with Galphimia Glauca showing  statistically significant effects of remedy over placebo8, and for complex homeopathic medicines (containing several different homeopathic medicines)  for sinusitis9 and rhinoconjunctivitis10 and otitis treated classically. There is also evidence that an homeopathic complex is equally effective as standard treatment for vertigo.7 Additonally, there is less strong evidence of benefit in the treatment of asthma and allergic disorders with classical homeopathy.3,6 The use of isopathic treatment (ie treatment of the same with the same, eg homeopathic dilutions of pollen for hayfever) of allergic disorders has been shown over a series of four RCTs to be statistically superior to placebo.11


The overall conclusion at this point must be that there is insufficient evidence to judge whether or not homeopathy is useful in the treatment of allergic, ENT and respiratory conditions, and that more RCTs and observational studies of the whole homeopathic "package of care" are required.


However, the evidence base so far includes clear evidence of superior effects of homeopathy over placebo in these conditions and of trends in favour of homeopathy over placebo. Finally, the real world study of the use of homeopathy “in the field” in the treatment of recurrent acute rhinopharyngitis12 shows that including homeopathy produces superior medical effectiveness, less complications of the disease, a reduced number of consultations, improved quality of life and reduction in amount of parental leave from work.


References


1. Bellavite P, Ortolani R, Pontarollo F, Piasere V, Benato G, Conforti A. Immunology and homeopathy. 4. Clinical studies-part 2. Evidence-based Complementary and Alternative Medicine: eCAM. 2006, 3(4):397-409. [Full text] 


2. Bellavite P, Ortolani R, Pontarollo F, Piasere V, Benato G, Conforti A. Immunology and homeopathy. 4. Clinical studies-part 1. Evidence-based Complementary and Alternative Medicine: eCAM. 2006, 3(3):293-301.  [Full text]


3. Bornhoft G, Wolf U, Ammon K, Righetti M, Maxion-Bergemann S, Baumgartner S, et al. Effectiveness, safety and cost-effectiveness of homeopathy in general practice - summarized health technology assessment. Forschende Komplementärmedizin. 2006, 13 Suppl 2:19-29. [PubMed abstract] 


4. Karkos PD, Leong SC, Arya AK, Papouliakos SM, Apostolidou MT, Issing WJ. 'Complementary ENT': a systematic review of commonly used supplements. Journal of Laryngology and Otology. 2006 Nov 24;1-4. [PubMed abstract] 


5. McCarney RW, Linde K, Lasserson TJ. Homeopathy for chronic asthma. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews: Reviews 2004 Issue 1 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd Chichester, UK DOI : 10 1002 /14651858 CD000353 pub2 2004. [Full text]


6. Passalacqua G, Bousquet PJ, Carlsen KH, Kemp J, Lockey RF, Niggemann B, et al. ARIA update: I--Systematic review of complementary and alternative medicine for rhinitis and asthma. Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology. 2006, 117(5):1054-62. [PubMed abstract]


7. Schneider B, Klein P, Weiser M. Treatment of vertigo with a homeopathic complex remedy compared with usual treatments: a meta-analysis of clinical trials. Arzneimittel-Forschung. 2005, 55(1):23-9. [PubMed abstract] [ENT & Audiology Specialist Library] 


8. Wiesenauer M, Gaus W. Double-blind trial comparing the effectiveness of the homeopathic preparation Galphimia potentiation D6, Galphimia dilution 10(-6) and placebo on pollinosis. Arzneimittel-Forschung. 1985;35(11):1745-7. [PubMed abstract]


9. Weiser M, Clasen BP. Controlled double-blind study of a homoeopathic sinusitis medication. Biol Ther. 1994, 13:4–11.


10. Sprenger F. The therapy of rhinitis. Biol Ther. 1989, 7:60–3.


11. Taylor MA, Reilly D, Llewellyn-Jones RH, McSharry C, Aitchison TC. Randomised controlled trial of homoeopathy versus placebo in perennial allergic rhinitis with overview of four trial series. BMJ. 2000 Aug 19-26;321(7259):471-6. Erratum in: BMJ 2000 Sep 23;321(7263):733. [Full text]


12. Trichard M, Chaufferin G, Nicoloyannis N. Pharmacoeconomic comparison between homeopathic and antibiotic treatment strategies in recurrent acute rhinopharyngitis in children. Homeopathy. 2005, 94(1):3-9. [PubMed abstract] [NHS EED structured abstract]


 

]]>

document.title: Is low folate a risk factor for depression? A meta-analysis and exploration of heterogeneity
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS D-E,OCTOBER 2008,DATE ADDED,FOLIC ACID,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,VITAMINS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Gilbody S, Lightfoot T, Sheldon T. Is low folate a risk factor for depression? A meta-analysis and exploration of heterogeneity. Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health. 2007, 61(7):631-7.

Authors' objectives

To conduct a systematic review of observational studies which examine the association between depression and folate.

Authors' conclusions

There is accumulating evidence that low folate status is associated with depression. Much of this evidence comes from case-control and cross-sectional studies. Cohort studies and definitive randomised-controlled trials to test the therapeutic benefit of folate are required to confirm or refute a causal relationship.

Access

Full text of this article is free for registered users.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Is Tai Chi an effective adjunct in cancer care? A systematic review of controlled clinical trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,TAI CHI,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,MARCH 2009]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Lee MS, Pittler MH, Ernst E. Is Tai Chi an effective adjunct in cancer care? A systematic review of controlled clinical trials. Support Care Cancer. 2007 Jun;15(6):597-601.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this systematic review is to summarize and critically evaluate the evidence available from controlled clinical trials of tai chi as a supportive therapy for cancer patients. 

Authors' conclusions

The evidence is not convincing enough to suggest that tai chi is an effective supportive treatment for cancer. Further research should attempt to answer the many open questions related to the usefulness of tai chi for supportive cancer care.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

Citation

Lee MS, Lee EN, Ernst E. Is tai chi beneficial for improving aerobic capacity? A systematic review. British Journal of Sports Medicine. 2009, 43(8):569-73.

Authors' objectives

To evaluate evidence from randomised clinical trials (RCTs) testing the effectiveness of tai chi for increasing aerobic capacity. 

Authors' conclusions

The existing evidence does not suggest that regular tai chi is an effective way of increasing aerobic capacity.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: 'Is this the end for homeopathy?'
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HOMEOPATHY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE]]>
document.body:
Hitting the Headlines summaries produced by the Centre for Reviews and Dissemination offer an analysis
of the evidence behind selected health stories reported in national newspapers.

Homeopathy is no more effective than placebo, reported four newspapers on 26 August 2005. The newspapers reported a well-conducted study that compared 110 trials of homeopathy with 110 trials of conventional medicine. The authors concluded that whilst the effects of conventional medicine are greater than placebo, the effects of homeopathy are not.

 

]]>

document.title: Kanglaite injection plus chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for non-small cell lung cancer patients: a systematic review and meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS I-L,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),CONDITIONS C,CANCER,LUNG CANCER,DECEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Liu X, Xu F, Wang G, Diao X, Li Y. Kanglaite injection plus chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for non-small cell lung cancer patients: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Current Therapeutic Research - Clinical and Experimental. 2008; 69(5): 381-411.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness and tolerability of Kanglaite (KLT) injection in patients with primary non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).

Authors' conclusions

This meta-analysis found that KLT injection in combination with chemotherapy was associated with improved response rate, quality of life, and symptoms, and a reduced incidence of adverse effects compared with chemotherapy alone in patients with NSCLC. These findings should be viewed with caution because of the low quality of the included trials.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Kava and St. John's Wort: current evidence for use in mood and anxiety disorders
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,ST JOHN'S WORT (HYPERICUM PERFORATUM),HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DEPRESSION,ANXIETY,KAVA (PIPER METHYSTICUM),CONDITIONS D-E,CONDITIONS M-O,CONDITIONS A-B,ANXIETY DISORDERS,HERBS H-P,HERBS R-Z,MARCH 2010,MENTAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Sarris J, Kavanagh DJ. Kava and St. John's Wort: current evidence for use in mood and anxiety disorders. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2009, 15(8):827-36.

Authors' objectives

The objective of this study was to conduct a comprehensive review of kava and SJW, to review any evidence of efficacy, mode of action, pharmacokinetics, safety and use in major depressive disorder, bipolar disorder, seasonal affective disorder (SAD), generalized anxiety disorder, social phobia (SP), panic disorder (PD), obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). 

Authors' conclusions

Current evidence for herbal medicines in the treatment of depression and anxiety only supports the use of Hypericum perforatum for depression, and Piper methysticum for generalized anxiety.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Laetrile for cancer: a systematic review of the clinical evidence
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,MARCH 2009,CARBOHYDRATES & CARBOHYDRATE DERIVATIVES,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,LAETRILE]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Milazzo S, Lejeune S, Ernst E. Laetrile for cancer: a systematic review of the clinical evidence. Support Care Cancer. 2007 Jun;15(6):583-95.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this review is to summarize all types of clinical data related to the effectiveness or safety of laetrile interventions as a treatment of any type of cancer. 

Authors' conclusions

Thirty six reports met the inclusion criteria. No controlled clinical trials were found. Three articles were nonconsecutive case series, 2 were consecutive case series, 6 were best case series, and 25 were case reports. None of these publications proved the effectiveness of laetrile.  Therefore, the claim that laetrile has beneficial effects for cancer patients is not supported by sound clinical data.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Language of publication restrictions in systematic reviews gave different results depending on whether the intervention was conventional or complementary
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,RESEARCH,SEPTEMBER 2007,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
Citation

Pham B, Klassen TP, Lawson ML, Moher D. Language of publication restrictions in systematic reviews gave different results depending on whether the intervention was conventional or complementary. Journal of Clinical Epidemiology. 2005, 58(8):769-76.

Authors' objectives

To assess whether language of publication restrictions impact the estimates of an intervention's effectiveness, whether such impact is similar for conventional medicine and complementary medicine interventions, and whether the results are influenced by publication bias and statistical heterogeneity.

Authors' conclusions

Language restrictions do not change the results of CM systematic reviews but do substantially alter the results of CAM systematic reviews. These findings are robust even after sensitivity analyses, and do not appear to be influenced by statistical heterogeneity and publication bias.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Larger effect sizes were associated with higher quality ratings in complementary and alternative medicine randomized controlled trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL,SEPTEMBER 2007,RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
Citation

Bausell RB, Lee WL, Soeken KL, Li YF, Berman BM. Larger effect sizes were associated with higher quality ratings in complementary and alternative medicine randomized controlled trials. Journal of Clinical Epidemiology. 2004, 57(5):438-46.

Authors' objectives

To determine if the quality of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) placebo controlled randomized controlled trials (RCTs) is related to the effect sizes they produce when the type of interventions and outcome variables are controlled. 

Authors' conclusions

Possible theoretical reasons for this unexpected positive relationship include (a) sampling error, (b) reduced within group variation, (c) fraudulent reporting, and (d) the restriction of the analyses to placebo controlled trial.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

 

]]>

document.title: Lead encephalopathy due to traditional medicines
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),AYURVEDIC MEDICINE,SAFETY,CAM GENERAL,DECEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Karri SK, Saper RB, Kales SN. Lead encephalopathy due to traditional medicines. Current Drug Safety. 2008 Jan;3(1):54-9.

Authors' objectives

To present a review on the potential of traditional medicines to cause lead encephalopathy. 

Authors' conclusions

Traditional medicine users should be screened for lead exposure and strongly encouraged to discontinue metal-containing remedies. Therefore, the United States Food and Drug Administration and corresponding agencies in other countries should require and enforce heavy metal testing for all imported traditional medicines and "dietary supplements".

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Literature review of back massage and similar techniques to promote sleep in elderly people
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,MASSAGE,SLEEP DISORDERS,CONDITIONS S,DECEMBER 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Schiff A. Ruckenmassage und verwandte Techniken zur Forderung des Schlafes bei alteren Menschen: eine Literaturanalyse. [Literature review of back massage and similar techniques to promote sleep in elderly people]. Pflege. 2006, 19(3):163-173. [German]

Authors' objectives

To review the use of back massage and similar techniques to promote sleep in elderly people.

Authors' conclusions

The results indicate that these interventions promote relaxation and sleep and that they are perceived as very pleasant by the elderly. However, they do not explain in detail the reasons for effects these and the role of touch. This review shows that further research (RCTs) is necessary to determine the effects of back massage and "Atemstimulierende Einreibung" on relaxation and sleep.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Location bias in controlled clinical trials of complementary/alternative therapies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,RESEARCH,SEPTEMBER 2007,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:
Citation

Pittler MH, Abbot NC, Harkness EF, Ernst E. Location bias in controlled clinical trials of complementary/alternative therapies. Journal of Clinical Epidemiology. 2000, 53(5):485-9. 

Authors' objectives

To systematically investigate location bias of controlled clinical trials in complementary/alternative medicine (CAM).

Authors' conclusions

More positive than negative trials of complementary therapies are published, except in high-impact factor mainstream medical (MM) journals. In non-impact factor CAM-journals positive studies were of poorer methodological quality than the corresponding negative studies. This was not the case in MM-journals which published on a wider range of therapies, except in those with high impact factors. Thus location of trials in terms of journal type and impact factor should be taken into account when the literature on complementary therapies is being examined.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

 

]]>

document.title: Long chain omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids in the treatment of psychiatric illnesses in children and adolescents
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,AUTISTIC DISORDER,ATTENTION DEFICIT / HYPERACTIVITY DISORDER,CONDITIONS S,DEPRESSION,SCHIZOPHRENIA,CONDITIONS D-E,CONDITIONS A-B,DATE ADDED,OMEGA-3 FATTY ACIDS,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,LIPIDS,OCTOBER 2008]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Clayton EH, Hanstock TL, Garg ML, Hazell PL. Long chain omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids in the treatment of psychiatric illnesses in children and adolescents. Acta Neuropsychiatrica. 2007,19(2):92-103.

Authors' objectives

Long chain omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (LCn-3PUFA) are in increasing use in the general population to treat health problems. The objective of the current article is to review the evidence for the rationale and benefit of LCn-3PUFA in the treatment of common psychiatric disorders in children and adolescents.

Authors' conclusions

While children and adolescents are receiving LCn-3PUFA for a range of psychiatric indications, there is only evidence of likely benefit for unipolar depression.

Authors' objectives

document.title: Mapping England-wide primary care access to CAM
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MAY 2009,USE OF CAM,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:
iCAM is a research centre based in the School of Integrated Health focusing on policy and governance in integrated, complementary and alternative medicine.


This website provides links to reports of preliminary PCT surveys to identify CAM services (2001/2, 2002/3 and 2003/4). The surveys entailed four phases of data collection: initial telephone contact with the PCTs, e-mail survey sent to all PCTs, follow up telephone and e-mail contact with PCTs, initial telephone survey of identified representatives of services.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Massage for low back pain: 2008 Annual evidence update
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,MASSAGE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,COMPLEMENTARY/ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,SPINAL PROBLEMS,CONDITIONS A-B,BACK PAIN,DATE ADDED,SEPTEMBER 2008]]>
document.body:
111-1Massage for low back pain: 2008 Annual evidence update

Evidence summary by Peter Fisher, Royal London Homoeopathic Hospital


Imamura et al.1 conducted a comprehensive ‘evidence-informed’ review of management of chronic low back pain with massage. They briefly discuss types of massage, history, theory etc. before reviewing the evidence from randomised controlled trials (RCTs).


The review identified a total of 9 RCTs, 5 of ‘higher quality’ (assessed by the Cochrane Collaboration Back Review Group methodological quality criteria), total n=865 and four of ‘lower quality’, n=331. Comparisons were: massage versus inert or sham therapy, massage v conventional physiotherapy, v exercise, v relaxation therapy, v acupuncture, v self-care education, v usual care, and massage plus other intervention, different massage techniques, therapist experience. The outcomes in most trials were pain and/or disability, but two trials (one high and one low quality) measured work-related outcomes. The paper also reviewed harm.


No serious adverse events were reported. Some massage techniques may cause produce post-massage soreness or bruising. The authors conclude that there is strong evidence that massage is effective for non-specific chronic low back pain (cLBP) and moderate evidence that it provides short- and longer-term relief of symptoms. It is beneficial in terms of symptoms and function, the results are better when it is delivered by a qualified therapist and combined with exercise and education.1


Hettinga et al.2 assessed the scale and quality of RCTs of mobilisation, manipulation and massage on cLBP, using the Van Tulder scale to assess quality. They found ten RCTs, of which only two were of ‘higher quality’. Smaller and lower quality studies showed greater differences between treatment and control groups. The authors conclude that high quality evidence shows that a package of mobilisation and manipulation is effective in terms of pain and function, but manipulation alone is not. In contrast to Imamura et al they found no higher quality evidence on massage. They further conclude that many RCTs in the area have shortcomings in terms of scale and quality.2


A small scale RCT published subsequent to these reviews compared massage and relaxation, concluding that patients receiving massage showed greater improvements in function, psychological variables and sleep than those who had relaxation therapy.3


References:


1. Imamura M, Furlan AD, Dryden T, Irvin E. Evidence-informed management of chronic low back pain with massage. Spine Journal. 2008, 8(1):121-33. [Full text on journal website]


2. Hettinga DM, Hurley DA, Jackson A, May S, Mercer C, Roberts L. Assessing the effect of sample size, methodological quality and statistical rigour on outcomes of randomised controlled trials on mobilisation, manipulation and massage for low back pain of at least 6 weeks duration. Physiotherapy. 2008, 94(2):97-104. [Abstract on journal website]


3. Field T, Hernandez RM, Diego M, Fraser M. Lower back pain and sleep disturbance are reduced following massage therapy. Journal of Bodywork & Movement Therapies. 2007; 11:141-5. [Full text on journal website]

 

Link back to 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM for low back pain 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Massage for symptom relief in patients with cancer: systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,MASSAGE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,MARCH 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Wilkinson S, Barnes K, Storey L. Massage for symptom relief in patients with cancer: systematic review. J Adv Nurs. 2008 Sep;63(5):430-9.

Authors' objectives

To assess evidence of the effectiveness of massage for patients with cancer, in terms of reducing physical or psychological symptoms, improving quality of life, or producing unwanted side effects.

Authors' conclusions

Ten trials met the inclusion criteria and their results suggest that massage might reduce anxiety in patients with cancer in the short term and may have a beneficial effect on physical symptoms of cancer, such as pain and nausea. However, the lack of rigorous research evidence precludes drawing definitive conclusions.

Further well-designed large trials with longer follow-up periods are needed to be able to draw firm conclusions about the efficacy and effectiveness of massage for cancer patients.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

Authors' objectives

To conduct a systematic review and meta-analysis of cohort studies of meat consumption and type 2 diabetes risk. 

Authors' conclusions

The results suggest that meat consumption increases the risk of type 2 diabetes. However, the possibility that residual confounding could explain this association cannot be excluded.

document.title: Meditation as an intervention for chronic pain: an integrative review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MEDITATION,CONDITIONS A-Z,PAIN,CONDITIONS P-R,JANUARY 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Teixeira ME. Meditation as an intervention for chronic pain: an integrative review. Holistic Nursing Practice. 2008, 22(4):225-235.

Authors' objectives

The purpose of this integrative review is to examine studies that have investigated meditation as an intervention for chronic pain, identify gaps in the literature, and make recommendations for further research.

Authors' conclusions

The findings from this integrative review suggest that meditation programs may help ease the burden of chronic pain with both short- and long-term effects but more work needs to be done to explore the effectiveness of these programs in diverse chronic pain populations. 

Access
