document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Menopause: a review of botanical dietary supplements
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS M-O,BLACK COHOSH (CIMICIFUGA RACEMOSA),MENOPAUSAL SYMPTOMS,GINSENG (PANAX GINSENG),RED CLOVER (TRIFOLIUM PRATENSE),DONG QUAI (ANGELICA SINENSIS),EVENING PRIMROSE (OENOTHERA BIENNIS),TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),HERBS D-G,HERBS A-C,SOY (GLYCINE MAX),HERBS R-Z,JULY 2007,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Low Dog T. Menopause: a review of botanical dietary supplements. American Journal of Medicine. 2005, 118 Suppl 12B:98-108.

Authors' objectives

Since the release of the Women's Health Initiative (WHI) findings, an increasing number of dietary supplement products specifically targeting women in menopause have appeared in the American marketplace. This growth highlights the need for a critical evaluation of the tolerability and effectiveness of these products. The purpose of this article is to assess the evidence for safety and benefit of botanical monopreparations used for relief of menopause-related symptoms.

Authors' conclusions

We conclude that black cohosh extracts appear to ease menopausal symptoms; ongoing studies funded by the National Institutes of Health (NIH) will provide more definitive safety and efficacy data. Soy isoflavone extracts appear to have minimal to no effect, although definitive conclusions are difficult given the wide variation in product composition and dose. Long-term safety of higher dosage (150 mg/day) soy isoflavone extracts is uncertain. Semipurified isoflavone red clover leaf extracts have minimal to no effect in reducing menopausal symptoms. Dong quai, ginseng extract, and evening primrose seed oil appear to be ineffective in ameliorating menopausal symptoms at the dosages and in the preparations used in these studies.

 

 

]]>

document.body:

Citation

Shea B, Wells G, Cranney A, Zytaruk N, Robinson V, Griffith L, Ortiz Z, Peterson J, Adachi J, Tugwell P, Guyatt G; Osteoporosis Methodology Group and The Osteoporosis Research Advisory Group. Meta-analyses of therapies for postmenopausal osteoporosis. VII. Meta-analysis of calcium supplementation for the prevention of postmenopausal osteoporosis. Endocrine Reviews. 2002, 23(4):552-9.

Authors' objectives

To summarize controlled trials examining the effect of calcium on bone density and fractures in postmenopausal women. 

Authors' conclusions

Calcium supplementation alone has a small positive effect on bone density. The data show a trend toward reduction in vertebral fractures, but do not meaningfully address the possible effect of calcium on reducing the incidence of nonvertebral fractures.

]]>

document.title: Meta-analysis of acustimulation effects on nausea and vomiting in pregnant women
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPRESSURE,ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,CONDITIONS M-O,PREGNANCY,NAUSEA,VOMITING,CONDITIONS P-R,CONDITIONS T-Z,DATE ADDED,JUNE 2007]]>
document.body:

Citation

Helmreich RJ, Shiao SY, Dune LS. Meta-analysis of acustimulation effects on nausea and vomiting in pregnant women. Explore (NY). 2006, 2(5):412-21.

Authors' objectives

The authors used meta-analysis to examine the effects of acustimulation  on the prevention of nausea and vomiting in pregnant women (NVP).

Authors' conclusions

This meta-analysis demonstrates that acupressure and electrical stimulation had greater impact than the acupuncture methods in the treatment of NVP. However, the number of acupuncture trials was limited for pregnant women, perhaps because it is impossible to self-administer the acupuncture and thus inconvenient for women experiencing NVP as chronic symptoms.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Meta-analysis of effectiveness and tolerability of treatment of mild to moderate depression with St. John's Wort
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,ST JOHN'S WORT (HYPERICUM PERFORATUM),HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,OCTOBER 2006,HERBS R-Z,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Roder C, Schaefer M, Leucht S. Meta-analyse zu Wirksamkeit und Vertraglichkeit der Behandlung der leichten und mittelschweren Depression mit Johanniskraut [Meta-analysis of effectiveness and tolerability of treatment of mild to moderate depression with St. John's Wort] Fortschritte der Neurologie-Psychiatrie. 2004, 72(6):330-43.

Authors' objectives

To conduct a meta-analysis to review St. John's Wort's place in the treatment of depression.

Authors' conclusions

The result of the meta-analysis viewed together with St. John's Wort's favourable side-effects profile, leading to a lower rate of drop-outs, suggests treatment with St. John's Wort should be attempted for milder forms of depression. Funnel plot analysis suggested publication bias could exist for the comparison with placebo. To put this in a perspective the fail-safe-N-test calculated that 423 studies with no effect would be needed to negate the presented result for placebo studies.

 

]]>

document.title: Meta-analysis of the effects of n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids on lipoproteins and other emerging lipid cardiovascular risk markers in patients with type 2 diabetes
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,DIABETES MELLITUS,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,CONDITIONS D-E,CONDITIONS C,FEBRUARY 2009,OMEGA-3 FATTY ACIDS,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,LIPIDS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Hartweg J, Farmer AJ, Perera R, Holman RR, and Neil HA. Meta-analysis of the effects of n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids on lipoproteins and other emerging lipid cardiovascular risk markers in patients with type 2 diabetes. Diabetologia. 2007, 50(8), 1593-602.

Authors' objectives

To determine the effects of marine-derived n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) on established and emerging lipid and lipoprotein cardiovascular risk markers in patients with type 2 diabetes. 

Authors' conclusions

In addition to recognised triacylglycerol-lowering effects, n-3 PUFA supplementation decreases VLDL-cholesterol and VLDL-triacylglycerol, but may have an adverse effect on LDL-cholesterol. Larger and longer term clinical trials are required to conclusively establish the effect of n-3 PUFA on cardiovascular risk markers and outcomes in type 2 diabetic patients.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Meta-analysis of the efficacy of the acetonic kava-kava extract WS1490 in patients with non-psychotic anxiety disorders
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBS H-P,ANXIETY DISORDERS,CONDITIONS A-B,KAVA (PIPER METHYSTICUM),DATE ADDED,JULY 2007]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Witte S, Loew D, Gaus W. Meta-analysis of the efficacy of the acetonic kava-kava extract WS1490 in patients with non-psychotic anxiety disorders. Phytotherapy Research. 2005, 19(3):183-8. 

Authors' objectives

The herbal medicinal product kava-kava, used for treating anxiety disorders, was assessed positively by the Cochrane review. However, it was withdrawn from the market in Switzerland and Germany due to cases of liver failure and 'unproven' efficacy. The aim of this study is to investigate the efficacy of kava for anxiety disorders.

Authors' conclusions

It is concluded that kava-kava extract WS1490, and possibly other kava extracts, are effective. Therefore they remain alternatives to benzodiazepines, selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and other antidepressants in the treatment of non-psychotic anxiety disorders.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Meta-analysis of the related nutritional supplements Dimethyl Sulfoxide and Methylsulfonylmethane in the treatment of osteoarthritis of the knee
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,OSTEOARTHRITIS,PAIN,CONDITIONS M-O,CONDITIONS A-B,CONDITIONS P-R,ARTHRITIS,SEPTEMBER 2010,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Brien S, Prescott P, Lewith G. Meta-analysis of the related nutritional supplements dimethyl sulfoxide and methylsulfonylmethane in the treatment of osteoarthritis of the knee. Evidence-Based Complementary and Alternative Medicine. 2009 May 27. [Epub ahead of print]

Authors' objectives

Dimethyl sulphoxide and methylsulfonylmethane are two related nutritional supplements used for symptomatic relief of osteoarthritis (OA). The authors conduct a meta-analysis to evaluate their efficacy in reducing pain associated with OA.

Authors' conclusions

Current evidence suggests DMSO and MSM are not clinically effective in the reduction of pain in the treatment of OA. No definitive conclusions can currently be drawn from the data due to the mixed findings and the use of inadequate dosing periods.

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,DIARRHOEA,CONDITIONS D-E,DATE ADDED,DECEMBER 2008]]>

Citation

Authors' objectives

To review evidence for the effectiveness of Lactobacillus GG (LGG) in treating acute infectious diarrhoea in children.

Authors' conclusions

The use of LGG is associated with moderate clinical benefits in the treatment of acute diarrhoea in children. These findings should be interpreted with caution due to the important methodological limitations and heterogeneity of most of the studies.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Methodological quality and outcomes of studies addressing manual cervical spine examinations: a review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CHIROPRACTIC,DATE ADDED,FEBRUARY 2008]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Hollerwöger D. Methodological quality and outcomes of studies addressing manual cervical spine examinations: a review. Manual Therapy. 2006, 11(2):93-8.

Authors' objectives

The aims of this review were, first to rate the methodological quality of studies which investigate the reliability of manual tests for cervical spine dysfunctions by applying a new quality assessment tool; secondly to compare the outcomes of these studies. 

Authors' conclusions

The studies' outcomes make the claim to be able to detect segmental cervical dysfunction based on a manual assessment only questionable. Further improvements in quality, uniform study designs, and a valid reference standard would be necessary in order to obtain more reliable data in the future.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

 

]]>

document.title: Mind and body therapy for fibromyalgia (Cochrane protocol)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,MEDITATION,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,YOGA,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS F-H,TAI CHI,RELAXATION TECHNIQUES,AUTOGENIC TRAINING,FIBROMYALGIA,CAM GENERAL,RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
This is the protocol for a Cochrane systematic review. This record will be updated when the review has been completed.

Citation

Hadhazy VA, Bausell B, Berman B, Creamer P, Ezzo J. Mind and body therapy for fibromyalgia. (Protocol) The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 1999, Issue 4. Art. No.: CD001980. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD001980.

Authors' objectives

The objectives are to systematically review all randomized and quasi-randomized (not strictly randomized methods of allocation (e.g., by date of birth, hospital record number or alternation) controlled trials of mind/body therapy for adults with FM syndrome. Multi component as well as single component mind/body protocols will be assessed. To review the effectiveness of mind/body treatments compared to: standard care/medication, non-intervention, attention/control, exercise alone.

]]>

document.title: Mind-body interventions during pregnancy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,YOGA,MEDITATION,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,RELAXATION TECHNIQUES,PREGNANCY,CONDITIONS P-R,AUGUST 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Beddoe AE, Lee KA. Mind-body interventions during pregnancy. Journal of Obstetric, Gynecologic, and Neonatal Nursing. 2008, 37(2):165-75.

Authors' objectives

To examine published evidence on the effectiveness of mind-body interventions during pregnancy on perceived stress, mood, and perinatal outcomes. 

Authors' conclusions

There is evidence that pregnant women have health benefits from mind-body therapies used in conjunction with conventional prenatal care. Further research is necessary to build on these studies in order to predict characteristics of subgroups that might benefit from mind-body practices and examine cost effectiveness of these interventions on perinatal outcomes.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.  

]]>

document.title: Mind–body interventions: applications in neurology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,MEDITATION,HYPNOSIS,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,BIOFEEDBACK,QI GONG,BREATHING TECHNIQUES,MINDFULNESS-BASED STRESS REDUCTION (MBSR),AUTOGENIC TRAINING,MUSCULOSKELETAL DISEASES,TAI CHI,RELAXATION TECHNIQUES,CONDITIONS M-O,FEBRUARY 2010,NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES]]>
document.body:
Citation

Wahbeh H, Elsas SM, Oken BS. Mind–body interventions: applications in neurology. Neurology. 2008, 70(24):2321-28.

Authors' objectives

The objective of this article is to give a clinical overview of mind-body interventions and their applications in neurology.

Authors' conclusions

There are several conditions where the evidence for mind-body therapies is quite strong such as migraine headache. Mind-body therapies for other neurology applications have limited evidence due mostly to small clinical trials and inadequate control groups.

Access

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Mindfulness meditation for low back pain: Annual evidence update 2008
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,BACK PAIN,CONDITIONS A-B,MINDFULNESS-BASED STRESS REDUCTION (MBSR),SEPTEMBER 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-1Mindfulness meditation for low back pain: Annual evidence update 2008

Commentary by Dr George Lewith, University of Southampton

Morone NE, Greco CM, Weiner DK. Mindfulness meditation for the treatment of chronic low back pain in older adults: a randomized controlled pilot study. Pain. 2008, 134(3):310-9.


This study is a small pilot study of 37 older adults with chronic persistent daily low back pain who received a mindfulness-based meditation programme (MBSR) designed around the central principles espoused by Kabat Zinn for the management of chronic and persistent pain. The study design involved cross-over where half the group was randomised to an 8 week mindfulness course and half to an initial waiting list control, immediately afterwards the waiting list control were offered mindfulness meditation. The two groups were compared using a range of outcome measures, including the Roland Morris Disability Scale, the SF36 (physical and mental function) and the Chronic Pain Acceptance Questionnaire.  


This preliminary pilot is clearly underpowered but does demonstrate that 80% of patients (30 out of 37) who were offered the mindfulness intervention were able to complete the full 8 weeks’ assessment. The programme itself seemed both acceptable and feasible and the primary comparison was between those initially randomised to the 8 week MBSR programme and waiting list control. Of the initial 19 randomised for the MBSR programme, 6 declined: 2 were too busy, 1 had a scheduling conflict and 3 encountered unexpected health or family obligations. Interestingly, in the waiting list control, 17 out of 18 were happy to be randomised to the 8 week mindfulness intervention. There was no substantial baseline difference between the two groups. The main effect relates to pain acceptance; this was a powerful effect that appears likely to be valid in spite of the small trial size. No obvious effects occurred with respect to the Roland Morris Disability Questionnaire but the SF36 physical functioning did show a small but significant change between the mindfulness group and the waiting list control.


Unfortunately in this study there was no control for attention and the major outcome related to the acceptance of chronic pain. It is quite possible that because pain was accepted, physical functioning improved, but fundamental disability did not.


Clearly this intervention needs further study, both in terms of long-term follow-up and with respect to the probable underlying psychological mechanisms involved in managing pain with various mindfulness techniques.

 

Link back to 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM for low back pain

 

]]>

document.title: Mindfulness meditation for oncology patients: a discussion and critical review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MEDITATION,CONDITIONS A-Z,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,DATE ADDED,DECEMBER 2008,2008]]>
document.body:
Citation

Ott M J, Norris R L, Bauer-Wu S M. Mindfulness meditation for oncology patients: a discussion and critical review. Integrative Cancer Therapies. 2006; 5(2): 98-108.

Authors' objectives

The purpose of this article is to provide a comprehensive over view and discussion of mindfulness meditation and its clinical applicability in oncology and to report and critically evaluate the existing and emerging research on mindfulness meditation as an intervention for cancer patients. 

Authors' conclusions

Mindfulness meditation has clinically relevant implications to alleviate psychological and physical suffering of persons living with cancer. Use of this behavioral intervention for oncology patients is an area of burgeoning interest to clinicians and researchers.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Mindfulness training as a clinical intervention: a conceptual and empirical review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-B,CONDITIONS C,CONDITIONS D-E,CONDITIONS F-H,DEPRESSION,PAIN,CANCER,ANXIETY,EATING DISORDERS,MINDFULNESS-BASED STRESS REDUCTION (MBSR),ANXIETY DISORDERS,PSORIASIS,CONDITIONS P-R,FIBROMYALGIA]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Baer RA. Mindfulness training as a clinical intervention: a conceptual and empirical review. Clinical Psychology Science and Practice. 2003, 10(2): 125-143.

Full-text online access is available to NHS staff via ATHENS passwords.

Authors' objectives

To summarize conceptual approaches to mindfulness and empirical research on the utility of mindfulness-based interventions.

Authors' conclusions

Although the current empirical literature includes many methodological flaws, findings suggest that mindfulness-based interventions may be helpful in the treatment of several disorders. Methodologically sound investigations are recommended in order to clarify the utility of these interventions.

 

]]>

document.title: Mindfulness-based 'third wave' cognitive and behavioural therapies versus other psychological therapies for depression (Cochrane protocol)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MINDFULNESS-BASED STRESS REDUCTION (MBSR),CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,CAM GENERAL,RESEARCH,OCTOBER 2010]]>
document.body:
This is the protocol for a Cochrane systematic review. This record will be updated when the review has been completed.

Citation

Hunot V, Moore THM, Caldwell D, Davies P, Jones H, Lewis G, Churchill R. Mindfulness-based 'third wave' cognitive and behavioural therapies versus other psychological therapies for depression (Protocol). Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2010, Issue 9. Art. No.: CD008704. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD008704.

Authors' objectives

  1. To examine the effectiveness and acceptability of all third wave CBT approaches compared with all other psychological therapy approaches for acute depression.
  2. To examine the effectiveness and acceptability of different third wave CBT approaches (ACT,compassionate mind training, functional analytic psychotherapy, extended behavioural activation and metacognitive therapy) compared with all other psychological therapy approaches for acute depression.
  3. To examine the effectiveness and acceptability of all third wave CBT approaches compared with different psychological therapy approaches (psychodynamic, behavioural, humanistic, integrative, cognitive-behavioural) for acute depression.
     

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,CONDITIONS A-Z,DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS D-E,MINDFULNESS-BASED STRESS REDUCTION (MBSR),OCTOBER 2010,RESEARCH,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:

Citation

Churchill R, Moore THM, Davies P, Caldwell D, Jones H, Lewis G, Hunot V. Mindfulness-based 'third wave' cognitive and behavioural therapies versus treatment as usual for depression (Protocol). Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2010, Issue 9. Art. No.: CD008705. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD008705.

Authors' objectives

  1. To examine the effectiveness and acceptability of all third wave CBT approaches compared with treatment as usual/waiting list/attention placebo control conditions for acute depression. 
  2. To examine the effectiveness and acceptability of different third wave CBT approaches (ACT, compassionate mind training, functional analytic psychotherapy, meta-cognitive therapy, dialectical behaviour therapy, MBCT, extended behavioural activation and meta-cognitive therapy) compared with treatment as usual/waiting list/attention placebo control conditions for acute depression. 
  3. To examine the effectiveness and acceptability of all third wave CBT approaches compared with different types of comparator (standard care, no treatment, waiting list, attention placebo) for acute depression.
]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,CONDITIONS A-Z,LABOUR,PREGNANCY,CONDITIONS P-R,MOXIBUSTION,CONDITIONS I-L,DATE ADDED,JULY 2010]]>

Citation

Authors' objectives

Moxibustion, acupuncture and other acupoint stimulations are commonly used for the correction of breech presentation. This systematic review aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of moxibustion and other acupoint stimulations to treat breech presentation. 

Authors' conclusions

Moxibustion, acupuncture and laser acupoint stimulation tend to be effective in the correction of breech presentation.

document.title: Multivitamin/mineral supplements and prevention of chronic disease
document.publisher: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS C,CANCER,JANUARY 2008,2008,DATE ADDED,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,VITAMINS,MINERALS]]>

Duplicate publications

Also published as an NIH consensus and state-of-the-science statement from the NIH State-of-the-Science Conference on Multivitamin/Mineral Supplements and Chronic Disease Prevention, May 15-17, 2006. 


Huang HY, Caballero B, Chang S, Alberg A J, Semba R D, Schneyer C R, Wilson R F, Cheng T Y, Vassy J, Prokopowicz G, Barnes G A, Bass E B. The efficacy and safety of multivitamin and mineral supplement use to prevent cancer and chronic disease in adults: a systematic review for a National Institutes of Health State-of-the-Science Conference. Annals of Internal Medicine. 2006;145(5):372-385. [Full text]

 

Authors' objectives

To review and synthesize published literature on the efficacy of multivitamin/mineral supplements and certain single nutrient supplements in the primary prevention of chronic disease in the general adult population, and on the safety of multivitamin/mineral supplements and certain single nutrient supplements, likely to be included in multivitamin/mineral supplements, in the general population of adults and children. 

Authors' conclusions

Multivitamin/mineral supplement use may prevent cancer in individuals with poor or suboptimal nutritional status. The heterogeneity in the study populations limits generalization to United States population. Multivitamin/mineral supplements conferred no benefit in preventing cardiovascular disease or cataract, and may prevent advanced age-related macular degeneration only in high-risk individuals. The overall quality and quantity of the literature on the safety of multivitamin/mineral supplements is limited. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Music and the reduction of post-operative pain
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS P-R,PAIN,MUSIC THERAPY,NOVEMBER 2006,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Dunn K. Music and the reduction of post-operative pain. Nursing Standard. 2004, 18(36):33-9.

Authors' objectives

To investigate the effictiveness of music in reducing post-operative pain.

Authors' conclusions

The studies reviewed cannot prove that music is effective in reducing post-operative pain, because the research methodology in the majority is poor. Patients, experience of listening to music post-operatively was positive, aiding distraction and increasing comfort. This shows the difference between inconsistent results for the objective measures of pain and what the patient is reporting.

]]>

document.title: Music for preoperative anxiety (Cochrane protocol)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-B,ANXIETY,MUSIC THERAPY,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED,RESEARCH,AUGUST 2008]]>
document.body:
This is the protocol for a Cochrane systematic review. This record will be updated when the review has been completed.

Citation

Dileo C, Bradt J. Music for preoperative anxiety. (Protocol) Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2008, Issue 1. Art. No.: CD006908. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD006908.

Authors' objectives

1. To identify randomized controlled trials examining the effects of music therapy or music medicine interventions (as defined by the authors) on preoperative anxiety in surgical patients.
2. To compare the efficacy of participation in standard care combined with music therapy or music medicine interventions with standard care alone.
3. To compare the efficacy of patient-preferred music with researcher-selected music.
4. To compare the efficacy of different types of music interventions (music therapy versus music medicine).

]]>

document.body:
111-1National Knowledge Week on Homeopathy June 2007: List of References

The HTA report on Homeopathy (2002) which aimed to summarise the available evidence on the effectiveness of homeopathy covered the evidence published prior to 2001.

Therefore, the searches for the National Knowledge Week focused on the period from 1 January 2001 to 1 April 2007 and aimed to identify all relevant systematic reviews published since the HTA report. Systematic reviews which were included in the HTA report have been excluded from this update.

The studies listed below have met our selection criteria. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise the selected studies here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.


HTA reports


Bornhoft G, Wolf U, Ammon K, Righetti M, Maxion-Bergemann S, Baumgartner S, et al. Effectiveness, safety and cost-effectiveness of homeopathy in general practice - summarized health technology assessment. Forschende Komplementärmedizin. 2006, 13 Suppl 2:19-29. [PubMed abstract] 


NHS Quality Improvement Scotland. Outcome of the scoping for an health technology assessment in homeopathy. Glasgow: NHS Quality Improvement Scotland (NHS QIS), 2006. [Full text] 


Systematic reviews and meta-analyses


Altunc U, Pittler MH, Ernst E. Homeopathy for childhood and adolescence ailments: systematic review of randomized clinical trials. Mayo Clinic proceedings. 2007, 82(1):69-75. [PubMed abstract] 


Bellavite P, Ortolani R, Pontarollo F, Piasere V, Benato G, Conforti A. Immunology and homeopathy. 4. Clinical studies-part 2. Evidence-based Complementary and Alternative Medicine: eCAM. 2006, 3(4):397-409. [Full text] 


Bellavite P, Ortolani R, Pontarollo F, Piasere V, Benato G, Conforti A. Immunology and homeopathy. 4. Clinical studies-part 1. Evidence-based Complementary and Alternative Medicine: eCAM. 2006, 3(3):293-301.  [Full text]


Grabia S, Ernst E. Homeopathic aggravations: a systematic review of randomised, placebo-controlled clinical trials. Homeopathy. 2003, 92(2):92-8. [PubMed abstract] [DARE Provisional record]


Holdcraft LC, Assefi N, Buchwald D. Complementary and alternative medicine in fibromyalgia and related syndromes. Best practice & research. Clinical Rheumatology. 2003, 17(4):667-83. [PubMed abstract] [DARE appraisal]


Jacobs J, Jonas WB, Jimenez-Perez M, Crothers D. Homeopathy for childhood diarrhea: combined results and metaanalysis from three randomized, controlled clinical trials. Pediatric Infectious Disease Journal. 2003, 22(3):229-34. [PubMed abstract]

Mills E, Wu P, Ernst E. Complementary therapies for the treatment of HIV: in search of the evidence. International Journal of STD & AIDS. 2005, 16(6):395-403. [PubMed abstract] 


Owen JM, Green BN. Homeopathic treatment of headaches: a systematic review of the literature. Journal of Chiropractic Medicine. 2004, 3(2):45-52. [Abstract]


Passalacqua G, Bousquet PJ, Carlsen KH, Kemp J, Lockey RF, Niggemann B, et al. ARIA update: I--Systematic review of complementary and alternative medicine for rhinitis and asthma. Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology. 2006, 117(5):1054-62. [PubMed abstract]


Pilkington K, Kirkwood G, Rampes H, Fisher P, Richardson J. Homeopathy for anxiety and anxiety disorders: a systematic review of the research. Homeopathy 2006, 95(3):151-62. [PubMed abstract] 


Pilkington K, Kirkwood G, Rampes H, Fisher P, Richardson J. Homeopathy for depression: a systematic review of the research evidence. Homeopathy. 2005, 94:153-63. [PubMed abstract] [DARE appraisal]  


Pittler MH, Ernst E. Complementary therapies for reducing body weight: a systematic review. International Journal of Obesity. 2005, 29(9):1030-8. [PubMed abstract]

Schneider B, Klein P, Weiser M. Treatment of vertigo with a homeopathic complex remedy compared with usual treatments: a meta-analysis of clinical trials. Arzneimittel-Forschung. 2005, 55(1):23-9. [PubMed abstract] [ENT & Audiology Specialist Library] 


Shang A, Huwiler-Muntener K, Nartey L, Juni P, Dorig S, Sterne JA, et al. Are the clinical effects of homoeopathy placebo effects? Comparative study of placebo-controlled trials of homoeopathy and allopathy. Lancet. 2005, 366(9487):726-32. [PubMed abstract]

Vickers AJ, Smith C. Homoeopathic Oscillococcinum for preventing and treating influenza and influenza-like syndromes. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews: Reviews 2006 Issue 3 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd Chichester, UK DOI : 10 1002 /14651858 CD001957 pub 2006. [Full text]

Position statement of the Canadian Paediatric Society: Homeopathy in the paediatric population. Paediatrics and Child Health. 2005, 10(3):173-82. [Full text]

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: National Knowledge Week on Homeopathy June 2007: Search Methodology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HOMEOPATHY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,2007,JUNE 2007,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-1National Knowledge Week on Homeopathy June 2007: Search Methodology

The National Knowledge Week for Homeopathy is introduced to identify, organise and present the most up-to-date evidence for this topic. The Library has searched comprehensively a large number of databases and has used strict selection criteria for the identified studies, in order to present the best current evidence available.

The HTA report on Homeopathy (2002) which aimed to summarise the available evidence on the effectiveness of homeopathy and covered the evidence published prior to 2001. Therefore, the searches for the National Knowledge Week focused on the period from 1 January 2001 to 1 April 2007 and aimed to identify all relevant systematic reviews published since the HTA report. Systematic reviews which were included in the HTA report have been excluded from this update.


Sources searched:

The Cochrane Library (CDSR, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHS EED), PubMed (and MEDLINE), EMBASE, AMED, CINAHL, PsycINFO.


Selection criteria

Inclusion criteria:

  1. Explicit description of search process and statement of methodology (at least 2 sources must have been searched and there must be a statement that the study is a meta-analysis or a systematic review).
  2. Topic relevance (studies should address homeopathy or complementary therapies as the main investigated intervention).

Exclusion criteria:

  1. The study is not a systematic review or a meta-analysis. 
  2. The study does not focus on homeopathy or CAM in general. 
  3. The study is published in a language other than English and English abstract is not available.

Search process


The searches were carried out on 2 April 2007 and were limited to articles published since 1 January 2001. To identify relevant systematic reviews the information specialist has searched the sources listed above using the CAM SL systematic reviews filter, which emphasizes specificity (precision) over sensitivity. In addition a search of PubMed using the systematic reviews subset was conducted.
More details of search terms and filters used are available by contacting the Library's information specialist. 


Search results


The total number of records retrieved was 687. After removing the duplicates there were 373 citations to be filtered. Of these 79 were selected as potential systematic reviews. If any uncertainty existed records were still included in the list. Systematic reviews included in the HTA report have been excluded.

The titles and abstracts of the potential systematic reviews were further screened for relevance. Studies with a main focus on non-clinical topics such as trial quality, reviews of secondary studies and protocols of on-going systematic reviews were excluded at this stage. The final selection included 26 systematic reviews and meta-analyses, 2 HTA reports and 1 position statement of a national body (Canadian Paediatric Society). The selected studies were categorised by medical speciality and/or condition. Based on the identified studies with a main focus on homeopathy several topics were selected for preparing brief commentaries on the use of homeopathy for specific diseases and conditions.


In addition a search for randomised controlled trials (RCTs) was carried out on the Cochrane CENTRAL database. This was to done to identify any recent RCTs that have been published after the completion of the respective systematic reviews.


 

]]>

document.title: Natural health product-drug interactions: a systematic review of clinical trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),SAFETY,CAM GENERAL,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Mills E, Wu P, Johnston BC, Gallicano K, Clarke M, Guyatt G. Natural health product-drug interactions: a systematic review of clinical trials. Therapeutic Drug Monitoring. 2005, 27(5):549-57.

Authors' objectives

Interactions between natural health products (NHP) and prescription medications are of increasing concern. This paper aims to identify all clinical trials of NHP-drug interactions. 

Authors' conclusions

Research on NHP-drug interactions is limited in number and scope. With the exception of St. John wort, clinicians and the public do not have information that permits strong inferences about interactions between NHPs and conventional medications.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Natural health product-HIV drug interactions: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,AIDS (ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY SYNDROME),HIV (HUMAN IMMUNODEFICIENCY VIRUS),CONDITIONS F-H,CONDITIONS A-B,SEPTEMBER 2010,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Mills E, Montori V, Perri D, Phillips E, Koren G. Natural health product-HIV drug interactions: a systematic review. International journal of STD & AIDS. 2005, 16(3):181-6.

Authors' objectives

The use of natural health products (NHPs) within the HIV community is high. Several NHPs have demonstrated interactions with HIV medications that could contribute to drug failure. We aimed to conduct a systematic review of clinical trials examining NHP-HIV drug interactions and their methodological characteristics.  

Authors' conclusions

This review finds that important drug level changes exist when NHPs are combined with HIV medications. Considering patient values and the implications of these studies, further research is urgently required to determine the extent of interactions with other commonly used NHPs.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Need for additional calcium to reduce the risk of hip fracture with vitamin D supplementation: evidence from a comparative metaanalysis of randomized controlled trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS M-O,CONDITIONS F-H,WOUNDS AND INJURIES,CONDITIONS T-Z,OSTEOPOROSIS,DECEMBER 2008,FRACTURES,DATE ADDED,CALCIUM,VITAMINS,MINERALS,VITAMIN D,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Boonen S, Lips P, Bouillon R, Bischoff-Ferrari HA, Vanderschueren D, Haentjens P. Need for additional calcium to reduce the risk of hip fracture with vitamin D supplementation: evidence from a comparative metaanalysis of randomized controlled trials. Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism. 2007; 92(4): 1415-1423.

Authors' objectives

The purpose of this study was to extend the metaanalysis of Bischoff-Ferrari et al., which found that 700-800 IU/d vitamin D reduced hip fracture risk in elderly individuals by 25%, by defining the need for additional calcium supplementation in individuals receiving vitamin D for the prevention of hip fractures. 

Authors' conclusions

These analyses, designed to extend the findings of Bischoff-Ferrari et al., suggest that oral vitamin D appears to reduce the risk of hip fractures only when calcium supplementation is added.

]]>

document.title: Nonhormonal drugs for contraception in men: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,CONDITIONS C,JULY 2006,TRIPTERYGIUM,CONTRACEPTION,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Lopez LM, Grimes DA, Schulz KF. Nonhormonal drugs for contraception in men: a systematic review. Obstetrical and Gynecological Survey. 2005, 60(11): 746-752.

Authors' objectives

This systematic review summarizes the clinical studies evaluating nonhormonal drugs administered to men for contraception. Relevant clinical results were found for gossypol, which is derived from the cotton plant, and for extracts of Tripterygium, a plant used in Chinese traditional medicine.

Authors' conclusions

At this time, no safe and effective nonhormonal drug is available for contraception in men.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Nonpharmacologic therapies for acute and chronic low back pain: a review of the evidence for an American Pain Society/American College of Physicians clinical practice guideline
document.topics: <![CDATA[ ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CHIROPRACTIC,CONDITIONS A-Z,MASSAGE,YOGA,CONDITIONS A-B,BACK PAIN,MAY 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
Citation

Chou R, Huffman LH; American Pain Society; American College of Physicians. Nonpharmacologic therapies for acute and chronic low back pain: a review of the evidence for an American Pain Society/American College of Physicians clinical practice guideline. Annals of Internal Medicine. 2007, 147(7):492-504.

Authors' objectives

To assess benefits and harms of acupuncture, back schools, psychological therapies, exercise therapy, functional restoration, interdisciplinary therapy, massage, physical therapies (interferential therapy, low-level laser therapy, lumbar supports, shortwave diathermy, superficial heat, traction, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, and ultrasonography), spinal manipulation, and yoga for acute or chronic low back pain (with or without leg pain). 

Authors' conclusions

LIMITATIONS: The primary source of data was systematic reviews. Non-English-language trials were included only if they were included in English-language systematic reviews. CONCLUSIONS: Therapies with good evidence of moderate efficacy for chronic or subacute low back pain are cognitive-behavioral therapy, exercise, spinal manipulation, and interdisciplinary rehabilitation. For acute low back pain, the only therapy with good evidence of efficacy is superficial heat.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Non-pharmacological interventions for breathlessness management in patients with lung cancer: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS T-Z,BREATHING TECHNIQUES,DYSPNOEA,CONDITIONS I-L,BREATHLESSNESS,CONDITIONS D-E,CONDITIONS C,CONDITIONS A-B,CANCER,LUNG CANCER,RELAXATION TECHNIQUES,FEBRUARY 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Zhao I, Yates P. Non-pharmacological interventions for breathlessness management in patients with lung cancer: a systematic review. Palliative Medicine. 2008; 22(6):693-701.

Authors' objectives

To review the published scientific literature for studies evaluating non-pharmacological interventions for breathlessness management in patients with lung cancer.

Authors' conclusions

Based on the results, non-pharmacological interventions are recommended as effective adjunctive strategies in managing breathlessness for patients with lung cancer. In order to refine such interventions, future research should seek to explore the core components of such approaches that are critical to achieving optimal outcomes, the contexts in which the interventions are most effective, and to evaluate the relative benefits of different methods for delivering such interventions.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.title: Nutrition and depression: A review of the evidence
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,DEPRESSION,CONDITIONS D-E,DECEMBER 2009,2009,DATE ADDED]]>

Citation

Harbottle L, Schonfelder N. Nutrition and depression: A review of the evidence. Journal of Mental Health. 2008, 17(6):576-87.

Authors' objectives

This review seeks to establish the current evidence base supporting nutritional interventions in unipolar depression.

Authors' conclusions

At present the evidence base is extremely weak but hints at a potential benefit of adjunctive nutritional supplementation in the treatment of depression and highlights the urgent need for more research in this area.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Nutrition and the cancer survivor: evidence to guide oncology nursing practice
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,FEBRUARY 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Toles M, Demark-Wahnefried W. Nutrition and the cancer survivor: evidence to guide oncology nursing practice. Seminars in Oncology Nursing. 2008, 24(3):171-9.

Authors' objectives

To conduct a systematic review of scientific reports related to diet and cancer survivorship that have been published since the 2006 American Cancer Society’s Guide for Informed Choices on Nutrition and Physical Activity During and After Cancer Treatment and to integrate these findings into a consistent message that can be delivered by nurses in hopes of improving the health and well-being of cancer survivors.

Authors' conclusions

Cancer survivors represent a growing population at high risk for recurrence and other co-morbidities. Evidence continues to accumulate regarding the importance of weight management, and a healthful diet (plant-based, low saturated fat) in improving the overall health and promoting disease-free and overall survival in this population.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Nutritional interventions and outcome in patients with cancer or preinvasive lesions: systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS C,CANCER,DATE ADDED,JANUARY 2008]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Davies A A, Davey Smith G, Harbord R, Bekkering G E, Sterne J A, Beynon R, Thomas S. Nutritional interventions and outcome in patients with cancer or preinvasive lesions: systematic review. Journal of the National Cancer Institute. 2006, 98(14):961-973.

Authors' objectives

Dietary modifications and supplements are used widely by patients with cancer and preinvasive lesions as an adjunct to standard treatment. Given the widespread use of nutritional modifications and supplements by such patients and concerns about the lack of benefit and possible harm, we conducted a systematic review of randomized controlled trials to examine the effect of nutritional interventions on patients with cancer or preinvasive lesions. 

Authors' conclusions

The impact of most nutritional interventions cannot be reliably estimated because of the limited number of trials, many of which were of low quality. There is no evidence that dietary modification by cancer patients improves survival and benefits disease prognosis.

 

 

]]>

document.title: Obesity and the Mediterranean diet: a systematic review of observational and intervention studies
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,OBESITY,CONDITIONS M-O,AUGUST 2009,AUGUST 2010,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,EUROPEAN UNION,GEOGRAPHY,EATING HABITS,INDIVIDUAL BEHAVIOUR,NUTRITION,FOOD,SETTINGS,SPECIAL DIETS,DETERMINANTS,BIOLOGICAL COMPOSITION,OBESITY,FOOD & NUTRITION,PUBLIC HEALTH]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Buckland G, Bach A, Serra-Majem L. Obesity and the Mediterranean diet: a systematic review of observational and intervention studies. Obesity Reviews. 2008, 9(6):582-93.

Authors' objectives

The purpose of this paper was to systematically review and analyse the epidemiological evidence on the Mediterranean diet and overweight/obesity.

Authors' conclusions

Although the results are inconsistent, the evidence points towards a possible role of the Mediterranean diet in preventing overweight/obesity, and physiological mechanisms can explain this protective effect. Despite this, more research is needed to substantiate this association. Epidemiological studies should use a consistent universal definition of the Mediterranean diet, and address common methodological limitations to strengthen the quality of research in this area.

Access

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Observational studies on the effect of dietary antioxidants on asthma: a meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ASTHMA,CONDITIONS A-B,VITAMIN E,VITAMIN C,BETA-CAROTENE,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,VITAMINS,NOVEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Gao J, Gao X, Li W, Zhu Y, Thompson PJ. Observational studies on the effect of dietary antioxidants on asthma: a meta-analysis. Respirology. 2008, 13(4):528-36.

Authors' objectives

It has been suggested that the rapid increase in asthma prevalence may in part be due to a decrease in the intake of dietary antioxidants, including vitamin C, vitamin E and beta-carotene. Epidemiological studies investigating the association between dietary antioxidant intake and asthma have generated inconsistent results. A meta-analysis was undertaken to examine the association between dietary antioxidant intake and the risk of asthma. 

Authors' conclusions

This meta-analysis does not support the hypothesis that dietary intake of the antioxidants vitamins C and E and beta-carotene influences the risk of asthma.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

Full-text online access to this article is available to NHS staff via ATHENS password.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Omega-3 fatty acids: evidence basis for treatment and future research in psychiatry
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS M-O,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,OMEGA-3 FATTY ACIDS,DATE ADDED,LIPIDS,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,OCTOBER 2008,MENTAL DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Freeman MP, Hibbeln JR, Wisner KL, Davis JM, Mischoulon D, Peet M, et al. Omega-3 fatty acids: evidence basis for treatment and future research in psychiatry. Journal of Clinical Psychiatry. 2006, 67(12):1954-67.

Authors' objectives

To determine if the available data support the use of omega-3 essential fatty acids (EFA) for clinical use in the prevention and/or treatment of psychiatric disorders. 

Authors' conclusions

The preponderance of epidemiologic and tissue compositional studies supports a protective effect of omega-3 EFA intake, particularly eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), in mood disorders. Meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials demonstrate a statistically significant benefit in unipolar and bipolar depression (p = .02). The results were highly heterogeneous, indicating that it is important to examine the characteristics of each individual study to note the differences in design and execution. There is less evidence of benefit in schizophrenia. EPA and DHA appear to have negligible risks and some potential benefit in major depressive disorder and bipolar disorder, but results remain inconclusive in most areas of interest in psychiatry. Treatment recommendations and directions for future research are described. Health benefits of omega-3 EFA may be especially important in patients with psychiatric disorders, due to high prevalence rates of smoking and obesity and the metabolic side effects of some psychotropic medications.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Osteopathic manipulative treatment for low back pain: 2008 annual evidence update
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OSTEOPATHY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-B,BACK PAIN,SEPTEMBER 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-1Osteopathic manipulative treatment for low back pain: 2008 annual evidence update

Commentary by Carol Fawkes, National Council for Osteopathic Research


Original study


Degenhardt BF, Darmani NA, Johnson JC, Towns LC, Rhodes DC, Trinh C, et al. Role of osteopathic manipulative treatment in altering pain biomarkers: a pilot study. The Journal of the American Osteopathic Association. 2007, 107(9):387-400. [Full text]


Commentary

The systematic review included in the 2007 evidence summary on osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) for low back pain was focussed exclusively on pain outcomes. This recent pilot study also aims to determine the role of OMT in pain management.


One of the goals of osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) is to evaluate biomechanical dysfunction and, in combination with other treatment modalities, promote healing in patients experiencing such disorders. Persistent pain experienced by many patients consulting osteopaths is associated with the production and release of multiple nociceptive and inflammatory mediators. The complexity of this process is not fully understood but the research team hypothesised that the concentration of circulatory neurochemical substances could be used as biomarkers whose concentrations would change if they were affected by OMT. Five pain biomarkers were assessed in this study, namely ß-endorphin (ßE), serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine [5-HT]), 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), anandamide (arachidonyletholamide [AEA]), and N-palmitoylethanolamide (PEA).


Twenty white participants, aged between 24 to 35 years, were enrolled in the study; ten subjects had chronic low back pain (CLBP) and ten subjects were age and gender-matched controls. Low back pain was defined as being present for a minimum of five days a week for at least three months. Each subject had blood drawn at the same time each day for five consecutive days. On days 1, 2, 3, and 5 subjects also completed an environmental questionnaire investigating stress levels, perceived pain levels, amount of sleep, diet quality and confounding substance use. On the 4th day of the study, all participants attended the research study centre one hour before blood was due to be drawn and underwent evaluation and osteopathic treatment by the primary investigator. Blood was drawn following this procedure. 


Pre-treatment measurements for each biomarker for days 1, 2, and 3 and were averaged to establish a baseline value for each subject. Median baseline values were compared for all continuous measures with the values obtained on day 4 at 30 minutes post treatment and with those on day 5 (24 hours post-treatment). Comparisons were made using the Wilcoxon signed rank test. Comparisons of biomarker concentrations between the CLBP and control group were carried out using the Mann-Whitney test. Correlation of changes in self-reported pain levels and environmental factors with changes in biomarkers was carried out measuring Spearmann rank correlation coefficients.


The study results can be summarised:

  • ß-endorphin. Baseline levels between the two groups were not 
    significantly different. The increase in ß-endorphin levels above baseline was statistically significantly at 24 hours post treatment representing a median increase of 11% (P = 0.01).  The control group did not differ significantly.
  • Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine [5-HT]). Concentrations of 5-HT decreased significantly when measured 24 hours post-treatment in the CLBP group relative to baseline measures and the control group. This represented a median increase of 37% (P=0.02)
  • 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA). Concentrations of 5-HIAA declined significantly at 30 minutes post-treatment but no significant change was observed for the CLBP or control group at 24 hours post-treatment.
  • 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA)/ (5-hydroxytryptamine [5-HT]) turnover. Turnover increased in CLBP subjects at 30 minutes and 24 hours post-treatment; the differences were not, however, statistically significant.
  • Anandamide (arachidonyletholamide [AEA]). AEA concentrations did not change significantly at either 30 minutes or 24 hours post-treatment. 
  • N-palmitoylethanolamide (PEA). No significant difference in PEA levels was noted between the control and the CLBP group when measured at 24 hours post-treatment.
  • Perceived pain, stress, sleep, and substance use. Changes in perceived pain, did not correlate with changes in ßE, 5-HT, AEA or PEA in the CLBP group when measured at 30 minutes or 24 hours post-treatment. Stress levels were significantly decreased at 24 hours post-treatment (P=0-001). There were no changes in sleep pattern or confounding substance use in either group following treatment.

Even though the sample size in the study was small, the study showed statistically significant biomarker changes in the overall population as well as when the two groups were compared. It is unclear where the biomarkers were formed or the mechanism by which the OMT affected the biomarker concentrations. The results are encouraging despite the fact that a small sample size was used producing tests with low statistical power. Further research including a greater sample size would gather further helpful information.

 

Link back to 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM for low back pain 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Osteopathic manipulative treatment for low back pain: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,OSTEOPATHY,OCTOBER 2006,CONDITIONS A-B,BACK PAIN,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Licciardone JC, Brimhall AK, King LN. Osteopathic manipulative treatment for low back pain: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. BMC Musculoskeletal Disorders. 2005 Aug 4;6:43.

Authors' objectives

The purpose of this study was to assess the efficacy of osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) as a complementary treatment for low back pain.

Authors' conclusions

OMT significantly reduces low back pain. The level of pain reduction is greater than expected from placebo effects alone and persists for at least three months. Additional research is warranted to elucidate mechanistically how OMT exerts its effects, to determine if OMT benefits are long lasting, and to assess the cost-effectiveness of OMT as a complementary treatment for low back pain.

 

]]>

document.title: Other complementary and alternative medicine modalities: acupuncture, magnets, reflexology, and homeopathy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HOMEOPATHY,ACUPUNCTURE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,REFLEXOLOGY,CONDITIONS M-O,CONDITIONS F-H,HOT FLUSHES,MENOPAUSAL SYMPTOMS,FEBRUARY 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Carpenter JS, Neal JG. Other complementary and alternative medicine modalities: acupuncture, magnets, reflexology, and homeopathy. American Journal of Medicine. 2005, 118 Suppl 12B:109-17.

Authors' objectives

This study aimed to evaluate evidence for the benefits and risks of acupuncture, magnets, reflexology, and homeopathy for menopause-related symptoms.

Authors' conclusions

There is a need for additional investigations of acupuncture and homeopathy for the treatment of hot flashes and other menopausal symptoms. However, existing evidence does not indicate a beneficial effect of magnets or reflexology in the treatment of hot flashes and other menopausal symptoms. Understanding whether, for whom, and how these interventions work is crucial to building the evidence base needed to evaluate any potential for these CAM therapies in the management of menopause-related symptoms.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

 

]]>

Authors' objectives

This review was conducted as a systematic attempt to document and evaluate all the available safety data on P. ginseng root extracts. 

Authors' conclusions

The data suggest that P. ginseng monopreparations are rarely associated with adverse events or drug interactions. The ones that are documented are usually mild and transient. Combined preparations are more often associated with such events but causal attribution is usually not possible.

document.body:
Citation

MacPherson H, Sinclair-Lian N, Thomas K. Patients seeking care from acupuncture practitioners in the UK: a national survey. Complementary Therapies in Medicine. 2006,14(1):20-30.

Authors' objectives

The primary aim was to describe the characteristics of acupuncture patients and in particular the main problem or symptom for which they were seeking treatment. Our secondary aim was to compare the profiles of acupuncture patients with those of a patient survey undertaken in 1988.

Authors' conclusions

This evidence from acupuncture patients' reports shows that musculoskeletal problems provide the main reason for seeking treatment. The large dataset from this study provides a wealth of information and a fresh raft of questions which will inform future research and policy-making.

 

]]>

Authors' conclusions

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Perceived benefit of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) for back pain: a national survey
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-B,BACK PAIN,USE OF CAM,CAM GENERAL,JUNE 2010]]>
document.body:
Citation

Kanodia AK, Legedza ATR, Davis RB, et al. Perceived benefit of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) for back pain: a national survey. Journal of the American Board of Family Medicine. 2010;23(3):354–362. [Full text]

Objectives

To examine the associations between the perceived helpfulness of various CAM therapies for back pain based on data from the 2002 National Health Interview Survey.

Results

Approximately 6% of the US population used CAM to treat their back pain in 2002. Sixty percent of respondents who used CAM for back pain perceived a "great deal" of benefit. Using multivariable logistic regression, the factor associated with perceived benefit from CAM modalities was reporting that a reason for using CAM was that "conventional medical treatment would not help" (odds ratio [OR], 1.46; 95% CI, 1.14-1.86). The 2 factors associated with less perceived benefit from CAM modalities were fair to poor self-reported health status (OR, 0.58; 95% CI, 0.41-0.82) and referral by a conventional medical practitioner for CAM (OR, 0.7; 95% CI, 0.54-0.92). Using chiropractic as a reference, massage (OR, 0.62; 95% CI, 0.46-0.83), relaxation techniques (OR, 0.25; 95% CI, 0.14-0.45), and herbal therapy (OR, 0.3; 95% CI, 0.19-0.46) were all associated with less perceived benefit whereas those with similar perceived benefit included yoga/tai chi/qi gong (OR, 0.71; 95% CI, 0.41-1.22) and acupuncture (OR, 0.71; 95% CI, 0.37-1.38).

Conclusions

The majority of respondents who used CAM for back pain perceived benefit. Specific factors and therapies associated with perceived benefit warrant further investigation.

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,AUGUST 2007,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL,EDUCATION/CPD]]>
document.body:
This distance learning course at the Open University starts in February and ends in October. This course is expected to run until February 2012.


This second level course provides an accessible but rigorous introduction to complementary and alternative approaches to health. It aims to stimulate lively debates about this controversial and topical subject and to equip students with information and analytical frameworks with which to enter the debates.

For more information about the course content, entry requirements and registration please see course webpage.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Petasites hybridus (butterbur) for treating allergic rhinitis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS,NOSE & SINUS DISORDERS,SINUSITIS,RHINOSINUSITIS,RHINITIS,ENT AND AUDIOLOGY,THERAPEUTIC INTERVENTIONS,COMPLEMENTARY THERAPIES,HERBAL REMEDIES,NON-DRUG TREATMENTS,BUTTERBUR (PETASITES VULGARIS),ALLERGIES,CONDITIONS A-B,DATE ADDED,2008,DECEMBER 2008]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Guo R, Pittler M H. Petasites hybridus (butterbur) for treating allergic rhinitis. Focus on Alternative and Complementary Therapies. 2007; 12(2): 81-84.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this study was to systematically review the literature to obtain all trials published on this topic and summarise their results.

Authors' conclusions

There is encouraging evidence to suggest that P. hybridus may be an effective herbal treatment for intermittent allergic rhinitis. However, because of the possible financial interests of the sponsor of three large trials of P. hybridus extract, independent replication is required before any firm conclusion can be drawn.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Pharmacokinetic interactions of drugs with St John's wort
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ST JOHN'S WORT (HYPERICUM PERFORATUM),HERBAL MEDICINE,HERBS R-Z,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Zhou S, Chan E, Pan SQ, Huang M, Lee EJ. Pharmacokinetic interactions of drugs with St John's wort. Journal of Psychopharmacology. 2004, 18(2):262-76.

Authors' objectives

There is a worldwide increasing use of herbs which are often administered in combination with therapeutic drugs, raising the potential for herb-drug interactions. St John's wort (Hypericum perforatum) is one of the most commonly used herbal antidepressants. The aim of this review was to identify known drug interaction with St John's wort.

Authors' conclusions

Because the potential interaction of St John's wort with other drugs is a major safety concern, additional systematic research on herb-drug interactions and appropriate regulation in herbal safety and efficacy is needed.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Physiological adjustments to stress measures following massage therapy: a review of the literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,MASSAGE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,STRESS,CONDITIONS S,DECEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Moraska A, Pollini RA, Boulanger K, Brooks MZ, Teitlebaum L. Physiological Adjustments to Stress Measures Following Massage Therapy: A Review of the Literature. Evidence-based Complementary and Alternative Medicine. 2008 May 7. [Epub ahead of print].

Authors' objectives

To summarize the effectiveness of massage therapy on stress-reactive physiological measures.

Authors' conclusions

To date, the research data is insufficient to make definitive statements regarding the multiple treatment effect of massage therapy on urinary cortisol or catecholamines, but some evidence for a positive effect on diastolic blood pressure has been documented. While significant improvement has been demonstrated following massage therapy, the general research body on this topic lacks the necessary scientific rigor to provide a definitive understanding of the effect massage therapy has on many physiological variables associated with stress.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Phytoestrogens in the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis (Cochrane protocol)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,OSTEOPOROSIS,CONDITIONS M-O,RESEARCH,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:
This is the protocol for a Cochrane systematic review. This record will be updated when the review has been completed.

Citation

Ardila E, Echevery J, Sanchez R. Phytoestrogens in the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis. (Protocol) The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2001, Issue 3. Art. No.: CD003131. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD003131.

Authors' objectives

To determine the efficacy and safety of phytoestrogens for the treatment of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women.

In particular, the principal objective of this review is to reliably answer the two following questions:

1) Are phytoestrogens effective in preventing bone fractures when administered in postmenopausal women?
2) Are phytoestrogens safe in terms of adverse events for the treatment of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women?

Secondary objectives are to determine the efficacy and safety of phytoestrogens in the following subgroups:

1) Early postmenopausal women (less than 35 years old)
2) Women who have sustained a fracture.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Phytotherapy for lower urinary tract symptoms secondary to benign prostatic hyperplasia
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS P-R,CONDITIONS T-Z,PROSTATIC HYPERPLASIA,URINARY TRACT INFECTIONS,AUGUST 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Dedhia RC, McVary KT. Phytotherapy for lower urinary tract symptoms secondary to benign prostatic hyperplasia. Journal of Urology. 2008, 179(6):2119-25.

Authors' objectives

To examine the available data from clinical trials for certain botanicals used for lower urinary tract symptoms secondary to benign prostatic hyperplasia, including Serenoa repens (saw palmetto), Pygeum africanum (African plum), Secale cereale (rye pollen) and Hypoxis rooperi (South African star grass).

Authors' conclusions

Most clinical trials of investigating the efficacy of botanicals suffer from well documented methodological flaws. Saw palmetto has been clearly shown as comparable to placebo in a trial of sound methodology. While preliminary results appear promising, to our knowledge the remaining botanicals have yet to be evaluated in a trial of similar quality.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Phytotherapy Research
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE]]>
document.body:
Phytotherapy Research is a monthly, international journal for the publication of original research papers, short communications, reviews and letters on medicinal plant research. Key areas of interest are pharmacology, toxicology, and the clinical applications of herbs and natural products in medicine, from case histories to full clinical trials, including studies of herb-drug interactions and other aspects of the safety of herbal medicines.

Latest issue, contents and abstracts are available via publisher's website. Full text online access is available only for subscribers.

 

]]>

document.title: Plant sterols/stanols as cholesterol lowering agents: A meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HIGH CHOLESTEROL,CONDITIONS F-H,FOOD AND BEVERAGES,AUGUST 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Abumweis SS, Barake R, Jones PJ. Plant sterols/stanols as cholesterol lowering agents: A meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials. Food & Nutrition Research. 2008, 52. doi: 10.3402/fnr.v52i0.1811. Epub 2008 Aug 18.

Authors' objectives

To more precisely quantify the effect of plant sterol enriched products on LDL cholesterol concentrations than what is reported previously, and to identify and quantify the effects of subjects’ characteristics, food carrier, frequency and time of intake on efficacy of plant sterols as cholesterol lowering agents. 

Authors' conclusions

Plant sterol containing products reduced LDL concentrations but the reduction was related to individuals’ baseline LDL levels, food carrier, and frequency and time of intake.
]]>
