document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Possible contraindications and adverse reactions associated with the use of ocular nutritional supplements
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,HERBS D-G,CONDITIONS D-E,GINKGO (GINKGO BILOBA),JANUARY 2011,LIPIDS,EYE DISEASES,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY,VITAMIN B COMPLEX,BETA-CAROTENE,VITAMIN C,VITAMIN A,VITAMIN E,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,VITAMINS,ESSENTIAL FATTY ACIDS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Bartlett H, Eperjesi F. Possible contraindications and adverse reactions associated with the use of ocular nutritional supplements. Ophthalmic Physiol Opt. 2005 May;25(3):179-94.

Authors' objectives

The role of oxidation in the development of age-related eye disease has prompted interest in the use of nutritional supplementation for prevention of onset and progression. The aim is to highlight possible contraindications and adverse reactions of isolated or high dose ocular nutritional supplements.

Authors' conclusions

Vitamin A should be avoided in women who may become pregnant, in those with liver disease, and in people who drink heavily. Relationships have been found between vitamin A and reduced bone mineral density, and beta-carotene and increased risk of lung cancer in smoking males. Vitamin E and Ginkgo biloba have anticoagulant and anti-platelet effects respectively, and high doses are contraindicated in those being treated for vascular disorders. Those patients with contraindications or who are considered at risk of adverse reactions should be advised to seek specialist dietary advice via their medical practitioner.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.  

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Potential effects of herbal medicines and nutritional supplements on coagulation in ENT practice
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DECEMBER 2009,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Javed F, Golagani A, Sharp H. Potential effects of herbal medicines and nutritional supplements on coagulation in ENT practice. Journal of Laryngology and Otology. 2008, 122(2):116-9.

Authors' objectives

Herbal remedies and other natural supplements have become popular alternative medical therapy. Patients using these products may present to ENT surgeons with epistaxis or with unexpected, excessive peri-operative bleeding. The purpose of this review was to consolidate the available data regarding herb-drug interactions and the direct effects of herbal medicines and nutritional supplements in isolation, regarding disturbance in haemostasis, so as to emphasise their individual importance.

Authors' conclusions

When encountering patients presenting with epistaxis, or in the elective surgical setting, a thorough enquiry about the use of herbal medicines is of great importance.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Practice parameter: treatment of postherpetic neuralgia. An evidence-based report of the Quality Standards Subcommittee of the American Academy of Neurology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ACUPUNCTURE,CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,CONDITIONS F-H,PAIN,HERPES SIMPLEX VIRUS,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),CONDITIONS P-R]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Dubinsky RM, Kabbani H, El-Chami Z, Boutwell C, Ali H. Practice parameter: treatment of postherpetic neuralgia. An evidence-based report of the Quality Standards Subcommittee of the American Academy of Neurology. Neurology. 2004, 63(6): 959-965.

Authors' objectives

This practice parameter was developed to answer the following clinical question: In patients with postherpetic neuralgia, which treatments provide benefit in terms of decreased pain and improved quality of life?

Authors' conclusions

Tricyclic antidepressants, gabapentin, pregabalin, opioids, and lidocaine patch were found to be effective in reducing the pain of postherpetic neuralgia.
Acupuncture, benzydamine cream, dextromethorphan, indomethacin, epidural methylprednisolone, epidural morphine sulfate, iontophoresis of vincristine, lorazepam, vitamin E, and zimelidine are not of benefit.
The effectiveness of carbamazepine, nicardipine, biperiden, chlorprothixene, ketamine, He:Ne laser irradiation, intralesional triamcinolone, cryocautery, topical piroxicam, extract of Ganoderma lucidum, dorsal root entry zone lesions, and stellate ganglion block are unproven in the treatment of postherpetic neuralgia.

 

]]>

Citation

Goh YI, Bollano E, Einarson TR, Koren G. Prenatal multivitamin supplementation and rates of pediatric cancers: a meta-analysis. Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics. 2007; 81(5): 685-691.

Authors' objectives

To conduct a systematic review and meta-analysis to assess the potential protective effect of prenatal multivitamins on several pediatric cancers. 

Authors' conclusions

Maternal ingestion of prenatal multivitamins is associated with a decreased risk for pediatric brain tumors, neuroblastoma, and leukemia. Presently, it is not known which constituent(s) among the multivitamins confer this protective effect.

document.title: Prescriptive clinical prediction rules in back pain research: a systematic review
document.publisher: Journal of Manual and Manipulative Therapy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CHIROPRACTIC,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS A-B,BACK PAIN,MARCH 2010,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

May S, Rosedale R. Prescriptive Clinical Prediction Rules in Back Pain Research: A Systematic Review. Journal of Manual and Manipulative Therapy. 2009, 17(1):36-45.

Authors' objectives

The purpose of this review was to evaluate existing clinical prediction rules (CPR) against established criteria to determine the quality of the studies and the overall development of the CPR against a set number of stages. 

Authors' conclusions

As regards the manipulation CPR, evidence to date for its clinical utility is limited and contradictory. For the stabilization CPR, there was limited evidence that it may be considered but only with caution and in similar patients. Overall, there is limited evidence to support the general application of spinal CPRs.

Access

document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS C,CANCER,JULY 2010,USE OF CAM,CAM GENERAL]]>

Citation

Bishop FL, Prescott P, Chan YK, Saville J, von Elm E, Lewith GT. Prevalence of complementary medicine use in pediatric cancer: a systematic review. Pediatrics. 2010 Apr;125(4):768-76.

Authors' objectives

To summarize the current evidence on the prevalence of CAM use in pediatric patients with cancer and assess the reported quality of included studies. 

Authors' conclusions

Many pediatric patients with cancer use CAM. It is important that pediatricians be aware of this fact and encourage open communication with patients and their parents. Using standardized survey methods and CAM definitions in future studies could improve their quality and help generate comparable data. Our quality-assessment tool could prove valuable for other reviews of prevalence studies.

Access

Citation

Ernst E. Prospective investigations into the safety of spinal manipulation. Journal of Pain and Symptom Management. 2001, 21(3):238-42.

Authors' objectives

Spinal manipulation (SM) is a popular form of treatment of back and neck pain, as well as of other conditions. Uncertainty exists as to its safety. The aim of this systematic review was to summarize the data of all prospective investigations into the safety of SM.

Authors' conclusions

The data indicate that mild and transient adverse events seem to be frequent. Serious adverse events are probably rare but their incidence can only be estimated at present. Further prospective investigations are needed to define their incidence more closely.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Psychological outcomes of spinal manipulation for low back pain: 2008 annual evidence update
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CHIROPRACTIC,OSTEOPATHY,CONDITIONS A-Z,NECK PAIN,BACK PAIN,CONDITIONS M-O,CONDITIONS A-B,DATE ADDED,SEPTEMBER 2008]]>
document.body:
111-1Psychological outcomes of spinal manipulation for low back pain: 2008 annual evidence update

Commentary by Carol Fawkes, National Council for Osteopathic Research


Original study

Williams NH, Hendry M, Lewis R, Russell I, Westmoreland A, Wilkinson C. Psychological response in spinal manipulation (PRISM): a systematic review of psychological outcomes in randomised controlled trials. Complementary Therapies in Medicine. 2007, 15(4):271-83. [PubMed abstract]


Commentary

The systematic review included in the 2007 evidence summary on osteopathic manipulative treatment for low back pain was focussed exclusively on pain outcomes* (see note below). This recent review examines the effectiveness of spinal manipulation in improving psychological outcomes.

Psychosocial factors have been identified as one of the most important risk factors for back and neck pain. Back and neck pain, along with other forms of spinal pain, is a common cause of disability and time lost from work.


Inclusion criteria

The authors in this review attempted to assess the effectiveness of spinal manipulation on improving psychological outcome. Inclusion criteria included:

  • Randomised controlled trials
  • Adults with back pain, neck pain and perceived cervicogenic headaches
  • Techniques used included manipulation or mobilisation of the spine
  • Outcomes included back pain beliefs, fear-avoidance beliefs, self-efficacy, generic outcomes with a psychological component, depression and anxiety
  • Studies included English and European languages

Search strategy

An extensive search strategy was devised and Medline, CENTRAL, Embase, CINAHL, AMED and PsycINFO were searched from inception to November 2005. A scoring system was developed based on criteria used by the Cochrane Collaboration “Back Review Group”. Clinical heterogeneity, or the difference between studies, was assessed by consideration of the type of intervention and its delivery, the setting, study population, and the length of the follow up period. The different psychological outcome measures used were assessed for compatibility.

The search strategy identified 2466 relevant studies. Following the review procedure, 254 studies were examined. Further examination identified 13 suitable trials which met the inclusion criteria specified by the review team. The 13 included trials exhibited heterogeneity concerning the area of the spine treated, the professional background of the therapist delivering the manipulation, the psychological outcome reported and the nature of the control group.

Regions of the spine treated in the studies were:
Whole of the spine: n = 1
The cervical spine: n = 4
The lumbar spine: n = 8.

Manipulation was delivered by osteopaths, chiropractors, physiotherapists or physicians; this was delivered using a combination of mobilisation and high velocity thrust techniques. Control interventions could be divided into two groups:

  • Verbal interventions: primary care, advice, education.
  • Physical treatment interventions: electrotherapy, sham manipulation, muscle relaxants, cervical collar and surgery.

Spinal manipulation compared with verbal interventions

Three trials used primary care as a comparator; one looked at back and neck manipulation compared with primary care. This study reported an improvement in a single depression item in favour of manipulation. Two other studies compared manipulation for back pain with optimal primary care: both studies found statistically significant improvements in depression score in favour of manipulation.


Spinal manipulation compared with physical treatment interventions

Two trials in the UK used an exercise programme as a comparator; one looked at the treatment of neck pain and found no significant difference. Another trial looked at back pain and found a small statistically significant difference in SF-36 mental score in favour of manipulation.

Two trials used electrotherapy as a comparator; one looked at interferential in the treatment of low back pain, and the other trial examined the treatment of neck pain with pulsed short-waved diathermy. No statistically significant difference was found for SF-36 or SF-12 mental health score.

Three low back pain trials used placebo-type interventions as a comparator and did not find statistically significant differences. Four poor quality trials found mixed results in the treatment of neck and back pain but none exhibited statistical significance.

The study authors drew the following conclusions from their findings:

  • A small outcome was found in psychological outcomes after spinal manipulation when compared with verbal interventions.
  • A smaller improvement was found when compared with physical interventions.
  • The study contributed clinically useful information that physical treatments including spinal manipulation have psychological benefits.

*NOTE

One further pilot study with a focus on pain outcomes has been published since June 2007. To see the commentary on this study click here.

 

Link back to 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM for low back pain

 

]]>

Authors' objectives

The most important risk factors for back and neck pain are psychosocial. Nevertheless, systematic reviews of spinal manipulation have concentrated on pain and spine related disability, and ignored psychological outcomes. Authors' conclusions

Authors' objectives

To systematically review and evaluate behavioral and psychological treatments applied to pediatric functional gastrointestinal disorders.

Authors' conclusions

Although many psychological treatments demonstrated evidence of positive effects, few well-designed randomized controlled trials of psychological treatments for functional gastrointestinal disorders exist. More work is needed to determine the most potent, essential elements of psychological treatments alone or in combination with standard medical intervention, and to establish their applicability with diverse populations. Clinical and research implications are discussed.

document.title: Psychosocial treatments of behavior symptoms in dementia: a systematic review of reports meeting quality standards
document.topics: <![CDATA[ AROMATHERAPY,CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS D-E,CONDITIONS A-B,DEMENTIA,MUSIC THERAPY,RELAXATION TECHNIQUES,ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE,DECEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

O'Connor DW, Ames D, Gardner B, King M. Psychosocial treatments of behavior symptoms in dementia: a systematic review of reports meeting quality standards. International Psychogeriatrics. 2009, 21(2):225-40.

Authors' objectives

To provide a systematic review of selected experimental studies of psychosocial treatments of behavioral disturbances in dementia. Psychosocial treatments are defined here as strategies derived from one of three psychologically oriented paradigms (learning theory, unmet needs and altered stress thresholds).

Authors' conclusions

Some psychosocial interventions appear to have specific therapeutic properties, over and above those due to the benefits of participating in a clinical trial. Their effects were mostly small to moderate with a short duration of action. This limited action means that treatments will work best in specific, time-limited situations. In the few studies that addressed within-group differences, there were marked variations in response. Some participants benefited greatly from a treatment, while others did not. Interventions proved more effective when tailored to individuals' preferences.

Access

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Public Assessment Reports for herbal medicines
document.publisher: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,CAM GENERAL,FEBRUARY 2009,REGULATION]]>
document.body:
Manufactured herbal medicines placed on the UK market are required to have either a Traditional Herbal Registration (THR) or a Marketing Authorisation (MA). This applies whether the product is marketed to consumers, herbal practitioners, retailers, or wholesalers.

The Public Assessment Reports provided are compiled and edited in accordance with EC Directive 2004/27/EC.

The compilation and editing of the original assessment reports into the Public Assessment Reports are performed by experienced medical writers. The draft copies of the Public Assessment Reports are then checked by medical, pharmaceutical, and, if necessary, preclinical and statistical assessors. The assessment reports are amended to incorporate any assessors’ comments. Before being made available to the public, all Public Assessment Reports are sent to the Marketing Authorisation/Traditional Herbal Registration holder (or a designated person of their choice) for comment.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Public perceptions of herbal medicines: General public qualitative & quantitative research
document.publisher: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),CAM GENERAL,JANUARY 2009,REGULATION,SAFETY,USE OF CAM]]>
document.body:
This report presents the findings of a programme of research carried out among the general public by Ipsos MORI on behalf of the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA).


The research programme comprised qualitative research involving four general public discussion groups and a large-scale quantitative survey of behaviour, attitudes and opinions.

The report is divided into a number of sections. These comprise: a summary of key findings, sections on methodology and analysis, and summaries of the findings arising from the qualitative research and quantitative survey.

Currently, most herbal medicines on the UK market are not subject to systematic regulation. While some herbal medicines have a product licence and a few over-the-counter (OTC) products now have a traditional herbal registration, the majority of herbal medicines are sold as unlicensed herbal remedies. These latter products are subject to only minimal regulation. In the coming years all manufactured OTC herbal medicines will require a traditional herbal registration or product licence and the MHRA therefore needs to understand public perceptions on the issues in order to communicate effectively about the changes in regulation.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Publication bias: direction of outcome less important than scientific quality
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,RESEARCH,SEPTEMBER 2007,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:
Citation

Abbot NE, Ernst E. Publication bias: direction of outcome less important than scientific quality. Perfusion. 1998, 11:182-184.

Authors' objectives

Publication bias, the tendency to publish work on the strength and direction of the results, is well recognised and its effect is to distort the body of scientific knowledge in favour of positive results. It may be especially important for complementary medicine (CM) which has a preponderance of positive reports in its specialist journals but which is also under-represented in the peer reviewed mainstream literature. The aim of this study was to test whether orthodox scientific reviewers are biased against positive findings in CM papers. 

Authors' conclusions

There was no evidence of publication bias on the part of the scientific reviewers as regards direction of study outcome but scientific quality of manuscript was found to be more important in terms of the accept/reject decision, an encouraging result for the refereeing process.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Reflexology for low back pain: 2008 Annual evidence update
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,REFLEXOLOGY,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-B,BACK PAIN,SEPTEMBER 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-1Reflexology for low back pain: 2008 Annual evidence update

Commentary by Dr George Lewith, University of Southampton


Poole H, Glenn S, Murphy P. A randomised controlled study of reflexology for the management of chronic low back pain. European Journal of Pain. 2007;11(8):878-87. 

Quinn F, Hughes CM, Baxter GD. Reflexology in the management of low back pain: A pilot randomised controlled trial. Complementary Therapies in Medicine. 2008, 16(1):3-8.


Both of these studies involved similar groups of patients with chronic low back pain.  Poole presents a large study (n = 243) in which the patients were randomised to reflexology, relaxation (possibly as an attention control) and treatment as usual. The reflexology was provided by a group of 5 professional and trained reflexologists. They made available 6 treatments of one hour duration over a 6-8 week period. Similarly, relaxation was provided by 4 trained therapists over 6 weeks using progressive muscle relaxation. Treatment as usual involved medication (both prescribed and over the counter), osteopathy, acupuncture, physiotherapy, aromatherapy, sports massage, chiropractic and Reiki. The outcomes were the Oswestry Low Back Pain Questionnaire, Beck Depression Inventory, a Visual Analogue Score for pain and the SF36. All groups showed similar improvement over time in all outcome measures, suggesting that no particular treatment was superior to any other.


Quinn et al. report a small trial of 19 patients designed as a pilot to evaluate reflexology versus a sham procedure. Seven patients received reflexology and 8 sham and outcome was assessed using a combination of visual analogue scale for pain, Roland Morris Disability Questionnaire and McGill Pain Questionnaire. Real or sham treatment was provided weekly over a 6 week period with follow-up at 12 and 18 weeks. Unfortunately there was no real attempt to assess the credibility of the sham procedure but this tiny pilot study does suggest that reflexology may have a specific effect on low back pain.


These two studies, taken together, suggest that there is a possibility that reflexology may have a treatment specific effect but it is unlikely that reflexology offers treatment advantages over other interventions for the management of chronic low back pain. Further work is clearly needed and these conclusions are tentative. 

 

Link back to 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM for low back pain

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Reflexology for symptom relief in patients with cancer
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,REFLEXOLOGY,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS C,CANCER,MARCH 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Wilkinson S, Lockhart K, Gambles M, Storey L. Reflexology for symptom relief in patients with cancer. Cancer Nurs. 2008, 31(5):354-60.

Authors' objectives

Complementary therapies are increasingly being used in hospices and hospitals alongside orthodox treatments in an attempt to improve patients' emotional, spiritual, psychological, and physical well-being. An average of 31% of UK patients with cancer use some form of complementary therapy. Many UK cancer centers, out-patient units, and hospices are providing complementary services. There is strong anecdotal evidence that complementary therapies assist in the palliation of physical and psychological symptoms. This systematic review examines the research evidence base for the effectiveness of reflexology in cancer care. 

Authors' conclusions

The study reports the results of a systematic review following the Cochrane principles of systematic reviewing. No meta-analysis was possible. Studies were retrieved from a comprehensive search of electronic databases from their start dates. An initial search was carried out in 2003 and updated in 2005 to 2006. Eligible studies were randomized controlled trials, controlled before and after studies, and interrupted time-series studies. Participants were adults with a diagnosis of cancer, receiving care in any healthcare setting. Interventions were limited to reflexology carried out by a qualified therapist as distinguished from another healthcare professional carrying out a reflexology intervention. Outcome measures were patient-reported levels of physical and psychological indices of symptom distress and quality of life (measured using validated assessment tools).

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

Patients should be asked about the use and source of herbal medicines and carefully monitored for drug interactions and adverse effects.

document.title: Reviewer bias against the unconventional? A randomized double-blind study of peer review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,RESEARCH,SEPTEMBER 2007,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:
Citation

Ernst E, Resch KL. Reviewer bias against the unconventional? A randomized double-blind study of peer review. Complementary Therapies in Medicine. 1999, 7(1):19-23. 

Authors' objectives

To test the hypothesis that there is a reviewer bias against publication of a test of an unconventional drug.

Authors' conclusions

In the present setting, there was no evidence for a reviewer-bias against testing an unconventional drug. The low inter-rater reliability, however, suggested inadequate validity of peer review.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Risk assessment for carnitine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,SAFETY,CARNITINE,AMINO ACIDS,CAM GENERAL,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Hathcock JN, Shao A. Risk assessment for carnitine. Regulatory Toxicology and Pharmacology. 2006, 46(1):23-8.

Abstract

Carnitine is a conditionally essential amino acid-like compound involved in the transport of long-chain fatty acids into the mitochondria during the beta-oxidation process. Carnitine has become an increasingly popular ingredient in dietary supplements, especially weight loss and some sports nutrition products. A number of clinical trials have been conducted examining the effect of carnitine supplementation on weight loss and energy balance. Regarding safety, systematic evaluation of the research designs and data do not provide a basis for risk assessment and the usual safe upper level of intake (UL) derived from it unless the newer methods described as the observed safe level (OSL) or highest observed intake (HOI) are utilized. The OSL risk assessment method indicates that the evidence of safety is strong at intakes up to 2000mg/day l-carnitine equivalents for chronic supplementation, and this level is identified as the OSL. Although much higher levels have been tested without adverse effects and may be safe, the data for intakes above 2000mg/day are not sufficient for a confident conclusion of long-term safety.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Risk management of nutritional supplements in chronic illness: the implications for the care of cancer and depression
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,DEPRESSION,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,CONDITIONS D-E,OCTOBER 2008,2008,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED,SAFETY,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Werneke U. Risk management of nutritional supplements in chronic illness: the implications for the care of cancer and depression. Proceedings of the Nutrition Society. 2007, 66(4):483-92.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this review is to systematically explore the main dimensions that clinicians have to consider when advising patients suffering from these conditions. 

Authors' conclusions

Supplements predominantly used by patients with cancer include vitamins A, C and E, beta-carotene and ubiquinone 10. Supplements predominantly used by patients with depression include S-adenosylmethionine, l-tryptophan and 5-hydroxytryptophan and inositol. Supplements potentially used by both groups include n-3 fatty acids, Se and folic acid. Four dimensions are identified and discussed: effectiveness; safety; communication; medico-legal aspects. These dimensions have to be addressed in an illness- and case-specific context. This task can be complex given the emerging clinical evidence, patients' own preferences and expectations and current prescribing guidelines.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Routine vitamin supplementation to prevent cardiovascular disease: a summary of the evidence for the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force
document.publisher: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,CONDITIONS C,FEBRUARY 2008,VITAMINS,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,VITAMIN E,VITAMIN A,BETA-CAROTENE,VITAMIN C,FOLIC ACID,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Morris CD, Carson S. Routine vitamin supplementation to prevent cardiovascular disease: a summary of the evidence for the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force. 2003:27. Rockville, MD, USA: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality.

Authors' objectives

To assess the evidence of the effectiveness of vitamin supplementation, specifically vitamins A, C, and E; beta-carotene; folic acid; antioxidant combinations; and multivitamin supplements, in preventing cardiovascular disease.

Authors' conclusions

Some good-quality cohort studies have reported an association between the use of vitamin supplements and lower risk for cardiovascular disease. Randomized, controlled trials of specific supplements, however, have failed to demonstrate a consistent or significant effect of any single vitamin or combination of vitamins on incidence of or death from cardiovascular disease. Understanding the sources of these differences will permit researchers to better analyze the cohort study data and to better design long-term clinical trials.

 

]]>

document.title: S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) as treatment for depression: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS D-E,DEPRESSION,SAME (S-ADENOSYL-L-METHIONINE),NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,OTHER SUPPLEMENTS,DATE ADDED,DECEMBER 2008]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Williams AL, Girard C, Jui D, Sabina A, Katz DL. S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) as treatment for depression: a systematic review. Clininical and Investigative Medicine. 2005, 28(3):132-9.

Authors' objectives

To assess the evidence evaluating S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) supplementation as treatment for depression. 

Authors' conclusions

All of the studies reviewed were short term, making translation to the clinical setting difficult. However, there appears to be a role for SAMe in the treatment of major depression in adults. Questions remain about mechanism of action, bioavailability, and absorption of oral SAMe. Further study of SAMe as independent and adjuvant therapy for major depression in adults is indicated.

document.title: Safety and efficacy of blue cohosh (Caulophyllum thalictroides) during pregnancy and lactation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBS A-C,CONDITIONS I-L,CONDITIONS P-R,PREGNANCY,LABOUR,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED,SAFETY,BLUE COHOSH (CAULOPHYLLUM THALICTROIDES),OCTOBER 2009,2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Dugoua JJ, Perri D, Seely D, Mills E, Koren G. Safety and efficacy of blue cohosh (Caulophyllum thalictroides) during pregnancy and lactation. Canadian Journal of Clinical Pharmacology. 2008, 15(1):e66-73.

Authors' objectives

To systematically review the literature for evidence on the use, safety and pharmacology of blue cohosh, focusing on issues pertaining to pregnancy and lactation. 

Authors' conclusions

Based on the available scientific information, blue cohosh should; 1) be used with extreme caution during pregnancy, 2) be used only under medical professional supervision and 3) not be available to the public as an over-the-counter product. There is an urgent need to conduct a retrospective or prospective cohort study of midwifes using blue cohosh in order to determine its safety.

 

]]>

document.title: Safety and efficacy of chastetree (Vitex agnus-castus) during pregnancy and lactation
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,PREGNANCY,CONDITIONS P-R,CHASTE TREE (VITEX AGNUS CASTUS),HERBS A-C,OCTOBER 2009,SAFETY,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Authors' objectives

To systematically review the literature for evidence on the use, safety and pharmacology of chastetree, focusing on issues pertaining to pregnancy and lactation. 

Authors' conclusions

Given its relatively common use amongst women of childbearing age, it is likely that some women may consume chastetree while unknowingly pregnant. Complementary and alternative medicine, midwifery and medical practitioners should be aware of this fact when prescribing chastetree to women of childbearing age, particularly when the patient is planning a family.

 

]]>

Authors' objectives

To systematically review the literature for evidence on the use, safety and pharmacology of cranberry, focusing on issues pertaining to pregnancy and lactation. 

Authors' conclusions

Women experience urinary tract infections with greater frequency during pregnancy. Given the evidence to support the use of cranberry for urinary tract infections (UTIs) and its safety profile, cranberry supplementation as fruit or fruit juice may be a valuable therapeutic choice in the treatment of UTIs during pregnancy.

document.title: Safety and efficacy of massage therapy for patients with cancer
document.publisher: H. Lee Moffitt Cancer Center and Research Institute
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,MASSAGE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,MARCH 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Corbin L. Safety and efficacy of massage therapy for patients with cancer. Cancer Control. 2005 Jul;12(3):158-64.

Authors' objectives

This article reviews and summarizes the literature on massage and cancer to help provide the clinician with information to help facilitate discussions with patients. 

Authors' conclusions

Conventional care for patients with cancer can safely incorporate massage therapy, although cancer patients may be at higher risk of rare adverse events. The strongest evidence for benefits of massage is for stress and anxiety reduction, although research for pain control and management of other symptoms common to patients with cancer, including pain, is promising. The oncologist should feel comfortable discussing massage therapy with patients and be able to refer patients to a qualified massage therapist as appropriate.

]]>

Dugoua JJ, Mills E, Perri D, Koren G. Safety and efficacy of St. John's wort (Hypericum) during pregnancy and lactation. Canadian Journal of Clinical Pharmacology. 2006;13(3):e268-e276.

Authors' objectives

To systematically review the literature for evidence on the use, safety, and pharmacology of St. John's wort focusing on issues pertaining to pregnancy and lactation. 

Authors' conclusions

Caution is warranted with the use of St John's wort during pregnancy until further high quality human research is conducted to determine its safety. St John's wort use during lactation appears to be of minimal risk, but may cause side effects. Caution is warranted when using medications along with St John's wort.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Safety considerations and potential interactions of vitamins: should vitamins be considered drugs?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY,VITAMINS,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,JANUARY 2011]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Rogovik AL, Vohra S, Goldman RD. Safety considerations and potential interactions of vitamins: should vitamins be considered drugs? Annals of Pharmacotherapy. 2010, 44(2):311-24.

Authors' objectives

To examine adverse effects, adverse events, and potential interactions of vitamins in light of their current prevalence of use, and to discuss whether vitamins should be considered over-the-counter drugs or natural health products/dietary supplements.

Authors' conclusions

The authors' recommendation is that vitamins A, E, D, folic acid, and niacin should be categorized as over-the-counter medications. Labeling of vitamins, especially those intended for children and other vulnerable groups, should include information on possible toxicities, dosing, recommended upper intake limits, and concurrent use with other products. Vitamin A should be excluded from multivitamin supplements and food fortificants.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.title: Safety issues in the preparation of homeopathic medicines
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HOMEOPATHY,SAFETY,REGULATION,CAM GENERAL,MARCH 2010]]>
document.body:
This technical document is WHO’s response to requests and recommendations made by relevant World Health Assembly resolutions, by Member States, as well as international conferences of drug regulatory authorities, and is a part of the implementation of the WHO Traditional Medicine Strategy and the WHO Medicines Strategy.

It aims to provide guidance to Member States on technical aspects of the production and manufacture of homeopathic medicines that potentially have implications for their safety. This is of relevance for establishing national quality standards and specifications for homeopathic medicines, as well as for controlling their quality. The document, however, does not address issues of efficacy or clinical utilization.

The full document is available to download [pdf 7.34Mb]. 

]]>

Authors' objectives

This qualitative review analyzes systematically the safety of drugs used to alleviate menopausal symptoms, other than hormone replacement therapy, in breast cancer patients.

Authors' conclusions

There are no valuable data indicating the absence of a harmful effect of drugs used to alleviate climacteric symptoms in breast cancer patients. There is a need for randomized trials to assess the safety of these drugs. In the meantime, patients should be informed about the absence of safety data.

document.title: Safety of green tea extracts : a systematic review by the US Pharmacopeia
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,TEA (CAMELLIA SINENSIS),HERBS R-Z,JANUARY 2010,SAFETY,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:

Citation

Sarma DN, Barrett ML, Chavez ML, Gardiner P, Ko R, Mahady GB, Marles RJ, Pellicore LS, Giancaspro GI, Low Dog T. Safety of green tea extracts : a systematic review by the US Pharmacopeia. Drug Safety. 2008, 31(6):469-84.

Authors' objectives

To carry out a systematic review of the the safety information for green tea products in order to re-evaluate the current safety class to which these products are assigned.

Authors' conclusions

Based on this safety review, the the US Pharmacopeia (USP) Dietary Supplement Information Expert Committee (DSI EC) determined that when dietary supplement products containing green tea extracts are used and formulated appropriately the Committee is unaware of significant safety issues that would prohibit monograph development, provided a caution statement is included in the labelling section. Following this decision, USP's DSI ECs may develop monographs for green tea extracts, and USP may offer its verification programmes related to that dietary ingredient.

Link to the full text of the systematic review

Authors' objectives

To provide a qualitative systematic review of the risk of spinal manipulation in the treatment of lumbar disk herniations (LDH) and to estimate the risk of spinal manipulation causing a severe adverse reaction in a patient presenting with LDH.

Authors' conclusions

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Safety of traditional arab herbal medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,SEPTEMBER 2010,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY]]>
document.body:
Citation

Saad B, Azaizeh H, Abu-Hijleh G, Said O. Safety of traditional arab herbal medicine. Evidence-based Complementary and Alternative Medicine. 2006, 3(4):433-9.

Abstract

Herbal remedies are widely used for the treatment and prevention of various diseases and often contain highly active pharmacological compounds. Many medicinal herbs and pharmaceutical drugs are therapeutic at one dose and toxic at another. Toxicity related to traditional medicines is becoming more widely recognized as these remedies become popular in the Mediterranean region as well as worldwide. Most reports concerning the toxic effects of herbal medicines are associated with hepatotoxicity although reports of other toxic effects including kidney, nervous system, blood, cardiovascular and dermatologic effects, mutagenicity and carcinogenicity have also been published in the medical literature. This article presents a systematic review on safety of traditional Arab medicine and the contribution of Arab scholars to toxicology. Use of modern cell biological, biochemical, in vitro and in vivo techniques for the evaluation of medicinal plants safety is also discussed.

]]>

Authors' objectives

This systematic review discusses the proposed uses, dosing parameters, adverse effects, toxicology, interactions and mechanism of action of kava. 

Authors' conclusions

A recommendation is made to consolidate and analyse available reports and to continue postmarket surveillance in an international repository to prevent duplicates and promote collection of thorough details at the time of each report so that any association with kava is clearly defined.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Searching biomedical databases on complementary medicine: the use of controlled vocabulary among authors, indexers and investigators
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED,SEPTEMBER 2007,RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
Citation

Murphy LS, Reinsch S, Najm WI, Dickerson VM, Seffinger MA, Adams A, Mishra SI. Searching biomedical databases on complementary medicine: the use of controlled vocabulary among authors, indexers and investigators. BMC Complementary and Alternative Medicine. 2003, 3:3.

Background

The optimal retrieval of a literature search in biomedicine depends on the appropriate use of Medical Subject Headings (MeSH), descriptors and keywords among authors and indexers. We hypothesized that authors, investigators and indexers in four biomedical databases are not consistent in their use of terminology in Complementary and Alternative Medicine (CAM). 

Authors' conclusions

Searching biomedical databases for CAM is challenging due to inconsistent use of controlled vocabulary and indexing procedures in different databases. A standard terminology should be used by investigators in conducting their search strategies and authors when writing titles, abstracts and submitting keywords for publications.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Searching multiple databases for systematic reviews: added value or diminishing returns?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,RESEARCH,SEPTEMBER 2007,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:
Citation

Stevinson C, Lawlor DA. Searching multiple databases for systematic reviews: added value or diminishing returns? Complementary Therapies in Medicine. 2004, 12(4):228-32.

Authors' objectives

To explore whether searching specialised bibliographic databases identified additional relevant papers to those located by a Medline search for a systematic review of exercise therapy.

Authors' conclusions

In this example, searching Medline and additional specialised databases along with checking reference lists and contacting experts was the most effective means of ensuring that all relevant papers were included in the review. Searching Medline alone for systematic reviews of exercise or other unconventional therapies is likely to be inadequate.

Access

Full-text online access to this article is available to NHS staff via ATHENS password.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Self-help interventions for depressive disorders and depressive symptoms: A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,CONDITIONS A-Z,ST JOHN'S WORT (HYPERICUM PERFORATUM),CONDITIONS D-E,RELAXATION TECHNIQUES,DEPRESSION,LIGHT THERAPY,HERBS R-Z,OCTOBER 2008,DATE ADDED,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,OTHER SUPPLEMENTS,SAME (S-ADENOSYL-L-METHIONINE)]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Morgan AJ, Jorm AF. Self-help interventions for depressive disorders and depressive symptoms: A systematic review. Annals of General Psychiatry. 2008, 7(1):13. 

Authors' objectives

To review the evidence for self-help interventions for depressive symptoms with the aim of identifying promising interventions that could inform future health promotion campaigns or stimulate further research.

Authors' conclusions

A number of self-help interventions have promising evidence for reducing subthreshold depressive symptoms. Other forms of evidence such as expert consensus may be more appropriate for interventions that are not feasible to evaluate in randomised controlled trials. There needs to be evaluation of whether promotion to the public of effective self-help strategies for subthreshold depressive symptoms could delay or prevent onset of depressive illness, reduce functional impairment, and prevent progression to other undesirable outcomes such as harmful use of substances.

]]>

document.title: Self-management strategies to reduce pain and improve function among older adults in community settings: a review of the evidence
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,MASSAGE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,YOGA,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS P-R,CONDITIONS M-O,PAIN,MUSIC THERAPY,TAI CHI,MUSCULOSKELETAL DISEASES,DECEMBER 2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Reid MC, Papaleontiou M, Ong A, Breckman R, Wethington E, Pillemer K. Self-management strategies to reduce pain and improve function among older adults in community settings: a review of the evidence. Pain Medicine. 2008, 9(4):409-24.

Authors' objectives

To review the evidence regarding self-management interventions for pain due to musculoskeletal disorders among older adults. 

Authors' conclusions

The results suggest that a broad range of self-management programs may provide benefits for older adults with chronic pain. Research is needed to establish the efficacy of the programs in diverse age and ethnic groups of older adults and identify strategies that maximize program reach, retention, and methods to ensure continued use of the strategies over time.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

Citation

Shin B-C, Lee M S, Park T-Y, Ernst E: Serious adverse events after spinal manipulation: a systematic review of the Korean literature. Focus on Alternative and Complementary Therapies. 2010, 15:198–201.

Authors' objectives

The aim of this systematic review was to summarise adverse effects after spinal manipulation reported in the South Korean literature. 

Authors' conclusions

It is concluded that adverse effects after spinal manipulation are not specific to chiropractic but occur with most types of spinal manipulation. Incidence figures can, however, not be derived from the data available to date.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Shengmai injection for hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS M-O,TRADITIONAL CHINESE MEDICINE (TCM),FEBRUARY 2010,NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Wu M, Li G, Shen Q. Shengmai injection for hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy: a systematic review . Chinese Journal of Evidence-Based Medicine 2008; 8(3): 190-195.

Authors' objectives

To evaluate the efficacy and safety of Shengmai injection for hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE).

Authors' conclusions

Shengmai injection has certain therapeutic values in treating HIE. Shengmai injection can speed up the recovery ECG, CK-BM and CK-BB of HIE patients, especially in those who have myocardial damage. Shengmai injection can also improve the NBNA score. However, because of the low statistical power and high risks for selection bias, performance bias and measurement bias in the included trials, these conclusions need to be interpreted cautiously.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Sitting-meditation interventions among youth: a review of treatment efficacy
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,OTHER THERAPIES OR MEDICAL SYSTEMS,MEDITATION,MINDFULNESS-BASED STRESS REDUCTION (MBSR),SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Black DS, Milam J, Sussman S. Sitting-meditation interventions among youth: a review of treatment efficacy. Pediatrics. 2009 Sep;124(3):e532-41.

Authors' objectives

Although the efficacy of meditation interventions has been examined among adult samples, meditation treatment effects among youth are relatively unknown. We systematically reviewed empirical studies for the health-related effects of sitting-meditative practices implemented among youth aged 6 to 18 years in school, clinic, and community settings.

Authors' conclusions

Sitting meditation seems to be an effective intervention in the treatment of physiologic, psychosocial, and behavioral conditions among youth. Because of current limitations, carefully constructed research is needed to advance our understanding of sitting meditation and its future use as an effective treatment modality among younger populations.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Soy isoflavones lower serum total and LDL cholesterol in humans: a meta-analysis of 11 randomized controlled trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,HIGH CHOLESTEROL,CONDITIONS F-H,SOY,DECEMBER 2008,FOOD AND BEVERAGES,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Taku K, Umegaki K, Sato Y, Taki Y, Endoh K, Watanabe S. Soy isoflavones lower serum total and LDL cholesterol in humans: a meta-analysis of 11 randomized controlled trials. American Journal of Clinical Nutrition. 2007, 85(4): 1148-1156.

Authors' objectives

This meta-analysis was primarily conducted to evaluate the precise effects of soy isoflavones on lipid profiles. The effects of soy protein that contains enriched and depleted isoflavones were also examined.

Authors' conclusions

Soy isoflavones significantly reduced serum total and LDL cholesterol but did not change HDL cholesterol and triacylglycerol. Soy protein that contained enriched or depleted isoflavones also significantly improved lipid profiles. Reductions in LDL cholesterol were larger in hypercholesterolemic than in normocholesterolemic subjects. 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Spinal manipulation for low back and neck pain: 2008 Annual evidence update
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,CHIROPRACTIC,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,COMPLEMENTARY/ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,SPINAL PROBLEMS,CONDITIONS A-B,CONDITIONS M-O,BACK PAIN,NECK PAIN,SEPTEMBER 2008,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
111-1Spinal manipulation for low back and neck pain: 2008 Annual evidence update

Prof Alan Breen, Anglo-European College of Chiropractic


Introduction

This commentary covers the topic of spinal manipulation for low back pain. In view of the recent WHO Task Force review on Whiplash and Related Disorders, we have also included its conclusions on spinal manipulation for neck pain.


Summary of findings

Most guidelines and reviews up to June 2007 support spinal manipulation for use in an evidence-based package of care for patients who are not recovering from episodes of low back pain, provided the therapy is delivered by professionals with competent skills. Subsequent reviews consolidate this, finding manipulation to be moderately effective in the sub-acute and chronic stages, and when the acute stage does not respond to simple evidence-based approaches.

For neck pain, the efficacy of manipulation was found to be greater than that of the therapies to which it was compared, and similar to mobilisation. The very rare vertebro-basilar stroke was found to be no more likely after a chiropractic visit than after a physician visit for neck pain or headache.


Low back pain

Only one evidence-based guideline has been published on non-pharmacologic interventions for low back pain in this review period.1 This recommends the use of spinal manipulation as having good evidence of moderate efficacy for subacute and chronic low back pain, but found no good evidence for its efficacy in the acute stage.  One subsequent trial2 found that neither manipulation nor diclofenac improved outcomes more than advice and paracetamol in patients with back pain under 6 weeks’ duration.

For chronic back pain, an updated systematic review of 25 trials up to the end of 20063 found strong evidence of manipulation having equivalence to medical care with exercise instruction. There was moderate evidence of superiority to general practice care and equivalence to physical therapy. This review also reported limited evidence of superiority over physical therapy with home exercise and over hospital outpatient care, medication, acupuncture and chemonucleolysis (the latter for disc herniation). A further review4,  found medication-assisted manipulation not to be supported.

In order to try to further assist effective targeting of manipulative treatment, attempts have been made to develop prediction rules to try to identify the patients likely to benefit the most from manipulation.5 However, these are thought to still lack substantial validation.6 Known prognostic factors, with the exception of co-morbidity, do not seem to have predictive effects on back pain outcomes in patients receiving care that includes manipulation.7,8


Neck pain

The Neck Pain Task Force of the World Health Organisation collated the evidence to inform clinical practice about the management of neck pain and its associated disorders.9 It also completed original research on the risks associated with the treatment of neck pain. For non-whiplash associated neck pain without radiculopathy, the Task Force found that therapies involving manual therapy and exercise were more effective than alternative strategies for patients with neck pain, including therapies which include educational interventions addressing self-efficacy. Of the manual therapies however, manipulation and mobilisation yielded comparable clinical outcomes.10


Safety of neck manipulation

The Task Force also reported on vertebro-basilar strokes, which are extremely rare, but have been reported to be associated with chiropractic visits. This association was found to be similar to physician visits, suggesting that such patients may have actually been in the prodromal phase of a stroke when consulting. There was no evidence of excess risk of vertebro-basilar stroke associated with chiropractic care compared to primary care.11 However, the risk of minor transient adverse effects appears to be higher with cervical manipulation than with mobilisation. The report concluded that the choice between manipulation and mobilisation should depend on patient preference.10 


References:


1. Chou R, Huffman LH. Nonpharmacologic therapies for acute and chronic low back pain: a review of the evidence for an American Pain Society/American College of Physicians clinical practice guideline. Annals of Internal Medicine. 2007, 147(7):492-504. [Full text]


2. Hancock MJ, Maher CG, Latimer J, McLachlan AJ, Cooper CW, Day RO, et al. Assessment of diclofenac or spinal manipulative therapy, or both, in addition to recommended first-line treatment for acute low back pain: a randomised controlled trial. Lancet. 2007, 370:1638-43. [PubMed abstract]


3. Bronfort G, Haas M, Evans R, Kawchuk G, Dagenais S. Evidence-informed management of chronic low back pain with spinal manipulation and mobilization. Spine Journal. 2008, 8(1):213-25. [Full text on journal website] 


4. Dagenais S, Mayer J, Wooley JR, Haldeman S. Evidence-informed management of chronic low back pain with medicine-assisted manipulation. Spine Journal. 2008, 8(1):142-9. [Full text on journal website] 


5. Childs JD, Fritz JM, Flynn TW, Irrgang JJ, Johnson KK, Majkowski GR, Delitto A. A clinical prediction rule to identify patients with low back pain most likely to benefit from spinal manipulation: a validation study. Annals of Internal Medicine. 2004, 141(12):920-8. [Full text]


6. Hancock MJ, Maher CG, Latimer J, Herbert RD, McAuley JH. Independent evaluation of a clinical prediction rule for spinal manipulative therapy: a randomised controlled trial. European Spine Journal. 2008, 17(7):936-43. [PubMed abstract]


7. Underwood MR, Morton V, Farrin A. Do baseline characteristics predict response to treatment for low back pain? Secondary analysis of the UK BEAM dataset [ISRCTN32683578]. Rheumatology (Oxford) 2007, 46(8):1297-302. [PubMed abstract]


8. Langworthy JM, Breen AC. Psychosocial factors and their predictive value in chiropractic patients with low back pain: a prospective inception cohort study. Chiropractic & Osteopathy. 2007, Mar 29;15:5. [Full text]


9. Lidgren L. Preface: Neck pain and the decade of the bone and joint 2000-2010. Spine. 2008, 33(4S): p. S1-S2.


10. Hurwitz EL, Carragee EJ, van der Velde G, Carroll L J, Nordin M, Guzman J, Peloso PM, Holm LW, Cote P, Hogg-Johnson S, Cassidy J D, Haldeman S. Treatment of neck pain: Noninvasive interventions: results of the Bone and Joint Decade 2000-2010 Task Force on Neck Pain and Its Associated Disorders. Spine. 2008, 33(4S) Neck Pain Task Force(Supplement): p. S123-S152. [Abstract on journal website]


11. Cassidy JD, Boyle E, Cote P, He Y, Hogg-Johnson S, Silver F L, Bondy S J. Risk of vertebrobasilar stroke and chiropractic care: Results of a population-based case-control and case-crossover study. Spine. 2008, 33(4S) Neck Pain Task Force(Supplement): p. S176-S183. [Abstract on journal website]

 

Link back to 2008 Annual evidence update on CAM for low back pain 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Spinal manipulation for low back pain
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CHIROPRACTIC,CONDITIONS A-Z,SPINAL PROBLEMS,CONDITIONS,MUSCULOSKELETAL,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,COMPLEMENTARY/ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,CONDITIONS A-B,BACK PAIN,PAIN,CONDITIONS P-R,DATE ADDED,SEPTEMBER 2007,2007]]>
document.body:
111-1Spinal manipulation for low back pain

National Knowledge Week on CAM for Low Back Pain 2007

Prof Alan Breen, Anglo-European College of Chiropractic

Contents

  • Summary of Findings
  • Acute Low Back Pain
  • Chronic Low Back Pain
  • Prevention of Back Pain
  • Safety of Spinal Manipulation for Low Back Pain
  • Further Studies

Summary of Findings


Most guidelines1 and reviews support very few treatments for non-specific low back pain; however, spinal manipulation is one that is usually identified as being adequately supported by evidence. Manipulation is generally not supported as a mono-therapy as, in common with other recommended treatments, it does not have large long-term effects in populations. It is therefore recommended as part of an evidence-based bio-psychosocial package of care for patients who are not recovering from acute or chronic low back pain. However, there is also evidence that it may add to this package, both in the short and long term. Due to lack of evidence, it is not recommended for the secondary prevention of low back pain.


Acute Low Back Pain


The European Guidelines are primarily aimed at general practice and the main context of their recommendations is non-specific back pain.1 The evidence upon which the recommendation concerning manipulation was based came from 6 systematic reviews and one recent Cochrane Review2 that included 17 RCTs on acute back pain. 


The European Guidelines recommend 5 treatment approaches, plus referral for spinal manipulation for episodes of up to 12 weeks duration. The other approaches are: information and reassurance, advice to stay active, avoidance of bed rest, simple analgesics if necessary for pain relief and multidisciplinary treatment programmes.  Spinal manipulation and multidisciplinary treatment programmes are specifically recommended for patients who are failing to return to normal activities, and in the latter case, for workers who have been on sick leave for more than 4-8 weeks. These are the only interventions, out of many common treatments, that the Acute Guideline recommends.


A further Australian MRC Guideline3 found conflicting evidence of manipulation being any more effective than placebo in the first 4 weeks of an episode. One further review4 found moderate evidence that manipulation provides more short-term pain relief for acute back pain than mobilisation, but limited evidence of faster recovery than the commonly used physical therapy treatments. A second systematic review and meta-analysis5 of 27 trials found that it produced slightly better outcomes at under 3 months but, again, little difference to exercise, usual physiotherapy and medical care in the first 4 weeks. These sources support the contention that, at least in the long term, spinal manipulation is probably more useful when there is non-recovery with initial advice, information and pain control.  However, one recent randomised trial6 found that using manual therapy added benefit to the 6-week results from advice alone in acute back pain. 
 
Evidence is lacking of the effectiveness of spinal manipulation for nerve root pain.  One systematic review4 found limited evidence of it being more effective than chemonucleolysis. It also found mobilisation to be inferior to exercise in patients recovering from disc herniation surgery.  One recent RCT of chiropractic manipulation for back pain and sciatica with disc protrusion7 found manipulation to be more effective than sham manipulation for pain reduction at 180-day follow-up.


Chronic Low Back Pain

Based on an extensive literature review in 2001, the European Guidelines1 on chronic back pain stress that no intervention has a large effect, probably because chronic back pain is generally of a low grade and there not the scope to show large improvement for any treatment with the current standard outcome measures.  However, there is strong evidence that manipulation is similar to GP care with analgesics. There is also moderate evidence that adding it to enhanced GP care is more effective than enhanced GP care alone.  The latter conclusion is supported by the large UK BEAM trial8, which was designed specifically to answer this question. This found manipulation to be effective and cost-effective when used within an evidence-based package of care9 when added to GP care that has been enhanced with specific education on back pain management.


The European Chronic Guideline recommends short courses of manipulation and NSAIDs, but exercise is recommended to be the mainstay of treatment.  It also recommends cognitive-behavioural therapies and a brief educational intervention by an individual health practitioner.  If this is not helpful, the recommendation is for behavioural therapy to encourage return to normal activity, and/or multidisciplinary rehabilitation to assist return to work. These are the only interventions recommended by the Guideline.  A recent Belgian guideline10 on acute low back pain reviewed the evidence and considered the existing national guidelines, but did not mention manipulation in its recommendations.


Prevention of Back Pain


The context of prevention in the European Guideline is around the consequences (e.g. distress, disability, work loss) of having what is considered to be a common life event that should normally be isolated, non-persistent, not severe and manageable by the individual unaided. As is the case for chronic non-specific back pain, the currently recommended mainstay for prevention is physical exercise generally. There is insufficient evidence to recommend any other approach (including manipulation) apart from multidimensional workplace interventions.  No subsequent randomised studies of manipulation for the prevention of back pain were found.


Safety of Spinal Manipulation for Low Back Pain


Evidence- based back pain guidelines generally regard manipulation (without general anaesthetic) for low back pain to be a safe procedure, based on the existing reviews.  One further narrative review that included prospective studies was found.11 This estimated the risk of causing a clinically worsened disk herniation or cauda equine syndrome to be very low.  


Further Studies


A systematic literature search for outcome studies of manual therapies published from 2002-2007 revealed 55 studies; 33 of which were randomised trials (see Methodology section). These reflect a shift of attention away from manipulation as a mono-therapy in general populations, to differences between types of manipulation, manipulation in combination with other therapies, manipulation compared with specific therapies and for subgroups of patients. The results of these trials were broadly consistent with the existing literature, but will need to be the subject of systematic review before summarisation of their evidence, or statistical pooling can occur.  


References


1. European Commission, C.B.M.C., COST B13: European Guidelines for the management of low back pain. European Spine Journal, 2006. 15(Supplement 2). [Full text available at: http://www.backpaineurope.org/index.html]


2. Assendelft WJJ, Morton SC, Yu Emily I, Suttorp MJ, Shekelle PG. Spinal manipulative therapy for low-back pain. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2004, Issue 1. Art. No.: CD000447. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD000447.pub2. [Full text] 


3. NHMRC, N.H.a.M.R.C.A.A.M.P.G.G., Evidence-based management of acute musculoskeletal pain. University of Queensland and the Commonwealth Department of Health and Ageing: Brisbane; 2003. p. 1-246. [Full text]


4. Bronfort G, Haas M, Evans RL, Bouter LM. Efficacy of spinal manipulation and mobilization for low back pain and neck pain: a systematic review and best evidence synthesis. Spine J. 2004, 4(3):335-56. [PubMed abstract]


5. Ferreira ML, Ferreira PH, Latimer J, Herbert R, Maher CG. Efficacy of spinal manipulative therapy for low back pain of less than three months' duration. Journal of Manipulative and Physiological Therapeutics. 2003, 26(9):593-601. [PubMed abstract] [DARE provisional record]


6. Wand BM, Bird C, McAuley JH, Dore CJ, MacDowell M, De Souza LH. Early intervention for the management of acute low back pain: a single-blind randomized controlled trial of biopsychosocial education, manual therapy, and exercise. Spine. 2004, 29(21):2350-6. [PubMed abstract]


7. Santilli V, Beghi E, Finucci S. Chiropractic manipulation in the treatment of acute back pain and sciatica with disc protrusion: a randomized double-blind clinical trial of active and simulated spinal manipulations. Spine J. 2006, 6(2):131-7. [PubMed abstract]


8. UK BEAM Trial Team. United Kingdom back pain exercise and manipulation (UK BEAM) randomised trial: effectiveness of physical treatments for back pain in primary care. BMJ. 2004, 329(7479):1377. [Full text]


9. UK BEAM Trial Team. United Kingdom back pain exercise and manipulation (UK BEAM) randomised trial: cost effectiveness of physical treatments for back pain in primary care. BMJ. 2004, 329(7479):1381-1385. [Full text] [NHS EED structured abstract].


10. Nielens H, V.Z.J., Mairiaux P, Gailly J, Van Den Hecke N, Mazina D, Camberlin C, Bartholomeeusen S, De Gauquier K, Paulus D and Ramaekers D, Chronic low back pain.  Good Clinical Practice (GCP). Belgian Health Care Knowledge Centre (KCE), 2006. KCE Report No. 48C (D/2006/10.273/71)(Study Number 2005-04). [Full text]


11. Oliphant D. Safety of spinal manipulation in the treatment of lumbar disk herniations: a systematic review and risk assessment. Journal of Manipulative and Physiological Therapeutics 2004;27:197-210. [PubMed abstract] [DARE provisional record]

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: St John's wort (Hypericum perforatum): drug interactions and clinical outcomes
document.topics: <![CDATA[ HERBAL MEDICINE,ST JOHN'S WORT (HYPERICUM PERFORATUM),COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBS R-Z,SAFETY,CAM GENERAL,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Henderson L, Yue QY, Bergquist C, Gerden B, Arlett P. St John's wort (Hypericum perforatum): drug interactions and clinical outcomes. British Journal of Clinical Pharmacology. 2002, 54(4):349-56. [Full text]

Authors' objectives

The aim of this work is to identify the medicines which interact with the herbal remedy St John's wort (SJW), and the mechanisms responsible.

Authors' conclusions

In Sweden and the UK the potential risks to patients were judged to be significant and therefore information about the interactions was provided to health care professionals and patients. The product information of the licensed medicines involved has been amended to reflect these newly identified interactions and SJW preparations have been voluntarily labelled with appropriate warnings.

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ST JOHN'S WORT (HYPERICUM PERFORATUM),HERBAL MEDICINE,HERBS R-Z,SEPTEMBER 2010,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Hammerness P, Basch E, Ulbricht C, Barrette EP, Foppa I, Basch S, Bent S, Boon H, Ernst E; Natural Standard Research Collaboration. St John's wort: a systematic review of adverse effects and drug interactions for the consultation psychiatrist. Psychosomatics. 2003, 44(4):271-82.

Abstract

St. John's wort is an herb commonly used in Europe for decades and more recently the topic of scientific investigation in this country. St. John's wort has been found more effective than placebo and equally as effective as tricyclic antidepressants in the short-term management of mild-to-moderate depression. Comparisons to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors have provided equivocal data. While it is generally well tolerated in clinical use, there is accumulating evidence of significant interactions with drugs. This evidence-based presentation of the literature includes a brief description of pharmacodynamics and clinical applications, followed by a systematic review of adverse effects, toxicity, and drug interactions.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.  

]]>
