document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Trends in access to complementary or alternative medicines via primary care in England: 1995-2001 results from a follow-up national survey
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,USE OF CAM,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED,JUNE 2007]]>
document.body:
Citation

Thomas KJ, Coleman P, Nicholl JP. Trends in access to complementary or alternative medicines via primary care in England: 1995-2001 results from a follow-up national survey. Family Practice. 2003, 20(5):575-7.

Authors' objectives

To assess the changes in the provision of CAM services in NHS primary care in England between 1995 and 2001.

Authors' conclusions

A prior national survey of one in eight randomly selected general practices in England estimated that 39% of general practices [95% confidence interval (CI) 35–43%] provided some access to complementary or alternative medicine (CAM) therapies in 1995. A repeat survey, conducted in 2001, estimated that one in two practices in England now offer their patients some access to CAMs (95% CI 46–52%). The change was due to increased provision in-house; the proportion of practices making NHS referrals remained unchanged. The proportion of services supported by patient payments rose from 26 to 42%.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Trends in use of complementary and alternative medicine by US adults: 1997-2002
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,JUNE 2007,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL,USE OF CAM]]>
document.body:
Citation

Tindle HA, Davis RB, Phillips RS, Eisenberg DM. Trends in use of complementary and alternative medicine by US adults: 1997-2002. Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine. 2005 Jan-Feb;11(1):42-9.

Authors' objectives

To compare CAM therapy use by US adults in 2002 and 1997. Two national surveys of CAM use by US adults were compared: (1) the Alternative Health/Complementary and Alternative Medicine supplement to the 2002 National Health Interview Survey (NHIS, N = 31,044) and (2) a 1997 national survey (N = 2055), each containing questions about 15 common CAM therapies.

Authors' conclusions

The prevalence of CAM use has remained stable from 1997 to 2002. Over one in three respondents used CAM in the past year, representing about 72 million US adults.

 

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Ukrain: a new cancer cure? A systematic review of randomised clinical trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY & ALTERNATIVE THERAPIES,SYMPTOM MANAGEMENT,CANCER,PALLIATIVE AND SUPPORTIVE CARE,CONDITIONS,CELANDINE (CHELIDONIUM MAJUS),JULY 2006,CONDITIONS C,CANCER,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD Reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Ernst E, Schmidt K. Ukrain: a new cancer cure? A systematic review of randomised clinical trials. BMC Cancer. 2005, 5: 69.

Authors' objectives

Ukrain is an anticancer drug based on the extract of the plant Chelidonium majus L. Numerous pre-clinical and clinical investigations seem to suggest that Ukrain is pharmacologically active and clinically effective. The authors's aim was to critically evaluate the clinical trial data in the form of a systematic review.

Authors' conclusions

The data from randomised clinical trials suggest Ukrain to have potential as an anticancer drug. However, numerous caveats prevent a positive conclusion, and independent rigorous studies are urgently needed.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Unconventional anticancer agents: a systematic review of clinical trials
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,HERBAL MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS C,CANCER,RESEARCH,SEPTEMBER 2007,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:
Citation

Vickers AJ, Kuo J, Cassileth BR. Unconventional anticancer agents: a systematic review of clinical trials. Journal of Clinical Oncology. 2006, 24(1):136-40.

Authors' objectives

A substantial number of cancer patients turn to treatments other than those recommended by mainstream oncologists in an effort to sustain tumor remission or halt the spread of cancer. These unconventional approaches include botanicals, high-dose nutritional supplementation, off-label pharmaceuticals, and animal products. The objective of this study was to review systematically the methodologies applied in clinical trials of unconventional treatments specifically for cancer.

Authors' conclusions

Unconventional cancer treatments have not been subject to appropriate early-phase trial development. Future research on unconventional therapies should involve dose-finding and phase II studies to determine the suitability of definitive trials.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Use and expenditure on complementary medicine in England: a population based survey
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,JUNE 2007,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL,USE OF CAM]]>
document.body:
Citation

Thomas KJ, Nicholl JP, Coleman P. Use and expenditure on complementary medicine in England: a population based survey. Complementary Therapies in Medicine. 2001, 9(1):2-11. 

Authors' objectives

Many claims are made that complementary medicine use is a substantial and growing part of health-care behaviour. Estimates of practitioner visits in the USA and Australia indicate high levels of use and expenditure. No reliable population-based estimates of practitioner use are available for the UK.

Authors' conclusions

This survey has demonstrated substantial use of practitioner-provided complementary therapies in England in 1998. The findings suggest that CAM is making a measurable contribution to first-contact primary care. However, we have shown that 90% of this provision is purchased privately. Further research into the cost-effectiveness of different CAM therapies for particular patient groups is now urgently needed to facilitate equal and appropriate access via the NHS.

]]>

document.title: Use of antioxidant supplements during breast cancer treatment: a comprehensive review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,CANCER,CONDITIONS A-B,CONDITIONS C,BREAST CANCER,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED,USE OF CAM,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,DECEMBER 2009,2009]]>
document.body:
Citation

Greenlee H, Hershman DL, Jacobson JS. Use of antioxidant supplements during breast cancer treatment: a comprehensive review. Breast Cancer Research and Treatment 2009; 115(3): 437-452.

Authors' objectives

To conduct a comprehensive review of literature on the associations between antioxidant supplement use during breast cancer treatment and patient outcomes. 

Authors' conclusions

The evidence is currently insufficient to inform clinician and patient guidelines on the use of antioxidant supplements during breast cancer treatment. Thus, well designed clinical trials and observational studies are needed to determine the short- and long-term effects of such agents.

Access

111-1Use of CAM for Low Back Pain: Surveys

National Knowledge Week on CAM for Low Back Pain 2007


The following large-scale, national surveys contain data on the use of CAM for low back pain:

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Use of complementary and alternative medicine by cancer patients: systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS C,CANCER,MARCH 2009,USE OF CAM,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
Citation

Spadacio C, Barros NF. Use of complementary and alternative medicine by cancer patients: systematic review. Rev Saude Publica. 2008, 42(1):158-64.

Authors' objectives

A systematic literature review of the profile of patients who choose to use this type of medicine, as well as their motivations, was carried out on the PubMed database.

Authors' conclusions

From the 43 articles analyzed, it could be concluded that the use of complementary and alternative medicine is part of these patients' social scope. Moreover, its use plays an important role in the identity construction of cancer patients, helping them to make decisions related to conventional treatment.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Use of complementary and alternative medicine in Germany - a survey of patients with inflammatory bowel disease
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS I-L,MAY 2007,INFLAMMATORY BOWEL DISEASE,USE OF CAM,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL]]>
document.body:
Citation

Joos S, Rosemann T, Szecsenyi J, Hahn EG, Willich SN, Brinkhaus B. Use of complementary and alternative medicine in Germany - a survey of patients with inflammatory bowel disease. BMC Complementary and Alternative Medicine. 2006, 6:19.

Authors' objectives

The aim of our study was to evaluate the use of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) in German patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

Authors' conclusions

The use of CAM in IBD patients is very common in Germany, although a large proportion of patients felt that information about CAM is not sufficient. However, to provide an evidence-based approach more research in this field is desperately needed. Therefore, physicians should increasingly inform IBD patients about benefits and limitations of CAM treatment.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Use of complementary and alternative medicine in patients with cancer: a UK survey
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,USE OF CAM,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED,JUNE 2007]]>
document.body:
Citation

Scott JA, Kearney N, Hummerston S, Molassiotis A. Use of complementary and alternative medicine in patients with cancer: a UK survey. European Journal of Oncology Nursing. 2005, 9(2):131-7.

Authors' objectives

Over the past decade Complementary and Alternative Medicine (CAM) use in the UK has increased dramatically. However, little research appears to exist regarding its use in patients diagnosed with cancer. The study was descriptive using a survey design.

Authors' conclusions

CAM use was reported by 29% of the sample. The use of relaxation, meditation and the use of medicinal teas were the most frequently used therapies. Findings suggest that CAM use within patients diagnosed with cancer in the UK has increased which has implications for patient and health care professional education.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Use of complementary and alternative therapies by patients with self-reported chronic back pain: a nationwide survey in Canada
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,BACK PAIN,PAIN,CONDITIONS A-B,CONDITIONS P-R,CAM GENERAL,USE OF CAM,DATE ADDED,OCTOBER 2007]]>
document.body:
Citation

Foltz V, St Pierre Y, Rozenberg S, Rossignol M, Bourgeois P, Joseph L, et al. Use of complementary and alternative therapies by patients with self-reported chronic back pain: a nationwide survey in Canada. Joint Bone Spine. 2005, 72(6):571-7.

Authors' objectives

Complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) is gaining popularity among patients with chronic back pain. We looked for factors associated with CAM use. 

Authors' conclusions

The results show that patients with chronic back pain who use CAM are more active, more involved in social life, and healthier, suggesting better management of their condition. They use CAM in addition to, rather than instead of, conventional care. CAM use in these patients may be ascribable to dissatisfaction with mainstream physicians.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Use of complementary or alternative medicine in a general population in Great Britain. Results from the National Omnibus survey
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,JUNE 2007,DATE ADDED,CAM GENERAL,USE OF CAM]]>
document.body:
Citation

Thomas K, Coleman P. Use of complementary or alternative medicine in a general population in Great Britain. Results from the National Omnibus survey. Journal of Public Health (Oxf). 2004, 26(2):152-7.

Authors' objectives

To estimate levels of use of complementary or alternative medicines (CAMs) by adults in England, Scotland and Wales and their socio-economic correlates.

Authors' conclusions

Strong correlations between the use of CAM and gross socio-economic indicators are demonstrated in the survey. Repeated national surveys of this type could provide a useful vehicle for collecting information about changing patterns of CAM use on a routine basis.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Use of the best case series to evaluate complementary and alternative therapies for cancer: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,CAM GENERAL,DATE ADDED,SEPTEMBER 2007,RESEARCH]]>
document.body:
Citation

Nahin RL. Use of the best case series to evaluate complementary and alternative therapies for cancer: a systematic review. Seminars in Oncology. 2002, 29(6):552-62.

Authors' objectives

The best case series (BCS) is a retrospective chart review that describes a series of patients who all appear to have benefitted from the treatment under study. The BCS has been advocated as the first research step for evaluating complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) treatments for cancer. However, the research value of the BCS has not been assessed. To address this deficiency, the present study evaluates the primary characteristics of the BCS process through a systematic review of the English language scientific literature.

Authors' conclusions

The primary factors confounding the identified BCS were lack of documentation of disease and/or the use of concurrent or recent conventional treatment. Despite these general deficiencies, four BCS (antineoplastons, hydrazine sulfate, laetrile, and Kelly-Gonzalez) were sufficiently convincing to warrant follow-up clinical trials. These data suggest that while well-documented BCS do have an impact on the research agenda, in general, additional rigor is needed during their compilation.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Usefulness of omega-3 fatty acids and the prevention of coronary heart disease
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CORONARY HEART DISEASE,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,CONDITIONS C,LIPIDS,JANUARY 2008,MONTHLY ADDITIONS,2008-JULY,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS,MANAGEMENT & INTERVENTIONS,POPULATION BASED & PREVENTATIVE SERVICES,SERVICES,CIRCULATORY DISEASES,CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES,PUBLIC HEALTH,OUTCOMES,FOOD & NUTRITION,DETERMINANTS,OMEGA-3 FATTY ACIDS,FISH OILS,DATE ADDED]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Harper CR, Jacobson TA. Usefulness of omega-3 fatty acids and the prevention of coronary heart disease. American Journal of Cardiology. 2005;96(11):1521-1529. [Full text]

Authors' objectives

To review systematically previously published reports assessing the different types of omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid interventions and cardiovascular outcomes.

Authors' conclusions

In conclusion, the evidence suggests a role for fish oil (eicosapentaenoic acid, docosahexaenoic acid) or fish in secondary prevention because recent clinical trial data have demonstrated a significant reduction in total mortality, coronary heart disease death, and sudden death. The data on alpha-linolenic acid have been limited by studies of smaller sample size and limited quality.

 

]]>

Authors' objectives

To determine the efficacy of intervention with high-dose vitamin A as an adjunct to standard treatment on outcome in acute lower respiratory tract infection in children in developing countries.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Vitamin and mineral supplement use among US adults after cancer diagnosis: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,CONDITIONS C,CANCER,CAM GENERAL,MARCH 2009,USE OF CAM,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Velicer CM, Ulrich CM. Vitamin and mineral supplement use among US adults after cancer diagnosis: a systematic review.  J Clin Oncol. 2008 Feb 1;26(4):665-73.

Authors' objectives

Vitamin and mineral supplement use is thought to be common among the 10 million adults in the United States who have been diagnosed with cancer; however, well-conducted studies of this topic are sparse. Moreover, the biologic effects of supplement use among cancer survivors are not well established and not necessarily beneficial. We present a systematic summary of studies published between 1999 and 2006, 32 in total, addressing vitamin and mineral supplement use among US adult cancer patients and survivors.

Authors' conclusions

Supplement use is widespread among cancer patients and longer-term survivors. In studies combining different cancer sites, 64% to 81% of survivors reported using any vitamin or mineral supplements and 26% to 77% reported using any multivitamins. In contrast, approximately 50% of US adults use dietary supplements and 33% use multivitamin/multimineral supplements. Between 14% and 32% of survivors initiate supplement use after diagnosis, and use differs by cancer site. Breast cancer survivors reported the highest use, whereas prostate cancer survivors reported the least. Higher level of education and female sex emerged as factors most consistently associated with supplement use. Up to 68% of physicians are unaware of supplement use among their cancer patients.

These results highlight the need for further studies of the association between dietary supplement use and cancer treatment toxicity, recurrence, survival, and quality of life to support evidence-based clinical guidelines for dietary supplement use among cancer patients and longer-term survivors.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.  

]]>

document.topics: <![CDATA[ DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS F-H,HIGH CHOLESTEROL,DECEMBER 2009,VITAMINS,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,VITAMIN C]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

McRae MP. Vitamin C supplementation lowers serum low-density lipoprotein cholesterol and triglycerides: a meta-analysis of 13 randomized controlled trials. Journal of Chiropractic Medicine. 2008; 7(2): 48-58.

Authors' objectives

The purpose of this study was to provide a comprehensive meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials to investigate the effect of vitamin C supplementation on LDL and HDL cholesterol as well as triglycerides in patients with hypercholesterolemia.

Authors' conclusions

Supplementation with at least 500 mg/d of vitamin C, for a minimum of 4 weeks, can result in a significant decrease in serum LDL cholesterol and triglyceride concentrations. However, there was a nonsignificant elevation of serum HDL cholesterol.
]]>

document.title: Vitamin D and calcium intake in relation to risk of endometrial cancer: a systematic review of the literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,CONDITIONS A-Z,CANCER,CONDITIONS C,CALCIUM,VITAMINS,VITAMIN D,MINERALS,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

McCullough ML, Bandera EV, Moore DF, Kushi LH. Vitamin D and calcium intake in relation to risk of endometrial cancer: a systematic review of the literature. Preventive Medicine. 2008 Apr;46(4):298-302.

Authors' objectives

In response to a recent ecologic study of UV exposure and endometrial cancer incidence, the authors present the epidemiologic evidence on the relation between intake of vitamin D and its metabolically related nutrient, calcium, and the occurrence of endometrial cancer.

Authors' conclusions

The limited epidemiological evidence suggests no relation between endometrial cancer in the ranges of dietary vitamin D examined, and suggests a possible inverse association for calcium from supplements. Prospective studies, ideally including plasma 25(OH) D to estimate vitamin D input from diet and sun exposure, are needed to further explore these hypotheses.

Access

]]>

document.title: Vitamin D and cognitive performance in adults: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ DIETARY AND NUTRITIONAL THERAPIES,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,COGNITION DISORDERS,DEMENTIA,CONDITIONS C,CONDITIONS D-E,NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENTS,VITAMINS,VITAMIN D,JULY 2010]]>
document.body:

Citation

Annweiler C, Allali G, Allain P, Bridenbaugh S, Schott AM, Kressig RW, Beauchet O. Vitamin D and cognitive performance in adults: a systematic review. European Journal of Neurology. 2009, 16(10):1083-1089.

Authors' objectives

The objective of this study was to systematically review all published data from the past 30 years which examined the association between serum 25OHD concentrations and cognitive performance in adults. 

Authors' conclusions

This systematic review shows that the association between serum 25OHD concentrations and cognitive performance is not yet clearly established. The inconclusive results of the reviewed studies could be due to methodology, types of the cognitive tasks used and/or the cellular mechanisms of vitamin D.

Citation

Zipitis C S, Akobeng A K. Vitamin D supplementation in early childhood and risk of type 1 diabetes: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Archives of Disease in Childhood 2008; 93(6): 512-517.

Authors' objectives

To assess whether vitamin D supplementation in infancy reduces the risk of type 1 diabetes in later life. 

Authors' conclusions

Vitamin D supplementation in early childhood may offer protection against the development of type 1 diabetes. The evidence for this is based on observational studies. Adequately powered, randomised controlled trials with long periods of follow-up are needed to establish causality and the best formulation, dose, duration and period of supplementation.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Warning over unlicensed ‘herbal valium’
document.publisher: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,HERBAL MEDICINE,CAM GENERAL,SAFETY,PATIENT INFORMATION,JANUARY 2011]]>
document.body:
The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) is warning people of the dangers of taking unlicensed herbal medicines containing aconite.

Aconite has recently been portrayed in the media as ‘herbal valium’, however, it is actually an extremely poisonous plant that is toxic to the heart.

It is also known as monkshood and herbal products containing this ingredient could be fatal or cause serious illness if consumed.

For more information see MHRA press release.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: What is Complementary and Alternative Medicine (CAM)?
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CAM GENERAL,MARCH 2011]]>
document.body:
111-1What is Complementary and Alternative Medicine (CAM)?

The term alternative medicine was originally introduced to refer to whole medical systems that did not fit with conventional medicine. These systems have completely different philosophies together with different ideas on causes of disease, methods of diagnosis and approaches to treatment and were seen as a replacement for conventional healthcare. Complementary medicine (or therapies) is used to refer to those methods which can be used alongside or to ‘complement’ conventional medicine, but the distinction between alternative and complementary medicine is not absolute and may depend on the context. Many people now use the term complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) to include both approaches. The term integrated (or integrative) medicine has been introduced more recently and is used to refer to systems in which conventional healthcare and complementary therapies are integrated within a practice or an institution.

Defining complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) is not straightforward. The general explanation is that they are a group of therapies, practices and approaches to healthcare which are found outside mainstream conventional medicine. For example, Eisenberg and colleagues used the following definition:

“Alternative medical therapies, functionally defined as interventions neither taught widely in medical schools nor generally available in US hospitals” (Eisenberg et al. 1998)

However, the situation is more complex than this: the list varies across different cultures and contexts and as the US National Centre for Complementary and Alternative Medicine (NCCAM) has pointed out that:

"The boundaries between CAM and conventional medicine are not absolute, and specific CAM practices may, over time, become widely accepted." (NCCAM 2010)

One of the most commonly used definitions is that used by the Cochrane Complementary Medicine Field, and this is the definition which the CAM Specialist Library has chosen to adopt:

“Complementary medicine includes all such practices and ideas which are outside the domain of conventional medicine in several countries and defined by its users as preventing or treating illness, or promoting health and well being. These practices complement mainstream medicine by 1) contributing to a common whole, 2) satisfying a demand not met by conventional practices, and 3) diversifying the conceptual framework of medicine.” (Berman 2006)

Overall, there is a diverse and constantly changing body of healthcare practices, some of which are based on differing theories, which explains the difficulty in developing a coherent and universally accepted definition.


What is included in CAM?

The US National Centre for Complementary and Alternative Medicine (NCCAM) has recently updated the background information about the types of CAM:

"CAM practices are often grouped into broad categories, such as natural products, mind-body medicine, and manipulative and body-based practices. Although these categories are not formally defined, they are useful for discussing CAM practices. Some CAM practices may fit into more than one category."

In the UK, the House of Lords Select Committee on Science and Technology report on Complementary and Alternative Medicine (HL Paper 123 2000) took a different line by categorising specific approaches and therapies into 3 groups:

Group 1: Professionally Organised Alternative Therapies
(acupuncture, chiropractic, herbal medicine, homeopathy and osteopathy)

Group 2: Complementary Therapies
(Alexander technique, aromatherapy, Bach and other flower remedies, body work therapies, including massage, counselling stress therapy, 
hypnotherapy, meditation, reflexology, shiatsu, healing,
Maharishi ayurvedic medicine, nutritional medicine, yoga)

Group 3: Alternative Disciplines 
3a: Long-established and traditional systems of healthcare 
(anthroposophical medicine, ayurvedic medicine, Chinese herbal medicine, Eastern medicine, naturopathy, traditional Chinese medicine)  
3b: Other alternative disciplines
(crystal therapy, dowsing, iridology, kinesiology, radionics) 

The CAM specialist collection

While we will be using the Cochrane Complementary Medicine Field definition as guidance on the eventual scope of the CAM specialist collection, we have chosen initially to simply list those practices, therapies or systems that are commonly used and for which some research evidence is available. Consequently, our list may change over time.


References

Berman BM. (2006) Cochrane Complementary Medicine Field. About The Cochrane Collaboration (Fields), Issue 1. Art. No.: CE000052. [Full text]

Eisenberg DM, Davis RB, Ettner SL, Appel S, Wilkey S, Van Rompay M, Kessler RC. (1998) Trends in alternative medicine use in the United States, 1990-1997: Results of a follow-up national survey. JAMA, 280:1569-75. [Abstract]

House of Lords Select Committee on Science and Technology. (2000) Session 1999-2000, 6th Report, Complementary and Alternative Medicine. HL Paper 123. London: Her Majesty's Stationary Office. [Full text]

NCCAM. (2010) What is Complementary and Alternative Medicine (CAM)? Bethesda, Maryland: NCCAM, National Institutes of Health. [Full text]


Further reading on defining and classifying CAM

Caspi O, Sechrest L, Pitluk HC, Marshall CL, Bell IR, Nichter M. (2003) On the definition of complementary, alternative, and integrative medicine: societal mega-stereotypes vs. the patients' perspectives. Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine, 9(6):58-62. [Abstract]

Kaptchuk TJ, Eisenberg DM. (2001) Varieties of healing. 2: a taxonomy of unconventional healing practices. Annals of Internal Medicine, 135(3):196-204. [Abstract] [Full text - pdf]

Newman Turner R. (1998) A proposal for classifying complementary therapies. Complementary Therapies in Medicine, 6(3):141-143. [Abstract]

Wootton JC. (2005) Classifying and defining complementary and alternative medicine. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine, 11(5): 777-778. [Full text - Athens password required]

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Why GPs refer patients to complementary medicine via the NHS: A qualitative exploration
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,USE OF CAM,CAM GENERAL,MAY 2009]]>
document.body:
Citation

Brien S, Howells E, Leydon G, Lewith G. Why GPs refer patients to complementary medicine via the NHS: A qualitative exploration. Primary Health Care Research and Development. 2008, 9:205-215.

Authors' objectives

This exploratory qualitative study was designed to explore UK GPs experiences of referring patients to CAM under an NHS contract.

Authors' conclusions

A CAM referral only took place if the patient readily agreed with this therapeutic approach, and in this respect it may differ from referrals by GPs to conventional medicinal practitioners. Such an approach, then, relies on patients having a positive view of CAM and as such could result in inequity in treatment access. Increasing knowledge about and evidence for CAM will assist GPs in making appropriate referrals in a timely manner. We propose a preliminary model that explains our findings about referrals considering patients need as well as the medical process. As data saturation may not have been achieved, further investigation is warranted to confirm or refute these suggestions.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Yoga for anxiety: a systematic review of the research evidence
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,YOGA,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,ANXIETY DISORDERS,CONDITIONS A-B,ANXIETY,DATE ADDED,JANUARY 2008]]>
document.body:
This review has been evaluated by a CRD reviewer as potentially meeting the CRD quality criteria and a structured abstract is in the process of being written. This provisional record is for information, please note that the review has not been appraised yet.

Citation

Kirkwood G, Rampes H, Tuffrey V, Richardson J, Pilkington K. Yoga for anxiety: a systematic review of the research evidence. British Journal of Sports Medicine. 2005, 39(12):884-891.

Authors' objectives

To carry out a systematic review of the research evidence on the effectiveness of yoga for the treatment of anxiety and anxiety disorders. 

Authors' conclusions

Owing to the diversity of conditions treated and poor quality of most of the studies, it is not possible to say that yoga is effective in treating anxiety or anxiety disorders in general. However, there are encouraging results, particularly with obsessive compulsive disorder. Further well conducted research is necessary which may be most productive if focused on specific anxiety disorders.

Access

Free full text is available upon registration.

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Yoga in the treatment of mood and anxiety disorders
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,YOGA,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DEPRESSION,ANXIETY,CONDITIONS A-B,CONDITIONS D-E,ANXIETY DISORDERS,MARCH 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

da Silva TL, Ravindran LN, Ravindran AV. Yoga in the treatment of mood and anxiety disorders: A review. Asian Journal of Psychiatry. 2009, 2(1):6-16.

Authors' objectives

Patient use of complementary and alternative treatments, including yoga, to manage mood and anxiety disorders, has been well documented. Despite research interest, there are few recent reviews of the evidence of the benefit of yoga in these conditions.

Authors' conclusions

Reasonable evidence supports the benefit of yoga in specific depressive disorders. The evidence is still preliminary in anxiety disorders. Given its patient appeal and the promising findings thus far, further research on yoga in these conditions is encouraged.

Access

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Yoga practice for the management of type II diabetes mellitus in adults: A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ CONDITIONS A-Z,YOGA,COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DIABETES MELLITUS,CONDITIONS D-E,DATE ADDED,AUGUST 2009,2009]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM SL. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Aljasir B, Bryson M, Al-Shehri B. Yoga Practice for the Management of Type II Diabetes Mellitus in Adults: A systematic review. Evidence-based Complementary and Alternative Medicine. 2008 May 7. [Epub ahead of print]

Authors' objectives

To assess the effect of practicing yoga for the management of type II diabetes.

Authors' conclusions

Short-term benefits for patients with diabetes may be achieved from practicing yoga. Further research is needed in this area. Factors like quality of the trials and other methodological issues should be improved by large randomized control trials with allocation concealment to assess the effectiveness of yoga on diabetes type II. A definitive recommendation for physicians to encourage their patients to practice yoga cannot be reached at present.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Complementary and Alternative Medicine]]>
document.title: Zen meditation: an integration of current evidence
document.topics: <![CDATA[ COMPLEMENTARY AND ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,CONDITIONS A-Z,MEDITATION,CONDITIONS F-H,CONDITIONS C,HYPERTENSION,HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE,COGNITION DISORDERS,STRESS,CONDITIONS S,SEPTEMBER 2010]]>
document.body:
This study has met our selection criteria but has not been fully appraised by the CAM specialist collection. Where there is an appraisal available we have linked to it. If there is no appraisal and you wish to appraise this systematic review here is a link to a list of appraisal tools.

Citation

Chiesa A. Zen meditation: an integration of current evidence. Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine. 2009, 15(5):585-92.

Authors' objectives

Despite the growing interest in the neurobiological and clinical correlates of many meditative practices, in particular mindfulness meditations, no review has specifically focused on current evidence on electroencephalographic, neuroimaging, biological, and clinical evidence about an important traditional practice, Zen meditation.

Authors' conclusions

To date, actual evidence about Zen meditation is scarce and highlights the necessity of further investigations. Comparison with further active treatments, explanation of possible mechanisms of action, and the limitations of current evidence are discussed.

NHS staff: for full text access to this resource contact your local NHS library.
